7, 8. Levit. XXIV. 2, 3. At least some of them in the daytime.

Tabernacle] Moses his Tent is called the Tabernacle. Sam. III. 3. And the
Temple diverse times by the name of the Tabernacle, and Sanctuary, and Tents of
the Lord, 2 Chronicles. XXXI. 2.

Forty days and forty nights] Moses twice fasted 40 days, Exodus XXXIV. 28.
Deuteronomy. IX. 18. and Chapter X. 10. And some conceive thrice out of Deuteronomy. IX. 25. Yet
this is not likely. Elias once; and our Savior once. Of Fasting, see the
Annotations on Joel I. 14.

Skin of his face shone] By reflexive rays and beams of the Divine splendour:
Trent Bible renders the word; And Painters commonly picture him. The Hebrew
word (...) a substantive signifies an Horn; but (...) the Verb signifies to
shine. And so Saint Paul interprets it, 2 Cor. III. 7.

Looking-glasses] Looking-glasses made not of Glasses, Ezra VIII. 27. and of
much use; and specially for armor inwarre, as Virgil often mentions.

Talents. Shekels] Shekel comes from Shakal, to weigh; And thence may our
English word scale come. A Shekel is 20. Gerahs, Exodus XXX. 13. Ezekiel. XLV. 12.
or two Bekahs, Exodus XXXVIII. 26. The Shekel is half an ounce in silver, or 2
s. 6d. And so the Gerah, 1 d. ob. and the Bekah 1 s. 3 d. The Talent is 3000
Shekels; which appears thus in the Text; The 603550 men are taxed at a Bekah a
piece. This makes 301775 Shekels. Now reckoning 3000 Shekels to a Talent; The
301775 Shekels make up 100 Talents, and 1775 Shekels; according to the sum
there specified, v. 25, 27, 28. And counting the Shekel at 2 s. 6d, the Talent
so comes to 375 l. starling. The Shekel of gold was of the same weight with
that of silver; but of far greater value; of ten to one with the Jews, as
may be gathered out of 1 Chronicles. XXII. 14. And so their Shekel of gold comes to
1 l. 5 s. their Talent of Gold comes to 3750. l. But gold now in Christendom
is at an higher rate. By silverings, as, 2 Samuel XVIII. 11, 12. Matthew. XXVI. 15.
usually Shekels are understood. See the Annotations on Ezekiel. IV. 10. And on
Esther III. 9.

Veil of the Covering] That hanged before,

Lamps to be set in order] Dressing them every morning, Chapter XXX. 7, 8. if not
at morning too: there being no windows in the Tabernacle; and so burning
always, Chapter XXXVII. 20. continually, Levit. XXIV. 2.

Blessed them] The offerers,

Of the Gongregation] Where Priests,

Everlasting] That their posterity should not need to be anointed again.
Everlasting see the Observations on Deuteronomy. XV. 17.

A Cloud] Even that Cloud, Exodus XIII. 21, 22. miraculously removed hither.

Not able] The manner therefore of the clouds abode,

Leviticus.
LEVITICUS takes up only the time of one month; viz: the first month of the
second year of their coming out of Egypt; whiles yet they stayed at Mount
Sinai: Compare together, Exodus XL. 2, 17. Levit. I. 1. and Chap. XXVII. 34. and
Number. I. 1. And this was in the 2509 year of the world; thus, 1656. to the
Flood. Thence to Abrams birth, in the 130 year of Terah, 352. Thence, to
Isaac's birth, 100. Thence, to Jacob's birth, 60. Thence, to Jacob's going down
into Egypt 130. Thence to the coming out of Egypt 210: and one year after their
coming forth; in all 2509. And not in the year of the world 2455. or 2514. This
Book contains principally the Function and Offices of the Levites; And
Ceremonials concerning Sacrifices, and Feasts, Rites, and Purifications:
Delivered by God to Moses out of the Tabernacle of the Congregation when it was
newly reared, Levit. I. 1. And accordingly is that, Levit. XXV. 1. to be
expounded.

The month of this Book may seem to be thus spent, taken up, and subdivided,
viz:

1. Day; The Tabernacle, Altar, and all other things belonging to the
Sanctuary, reared, placed, anointed, Exodus XL. Levit. VIII.

The Consecration of Aaron, and his sons, Commanded, Exodus XXIX. Begun, Exodus
XL. fully finished, Levit. VIII. in the space of seven days.

And seven days to make an Atonement for the Altar, and sanctify it, Exodus
XXIX. 37.

8. Day; The Princes Offerings of six Wagons, and twelve Oxen, for carriage
and service of the Tabernacle. Their Offerings at the Dedication of the Altar;
each Prince on his day: which so continued twelve days, Number. VII. And likely
during that time of twelve days, Moses received from the Lord, out of the
Tabernacle of the Congregation, those Laws for Sacrifices, and Offerings,
Levit. Chapter I, -- VII.

8. Day; The Consecration of Aaron, and his sons, being ended, Aaron does
first Sacrifice, Levit. IX.

In the sacrifices and offerings Levitically are considerable; Principally, and
more Generally: The Persons, Offerer or Bringer, Lev. 1. 4. and 3. 2. and 7. 30.
Sacrificer, Priests, Lev. 1. 6. 2 Chronicles. 29. 24. Now wine or strong drink,

34. and chapter 35. 11* -- 14.

As the sin-offering is, so is the trespasse-offering; there is one law for
them, Lev. 7. 1, -- 7. And in some things they are hardly distinguishable. And
the trespasse-offering seems to be for the greater offenses.

9. Day; Nadab, and Abihu offer Incense with strange fire; and are slain,
Levit. X. 11, 12, 13. Days Seem those Laws given from the Lord, to Moses and
Aaron, touching Beasts, Fishes, Fowls, clean and unclean, Chapter XI. Moses, for
Purification of Women in childbirth, Chapter XII. Moses and Aaron; for Leprosies,
and their cleansings, Chapter XIII. XIV. For issues of men and women, and their
cleansings, Chapter XV.

14. Day; Celebration of the Passover, Number. IX. whether the Feast of
unleavened Bread, for seven days, was added hereunto, is not expressed. After
the death of Nadab and Abihu, Moses receives Laws from the Lord, touching the
High Priests coming into the most Holy Place, once a year, to make an
Atonement, on the tenth day of the seventh month. And the manner of it, Chapter
XVI. Place of Sacrificing. And touching Blood, Chapter XVII. Unlawful mixtures, and
Lusts; and other sins. And the Punishments of them, Chapter XVIII, XIX, XX.
Priests; their Holiness; Honor: and cleansing, Chapter XXI, XXII. Feasts, Chapter
XXIII. Oil, and Lamps. And Shewbread, Chapter XXIV. 1, -- 9.
Shelomiths son blasphemeth, Chapter XXIV. 10, -- 14. Thereafter, Moses receives
Laws from the Lord; touching Blasphemy, and Murder, Chap. XXIV. 15 -- 23.
Sabbath-year: and Jubilee; Chapter 25. Idolatry, and Religiousnesse: with Blessings
and Curses, Chapter XXVI. Vows and Tithes, Chap. XXVII.

For the better understanding, and remembering of this Book; And specially of
the Offerings, and Sacrifices therein contained, The Table ensuing, and the
Directions thereof, may give some part of help and furtherance; though the same
be not in all points perfect and complete.

Sacrifices then are of a Divine Institution. And were indeed practiced by
Adam, and his children; and in all ages. But by Moses enlarged with many
Observations, Circumstances, and Prefigurations contained in them. Yet not
principally commanded; nor so much as Moral duties of Piety, and Honesty, 1 Samuel 15. 22. Psalm. L. 5, -- 16. Mark XII. 33. Hos. VI. 6. Matthew. XII. 7. as
Joel II. 13. Esaias I. 11. and Jer. VI. 20. Amos V. 21. Jer. VII. 21, 22, 23.

Of the Cattell] The kinds of Beasts and Birds, Levit. XIV. 4. in the
cleansing of the Leper, was not properly a Sacrifice. These Creatures for
Sacrifice, were of common use for man's sustenance and maintenance; And so were
lawful to be eaten in civil and common use, Deuteronomy. XIV. 4, 26. and Chapter XII.
15, 21. And they were easy to be had. As also Bread, Flower, Cakes, Wafers,
Wine, Salt, Oil, Frankincense, used most in the Meat, and Drink Offerings;
And such likewise are Water, Bread and Wine, in our Sacraments. See Levit. I,
II, III, IV. Chapter and Chapter VII. v. 11, 12, 13.

A Burnt-Sacrifice] In all Burnt-Offerings; Levit. I. and Chapter VI. 22, 23, 30.

In all other Sin Offerings; and Trespasse-Offerings; besides the fat, and
kidneys, burnt to the Lord: All the Flesh was the Priests, and to be eaten by
him, and his. And so in all other Meat Offerings, Levit. VI. 16, 17, 18, 26,
29. and Chapter VII. 6, 7, 9, 10, 14.

In the Peace Offerings, the Wave-breast; and heave, or right shoulder, were
the Priests, to be eaten by him, and his: And the rest of the Flesh belonged to
the bringer of the Peace Offering, to be eaten by him and his, Levit. VII. 31,
32, 33, 34. and v. 15, -- 21.

The Levites had no part in any Offerings.

Burnt-Offerings used for Sinne-Offerings, in Jobs time; Job XLII: 8.

At the doore] Killed there. Because thither it was lawful for the Offerer or
Bringer of it to come, that he might put his hand upon the head of the
Sacrifice, Lev. I. 3, 4. and III. 2, 8, 13. and IV. 15, 24, 29, 33.

Leaven] Leaven generally forbid in Meat Offerings; Lev. VII. 13. and Chapter
XXIII. 17.

Confesse]

That soul shall be cut off from his people] This Punishment as it is awarded
here against the eating of the flesh of the Peace Offering, Genesis XVII. 14. who
eat leavened bread during the Feast of the Passover, Exodus XII. 15, 19. who
do any work on the Sabbath Day, Exodus XXXI. 14. who eat of the fat of Beasts
of which men offer Sacrifices, Levit. VII. 25. who eat Blood, v. 27. and Chapter
XVII. 10, 14. who bring not the Sacrifice to the door of the Tabernacle, to be
killed there, not elsewhere, Levit. XVII. 4, 9. who eat of the Sacrifice of
Peace Offering on the third day, Levit. XIX. 8. who give of their Seed to
Moloch, Levit. XX. 2, 3. or kill not such a sinner, v. 4, 5. who go a whoring
after Wizzards, and such as have familiar spirits, v. 6. who commit incest, v.
17. or lie with a woman in her sickness, v. 18. who goes unto the holy things
which the children of Israel hallow unto the Lord, having his uncleanness upon
him, Levit. XXII. 3. who does any work, or is not afflicted on the Fast Day of
Atonement, Levit. XXIII. 29, 30. who keep not the Passover, Number. IX. 13. who
sin presumptuously, Number. XV. 30, 31. who being unclean, do not purify
themselves, Number. XIX. 13, 20. who being idolaters, come to a Prophet to enquire
concerning the Lord, Ezekiel. XIV. 8. This kind of punishment has variation of
phrases in the expressions in Scripture, thus, shall be cut off, utterly cut
off, cut off from Israel, from the Congregation of Israel, from among the
Congregation, in the sight of their people, from the midst of my people, cut
off from the earth; cut off from my presence: which likely do import various
kinds, and degrees of punishments, according to the nature of the sins
spoken to in them. How far this phrase advances the Jewish Excommunication,
I leave to further consideration.

The unclean might eat of common meats; as the child-bed-woman, Levit. XII.
But in no case of Sacred meats, as, Leviticus VII. 20.

Fat] the Fat of other clean Beasts then of such as were fit for Sacrifice,
Levit. VII. 25. The Fat also of the flesh, or body of the beast sacrificed
might lawfully be eaten, Neh. VIII. 10. Esaias XXV. 6. and LV. 2. But the Fat or
Suet that was about the flanck, and the kidneys, or about and upon the
entrails, Levit. III. 3, 4. was reserved out of all Sacrifices as Gods portion,
to be burnt upon his Altar, Levit. III. 15, 16. and IV. 8, 10. and XVII. 6.
Deuteronomy. XXXII. 38. 1 Samuel II. 15, 16. And is forbidden therefore to be eaten by
any, Levit. III. 17. and XVII. 23, 25.

Take Aaron] On the same day, Moses began to consecrate, and anoint the
Tabernacle, Altar, and all things belonging to them; As also Aaron and his
sons, Exodus XL. 1, -- 17. Levit. VIII. 1, -- 36.

Anointed] Aaron and all his sons were at first anointed, v. 30. Number. III. 3.
XXXV. 25. Psalm. CXXXIII. 2. Not the Levites. And the High Priest only was
anointed afterward, Exodus XXIX. 29, 30. Levit. XVI. 32. We read often of the
Anointing of Kings, 1 Samuel X. 1. XVI. 13. 2 Samuel 11. 4. 1 Kings I. 39. 2 Kings
IX. 6. XXIII. 30. Psalm. LXXXIX. 20. But never of Prophets. That of Elisaeus, 1
Kings XIX. 16. seems not to have been done with material oil; see ver. 19.
As neither that of Hazael to be King of Syria; compare 1 Kings XIX. 15. with 2
Kings VIII. 13. nor that of Absolon, 2 Samuel XIX. 10. nor that of Cyrus, Esaias
XLV. 1. there being no such custom of oiling Kings in his Country: But
anointing in those places is taken simply, without that Ceremony, for designing
them to their Offices.

Burned] Moses at the Consecration of Aaron, ver. 20. 21, 28. But upon Aarons
first Sacrificing, fire came out from before the Lord, out of the Sanctuary, or
came down from heaven rather, Levit. IX. 24. which must never after be suffered
to go out.

Nadab and Abihu] Nadab and Abihu took Strange or Common Fire, Number. XVI. 35.
that is, from heaven, or the Sanctuary, or from the Altar of burnt-Offering,
like lightning, struck them with sudden death; not consuming their bodies, or
their coats, Levit. X. 4, 5.

Some Names of some Beasts, Esaias III. 18, -- 23. and on Jer. XVII. 3.

Hoof] The Beasts, ver. 26. Deuteronomy. XIV. 6.

Fins] Fish (here we meet with a phrase of a flesh of fish, Levit. XI. 11. and,
Number. XI. 22. as well as, 1 Cor. XV. 39.) that had Fins and Scales, were
likewise clean, and to be eaten, Deuteronomy. XIV. 9, 10.

Come not] The High Priest must enter into the most Holy place but once in the
year, Levit. XVI. 29, 34. Exodus XXX. 10. Heb. IX. 7. That is, for his Priestly
Ministration and Expiation. And then he was to be clothed, not with the
glorious garments which were peculiar to the High Priest; but with those which
were Common to him with the inferior Priests, Levit. XVI. 4. as being a day of
Humiliation and Afflicting the soul, Levit. XVI. 29. Yet upon other necessary
occasions, he might enter in at other times, as at the taking down, and setting
up of the Tabernacle in their removals and journeys in the Wilderness; And
when they took thence the Arc, upon several occasions, as Josh. VI. 4. 1.
Sam. IV. 3.

Not to the doore] No Sacrifices must be offered, Tabernacle, Levit. XVII. 3,
-- 9. Yet upon Extraordinary, and necessary Occasions, God commands, Deuteronomy.
XXVII. 5, 6, 7, 8. And holy men of Prophetical spirits, though not Priests, did
Sacrifice; and for a present time and use, did make and use other Altars; as
Samuel, 1 Samuel VII. 9, 17. and Chapter XI. 15. and Chapter XVI. 2, 5. And David, 2 Samuel
VI. 13. and XXIV. 18, 25. And Solomon, 1 King. VIII. 64. And Elijah, 1 King.
XVIII. 32. And Gideon, and Manoah, See Judge. II. 5. and VI. 26. and XIII. 16,
19. and XXI. 4.

Blood] Blood, to make an atonement for their souls, Levit. XVII. Type of the
Messiah his Blood, Romans 3. 25. Ephesians. I. 7. Col. I. 14, 20. Heb. IX. 12, 22.
which is the principal cause of the prohibition of the eating of Blood.

Defiled] The dignity and estimation of the Priest, principaly of the
High Priest. See v. 4, 7, 8, 9 -- 15. and v. 21, 23. is remarkable.

Burnt] The Capital punishments among the Jews, Burning, Genesis XXXVIII. 24.
Levit. XXI. 9. Josh. VII. 15. Stoning, Levit. XX. 2, 27. and 24. 14, 16, 23.
Hanging, Number. XXV. 4. Deuteronomy. XXI. 22. And in aftertimes, by example of the
Romans, Crucifying, and Beheading, as in our Savior, and John Baptist.

Superfluous] In a Freewill-Offering, Superfluous, or lacking in his parts, was
accepted.

To the Feasts, Levit. XXIII. are added, the Feasts of the New-Moones, Number.
XXVIII. 11, -- 15. 1 Chronicles. 23. 31. 2 Chronicles. II. 4. and Chapter VIII. 13. The Feast
of Purim, Esth. IX. 17, 19, 22, 26, 28. And of that Dedication, John X. 22.

Sabbath] Sabbath is called Sabbath of Rest, or Rest of Rest; and so, v. 32.
And Sabbath sometimes signifies besides the seventh day weekly, other
Feast-dayes also, as Levit. XXIII. 11, 24, 32, 39. And sometimes the whole
week; as Levit. XXIII. 15. Luke XVIII. 12. John XX. 1. Of the Sabbath Day, see
the Annotations on Jer. XVII. 21, 22, 24, 27.

The seventh moneth] The seventh month had as many Feasts in it, Levit. XXIII.
Deuteronomy. XVI. And the only set Fast Day.

Of blowing of Trumpets] The Feast of blowing Trumpets was the first day of the
seventh month; Beside the Feast of the New-Moone, Levit. XXIII. v. 24. And the
year of Jubilee began with Blowing of Trumpets on the tenth day of that month;
which also was the day of Expiation, Levit. XXV. 9. And the Feast of
Tabernacles for seven days followed after in the same month.

Twelve Cakes] The twelve Cakes of Show bread, and of a good bigness, set in
two rows, six on a row, seem to be two rows in Longitude upon the Table, one
by another; And so the Frankincense upon each Cake; rather then in Altitude one
upon another; And so but one Frankincense upon either row; See v. 6, 7. The
Table being two Cubits long, and one Cubit broad, Exodus XXV. 23. And the
Frankincense being to be burned every Sabbath, Levit, XXIV. 7, 9. yet some make
them to be two rows; six upon one another in either row, on heaps in height. In
the Temple there were ten Tables of Shewbread, five on the right hand, and
five on the left; 1 Chronicles. 28. 16. 2 Chronicles. IV. 8.

A Jubile] The Jubile-year had all the privileges of the Sabbath-year, Levit.
XXV.

Fruit for three years] Viz: Esaias XXXVII. 10.

Numbers.
THis Book begins with the year of the World, Not the 2455, or 2544: But the
2514, or rather 2510 and a little over. Thus, 2369, to the end of Genesis, and
death of Joseph. Thence 60 to the birth of Moses. Thence 80 to the coming of
the Israelites out of Egypt. And thence, 1 year, and one month, to the
beginning of this Book; which is the second year, second month, first day of
their coming out.

It contains an History, not of 39, years; but expressly of 38. years and 9
months, Number. I. 1. and Chapter XXXIII. 48, 49. compared with Deuteronomy. I. 3, 4, 5.
That in Number. IX. 1, etc. is but a Rehearsal of what was both given in charge,
and was done before. And some other like Repetitions there are.

603550.] Egypt it self 400 years, then their spawning or multiplying there had
been very small; considering that from three persons that came out of the Arc
with Noah, within the space of 400 years to the time of Abraham; issued such
infinite numbers, and troops of people, in several Kingdoms, and Countries in
the world; as out of the Sacred Text and Story, does plainly appear.

The Order of the Camp, and march of the Israelites in the Wilderness, Chapter II.
and III. is thus; viz:

The Tabernacle in the midst and Center of all the Host.

Round about the Tabernacle, the Levites camped and marched, viz: On the West,
the Gershonites; Number. III. 23. South, the Kohathites, Number. III. 29. North, the
Merarites; Number. III. 35. East, Moses and Aaron, and his sons, Number. III. 38
Males from a month old and upwards 7500. 8600. 6200.
22300.

Round about the Levites; at a good distance, ( Josh. III. 4.) Camped, and
Marched, on the East Side, Judah; and in his Camp Issachar, and Zebulun; likely
on either side, or each hand of Judah; he being in the midst. And so in the
other Camps following. South Side, Reuben; and in his Camp, Simeon and Gad.
West Side, Ephraim; and in his Camp, Manasse, and Benjamin. North-side, Dan;
and in his Camp, Asher, and Naphtali. Number. II. and X. Chap.


In all, 603550. And this is the same number of Males, from twenty years old
and upwards, when they gave a Bekah, or ten Gerahs each man, that is half a
Shekel, after the Shekel of the Sanctuary, to the building of the Tabernacle,
Exodus XXXVIII. 26. As was commanded, Exodus XXX. 11, -- 16. In the last
numbering in the wilderness, in the fourtieth year, after the death of Aaron,
and the death of that Generation, for their rebellion, and murmuring, Number. XIV.
29, -- 35. The males from 20 years old and upwards, all that were able to go to
war, were 601730. The Levites still numbered, not with them, but by
themselves, Number. XXVI. 51.

22000.] ver. 22, 28, 34. which make up 22300. being all the males from a
month old and upwards. And the Firstborn males of all the children of Israel
in the twelve Tribes, from a month old, and upwards, being 22273. Chapter III. 43.
(which argues at least twenty seven males in each family): And the surplusage
of 273. verse 46. being redeemed at five Shekels apiece, amounting to 1375.
Shekels, verse 50: All this argues the foresaid 300. male-Levites to be
wittingly left out in the casting up of the sum; most likely omitted so,
Because they were such Firstborn of the Levites, as were born from the time of
the coming out of Egypt to the time of this reckoning; and in that regard were
sanctified to God as his own, by his Law and challenge, Exodus XIII. 2. and so
could not come into the number of the other Levites which were to be changed
for the Firstborn of the other Tribes, and in their stead to be substituted,
and appropriated to God and his service.

This number of the Levites was very far less then were of each other Tribe,
Chapter III. with Chapter I. The number of the least Tribe, from twenty years old and
upward, males able to go forth to war, being 3200. Of the greatest, 74600.
And the number of the male-Levites from a month old and upwards, being only
22300.

The charge of Aaron, Eleazar, and Ithamar, distinctly; and of the Kohathites,
Gershonites, and Merarites, severally, is prescribed in the taking down, and
carrying, and setting up of the Tabernacle. See Chapter X. 17, 21.

From thirty] The Levites at the age of thirty years, entered into the full
possession of their Offices, to wait upon the service of the Tabernacle, Number.
IV. 3. At the age of twenty five they entered, or might enter upon them, as
Novices, and subservients in some secondary, or inferior administrations, as
Probationers, and Proficients, Number. VIII. 24. And when the Temple should be
builded, they were ordered to begin and enter at twenty years of age, 1 Chronicles.
XXIII. ver. 24 -- 27. Ezra III. 8. And that by David's appointment together with
the Prophets, Gad and Nathan, 2 Chronicles. VIII. 14. and Chapter XXIX. 25.

They continued in their Offices till fifty. Number. IV. 3, 47. At fifty they
ceased waiting upon the service of the Tabernacle, but were Overseers there,
Chapter VIII. 25, 26. And in their several Cities, as being well experienced in the
Judicial Laws, they judged of matters brought before them. The Levites Offices
distinct from the Priests, are set down in many particulars, 1 Chronicles. XXIII.
28, -- 32.

David in his time by divine warrant does distribute them, for the service of
the Temple, into three sorts, to three several Functions, and Offices. One was
to Attend the Priests, and to be helpful and subservient unto them in their
several Services. Of these there are sundry Orders set down, 1 Chronicles. XXIII.
and XXIV. Chapters. A second to solemnize the Service of God, with all manner of
Music; by Voice; and Instruments, both winded, and stringed. The third sort
was to be Porters. Of whom, 1 Chronicles. XXIII. 5. and Chapter XXVI. and 2 Chronicles.
XXIII. 4, 5, 6, 19. and XXXV. 15. Their Orders are set down, 1 Chronicles. XXV.
These three Sorts being divided by Lot into twenty four Orders, or Courses, as
the Priests were; That the first Course of these might attend with the first
Course of the Priests; and leave the Temple, when they left it.

The Levites also had other Offices, over the Treasures of the house of God;
and of the Dedicate things; and for the outward business over Israel for
officers, and Judges, in all business of the Lord, and in the service of the
King, 1 Chronicles. XXVI. 20, -- 32. over diverse Tribes. See further, 1 Chronicles.
XXIII. 28, -- 32.

Even those] Levites numbered, males from thirty years old to fifty, are 8580.
Upon which reckoning there was then one such Levite for every seventy such
males in Israel. In David's time, the Levites (besides the Priests) from thirty
years old to fifty, were 38000. 1 Chronicles. XXIII. 3.

She] The Blessing of conceaving Seed, divorce her Husband, Mar. X. 12.

Woman] Women might be Nazarites, Number. VI. 2. And such likely was Sampsons
mother, Judge. XIII. 4.

The word Nazarite signifies one that is separate: And the name Pharisee is of
the same signification. And of these Nazarites, some were for a certain time,
of months, or years, at their own choice, by their own special vow; as Acts
XVIII. 18. and Chapter XXI. 24. Of whom these Laws here are chiefly to be
understood. Some for term of life; as Sampson, Judge. XIII. 5. and so Samuel, 1 Samuel I. 11, 28. And John Baptist, Luke I. 15. Our Savior was not a Nazarite,
as has been commonly mis-conceived, out of a mis-translation, and
misunderstanding of that text, Matthew. II. 23.

Offered] At the Consecration of the Tabernacle, Gershonites, for carriage.

Four Wagons and eight Oxen, to the Merarites, Number. VII. 7, 8. as they had the
more need.

The Kohathites Levites were to carry upon their shoulders, Number. VII. 9. 2 Samuel
VI. 6. 1 Chronicles. XV. 2, 13, 15. And what it was, see Number. III. 31. and IV. 15.

The Priests, Aaron and his sons being so few, were not then to Carry, but to
Cover, Number. IV. ver. 5, -- 15. Deuteronomy. XXXI. 25. But afterward growing more in
number, they only were to carry the Arc, as Josh. III. 3, 6, 8, 13, 14, 15,
17. and IV. 3, 9, 10, 11, 18. and chapter VI. 4, 6. and 2 Samuel XV. 29. and not very
rarely; as some writing on Josh. III, 3. and on 1 Chronicles. XV. 15. do conceive.

Altar] The Altar of Burnt-Offering had seven days spent for the Consecration
and Expiation of it to sanctify it, Exodus XXIX. 37. (As likewise for Ezekiels
Altar, Ezekiel. XLIII. 18, -- 27.) Yet twelve days spent at the Dedication of it,
Number. VII.

Silver charger] The silver Vessels of Chargers and Bowls, Exodus XXXVII.

From off the Mercy-seat] Moses hears the voice of one speaking to him from off
the Mercy-seat, Number. Exodus XXV. 22. Whereas formerly the Lord spoke out of the
Tabernacle of the Congregation, Levit. I. 1. Number. I. 1.

Take the Levites] The Consecration of the Levites was done in one day. seven
days. Which was so appointed, Exodus XXIX. 35. and so executed, Levit. VIII.
33, 35.

Certain men] the second month is extended to more days then are here
mentioned, v. 10. As in Hezekiah's time, 2 Chronicles. XXX. 2. 15.

Priests] The blowing of Trumpets is to be used by the Priests alone, Number. X.
8. 2 Chronicles. XXIX. 26. And that, in Convocating Assemblies; in journeying
through the wilderness; in going forth to war, Number. X. 2, -- 9. and Chapter
XXXI. 6. 2 Chronicles. XIII. 12, 14. in the first day, and tenth day, of the seventh
month, Number. XXIX. 1. Levit. XXV. 9. in the New Moons, Number. X. 10. Psalm.
LXXXI. 3. In all their solemn Feasts; over their Burnt-Offerings, and
Peace Offerings, Number. X. 10. And upon Extraordinary Occasions, of Fasts, and
Humiliations. Joel II. 1, 15, Or of Joy and Gladness, Number. X. 10. as when
David brought in the Arc to the place which he had prepared for it, 1 Chronicles.
XV. 24, 28. And appointed Priests to minister before it, 1 Chronicles. XVI. 6, 42.
And when Solomon brought the Arc into the Oracle, he mightily had multiplied
the number of Trumpets, and had 120 Priests sounding them at that Solemnity, 2 Chronicles. V. 12, 13. And at the Dedication of the Temple, the Priests sounded
Trumpets, 2 Chronicles. V. 12. and VII. 6. As also at the laying of the foundation
of the second Temple by Zerubbabel, Ezra III. 10. And the Dedication of the
Walls of Jerusalem by Nehemiah, chapt. XII. 35. And in Hezeki^h's joyful
Reformation, 2 Chronicles. XXIX. 26, 27, 28. Besides, there were civil Trumpets for
civil use, sounded by others then Priests; As in War, Judge. VII. 2 Samuel II.
28. At the Coronations of Kings, as of Solomon; Jehu; and Joash. And upon other
occasions.

The Levites used other Instruments of Music, and not Trumpets, 1 Chronicles. XV.
19, 20, 21. and Chapter XVI. 5. 2 Cron. V. 12. and Chapter VII. 6. and Chapter XXIX. 25,
26, 27, 28. And used them, and song, at the daily Sacrifices, and all Festival
Sacrifices, 1 Chronicles. XXIII. 30, 31. And happily in the night, 1 Chronicles. IX. 33.
Psalm. CXXXIV. 1.

On the] The Israelites journeyed from Mount Sinai, a year within thirteen
days, Exodus XIX. I.) See v. 12. Deuteronomy. I. 6, 7.

Hobab] Jethro, or Hobab, Revel or Raguel, a Midianite, and father-in-Law of
Moses, comes to Moses to Horeb, and brings to him his wife, and two sons. And
Moses upon his counsel, appointing very many Rulers, and Judges over the
people, Jethro returns into his own Land, Exodus XVIII. Deuteronomy. I. 9, -- 18. He
(rather then his supposed son Hobab, the supposed brother-in-law of Moses)
being come again, as it seems, thither toward the end of that year, and
entreated there by Moses to stay and go along with them, refuses to do so; Yet
being again prayed and pressed by Moses thereunto, in this Text he either
yields, (no reply being mentioned); or not long after, both he, and his
house, and kindred, return to Moses; (It may be, warned by Moses to come then;
as Saul in his time warned them to depart from the Amalakites, 1 Samuel XV. 6)
and so were saved from that destruction of the Midianites, Number. XXXI. which
return is plainly gathered out of Number. XXIV. 21. Judge. I. 16. and IV. 11. and 1 Samuel XV. 6. 1 Chronicles. II. 55. Jer. XXXV. 6. compared with 2 King. X. 15, 23.

Seventy men] These LXX. Elders, were appointed about a year after those many
Rulers, and Judges, Exodus XVIII. They prophesied, and did not cease for the
time; like whereunto was the case of Saul, 1 Samuel X. 10. God by this sign
sealing so, and at first honoring their Vocation; though this extraordinary
Gift ceased afterward. These LXX. are added to assist Moses in the Government
of this People in the Wilderness. Yet it seems from hence in afterages the
Jews took their rise of Constituting their Sanedrim or Synedrion of LXX.
Elders for their Senate, and Supreme Court of Judicature in that Nation. Of
LXX. see Ezekiel. VIII. 11. Exodus XXIV. 1, 9. Luke X. 1, 17.

Quailes] Quails given the second time, Exodus XVI. 13. those being at their
eighth Station, in the Wilderness of Sin, and before they came to Sinai. These
at the thirteenth Station, and after they left Mount Sinai* in Kibroth
Hattaavah: And continuing for a full month, Psalm. LXXVIII. 26, -- 31.

Ethiopian] Zipporah called an Ethiopian or Cushite, Ethiopia, or part of
Arabia, wherein Midian stood or bordered with it; Arabia containing other
Nations also lying Northward upon the Arabic Gulf, or Red Sea. Miriam her
sister-in-law, seems to envy her, and fall foul upon Moses: and being first
and deepest in the fault more then Aaron, is exemplarily punished.

The man Moses] The commendation of Moses, Number. XII. 3, -- 8.

Kadesh] Kadesh is Kadesh-Barneah in the Wilderness of Paran, Canaan, in a
Mountain of the Amorites, Deuteronomy. I. 19, 20. nigh to Mount Seir, ver. 44. whence
Moses sent the Spies, Number. XII. 16. and Chapter XIII. 26. and XXXIV. 4. Josh. XV.
3. Being the fifteenth station of the Israelites, Deuteronomy. I. 2, 19. and II. 14.
and IX. 23. Josh. XIV. 6, 7. and XV. 3. The Israelites abode at Kadesh-barneah,
and compassed Mount Seir about the space of thirty eight years, compared with
Deuteronomy. I. 2, 46 and II. 14.

Another Kadesh was a City in the uttermost border of Edom, or Idumea toward
Ezion-Gaber, and the Red Sea, Number. XXXIII. 36. Deuteronomy. II. 8. and in the
Wilderness Sin, by the waters of Meribah, and the 33. Station of the
Israelites. Thither they came in the fourtieth year, first month. And there
Miriam died, four months before Aaron, who died in the next Station at Hor.
Hence Moses sent Messengers to the King of Edom, Number. XX. 1, 14, 15, 16, 22,
and XXVII. 14. and XXXIII. 36, 37, 38. Deuteronomy. XXXII. 51. Judge. XI. 17.

Forty years] These forty years wandering in the Wilderness, sending of Spies
to search the Land; but from their coming out of Egypt, Number. XXXIII. 3, 38.
Josh. IV. 19. Deuteronomy. VIII. 2. This appears also out of the ages of Moses and
Aaron, Exodus VII. 7. compared with Number. XXXIII. 39. and Deuteronomy. XXXIV. 7. After
the Return of the Spies, the Israelites continued in the Wilderness but thirty
eight years, and odd months; which yet are said to be forty years, as the
next full number. So Gideons seventy sons, Judge. VIII. 30. are said to be
slain, Ch, IX. 5, 18, 56. though Jothan one of them escaped. And so the
Disciples are called 11. to whom Jesus appeared on the day of his Resurrection
at Evening, when yet Thomas was absent, Mark XVI. 14. Luke XXIV. 33, -- 40.
John XX. 19, -- 25. compared together. And so the LXX. Elders are said to be
gathered, and set round about the Tabernacle, when yet Eldad and Medad came
not, Number. XI. 24. And not unlike is that of David's reign forty years, 2 Samuel
V. 4, 5. when yet six months were over and above. And Solomon's Building the
Temple in seven years, 1 King. VI. 30. when yet six months are to be added, by
comparing v. 1. and last.

Hormah] This History at Hormah is another, from that at Hormah, Number. XXI. 1,
2, 3. See another Hormah, Judge. I. 17.

And all the men] Compared with Chapter the Children of Korah were not swallowed up
of the earth, likely miraculously saved: Or rather, they departing from their
fathers tent, according to that command of God, and Moses, ver. 24, and 26. And
of their race came such as made some of our Psalms, or at least were famous
Singers in the Temple; and Samuel also, the great Prophet, and Judge in Israel,
1 Chronicles. VI. 33, -- 38.

Broad plates] The Altar thus covered twice with Plates of brass; Exodus
XXXVIII. 2.

Altar] The Levites might not approach to the Altar to minister at it, nor eat
of the Sacrifices.

The First-fruits] First Fruits seem to be of many sorts; Levit. XXIII. 10.
Secondly, Two Wave-Loaves, of two tenth deals, at the Feast of Pentecost or
weeks, Number. XXVIII. 26. Levit. XXIII. 15, 16, 17, 20. Thirdly, A Cake of the
first of their doughs, for an Heave Offering, Number. XV. 20, 21. Fourthly,
brought in a Basket, in the seventh month, when all their fruits were gathered
in, as most understand that place, Deuteronomy. XXVI. 1, -- 11. First Fruits enjoined
without any set or certain proportion or stint, Deuteronomy. XVIII. 4. Of these, and
other kinds of First Fruits, see more in this Text, And Exodus XXII. 29. and
XXIII. 19. and XXXIV. 22, 26. Levit. II. 12, 14, 15, 16. Deuteronomy. XVIII. 4. Ezekiel.
XLIV. 30.

The tenth] So, ver. 21. Tithes, and their kinds and sorts; thus; Tithes of
the yearly increase of all things in the Land paid to the Levites, after the
First fruits had been first deducted, and brought to the Priests, Exodus XXXIV.
26. Levit. XXIII. 10. Out of the nine parts remaining, there seems another
Tenth taken, set apart for their Journeys, Sacrifices, and Feastings, thrice a
year at Jerusalem; and therefore brought up thither, and there eaten by the
owners, their families, and the Levites, as most probably appears out of Deuteronomy.
XII. 5, 6, 7, 11, 12, 17, 18, 26. and Chapter XIV. 22, -- 26. And this second Tithe
seems every third year to be distributed to the poor. Or rather a third Tithe
every third year, not carried to Jerusalem, and eaten there; But gathered for
these charitable uses only, and to be eaten any where throughout the Land,
Deuteronomy. XIV. 28, 29. and XXVI. 12, 13. And this third year is therefore called
the year of Tything, Deuteronomy. XXVI. 12. Amos IV. 4.

Of Tithes see more, 2 Chronicles. XXXI. 4, -- 19. Nehem. X. 32, -- 39. and XII. 44,
47. and XIII. 5, 12, 13. Mal. III. 8, 10. Luke XI. 42. and XVIII. 12. Heb. VII.
2, -- 9.

The great maintenance of the Levites, appears in that the whole Tribe of Levi
being three or four times less in number then any other Tribe, yet had they
distinguished from all the Priests, the Tithes of all the Tribes, and so more
then any one other Tribe; Besides their thirty five Cities and Suburbs, whereof
five were Cities of Refuge; Josh. XXI. one belonging to the Kohathites Levites;
two to the Gershonites, and two to the Merarites. In all twice at least more
Cities then some other Tribes had that were twice their number. See also that,
Number. XXXI. 30, 47.

The greater maintenance of the Priests appears, in that being but three
persons at first, at least of ripe and mature age, yet they had the Tithes
yearly of all the Levites Tithes, which were at first 8580 of thirty years old,
and upwards; and so about the hundred part of all the fruits and increase of
all Israel. And as the numbers of the Priests multiplied afterward, so did in
all probability the number of the other Tribes. They had also all the
First Fruits of all things, from all persons, throughout the twelve Tribes,
even of their doughs and bakings, Deuteronomy. XVIII. 4. Number. XV. 20, 21. which, as
some think, exceeded their Tithes aforesaid. They had also all the Firstborn
of Oxen, Sheep, and Goats, which were given to them in kind; And the
Redemption money of the Firstborn of Men, and of unclean Beasts and cattle,
Number. III. 46 -- 52. Exodus XXXIV. 19. 20, and Chapter XXII. 29, 30. Deuteronomy. XV. 19.
They had also all Oblations, both Voluntary, and by Vow; And the Redemption of
Things, and of Persons, Devoted to God: And all Sacrifices for Sins and for
Trespasses, and the Meat and Drink Offerings, and Heave-offerings; And the
Breast and Shoulder in Peace Offerings, Deuteronomy. XVIII. 3. And the Skins of the
whole Burnt-offerings. And all their Tithes, First Fruits and Oblations were to
be of the best and choicest sorts, Number. XVIII. 12, 29. Besides these they had
thirteen Cities, and Suburbs, and Privileges belonging to them, whereof one
was a City of Refuge, Josh XXI. 13. See Number. XVIII. 8, -- 19. And that also
Number. XXXI. 28, 29, 37, 38, 39, 40, 50. Levit. X. 12, 13, 14, 15. and Chapter XXVII.
21, 28. See the Annotations on Number. XVIII. 29.

Rock] At Rephidim by Mount Sinai, Exodus XVII. 1, -- 7. being the eleventh
Station of the Israelites, Number. XXXIII. 14. Moses with his miraculous Rod,
struck the Rock in Horeb, in a due obedience to Gods commandment, and waters
came forth: And he named the place Massah, and Meribah, Exodus XVII. 5, 6, 7.
But at Kadesh in the Wilderness of Zin, where Miriam died, being the thirty
third Station, Number. XXXIII. 36. Moses, with Aarons miraculous Rod (for he took
it from before the Lord, as he commanded him), having his spirit provoked by
the rebellious people, smiles the Rock twice without any such command, or
commission to smite at all. And he, and Aaron likewise, speak unadvisedly with
their lips, uttering words of passion and incredulity, and so rebelling against
Gods commandment. And thereupon they not sanctifying the Lord in the eyes of
the children of Israel; He was sanctified in them, by his excluding them from
entrance into the Land of Canaan. And this also is called the water of Meribah,
or Strife; as here, so Chapter XXVII. 14. Psalm. CVI. 32, 33.

Aaron] Aaron, dies seven months and seven days before Moses, at Mount Hor,
(the Place called Mosera, Deuteronomy. X 6.) in the thirty fourth Station. For Aaron
dying in the fourtieth year, fifth month, first day, Number. XXXIII. 38. And that
compared with the months mourning for Moses, Deuteronomy. XXXIV. 8. and three days
preparation to pass over Jordan, Josh. I. 1. and Chapter III. 2. And their coming
out of Jordan, on the first month, tenth day, Josh. IV. 19. Do show that Moses
died in the twelfth month, seventh day: And so seven months, and seven days
after Aaron. In which short interval of time, many, and mighty things were done
and achieved; as among other things, Sihon, and Og, and their Kingdoms
conquered; the Midianites almost destroyed; among whom Balaam was slain, Josh.
XIII. 22. and the book of Deuteronomie written, Number. XXI. and XXXI. Deuteronomy. I. 1,
3.

Fiery Serpents only in the later part of the fourtieth year, Aarons death.

Heshbon] Heshbon a chief City in Moab; Sihon King of the Amorites, Deuteronomy. I. 4.
afterward of Gad; and out of that Tribe, given to the Merarites, Josh. XIII.
26. and XXI. 38, 39, 40. 1 Chronicles. VI. 80, 81. Afterward recovered by the
Moabites; and wasted by Shalmanesar, Esaias XV. 4. and XVI. 8, 9. and after by
the Babylonians, Jer. XLVIII. 45. There may seem to be another Heshbon of the
Ammonites, Jer. XLIX. 2, 3. And one in the Tribe of Reuben, Number. XXXII. 37.
Josh. XIII. 15, 17. Heshbon signifies Devises; And an allusion is made to the
name, Jer. XLVIII. 2. in the judgment there denounced against it; like to this
is English, There is mischief devised against the Devises, the name of a town
with us.

Balak] Balak needed not to have hired Balaam, Number. XXII. and XXIII. and XXIV.
if he had known the prohibition of God to Israel, Deuteronomy. II. 9. which they
obeyed, Judge. II. 15, 17, 18, 25. 2 Chronicles. XX. 10. Yet that part, which was
great, of the Lands of Moab, which Sihon had lately conquered from Vehab, King
of Moab, as Tremelius translates, Number. XXI. 26. the Israelites conquering
Sihon, in that right possessed it, Number. XXXIII. 49. Deuteronomy. I. 5. and XXXIV. 1,
5, 6, 8. and it was given to the Reubenites, and Gadites, Josh. XIII.

Unicorne] So Deuteronomy. Job XXXIX. 9, 10. Psalm. XXII. 21. and XXIX. 6. and XCII.
10. Esaias XXXIV. 7. Yet the translation of the word is doubted of; or at least
the nature of the beast, such as the Pensil of our Painters does portray out
unto us; because no such beast was known or seen by any man. And the Unicornes
horn so deemed, is of some strange Fish, not of any known Beast. Some learned
render the word Bufale, or Buff; or else the wild Ox called by the Latins
Urus; eminent for bigness, strength, horns, and untamable fierceness.

Advertise thee] Balaam called a South-sayer, Josh. XIII. 22. and a Prophet, 2
Pet. II. 16. gives this advertisement to Balak, which seems to have a relation
to that which follows in the residue of that Chapter. Yet besides he gives
counsel to Balak, or at least after to the Midianites to draw the Israelites
into sin, Number. XXXI. 16. which coming so to pass, He himself in his return,
is slain by the sword amongst the Midianites, Number. XXXI. 8. in that
Expedition, wherein Joshuah, though not named, may seem to be the General, and
Phineas chief of the Priests, sounding Trumpets in that war, wherein 12000.
Israelites, not having one man slain, did yet slay five Kings of Midian, (or
Dukes of Sihon, dwelling in the Country; as it is, Josh. XIII. 21.) and all
the males of that populous Nation (save such as escaped by flight, whose
posterities in the days of Gideon came to prevail against Israel, Judge. VI.
1, 2.) And they took a mighty prey and booty; whereout, after Purifications of
themselves, and the Prey, there was paid a tribute and portion to the Priests,
and a portion to the Levites; and a voluntary Oblation after made by the
Captains to the Lord, Number. XXXI.

Of the 24000. Cor. X. 8. likely were the vulgar sort that died in the
slaughter, Number. XXV. 5. and the other thousand were the heads of the people
hung up, ver. 4. without supposing any Pestilence at that time. Or if by
Plague, Number. XXV. 9. Psalm CVI. 30. we understand the Pestilence, then most
probably, the 23000. died of it; and the other thousand by Hanging, and
Slaughter.

22200.] Moab; in the fourtieth year of their wandering in the Wilderness,
Simeon was far the least in number, and Judah the most. And the whole number
of fighting men of the twelve Tribes, after that generation died in the
Wilderness, upon that judgment, Numb. XIV. 29, -- 35. and upon sundry other
judgments besides, was now 1820. less in number, then in the former numbering
at Mount Sinai, thirty nine years before.

23000.] And so but 700 more then they were in the former numbering at Sinai,
Chapter III. Number. XIII. and XIV.

Sin] This Wilderness differs from Zin, ver. 36. This being the eighth Station
of the Israelites: that of Zin the thirty third, which is Kadesh, where Miriam
died, as was said, Number. XXXIII. 11, 36.

Rephidim] See the Observations on Chapter

Abarim] Pluraly; Number. XXXIII. 47. in the Confines of the Amorites, and
Moabites; whereof the tops had several names, as Nebo, Pisgah, Pehor: But Mount
Sinai was none of them, being far enough of.

Salt Sea] Is not that Lake of Genesareth. Sodom, and Gomorrah, Admah, and
Zeboim had stood, Deuteronomy. XXIX. 23. Hos. XI. 8.

Riblah] Riblah in the Land of Hamath, part of the East border of Canaan, near
the North quarter. Here Pharaoh-Nechoh put Jehoahaz in bonds, 2 Kings XXIII.
33. And Nebuchadnezzar put King Zedekiah in bonds, and put out his eyes, 2
King. XXV. 6, 7. And slew the High Priest, and second Priest, and the sons of
Zedekiah, and other prime men, ver. 18, -- 21. Jer. LII. 10, 27. This Riblah
seems to be that which was afterward called Antiochia in Syria. Of this see my
Annotations on Ezekiel. XI. 10, 11.

Chinnereth] Number. XXXIV. 11. Deuteronomy. III. 17. Josh. XI. 2. and XII. 27. and XIX.
35. is called in the New Testament Genezareth. Luke V. 1. which Lake is also
called the Sea of Galilee, Matthew. IV. 18. Mark I. 16. And the Sea of Tiberias,
Josh. XXI. 1. And absolutely the Sea, Matthew. XVII. 27.

Suburbs] The Suburbs of the Cities of the Priests, utmost Bounds and Borders
of each Quarter, East, West, North, and South.

Forty eight Cities] See Josh. Chron. 6. compared together; and the Great
Annotations upon the said sixth Chapter.

Shall not be guilty] The innocent man, murder.

Only to the family] Israelites might marry wives of other Tribes, Number. XXXVI.
Yea, of other Nations if they were Proselytes; and not of those Nations which
God expressly devoted to destruction, Deuteronomy. VII. 3. and XXI. 10, -- 13. Of
their marriages with Heathens, and mixing the holy seed, See Ezra IX. and X.
Chapter Neh. IX. 2. and X. 30. and XIII. 3. 23, -- 30.

Deuteronomie.
DEUTERONOMIE was written in the year of the world, not 2493. But in the year
2553. or rather 2548. thirty eight years, and odd months, from the time of
the beginning of the Book of Numbers. And about 1450 years before Christ's time.

It contains to the fifteenth Verse of the last Chapter, an History of one
month, and seven days, viz: From month eleven, day one, to month twelve,
day seven; at which time Moses died; as has been formerly gathered upon Aarons
death. See and compare together Deuteronomy. I. 3. and XXXIV. 8. and Josh. IV. 19. In
which short time the Book was written by Moses; And, besides sundry
Repetitions, and Explications, other new Laws given; A second Edition, as it
were, of the Covenant made with the new Generation; with some other
Consequences, and last Acts of Moses.

The last Chapter of Deuteronomie was written after Moses his death. As
likewise the Conclusion of the Book of Jeremie, was written after his Death,
Jer. LI. 64. and LII. 31, 34. And that XXXIV. Chapter contains one month more,
of the Israelites mourning for the death of Moses.

This Book of Deuteronomie, and that of the Psalms, are of chief note in the
Old Testament, for the Life of Religion, the spiritual power of Worship and
Obedience in the inner man.

Yet this Book of Deuteronomie seems not to be that which was to be written
very plainly upon great stones plaistered, in Mount Ebal; For that was the
Decalogue only, or those Blessings and Curses, only, Deuteronomy. XXVII. 2, -- 26.
Josh. VIII. 30, 35. Nor seems it to be this book of Deuteronomie only that was
to be Copied out by the King, and He to read therein all the days of his life,
Deuteronomy. XVII. v. 18, 19, 20. Not yet seems it to be this book only, that was to
be solemnly read by the Priests, every seventh or Sabbatical year in the Feast
of Tabernacles, in the audience of all the people, Chapt. XXXI. 9, -- 13. As in
the three foresaid particulars some would have it. Nor yet is it this Book
only; or that Song only, Deuteronomy. XXXII. that was to be put and placed by the
Priests, in, at, or by the side of the Arc of the Covenant, Deuteronomy. XXXI. 25,
26. But the whole book of the Law, the five Books of Moses were to be Copied
out by the King, read in every Sabbath-year, and laid up and preserved safe by
the Arc of the Testimony.

The Judicial Laws, most of all mentioned in this Book, and peculiarly
belonging to the Country and People of the Jews, are grounded upon an equity
of Right Reason for that Country and People. And so far are useful to all
others.

The ten first Chapters are most-what of precedent Passages, Repetitions of
what things were formerly done; with Exhortations to Obedience intermixed.
Moses yet herein not binding himself to an exact order in observation of the
times, and places.

These] Is an Inscription of the whole book, Moses delivered, and did, what in
this book is contained.

Eleven] The eleven days journey end either at Kadesh-barneah; Mount Seir, and
Kadesh-barneah, it ends at, and in the Plains of Moab. Both which ser^^ to
show how soon they might have come from Horeb or Sinai to Canaan; had they not
provoked God by their sin, Number. XIV. instead of that eleven days journey, to
keep them wandering in the wilderness 38. years after.

Horeb] Horeb and Mount Sinai are taken for the same, Exodus III 1. See on that
Text, Deuteronomy. I. 2, 6, 19. and IV. 10, 15. and V. 2. and IX. 8. 1 King. XIX. 8
Mal. IV. 4. They being close neighbors, or rather two tops of the same Mount.
The Israelites abode almost a year there, Deuteronomy. I. 6. Exodus XIX. 1 Number. X. 11.

Og that dwelt at Ashteroth, Edrei, another of his royal Cities, Chapter III. 1.
Number. XXI. 33. Josh. XIII. 12, 31. and XII. 4.

Angry] Gods anger at Moses here mentioned, Kadesh-barnea, Number. XIII. and XIV.
But in the fourtieth year at that other Kadesh, when and where Miriam died,
Number. XX. 1, 2, 12.

Many dayes] The Israelites abode in Kadesh many days. Seir many days: The
space in which they came from Kadesh-barnea, till they came over the brook
Zered, or pitched in the Valley of Zared, in Moab, being their thirty ninth
Station, was thirty eight years; which was in the beginning of the fourtieth
year of their coming out of Egypt, Deuteronomy. II. 1, 2, 3, 7, 14. some take thirty
seven years and a half of this time to be spent at Kadesh-barnea: And sure the
most of it was spent there; and the lesser and later part of it in compassing
Mount Seir: And the other half year spent in coming from Mount Seir to Zered.
See Deuteronomy. II. 7.

Distress not] And so, v. 19. The Israelites forbidden to distress the
Moabites, and Ammonites; or to possess their Lands. Yet what Sihon had lately
conquered from them, and possessed; which was no small part of their Countries,
all that, the Israelites conquering Sihon, by right of that Conquest, did
fairly possess, Josh. XIII. 15, -- 25. Judge. XI. 12, -- 27.

Gyants] There are mentioned Anakims, Deuteronomy. II. 11, 20. and Chapter III. 11, 13.
Number. XIII. 33. See further, Genesis VI. 4, 1 Samuel XVII. 4. and 2 Samuel XXI. 16, --
22.

Mount Sion, which is Hermon] Called by the Sidonians Syrion, by the Amorites
Shenir, in the Valley of Lebanon, Deuteronomy. III. 9. and IV. 48. Josh. XI. 17. and
XIII. 5. and XII. 5. 1 Chronicles. V. 23. And Mount Sion, that strong hold, in the
City of David, being the South-part of Jerusalem, and not seated on the
North-side of it, 2 Samuel V. 7, 9. 1 King. VIII. 1. Psalm. II. 6. and IX. 11. and
XLVIII. 2. (upon which Text see the Annotations) are two differing Mountains,
and far asunder. They differ also in their Original Characters and letters;
the former being written (...) and the later (...); though the New Testament
write the later also Sion, Romans IX. 33 (...) XI. 26. As likewise the Hebrew
(...) is written Sidon; And (...) is written Tire, Matthew. XI. 21, 22.

Called] We may not conceive a miracle in Moses voice,

My Commandments] So it is in the Masorets marginal reading. Moses, expounding
the sense and meaning of Gods words that went next before,

Seventh day] Some words are added by Moses to those uttered by God on Mount
Sinai, Exodus XX. 10, 11. as an Explication of them. And also a Reason is given
of the fourth Commandment differing altogether from that Reason in Exodus XX.
11. which Reason here yet evinceth not, that therefore God brought the
Israelites out of Egypt on the Sabbath Day. But the putting of Wife before
House, ver. 21. contrary to that order of House before Wife, in Exodus XX. 17.
confounds the late Papists silly shift in dividing the last Commandment into
two, to make up ten, Deuteronomy. IV. 13. to color thereby their taking away the
second Commandment; or shufling of it into the first: so that by them is not
known which is the ninth, and which the tenth Commandment.

Seven Nations] So many are here reckoned. Josh. III. 10. Six in Exodus XXXIII.
2. Deuteronomy. XX. 17. Judge. III. 5. In many places fewer. In Genesis XV. 19, 20, 21.
ten Nations are reckoned. And among them the Philistines are never mentioned.
Yet all the inhabitants of the whole Land go many times under the names of
Canaanites, and Amorites; as Genesis XXIV. 3. and Chapter XV. 16.

Utterly destroy them] Such is Gods Command; v. 16. See Exodus XXXIV. 11, 12.
Deuteronomy. IX. 3. and XX. 16, 17. Yet this was not a thing to be done in one year,
or in Ioshuah's Lifetime, Josh. XXIII. 4, 5, 13. Judge. l. 9, 21, 27, 29, 30,
31, 33, 34. But by little and little, Exodus XXIII. 29, 30. Deuteronomy. VII. 22. Yet
God justly threatens and blames them for their neglect in Conquering and
Expelling them, Number. XXXIII. 55, 56. Josh. XXIII. 13. Judge. II. 3, 21, 22, 23.
And he never gave them the possession of their full Bounds, as of Tire, Sidon,
and of all the Land of the Philistines, because they kept not for their part
the Condition of their Covenant with him, Judge. II. 20, 21.

Neither shall thou] Marriage forbid with the Canaanites strictly. Ezra IX. 1,
2. Neh. XIII. 23. A reason is given, Deuteronomy. VII. 4. Neh. XIII. 26. Exodus XXXIV.
16. The mischief of that marriage between Jehoram the son of Iehoshaphat King
of Judah, and Athaliah the daughter of Ahab King of Israel, is recorded, 2
King. VIII. 18. Yet in case they became Proselytes, Converts to the true
Religion; the marriage with all of them seems lawful: as in that case, Deuteronomy.
XXI. 10, 13. And in the case of Rahab, and Ruth; of the wife of Joseph in
Egypt: of the wife of Moses; of Maacah the daughter of the King of Geshur with
David; and of Pharaohs daughter with Solomon. And this made Jacobs sons
propound or pretend the condition of Circumcision to Shechem, and the
Shechemites, Gen, XXXIV. 14, 15, 16. In the New Testament, we read the
prohibition, 2 Cor. VI. 14. And the precept, 1 Cor. VII. 12 -- 16. which rules
touching Infidels seem to serve for the case of gross Heretics, and
Apostates. Against unlawful marriages see more, Judge. III. 6, 7. and XIV. 2, 3.
1 King. XI. 2. Ezra IX. and X. Chapters, Neh. X. 30. and XIII. 3, 30.

Rayment] The raiment waxing not old on the Israelites in the Wilderness,
Deuteronomy. XXIX. 5. Neh. IX. 21.

This day] Is taken sometimes properly: sometimes as for a short time; here.
Sometimes for a longer time indefinitely, as Hester I. 18. And the Phrase since
yesterday, and the third day, is sometimes taken properly, or for a short time,
Genesis XXXI. 2, 5. Exodus IV. 10. and XXI. 36. 2 Samuel III. 17. Job. VIII. 9.
Sometimes for a long time, 1 Samuel XIV. 21. and XIX. 7. 2 King. XIII. 5. 1 Chronicles
XI. 2. (As likewise to morrow is taken, sometimes for a short time, as 1 Samuel
XXVIII. 19. Sometimes for a long time, as Josh. IV. 6, 21.) Sometimes for
never. Josh. III. 4. 1 Samuel IV. 7. Of to day, and to morrow, see Josh. XXII.
18. and IV. 6, 21. Esaias XXII. 13. Matthew. 6. 30. 1 Cor. XV. 32.

Arke] Besides that famous Arc for the Tables of the Covenant, Exodus XXXVII.
1, etc. There seems here one formerly made, for present use, wherein the
Tables by Gods commandment were first put. And possibly this Arc with the
Tables might be put into that famous Arc built afterward, Exodus XXXVII. Deuteronomy.
X 5.

Journey] These verses seem to be as a Parenthesis inserted by Moses: v. 6, 7.
are more distinctly and orderly recorded, Number. XXXIII. 30, -- 39. without any
coming or returning, again and again, to one and the same place.

Altars] Idolaters had their Priests, Jer. VII. 31. XIX. 5. Ezekiel. XVI. 20, 21.
and XX. 26, 31. Feasts, Incense, costly clothes, and other services of them.
See Deuteronomy. VII. 5. and XII. 31. and sundry other places, as Esaias I. 29. and
LVII. 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. and LXV. 3, 4, 11. and LXVI. 3. Amos II. 8. 1 Cor. VIII.
10. and X. 21. Jer. X. 9. XVII. 2. And see their eager rage after idolatry,
Ezekiel. XVI. 15, 25, 26, 28, 29, 30, 31.

A poor man] Private poor rather then public beggars were, Matthew. XXVI. 11.

For ever] Ever, has reference, Exodus XXI. 6. 1 Samuel I. 22. and XXV II. 12. 2
King. V. 27. 2 Chronicles. XIII. 5. Psalm. XXXVII. 18, 27. and LXXXIX. 1 Esaias XIII.
20. and XIV. 20. and XXV. 8. and XXXIII. 20. and XXXIV. 10. Jer. VII. and XVII.
4, 25. and XXV. 5. and XXXI. 40. and XXXV. 19. and L. 39. and LI. 26, 62. Lam.
V. 20. Sometimes to the term of a man's life. 1 Kings I. 31. Dan. III. 9. Josh.
8. 28. Genesis XLIII. 9. 1 Samuel I. 22. 1 Chronicles. XXVIII. 4. Psalm. XXXVII. 27, 29.
and CXIX. 44, 98. Esaias XXXII. 17. Sometimes to the year of Jubilee, As in this
Text, and Exodus XXI. 6. compared with Levit. XXV. 40. Sometimes to so long as
the conditions annexed to a thing are observed, 2 Chronicles. XX. 7. 1 Samuel II. 30.
Sometimes to the continuance of a State of polity, Number. X. 8. See the
Annotations on 1 Kings VIII. 13. Sometimes to the Time and Coming of the
Messiah, 1 Chronicles. XV. 2. and XVII. 12, 14, 22, 23, 27. and in many places of
the Prophets. Sometimes to eternity, Exodus III. 15. and XV. 18. Deuteronomy. XXXII.
40. Luke I. 33. And so never is taken sometimes for a long time: sometimes for
almost all times of a man's life, Luke XV. 29. Sometimes for a man's life, 2 Samuel
XII. 10. Sometimes for eternity.

The flock and the herd] Oxen, Exodus XIII. 6, 7. Number. XXVIII. 16, -- 24. 2 Chronicles. XXXV. 7, 8. 9. and Chapter XXX. 24. All which Festival time is called the
Passover, and so Joh. XVIII. 28. A Lamb, or a Kid, might be used for the
Passover properly so called, on the fourteenth day, at the going down of the
Sun, Exodus XII. 5. Deuteronomy. XVI. 6.

A matter too hard] As Judges and Officers were to be appointed in all Cities
in Canaan, Deuteronomy. XVI. 18, 19, 20. So here the highest Court of Judicature over
the whole Land, in difficult Causes, and for matters of Appeal, was appointed
to be in that one place which the Lord should choose; which in aftertimes
appeared to be the City Jerusalem. And here it is not sure and evident whether
this Supreme Court were to be one, mixed of the Priests, and the Civil Judge
jointly; Or (though this not so likely) two distinct Courts, Ecclesiastical,
and Civil; both Supreme in their kind. Judgment of death was awarded upon
presumptuous disobedience to their Sentence. And more of this Supreme Court
Moses does not deliver. Yet upon this, the Jews in after-ages grounded their
great Sanhedrin in Jerusalem; and not upon the LXX. Number. XI. For those were
only added to assist Moses in his troublesome government of that unruly Camp
of the Jews in the Wilderness; as likewise those Rulers and Judges, Exodus
XVIII.

The Priests due] Of the very great maintenance of the Priests, Number.

Three Cities more] Three other Cities of Refuge,

To Battel] The Law of war, Deuteronomy. XX. 1, 10, -- 18. and Chapter VII. 2, 3, 16,
23, 24. and Exodus XXXIV. 11, -- 16. enjoined by God to the Israelites, was
various, according to the several Cities and Nations against whom, whether
near, or very far off, Deuteronomy. XX. 15, 16, 17. and according to the several
Causes and Occasions, whereupon they were to wage it: And is best expounded by
their Practices in Scripture recorded.

Against the Amalakites, see the injunction, Exodus XVII. 14, 16. Deuteronomy. XXV. 17,
18, 19. Against the Midianites, see that, Number. XXXI. Where they slew all the
males they could, even to the malechildren; and every woman that had known man,
and took the spoil, and all their cattle, flocks, and goods, as a prey to
themselves.

Against the Amorites, Sihon, and Og, (included in the seven Nations, or in the
same condition with them) See Number. XXI. and Deuteronomy. II. 34, 35. and Chapter III. 6,
7. where they slew the men, women and children. But all the Cattle, and spoil,
they took for a prey to themselves.

Against Jericho, see Josh. VI. 17, -- 26. where the City, the first that
withstood them in the Land of Canaan, was singularly accursed, and all therein,
ver. 17, 18, 24, 26. 1 King. XVI. 34. And accordingly they slew man and woman,
young and old, and Ox, and Sheep, and Ass: Only the silver and the gold, and
the vessels of brass and iron, they put into the Treasury of the House of the
Lord, as God commanded; keeping nothing to themselves: And as Achan, with his,
and all he had, perished; They being first stoned, and then burnt for the
transgression: So Rahab, her parents, brethren, and all that she had, were
saved, upon the special cause and occasion of her Faith in hiding the Spies.

Against Ai, See Josh. VIII. 2, 26, 27. where they slew all, as at Jericho:
only the spoil, and cattle thereof, they took as a prey to themselves.

Against the five Kings of the Amorites: And against seven; See Josh. X. 10,
28, 30, 32, 33, 35, 37, 39, 40. where they slew all the souls that breathed; as
they did at Jericho: But for the spoil, and cattle, they did as at Ai and took
them as a prey to themselves.

Against all those Kings at the waters of Merom, and presently after, they did
the like, Josh. XI. 11, 12, 13, 14.

The Gibeonites, upon a crafty contrivance, got to be spared, and obtained a
league to live. And though all the congregation murmured against the Princes for
it, yet because of the oath, Joshuah and the Princes only adjudged them to
bondage, to be hewers of wood, and drawers of water for the House of God for
ever, Josh. IX. 13, -- 27. And Saul afterward in a wrong zeal, slaying many
of them, was punished for it, in his sons, 2 Samuel XXI. 1, -- 9.

Many other of the seven Nations were not conquered, Or so conquered, as
brought only under Tribute, See Deuteronomy. VII. 22. Josh. XIII. 1, -- 6. and XIII.
3. and XV. 63. and XVI. 10. and XVII. 12, 13. Judge. I. 1, 19, 21, 27, -- 36.
For which yet the Israelites were reproved, Judge. II. 1, 2, 3. And doomed so,
as we read, Judge. II. 21, 22, 23. according to that Prediction, Number. XXXIII.
55. and Threatening, Josh. XXIII. 13. And of the Race of the seven Nations, see
that in the days of Solomon, 1 King. IX. 20, 21.

And if that Law of war, Deuteronomy. XX. 10, -- 15. should be extended to the seven
Nations also; yet they deprived themselves of the benefit of it, in not
yielding to conditions of peace; or staying to be besieged; But engaging first,
and beginning the war upon the Israelites; as appears mainly in Josh. Chapter X.
and XI.

The Captive^, a beautiful woman] Seems a permission and Indulgence, in case
of war; rather then an Allowance; As appears by the displeasing Rites before
the marriage; and the slight dismission. It is not much unlike that Bill of
Divorce, Deuteronomy. XXIV. 1. Matthew. XIX. 8. And the case of Usury; as some account
that, Deuteronomy. XXIII. 20.

Two wives] Moses supposing the practice of having two wives together, Deuteronomy.
XXI. 15, 16, 17.

Hanged is accursed] That Curse seems not to be for the kind of punishment;
Number. XXV. 4. John XVI. 26. 2 Samuel XXI. 6. It is true of Christ, Gal. III. 13.
Josh. XIX. 31. by reason of all our horrible sins laid upon him, I mean the
debt of our sins; He becoming our Surety; and so sin for us, 2 Cor. V. 21.
that is, a Sacrifice for sin; as Sacrifices for sin in the Levitical Law are
termed sometimes by the name of sin. The imputation of Guilt would seem to
make him a sinner.

Not weare] That difference of Apparel,

If a man] Is understood of an unmarried man, Exodus XXII. 16, 17. The
difference is in enticing her there; and in laying hold on her here, though not
violently to ravish her. And therefore the Offender is ordered and punished
somewhat less there; and more here.

An Ammonite] The Israelite was to respect more, Rome, by birth, or purchase
Acts XVI. 37, 38. and XXII. 25, -- 28. were thereby invested with the
Privileges of Romans. The Moabite, and Ammonite were not to be so privileged
in their tenth generation: which yet must be understood, either of the men
only, or else with exception of some such singular Cases, as was that of Ruth,
Chapter IV. 10.

Upon Mount] The Tribe of Levi was to stand on Mount Gerizim, Ephraim by
Sichem, with five other Tribes, whereof Joseph is one: And the six other Tribes
to stand on Mount Ebal. And so the Priests called Levites, Deuteronomy. XXVII. 14. may
seem to stand with the Ark in the narrow valley between both: And there
turning to Mount Ebal, to pronounce the Curses, whereunto all the people and
Tribes on Mount Ebal were to say Amen. The other part concerning the Blessings
is not expressed; but in all points, and circumstances easily to be gathered
and understood, Deuteronomy. XI. 26, -- 30. and XXVII. 12, -- 26 This was done in the
first year of their coming over Jordan Josh. VIII. 32, -- 35. when, and where
were read likewise all the words of the Law of Moses, before all the
Congregation of Israel.

With ships] Ships, besides the Ark of Noah, Jacobs blessing of Zebulun, Genesis
XLIX. 13. and in Moses his threatening the Israelites in this place.

Not given] Gods hand in giving and working of Grace. See Chapter XXX. 6. Jer.
XXIV. 7. and XXXI. 33. and XXXII. 39. Ezekiel. XI. 19, 20. and Chapter XXXVI. 26, 27.
Heb. VIII. 10, 11. John VI. 44, 45, 65 Phil. I. 29. and II. 13. Ephesians. II. 8.
2. Tim. II. 25. And he gives grace to the remnant which is according to the
election of Grace, Matthew. XI. 25. and XIII. 11. Mark IV. 11, 12, John XII. 39.
Romans XI. 7. Ephesians. I. 5. 2 Chronicles. XXX. 12.

Mount] This Mount Hor, Aaron died, Number. XX. 25, 26. was South of Judea. And
Mount Hor, on the North-bounds of Judea, Number. XXXIV. 7. are far differing and
distant mountains.

King in Jeshurum] Moses King in Ieshurum, Tribes, does omit Simeon, if we
account him not included in Judah, as his Lot in the division of Canaan fell
within the Lot and Tribe of Judah; and their expeditions against their enemies
in conquering their own shares were joint, and undertaken together, Josh.
XVIII. and XIX. Judge. I 3.

Dwell between his shoulders] That is, Jerusalem. For though the Southern, and
Superior part of Jerusalem, where Mount Sion was, and which was called the City
of David, did belong to the Tribe of Judah; yet the Northern, and inferior
part of it, where Mount Moriah was, whereon the Temple was built, belonged to
the Tribe of Benjamin. The huge deep valley of Mello between the two Mountains,
being filled up and levelled by Solomon; so that thence afterward, Sion, and
Moriah, might be called two tops of one Mountain, Sion the higher top, and
Moriah the lower.

Died] The time of Moses his death was in the fourtieth year, Egypt; and one
hundred and twentieth year of his age. See upon Aarons death, Number. XXXIII. 38.

No man knoweth] The reason of concealing the place of the Burial of Moses;
Michael the Archangel his contending with the Devil, and disputing about the
body of Moses, Jude ver. 9. was not revealed in the Scripture of the Old
Testament. And this dispute might be, lest the Israelites knowing it, might
carry it with them (as Joseph's bones) into Canaan, into which God had said,
That he should not enter; or rather, That the people might not idolize it.

Joshua.
THE Book of Joshua was not probably written by him; though of, and concerning
him; For besides some things contained in it, which are deemed by some, to be
done after his death; As that concerning Caleb and his daughter Achsah, Chapter XV.
16, -- 19. And most surely the Conquering of Leshem or Laish by the Danites,
Chapter XIX. 47. Judge. XVIII. 7. -- 29. And those things recorded, Chapter XXIV. 29, --
33. Some other things seem to plead, That it was written by some Prophet Long
after his death. Whence that phrase remains unto this day, is so frequently
used, Chapter IV. 9. and Chapter VI. 25. and VII. 26. and VIII. 29, and IX. 27. and X.
27. and XIII. 13. and XIV. 14. and XV. 63. And the Book of Iasher is named, Chapter
X. 13. which seems written at soonest in David's time, as recording an Act of
his, 2 Samuel I. 18. unless we say, This Book of Iasher in Joshua's time, to be
continued on, and enlarged in aftertimes, by adding and inserting memorable
acts in after-ages; And so in David's time. And further the Mountains of Judah,
and the Mountains of Israel are mentioned, Josh. XI. 21. Which many possibly
seem to intimate the Book to be written after the division of the Nation into
the two Kingdoms of Judah and Israel.

Joshua was the Tribe of Ephraim, Number. XIII. 8. 1 Chronicles. VII. 27. And he lived
one hundred and ten years, Chapter XXIV. 29. and was six full years in conquering
the Land; and in the seventh fell to the Dividing of it by Lot; as is gathered
out of the age of Caleb, Josh. XIV. 7, 10. And diverse years Joshua lived and
governed after that time; but how many, it does not appear out of this Book:
yet is gathered out of other places to be ten years more: and so this Book to
contain an History of seventeen years, from the Beginning of his Government to
his Death. The truth of this account stands upon this computation; from the
coming out of Egypt, to the fourth of Solomon, are four hundred and eighty
years, 1 King. VI. 1. which are made up thus; forty years in the Wilderness;
seventeen of Joshua; two hundred ninety nine of the Judges; counting in the
twenty of Sampson, as coincident and concurring with the first twenty years of
Eli; twenty years more of Eli; twenty of Samuel; forty of Saul; forty of
David; four of Solomon: In all, 480.

Within three dayes] This Edict and Proclamation of three days, Jordan, set
down here, does begin and commence after the History of the two Spies, and
their return to Joshua; which History yet is recorded after in the Chapter
following. And thereupon the mention of the said three days is taken up again
the second time, Chapter III. 2. when new directions are given for their Passage,
and the manner of it.

Rahab] Rahab, Harlot, because at least she had been so, though now a believing
Convert, ver. 9, 10, 11. Heb. XI. 31. James II. 25. She had her house on the
wall of Jericho, ver. 15. which fell not when the rest of wall fell, Chapter VI.
20, 22.

In framing her excuses for the Spies sake, she bewrayes her infirmity, in
making equivocations, or untruths rather, ver. 4, 5. In transacting with the
Spies, some speeches seem to pass between them after they were let down the
wall, ver. 18.

In pleading for her family, she makes no mention of an Husband, ver. 13. and
Chapter VI. 23.

She was after married to Salmon, eldest son of Nahshon, which Nahshon was
great-grand-childe to Hezron or Esrom that went down with Jacob into Egppt,
Genesis XLVI. 12. And was Prince of Judah, at the numbering of the people, Number. I.
7. at the marshalling of the Camps, Number. II. 3. at the Dedication of the Altar,
Number. VII. 12. and at the setting forward in their journeys, Number. X. 14. But
died in the Wilderness, Number. XIV. 29. This marriage of Rahab to Salmon, now
Prince of Judah, is not recorded in the Old Testament: But mentioned, Matthew. I.
5. in the Genealogy of our Savior; wherein, as Rachab; so Thamar, Ruth, and
Bathshebah, are mentioned. Now there being four hundred and eighty years from
the coming of the children of Israel out of Egypt to the Building of the
Temple, in the fourth year of Solomon, 1 Kings VI. 1. whereof forty years were
spent in the wilderness, and seventy in David's life time, 2 Samuel V. 4. and
four in Solomon's reign; The Remaining time between Rahabs receiving the Spies,
and David's Birth must be 366. which may, and must be made up in some such
reckoning as this; viz. Supposing Rahab to be eighteen years old when she
received the Spies; and sixty six when she did bear Boaz to Salmon; then of
necessity must Boaz beget Obed, and Obed beget Iesse, and Iesse beget David,
each about the age of 106. Which well considered, evidenceth and evinceth these
two things. 1. That the years of the six Oppressors in the times of the Judges,
Chapter III. 8, 14. and IV. 3. and VI. 1. and X. 8. and XIII. 1. which amount to
111. years, cannot be reckoned distinct and apart; But are to be included
within the years of the Judges, and of the Rest of the Land. For otherwise the
years between Rahabs receiving the two Spies, and David's birth, would rise to
477. which cannot be true. And secondly, that the years 480. which is that
famous Link of time, 1 King. VI. 1. cannot possibly be forced to any more then
480. much less to 580. as some learned men of late would have it; and contrary
to that sacred text, 1 King. VI. 1. which never received any veri^^s Lection;
and contrary to the clear evidence and notation of pa^^^cular times set down in
Scripture, which exacty make up that sum of 480. as was now showed: viz.
forty in the Wilderness; seventeen in Ioshuah's Government; 299. in the
Judges times, eighty in Eli, Samuel, and Saul's times; forty in David's; and
four in Solomon's.

Ark] The Ark here leads the way before the host, Jordan and Canaan; without
any more mention of the Pillar of Cloud and Fire.

Two thousand Cubits] The distance of two thousand Cubits from the Ark, Josh.
III. 4. was on either side of it; and seems to be the same distance that was
kept from it, in their Campings or Pitchings, and in their Journeyings in the
Wilderness: And may well be deemed to be the Sabbath-dayes journey mentioned,
Acts I. 12. Comparing together John XI. 18. and Luke XXIV. 50.

Rose up upon an heap] When the Israelites passed through Jordan, not as a wall
unto them, on the right hand, and on the left; as likely they were when Elias,
and Elizeus divided them with a mantle, 2 King. II. 8, 14. And as certainly the
waters of the redsea were, Exodus 14. 21, 22. But God stopped the waters of the
river that came down from above, and they stood and rose upon an heap, very
far from the City Adam: And thereupon those waters that came down from Adam
to the Salt and Dead Sea, and Lake of Sodom and Asphaltites, did run away,
failed, were cut off.

Midst] The often mentioning the midst of the river of Jordan to be the place
where the Priests feet stood bearing the Ark of the Lord; Gilgal, Josh. III.
17. and IV. 3, 5, 8, 9, 10, 18. does induce me to take the word midst in its
proper signification, having no manner of inconvenience in it for so doing,
rather then to transfer it to the Channel close by the further side and banck.

Passed over] The place of their passage over Jordan, Beth-barah, in the Tribe
of Reuben, beyond Jordan, Judge. VII. 24. And Bethabara, John. I. 28. (not
Bethania, as the Trent-Bible erroneously there has it) where John baptized
Jesus; as well as others. And Betharabah seems to be a City not far from the
Passage on the other side, a City of Benjamin, bordering upon Judah, Josh. XV.
6. 61. and XVIII. 22. Though some not so rightly place the foresaid town higher
upon the river more then twenty miles above Adam; and far off from the border
of Judah. At this Passage the Altar Ed seems to be builded in the Tribe of
Reuben, Josh. XXII. 11.

Twelve men] Reuben, Gad, are here included in the twelve; though their
Possessions were beyond Jordan. And of these two Tribes, and half Manasseh,
about forty thousand armed men passed over Jordan to the war, ver. 13. which
were yet but a few more then one third part of their military men, Number. XXVI.
7, 18, 34. The rest stayed behind for their many necessary occasions.

Came up] They came over Jordan, Circumcised the eleventh; And did eat the
Passover on the fourteenth, Chapter V. 2, 10. Both which were omitted in the
wilderness; at least since the Return of the twelve Spies, and after that
Passover at Mount Sinai, Number. IX. 5. See Josh. V. 5, 7. And on the XVI. day
Manna ceased, ver. 12.

The second time] Not that these were Circumcised once before. ver. 7. It was
neglected, or omitted many years for some reasons. And at this time upon many
reasons renewed, and again enjoined by God. See the Annotations upon this text.

Gilgal] Of this place, Hos. IV. 15.

A man] This Captain of the Lords host, Gabriel, or any other created Angel;
but Michael the Archangel, Jude 9. Michael the great Prince of Gods people,
Dan. X. 21. and XII. 1. the Angel of the Covenant, Mal. III. 1. Christ the
Son of God; Appearing here, and sundry other times, in the shape of man, as a
foregoing presage and prologue, to typifie his future Incarnation. And this
appears, by Joshua's Adoration of him, as his Lord Jehovah, Chapter VI. 2. and by
His acceptance of it, which an Angel would have refused, Apoc. XIX. 10. by his
Commanding Joshua to put off his shoes, because the place was holy; like to
that, Exodus III. 5. Not that the Place was capable of any inherent holiness in
it self, but hallowed by Gods holy presence in it, and in that relation only
so esteemed; and which ceased so to be when his Presence was withdrawn from it.
This Captain instructs Joshua about the manner of besieging, and conquering
Jericho, Chapter VI. 2, -- 5.

Seventh day] Sabbath Day must needs be one of the seven wherein the Camp of
Israel did march round about the walls of Jericho; Sabbath.

Priests shall blow with the Trumpets] Priests, not Levites. And Priests, not
Levites carry the Ark. See the Observations on Number. X. 8. and on Chapter VII. v. 1,
-- 9.

Achan] Achan is called also Achar, Chron. II. 7. which signifies a Troubler;
and the Place of his execution is called the Valley of Achor, v. 26., that is
trouble. He was Grandchild of Zabdi; otherwise called Zimri, 1 Chronicles. II. 6.

Ai] Ai is called Hai, Genesis XII. 8. and Aijah, Neh. XI. 31. in the tribe of
Benjamin, very near to Bethel, Ezra II. 28. Neh. VII. 32. and differs from that
Ai, situate between Heshbon and Rabbah, in the tribe of God; yet taken by the
Ammonites; whereof see Jeremie XLIX. 3.

Bethaven] Bethaven, and Bethel, two distinct towns, not far asunder, near
the North bounds of the Tribe of Benjamin. Yet Hosea calls Bethel by the name
of Bethaven, the house of vanity, and vain Idols, in scorn and derision, for
Jeroboams golden Calf there set up, Hos. IV. 15. and V. 8. and X. 5. See the
Observations on 1 King. XII. 29, 32.

Taketh] By Divine instinct and command Lots are here used; In which case their
judgment is infallible. Of Lots, see my Annotations on Jonah. I. 7.

And his sonnes] Gods severe judgment upon his whole family, ver. 24, 25. is
warranted by Him, who is sole Dispensor, and Sovereigne Lord over his own Law,
Deuteronomy. XXIV. 16. And at the most, his Sacrilege, was but the Occasion, not the
Cause of Gods judgment upon his family; They having sin enough in themselves
otherwise, for Gods justice to work upon, though they had no hand in this
sacrilegious act.

Ambush] God appoints both the End, and the Means, 1 Chronicles. XIV. 14, 15. And
Gods people having the assurance of Gods Particular Promises, do yet carefully
use the Means; as Josh. XI. 7. and X. 9. Acts XXVII. 24, 31. Judge. XX. 28, 29.
Stratagems in war are lawful.

Chose out] Not likely that the 30000. did lie in wait behind Ai Westward,
between Ai and Bethel; but only 5000. ver. 12, 17.

Gibeon] Gibeon was a great City, Chapter X. 2. and XI. 19. allotted afterward to
Benjamin; and out of that Tribe to the Priests, Chapter XXI. 13, 17. The
Tabernacle, and Altar were here in David's and Solomon's time, 1 Chronicles. XXI. 20.
