2 Chronicles. I. 3. David orders the service of it here, 1 Chronicles. XVI. 30. Solomon
sacrifices at this High Place: God appears to him here: And he brings the
Tabernacle, and Altar thence, to the Treasuries of the Temple, 1 King. III. 4.
Here Joshua vanquished the five Kings of the Amorites, Chapter X. And had the Sun
stand still upon his prayer. Here David smote the Philistines, 1 Chronicles. XIV.
16. By the poole of Gibeon was that mortal fight between twelve of Abners, and
twelve of Ioabs men; whence the place was called the field of strong men in
Gibeon. Here Abner in his flight slays Asabel the brother of Ioab; And Ioab
pursues Abner by the way of the Wilderness of Gibeon, 2 Samuel II. 12, 16, 24.
and Chapter III. 30. At the great stone in Gibeon Ioab slew Amasa, his
Cousen-german, 2 Samuel XX. 8. And by the great waters that are in Gibeon,
Iohanan fights, and puts to flight Ishmael, Ier. XLI. 12. The Gibeonites were
Hivites, Josh. IX. 7. yet called also by the more general name of Amorites, 2 Samuel XXI. 2. They were those which in aftertimes were called Nethinims, etc.
that is, Deodands, given and devoted to that Drudgery, ver. 23, 27. Of whom see
2 Samuel XXI. 2. 1 Chronicles. IX. 2. Ezra II. 43, 58, 62, 70. and VII. 7, 24. and
VIII. 17, 20. Neh. VII. 46, 60, 73. and X. 28. and XI. 3, 21. Something like to
these were those other of these Nations, on whom Solomon did raise a tribute of
Bondage, 1 King. IX. 20, 21. Of whom see more on that place.

The Oath and League made with the Gibeonites, and their Cities, ver. 17.
though surreptitiously and fraudulently gotten, and also rashly granted, yet
seems in the substance of it to be lawful; otherwise an unlawful Oath should
be broken: whereas this was kept with all faithfulness; Joshua fighting in
their defense, and that by the Lords approbation and encouragement, Chapter X. 7,
8. And this seems lawful, because they sued for Peace before they were
besieged; and willingly submitted to all Conditions, without any reservation of
their Lands, Goods, Laws, Liberties, much less of their superstitions and
idolatries, (which otherwise might have ensnared the Israelites); but of their
Lives only, and they to be employed in the Israelites service. Cities, and
People of other Nations then these, very far off, might be received upon
far easier terms and conditions. But upon all these Conditions, others of
these Nations themselves might have been spared their lives. Yet God in his
providence so ordered, That there was not a City that made peace with the
Israelities, saving these Hittites of Gibeon only, and their Cities: All other
they took in battle; for it was of the Lord so to harden their hearts, that
they might be destroyed, Chapter XI. 19, 20. And therefore, the Congregation here
murmured unjustly (happily through ignorance) against Joshua, and the Princes,
for this League and Oath: And Saul was justly punished, and that grievously, in
his posterity; and the Land also with famine, many ages after this, because he
sought to slay and destroy them from remaining in any of the coasts of Israel,
contrary to this League and Oath; though Soul did it in a pretended or wrong
zeal to the children of Israel and Judah, 2 Samuel XXI. 1, -- 6.

Adoni-Zedek seems, Melchizede^, Genesis XIV. 18. But Adoni-bezeck, Judge. I. 7.
seems not any successor to this Adonizedeek, much less himself; He himself
being slain; ver. 23, 26. But Adoni-bezeck was Lord or King, not of Jerusalem;
but of Bezeck, in the Tribe of Judah; where Saul numbered against Nahash 330000.
men, 1 Samuel XI. 8.

Jerusalem, is called also Jebus, Judge. XIX. 10. 1 Chronicles. XI. 4, 5. of Jebusi
the son of Canaan, Genesis X. 16. And Salem, Genesis XIV. 18. Psalm. LXXVI. 2. The
name seems composed of them. If not; then of Jireh, and Salem, the place Salem
[Gen. XIV. 18. Psalm. LXXVI. 2.] where God appeared [ Genesis XXII. 14.] Or, Jiereh
Shalem, signifying the Vision of Peace, or Possession of Peace, or Peace shall
be seen or provided, a place of providence, Genesis XXII. 14. See Hebr. VII. 1,
2. And it is of the Dual number, being a double City, belonging to two Tribes,
Judah, and Benjamin; Josh. XV. 8, 63. and XVIII. 28. Judge. I. 8, 21. Jer.
XXXIX. 3. The Southern and higher part belonging to Judah, wherein the strong
hold of Zion was; taken at last by David presently after his anointing King
over all Israel; and built and called his City, 2 Samuel V. 6, -- 9. 1 Chronicles. XI.
4, -- 8. And became the Burial-place of the Kings of Judah. And David's
Sepulcher continued there till the Apostles times, Acts II. 29. near 1100.
years. And the Ark for a time, was placed there, 2 Samuel VI. 12, -- 17.
whereupon Zion is called the City of God, Gods holy Hill. The Northern, and
lower part, belonging to Benjamin; wherein the Temple stood, on Mount Moriah, 2
Chon. III. 1. Honorable things are spoken of this City, Psalm. LXXXVII. 2, 3.
This City is called the City of God, of the Lord of Hoasts, of the great King;
the holy place of the Tabernacles of the most High, Psalm. XLVI. 4. and XLVIII.
8. The Throne of the Lord, Jer. III. 17. Jehovah-Shammah (in that visionarie
Description) Ezekiel. XLVIII. 35. It is called the City of Solemnities, Esaias
XXXIII. 20. a City of Righteousness, Esaias V. 26. a City of Truth, Zech. VIII.
3. a Faithful City, Esaias I. 26. a City sought out, and not forsaken, Esaias LXII.
12. The walls thereof are called Salvation; and her gates Praise; and they are
ever in Gods sight, Esaias XLIX. 16. and LX. 18.

Hoham] These other four Kings were all South of Jerusalem: Judah.

Lachish] Of this City see the Annotations on Micah I. 13.

The Lord said] The Lord spoke to Joshua; Urim and Thummim.

Hailestones] Gods two Miracles in this battle. Egypt, Exodus IX. 18, -- 25.
which killed more Amorites then were slain by the sword; braining likely the
body of their host, as they fled, where they were thickest, and those that
were foremost in the flight; and not hurting the Pursuers, who were
intermingled, yet likely mostwhat in the Rear of the enemy. II. By the
miraculous standing still (upon Joshua's Prayer, first privately made, and
granted; after publicly pronounced in the sight of Israel) of the Sun, and
of the Moon; and with them of the whole frame of Heaven; about a whole day,
till the people had avenged themselves upon their enemies.

Jasher] The Book of Jasher records the Miracle. David's time, 2 Samuel I. 18. And
this Book being no part of Canonical inspired Scripture; but a Civil Chronicle
or Annals among the Jews, is since perished; as diverse others of like nature;
Among which are those books of Chronicles, not Canonical, but Civil, so often
cited in our two books of the Kings.

No day] That day in Hezekiah's time, King. XX. 11. But that, not till many
ages after; And this book first written.

Returned] If Joshua here resolved to return to Gilgal, Kadesh-barnea, unto
Gaza, in a short time, intervened, ver. 16, -- 42. before he actually returned
thither, ver. 43.

Ioshua] And c. XI. Joshua took Hebron, or Kiriath-Arba, and Debir, or
Kiriath-Sepher, and cut off the Anakims. Yet under the conduct of Caleb this
was perfected; Joshua assigning him, out of his army, the Tribe of Judah, for
his assistance therein, Chapter XIV. 6, -- 15. and Chapter XV. 13, -- 19. which thing
seems to be repeated, Judge. I. 10, -- 15. rather then a new Conquest made again
after the death of Joshua.

Goshen] And Chapter XI. Chapter XV. 51. This Goshen in Canaan; differing from that in
Egypt.

Sand] Hyperbolees much used in Scripture. Genesis XXII. 17. and XLI. 49. Judge.
VII. 12. and Chapter XX. 16. 1 Samuel XIII. 5. 2 Samuel I. 23. 1 King. I. 40. and IV.
20, 29. 2 King. XIX. 24. 1 Chronicles. XII. 8. and XVI. 33. 2 Chronicles. I. 9. and
XXVIII. 9. Job. XX. 6. and XXII. 24. and XL. 23. Psalm. VI. 6. Esaias XXXIV. 3, 5,
7, 9. and XLVIII. 19. Jer. IV. 24. and XV. 8. Joel. III. 18. Amos II. 9. and
IX. 13. John XXI. 25.

A long time] After the battle at the waters of Merom, Joshua did make war a
long time with all those Northern Kings in Canaan: about six years; as is
gathered out of Chapter XIV. 6, -- 15.

Arnon] Arnon the River, Iabbok; and both from rocky Mountains that lie in the
East part of the Tribe of Gad. It runs Southward, and falls into the
North-East corner of the Dead Sea. It is the border between Sihon, or Reuben on
the West, and Ammon on the East; and between Sihon or Reuben on the North, and
Moab on the South.

Iabbok] Iabbok the River, Arnon; but runs North a little; and after turns
his stream West; and falls into Jordan a little below the Sea of Galilee. It
divided the Land of Gilead between Sihon and Og; and afterward between Gad, on
the South, and half Manasseh on the North.

Remains yet] The Land both Conquered, Josh. XXIII. 4, 5. Begun at Gilgal,
Chapter XIV. 6. and Chapter XV. and Chapter XVI. and Chapter XVII. Resumed, and Perfected at
Shiloh, Chapter XVIII. and XIX. But we never read, That they did Conquer the whole
Land, and all their several Shares and Lots; through their own default and
breach of Covenant with God, by Disobedience, Chapt. XXIII. 13.

Aroer] The City Aroer was near the Rise of the River Arnon; Heshbon, Dibon,
and Ataroth; which being bordering Cities, are said to belong to them both,
sometimes to the one, sometimes to the other; To Reuben, Josh. XIII. 16, 17.
Number. XXXII. 37. To Gad, Josh. XXI. 39. Number. XXXII. 34. 1 Chronicles. VI. 81.

Distributed] The whole Country, be enlarged or lessened, according to the
greatness or smalnesse of the number that belonged to it, Number. XXVI. 53, --
56. and Chap. XXXIII. 54. which last point of division was left to the wisdom
of the High Priest, Joshua, and the Elders, whom God had appointed to divide
it, ver. 1. and Chapter XVII. 14, -- 18.

By lot] Lots fell out providentialy to the twelve Tribes, Jacob, Genesis XLIX.
and Moses, Deuteronomy. XXXIII. And so in the Cities of the Levites; the Lot cast the
thirteen Cities of the Priests in the Tribes of Judah, Benjamin, and Simeon,
which were nearest the Temple, Josh. XXI. 9, 10, 17. when it was builded.

Old] Calebs age, Kadeshbarnea was forty. At this Division of the Land eighty
five. So that forty five years intervened, viz. 38. in the wilderness, and
seven of Joshua's Government until this time. And Caleb here, ver. 9, -- 14.
And Joshua, Chapter XIX. 49, 50. did both ask, and both had certain inheritances
given them two, according to the word of the Lord. The City and Suburbs of
Hebron were given to the Priests, for a City of refuge: The fields and Villages
thereof to Caleb, Chapter XXI. 11, 12, 13.

Caleb] Not that Caleb, Chron. II. 18, 42. the son of Hezron, unless by
son we understand great-grand-childe; But Caleb that is constantly called the
son of Jephunne; And Othniel constantly called the son of Kenaz, are here
yet called brethren: And Othniel is again called the younger brother of Caleb,
Judge. I. 13. and III. 9. which could not be except by one mother: But Othniel
marrying the daughter of Caleb, ver, 17. And cosen-germans, Nephews, and the
like being often called brethren in Scripture, It is likely that either
Iephunne, and Kenaz were brethren, and so Caleb and Othniel cosen-germans; or
that Caleb and Kenaz were brethren, and so Othniel Calebs Nephew; or that the
Kenezite mentioned, Number. XXXII. 12. might be Grandfather to them both. But no
certainty appears for any further determination.

Separate] The bordering Cities of the children of Ephraim, Manasseh. See also,
chapter XVII. 8, 9. And as Ephraim had part in Manasseh, so Manasseh had Cities in
Issachar, and in Asher, chapter XVII. 11.

The Portion] Ten portions to Manasseh; ver. 2. And the portion of the sixth
son, who was Hopher, was divided into five portions among his grandchildren,
the daughters of Zelophahad; which so made up ten portions, though the five
last were but as big, as one of the former five.

One lot] Both Ephraim and Manasseh seek for a larger portion and Lot then what
did befall them in the General Division.

Shiloh] Shiloh was on the North-side of Bethel, Bethel to Shechem, on the
South of that Lebanon, Judge. XXI. 19. And so situated on the border between
Ephraim and Benjamin; yet belonged to Ephraim, not to Benjamin, Judge. XXI. 1,
21. There was the Tabernacle, as was formerly said. There were the Lots cast
for seven Tribes. Josh. XVIII. 8. Thence were the two Tribes and a half
dismissed to their Possessions, after the war, Josh. XXII. 9. And thither
were the whole Congregation of Israel gathered to go up to war against them,
upon a wrong surmise concerning the Altar Ed, ver. 12. Thither came all the
other Tribes to ask counsel of the Lord in their war against the Tribe of
Benjamin, and there was their Camp, Judge. XX. 18. and XXI. 12. and XIX. 18.
Thither came Elkanah and Hannah to worship; and Samuel ministered there before
the Lord, 1 Samuel I. 3. and II. 11. and III. 21. And there the Prophet Ahijah
dwelt in the days of the first Jeroboam, 1 King. XIV. 2.

Tabernacle] The Tabernacle, coming over Jordan, was first set up in Gilgal;
Not that Gilgal of the Nations, Josh. XII. 23. Genesis XIV. 1. Esaias IX. 1. (whence
happily Galilee might take its name); But that Gilgal in the Tribe of Benjamin,
Josh. IV. 19, 20. Afterward in Joshua's time it was set up here in Shiloh, in
the Tribe of Ephraim, near the Center of the Land; which was by Sichem, Chapter
XXIV. 1, 25, 26. And Bochim, Judge. II. 1, 5. may seem to be conjoined to it.
It may seem to be fetched thence for a present use, to that solemn Assembly
at Shechem, in Joshua's time, Chapter XXIV. 1, 26. But being returned to Shiloh, it
continued there above three hundred years, at least till the death of Eli, 1 Samuel I. 3, 9, 24. and II. 14. and III. 3, 21. and IV. 3. It may seem to be
again at Gilgal with the Ark, in Samuel and Saul's time, 1 Samuel X. 8. and Chapter
XI. 15. But soon after we surely find it to be at Nob in the Tribe of
Benjamin, near Anathoth, Neh. XI. 32. when David came thither in his flight
from Saul, 1 Samuel XXI. 1, -- 9. After that sacrilegious slaughter of eighty
five Priests by Saul at Nob, 1 Samuel XXII. 18. it was soon removed, in the days
of David, to Gibeon, in the same Tribe of Benjamin, (and not far from
Bethel;) the City first of the wily Gibeonites Hivites, but after given to the
Priests, Josh. IX. and chapter XXI. 17. See 1 Chronicles. XVI. 39, 40. and XXI. 29. and
2 Chronicles. I. 3, 5, 6, 13. 1 King. III. ver. 4, 5. And lastly, when Solomon had
built the Temple, he brought the Tabernacle thence to Jerusalem, 1 King. VIII.
4. 2 Chronicles. I. 3 5 6, 13. and chapter V. 5. And placed it likely in and among the
Treasuries of the Temple.

For the Ark see the Observations on 1 Samuel IV. 3.

Tabor] A Mountain in the Tribe of Issachar, Carmel. See Joshua XIX. 26 34.
Here Barak was with his ten thousand men against Sisera, Judge. IV. 6, 12, 14.
See more of this in my Annotations on Hos. V. 1.

Tyre] Called the strong City, Tsor in Hebrew, signifying a Rock; situate, like
Venice, in the Sea. A famous Port and Mart-town in Phoenicia, the lower part of
Syria, whence the whole Country is supposed to take the name of Syria,
omitting the letter [ t] in Tsor. More of this see in my Annotations on Amos.
I. 9.

Bethshemesh] A City in the Tribe of Naphtali, ver. 32. and 39. Judge. I. 33.
Another in the Tribe of Judah, given to the Priests, Josh. XXI. 16. 1 Chronicles.
VI. 59. 1 Samuel VI. 12. 2 King. XIV. 13. Another also in Egypt, Jer. XLIII. 13.
the same as is supposed with On, Genesis XLI. 45. by the Greeks called Heliopolis,
and now Damiata. The word signifies a City or House of the Sun. As also
Kirharesheth a City in Moab, Esaias XVI. 7. has the same denomination. And all,
because of Temples and Idol-service used there by the ancient inhabitants to
the Sun. From which the Jews sometimes were not altogether free, 2 King.
XXIII. 5, 11.

Cities of refuge] The six Cities of refuge belonged to the Levites; Hebron,
and Shechem, to the Koathites; Golan, and Kedesh to the Gershonites; Bezer and
Ramoth, to the Merarites, Josh. XX. and XXI Chapters.

In Galilee] Galilee is often mentioned in the Old Testament. chapter XXI. 32. 1
King. IX. 11. 2 King. XV. 29. 1 Chronicles. VI. 76. Esaias IX. 1. Galilee divided into
the Upper, in the Tribe of Naphtali; and the Lower, in the Tribe of Zabulon;
Jordan. The Upper is called Galilee of the Gentiles because both Populous, and
replenished with many Gentiles as lying nearest to them 1 King. IX. 11. Matthew.
XV. 21. Mar. VII. 31. And so is Harosheth, called Harosheth of the Gentiles,
Judge. IV. 2. as lying in that Tribe of Naphtali.

Thirteen] Thirteen Cities with their Suburbs in title and dominion given to
the Priests Josh. XXI. 4. See the Annotations on 1 Chronicles. VI. 59. Though one of
them at that time, was too much for their present use and habitation; we
reading but of three of them in number about fifty years before this time.

Called] The two Tribes and a half dismissed, Josh. XX. 11.

Divide] This Dividing the spoil with their brethren, Jordan, seems to relate
to that, Number. XXXI. 27. And David seems hereupon to revive and enact that Law
of like Division, 1 Saem. XXX. 24, 25.

Mention of the name] The not naming of Idols is mentioned, Exodus XXIII. 13.
Deuteronomy. XII. 3. Psalm. XVI. 4. And a like, Ephesians. V. 3. Yet the thing in it self
is not simply and absolutely unlawful.

Shechem] Shechem was a City in Mount Ephraim, Josh. XX. 7. North-North-East
from Shiloh, and Bethel; and close by Mount Gerizim, and Ebal Judge. IX. 7. Here
Abraham and Jacob had sojourned; And Jacobs two sons, Simeon and Levi, young
men, upon Dinah's ravishment, murdered the Citizens, Genesis XXXIV. Here after
Gideons death, the Citizens worshipped Baal-Berith; and rebelled with
Abimelech; and were after punished and spoiled by him, Judge. IX. This City in
Joshua's time was made a City of Refuge, and given to the Kohathite-Levites,
Josh. XXI. 21. And here Joshua made a Covenant with all the people to serve the
Lord, Chap. XXIV. ver. 25. The Mount Ephraim whereon the City stood, was famous
for Burials: Here they buried Joseph's bones in Shechem, in a parcel of ground
which Jacob bought of the children of Hamor or Emor, Josh. XXIV. 32. Acts VII.
16. Genesis XXXIII. 19. Here was great Joshua himself an Ephraimite, buried in his
inheritance in Timnath-Scrah, or Here Is, which is in Mount Ephraim, on the
North-side of the hill Goash, Josh. XXIV. 30. Judge. II. 9. And here was the
High Priest Eleazar buried in an Hill that pertained to Phineas his son, which
was given him in Mount Ephraim, Josh. XXIV. 33. Here Deborah dwelt, Judge. IV.
5. And Tola the Judge, chapter X. 1. Hither came Rehoboam to be made King: But
Jeroboam was there made King in his stead; who built or fortified the City, and
dwelt there, 1 King. XII. 1, 20, 25.

Judges.
THE Book of JUDGES contains an History, not of four hundred and ten years; but
of two hundred ninty and nine years. So, Counting the years of the VI.
Oppressors within the years and times of the Judges; as I have showed they
necessarily must, upon Rahabs marriage with Prince Salmon* Josh. II. And so
Expounding the Texts following, according to the truth of the times, thus; That
the Land had Rest by Othniel, in the fourtieth year after it was first settled
in Rest by Joshua at his Death, Judge. III. 11. not after the Death of Moses.
And again had Rest by Ehud in the eightieth year, after the former Rest by
Othniel, Chapter III. 30. And again had Rest by Deborah in the fourtieth year,
after the former Rest by Ehud, Chapter V. 31. And again had Rest by Gideon, in the
fourtieth year, after the former Rest by Deborah, Chapter VIII. 28. These make up
two hundred years. And then follow three of Abimelech; twenty three of Tolah;
twenty two of Jair; six of Jephthah; seven of Ibzan; ten of Elon; eight of
Abdon; twenty of Sampson, which make np the other ninty nine years; in all two
hunded, ninty nine. The text, Judge. IV. 3, 4. seems to accord with rhis
reckoning: and to account Jabins Oppression within the years of Deborah. But
yet counting, beside these, the times of the VI. Oppressors distinctly over and
above, which amount to one hundred and eleven years; and is according to the
seeming letter of the texts; And then forty years of Eli being added
thereunto, the sum arises to those 450. years mentioned by Paul, Acts XIII.
20. But reading the words of Saint Paul, as in order they stand there in the
Original; and after these things about four hundred and fifty years; he gave
them Judges until Samuel the Prophet; we may rather conceive the four hundred
and fifty years to comprehend all the time, from the choosing of the Fathers,
till the Division of the Land by Joshua; it being four hundred fifty two from
the Birth of Isaac, and four hundred forty seven from the Rejection of
Ishmael; both ways about four hundred and fifty, wherein those things
mentioned, ver. 18, 19, 20. were done and accomplished. And after that time he
gave them Judges until Samuel the Prophet: And after that time, He gave them
Kings. And thus the most learned Primate of all Ireland has it in his learned
Annals.

This Book seems written of, and concerning the Judges, (as the Book of Ruth
concerning Ruth;) And long after their times; As may seem to be gathered by
those phrases, remain unto this day, and the like, Chapter I. 21, 26. and VI. 24.
and X. 4. and XV. 19. And Chapter XVIII. 30. must needs have relation at soonest to
the captivity of the Arc in the days of Samuel, 1 Samuel IV. 17. Psalm. LXXVIII.
60, 61.

Asked] They asked the Lord; Phineas the High Priest; who by Urim and Thummim
makes answer, Number. XXVII. 21. Both which were on or in the Breastplate; and the
Breastplate was annexed to the Ephod, Exodus XXVIII. 28, 30. and XXXIX. 21.
which made David call for the Ephod, and High Priest, thereby to enquire of the
Lord, 1 Samuel XXIII. 9, 10, 11, 12. and Chapter XXVIII. 6. So Ezra II. 63. See more
on 1 Samuel XXIII. 9.

Bezek] Bezek a City in the tribe of Judah; Jerusalem, lying from it
South-West; and midway between (...) and Bethlehem.

Adoni-Bezek] Josh. X. 1.

Said, seventy Kings] His seventy Kings subdued, and mangled by him, must needs
be very petty Kings of Provinces, or Cities; if not such Princes as are now in
Germany, where all the brethren of a Prince are called Princes likewise. And
these seventy were such, as in the time of all his reign and tyranny
Adoni-bezek had subdued. He was brought from Bezek to Jerusalem to be made a
public example there.

Ierusalem] Judah had taken Jerusalem, i. e. that part of it which belonged to
Judah, Josh. XV. 8. yet so as the Jebusite still dwelt therein with the
children of Judah, ver. 63. even till David's time, 2 Samuel V. 6, 7, 8. And
Benjamin did the like, and no more, with their part of Jerusalem, Judge. I. 21.
yet both had little hold in it in that Levites time, Judge. XIX. 10, 11, 12. or
happily at that time had never got any hold in it at all.

Hebron] Of this City see the Observations on 2 Samuel

Caleb] Of Caleb see the Observations on Josh.

A South-Land] Or dry Land.

Kenite] and Chapter IV. 11. and Chapter V. 24. See 1 Chronicles. II. 55. Genesis XV. 19. Number.
XXIV. 21. 1 Samuel XV. 6. And see my Observations on Number. X. 29.

Palm Trees] Jericho. Of this see the Observations on Chapter III. 13.

Gaza] Judah took Gaza, Askelon, and Ekron: And lost them soon afterward, Chapter
III. 3.

Bethel] Of this see the Observations on 1 King. XXXII.

Beths^an] And the rest in this verse, were Cities in that half Tribe of
Manasseh that lay West of Jordan.

Angel] The Angel here seems to be no created Angel: Mal. III. 1. that
appeared to Moses in the Bush, Exodus III. 2. called Jehovah, ver. 4. and to
Joshua, Josh. V. 14. And to Gideon, Judge. VI. 16. And to Manoah, and his wife,
Chapter XIII. Of whom Jacob spoke, Genesis XLVIII. 24. And of whom God spoke unto
Moses, Exodus XXIII. 21, 22, 23. termed both Jehovah, Exodus XIII. 21. XIV. 10,
24. and his face, or presence, Exodus XXXIII. 14, 15. and an Angel, Exodus
XXXIII. 2. the Messiah, Acts VII. 38. the Son of God, Heb. I. 3. See on Judge.
XIII. 3. But whether this History fell out in the lifetime of Joshua, or after
his death, is somewhat more uncertain.

all the days of Joshua] Therefore the Angel's coming to Bochim, Joshua, and
those Elders.

Mount of Ephraim] Of this see the Observations on Joshua XXIV.

Baal and Ashtaroth] Of these see the Observations on Chapter

Judges] This Chapter seems to be a summarie of the bulk of this Book.

Left those Nations] Ver. and Chapter III. 1, 2, 4. See the Observations on Deuteronomy.
VII 1. and 2.

King of Mesopotamia] Heb. Aram-Naharaim, i. e. of Syria between the two
rivers, Tigris and Euphrates: Naharaim being of the Dual number.

Forty years] See the Observations on the beginning of this Book.

Palme-trees] Jericho, the City of Palme-trees, Deuteronomy. XXXIV. 3. Chron. XXVIII.
15. This was nigh Jordan on the West Side of it; and Gilgal in the East border
of Jericho, where Rahab entertained and hid the two Spies: And from the Plains
of Moab, Pisga and Shirtim, which were over against Jericho, on the East Side
of Jordan the Israelites passed over. Here the Israelites kept the Passover:
and the Captain of the Lords Host appeared to Joshua This was burnt, Josh. VI.
24. And the Re-builder of it cursed, ver. 26. And the same verified in Hiel, in
the days of Ahab, 1 King. XVI. 34. So that the Kenites being in it; and Eglons
possessing of it mentioned here; And that of David's ill-intreated messengers
residing here, 2 Samuel X. 5. must be meant of some mean buildings, or Forts
only in it, or rather by it. It fell by Lot to the Tribe of Benjamin, Josh.
XVIII. 21. Here was a College of the sons of the Prophets in the times of
Elias; and Eliseus: and the waters healed by Eliseus, Hither were sent back
courteously the many Jews captived by Pekah in the days of Ahaz, 2 Chronicles.
XXVIII. And in the Plains here was Zedekiah taken by Nebuchadnezzars forces.
And in the days of our Savior, he did herein, or hard by, give sight to
blind men; and converted Zacheus.

And he arose] Reverence to God and his Word, Number. XXIII. 18. 2 King. XX III.
2. 2 Chronicles. XXXIV. 31. Neh. VIII. 6.

Oxe-goad] Miraculous are the victories of Shamgar, Sampson slaying one
thousand of them with the jaw bone of an Ass, Chapter XV. 15, 16.

Jabin] This Jabin successor to that Jabin slain by Joshua, his City Hazor
burnt, Josh. XI 1, 10, 11, 13. Yet this successor or son, reinforceth
himself, and twenty years oppressed Israel; and was destroyed at last by
Deborah and Barak, ver. 24.

Hazor] A City in Naphtali, and upper Galilee, East from Rehob in Asher: and in
former times head of the neighboring Kingdoms, I^sh. XI. 10. There was
another Hazor, or two, in the Tribe of Judah, Josh. XV. 23, 25.

Haresheth of the Gentiles] Ver. 16. In Naphtali, about thirty miles East from
Hazor; near the South-bottome of the waters of Merom. Here he dwells, because
Joshua had burnt Hazor, Josh. XI. 11, 13.

Charets of iron] Much use of these in war; Observations on Chapter XX. 2. and on
2 Samuel VIII. 5.

A Prophetesse] See the Observations on Zeph. Sam. XVIII. 10.

at that time] Even when, and while Iabin oppressed them. So that those twenty
years, v. 3. are within those forty years of Deborah, V. 31.

Ramah] See the Annotations on Hos. Josh. XVIII. 25. and XIX. 29, 36. 1 Samuel I.
1. Those in Benjamin, Ephraim, and Judah, were the chief Places, famous by
Deborah, Samuel, Saul, and David; as the sacred Histories do record.

Barak] This Barak, Rahab, Gideon, Jephthah, Sampson, commended for their
Faith, Heb. XI. 31, 32. though weak in Faith; and not without their many
failings.

Tabor] In the South-part of Zebulon; not far from the river Kishon, as it
runs into the South-bottome of the Sea of Galilee. Of Tabor see more in the
Annotations on Hos. V. 1.

Of a Woman] Deborah, and Jael.

Zaanaim] Zaanaim by Kedesh in Naphtali, Barak dwelled.

Not a man left] Not a man left in the field to make any resistance, Psalm. XIV.
3. and LIII. 3. Romans III. 12.

Shamgar] Of him, Chapter III. 31. And of Jael, Chapter IV. 18.

Was there a speare] 1 Samuel XIII. 19.

From the noise] They could not fetch water without danger from the enemy.

Out of] Hence to the end of the Song, Deborah relates how the several Tribes
behaved themselves in this Expedition; with their praise, or dispraise. And
here Reuben, Gilead, and Dan, and Asher are blamed; and Meroz cursed: and Jael
the wife of Heber is blessed.

Roote] Most likely, understood of Deborah of Mount Ephraim, the firstrise and
mover of this Expedition; though some extend it to Joshua; and others
understand it of the Tribes of Judah and Simeon.

Amalek] Amalek joined here with the Canaanites, in this battle against the
Israelites.

After thee Benjamin] After Ephraim came Benjamin, to assist in this war.

Out of Machir] That half Tribe of Manasseh that dwelt within Canaan. For
though the one half of the children of Machir had their inheritance in Gilead,
Josh. XIII. 31. which is here blamed, ver. 17. yet the other half of Machirs
children had their inheritance within Canaan; West of Jordan, Josh. XVII. 1, 2.
who are here commended.

Barak] Not of Issachar: Naphtali, dwelling in Kedesh of Naphtali. Chapter IV. 6.

Divisions of Reuben] Divided among themselves touching this war; or divided
from the other Tribes, and deserting them in it.

Megiddo] Megiddo an eminent City which Manasseh had in Issachar, Josh. XVII.
11. not far from Jezreel, and the river Kishon. Joshua slew the King of it,
Josh. XII. 21. And Josiah was slain, or had his deaths wound, in the valley of
it, 2 King. XXIII. 29, 30. 2 Chronicles. XXXV. 34.

Taanach] Taanach a royal City, near Megiddo, Josh. XII. 21.

Took no gaine] Took none of Jabin; nor got any gain by this fight with Israel.

The Sta^s] The Stars in their stations; Joshua's time, Josh. X. and in Samuels
time, 1 Samuel VII. Or frighting them with dreadful noises, as in Iehorams time,
2 King. VII. 6.

Rest forty years] from that eightieth year mentioned, Chapter III. 30. See the
Annotations on Chapter III. 11. and the Observations on the beginning of this Book.

Midian] See the Annotations on Hab.

Angel] Christ the Angel of the Covenant. ver. 14, 15, 16, 22, 23.

Thy might] Which I now give thee; with my promise to assist thee; as ver. 16.

My Present] Not Sacrifice, Abraham entertained the Angels, Genesis XVIII. and
Manoab, Judge. XIII. 15.

Fire] Here fire comes out of a rock: Exodus XVII. 7.

Of seven years old] The same age that the tyranny and oppression of the
Midianites had arrived to.

And build an Altar] Gideon had Gods warrant and command for all, ver. 24.

That he may die] Their idolatrous zeal.

Ierubbaal] Gideon so called by his father; not in way of reproach, but of
honor rather. In 2 Samuel XI. 21. he is called Ierubbosheth. And so Eshbaal, and
Meribbaal, the son, and grandchilde of Saul, 1 Chronicles. VIII. 33, 34. are
called Ishbosheth, and Mephibosheth, 2 Samuel II. 8. and IV. 4.

Iezreel] As here in Iezreel the Midianites pitched; Saul's time, 1 Samuel XXIX.
1, 11. And hence came the news of Saul's death, 2 Samuel IV. 4. who was slain in
Mount Gilboa on the North-side of Iezreel. This Iezreel was not that in the
Tribe of Judah, Josh. XV. 56. But in Manasseh; toward Issachar; about twelve
miles Northward from Samaria. Ahab from Carmel rode hither, and Elijah did run
before his Chariot, 1 King. XVIII. 45, 46. Here Ahab gets Naboths Vineyard, and
came from Samaria in the Tribe of Ephraim hither to take possession, 1 King.
XXI. 18. having his habitations and Palaces in both Cities. And besides Gods
judgment upon Ahab himself, ver. 19. both Ioram, and Iezebel, the son, and
wife of Ahab, were slain here by Iehu; and also all that belonged to Ahab in
Iezreel: And the heads of Ahabs seventy sons were brought from Samaria to
Iezreel, 2 King. IX. and X Chapters.

Messengers] The Tribes here named were the next to Gideon, Iabin.

Fleece of wooll] Herein is Gods great condescension to Gideon,

From Mount Gilead] Or toward Mount Gilead.

The people] The three hundred lappers,

Fled] The places named here were in that half Manasseh where the overthrow was
given. Abelmeholah was the habitation of the Prophet Elizaeus in after-ages, 1
King. XIX. 19.

Succoth] And so of Penuel, ver. 8. See Genesis XXXIII. 17. and XXXII. 30. They,
and Karker were in the tribe of Gad.

Ishmaelites] Midianites and Ishmaelites seem confounded together: Genesis
XXXVII. 25, 27, 28.

Golden ear-rings] The weight and multitude of them. Exodus XXXII. 2. and XXXV.
22.

Ephod] See the Observations on 1 Samuel Hos. III. 4.

Ophrah] In the East border of this Western half Manasseh, near Jordan.

Baalim] Baalim in the Plural number, Ashtaroth of the plural number, and
feminine gender, seems to be so to their She-goddesses, Judge. II. 13. and X.
6. And there are sundry specifications of Baal; As Berith, and Baal-Berith
here, and Chapter IX. 4, 46. the God of the Shechemites. Peor and Baal-Peor, the
idol-god of the Moabites and Midianites, Number. XXV. 3, 17, 18. Baal-Zebub,
called also Beelzebub, or Beelzebul, the god of Ekron, 2 King. I. 2. And from
Baal, were names imposed, both upon persons, and places: as we read of Ethbaal,
the King of Sidon, Iezebels father, 1 King. XVI. 31. of Esh-baal, 1 Chronicles.
VIII. 32. of Baal-hanan, Genesis XXXVI. 38. of Jerubbaal, Judge. VI. 32. of
Merib-baal, the other name of Mephibosheth, 1 Chronicles. VIII. 34. As also of
Baal-Zephon, Exodus XIV. 2. and Baal-Meon, Josh. XVII. 17. And from other
particular Idols, specially among the Babylonians, were like denominations
taken. Whether Bell be a contraction, or in a diverse dialect, the same with
Baal, is not so certain. God himself also was called Baal; But refused after
to be so styled, because the name had been so commonly given to Idols, Hos. II.
16. Of Bell, see the Annotations on Esaias XLVI. 1. Ashteroth or Ashtoreth or
Ashtaroth is more specificaly the goddess of the Sidonians, 1 King XI. 5, 33.
2 King. XXIII. 13. and of the Philistines, 1 Samuel XXXI. 10. Take also these
other names of Idol-gods in Scripture; Chemosh, of the Moabites, and Ammonites,
Judge. XI. 24. 1 King. XI. 5, 7, 33. 2 King. XXIII. 13.

Dagon, of the Philistines, Judge. XVI. 23. 1 Samuel V. 2, -- 7. 1 Chronicles. X. 10.

Moloch, or Molech, or Milchom, of the Ammonites 1 King. XI. 5, 7, 33. 2 King.
XXIII. 13.

Bell, and Nebo, and Belteshazzar, and Merodach, and Succoth-Benoth, of the
Babylonians, Esaias XLVI. 1. Dan. IV. 8. 2 King. XVII. 30. Ier. L. 2.

Nishrosh, of the Assyrians, and Sennacherib, 2 King. XIX. 37.

Rimmon of the Syrians, 2 King. V. 18.

2 King. XVII. 30, 31.
Nergal, of the men of Cuth. Ashimah, of the men of Hamath; Nibhaz and Tartak,
of the Avites; Adrammelech, and Anammelech, of Se phervaim;
Siccuth, Chiun, and Remphan; named, Amos V. 26. Acts VII. 43.

The seven Planets under several names, by several Nations.

And from the Egyptian Apis the Bull, and Mevis the Cow, the Jews took their
Idol of the golden Calf or Ox, Psalm. CVI. 20. And Ieroboam's Calves.



These Idols are called (...) quasi (...) not gods, 1 Cor. VIII. 4. Ier. 2. 11.
and V. 7. and Chapter XVI. 20. or nothing worth, Ier. XI. 13. Vanities; They are
called Shames, Abominations, 1 King. XI. 5. Dungie, or Dunghil-gods, Deuteronomy.
XXIX. 17. Devils, Deuteronomy. XXXII. 17. 2 Chronicles. XI. 15. 1 Cor. X. 20, 21. Apoc. IX.
20. Psalm. CVI. 37. 2 King. XX. 1.

Shechem] See the Observations on Josh.

Threescore and ten persons] So ver. 18, 24, 56. and Chapter VIII. 30. The whole
number designed to slaughter, though the youngest of them Iotham escaped; and
Abimelech himself was the murderer. And this is a thing usual in the Scripture.
As Genesis XLII. 13. Number. XIV. 32, 33. 1 Cor. XV. 5.

Gerizim] Near Shechem.

Millo] See the Observations on 1 Samuel V. 9.

Iair] Not that Iair, Number. XXXII. 41. Deuteronomy. III. 14. But of his posterity, and
name.

Thirty Cities] That former Jair in the days of Moses, Chron. II. 22. though
the sons of Machir, the son of Manasseh, and the father of Gilead, and
grandfather of this Iair, had among them sixty Cities, in the days of Moses,
Josh. XIII. 30, 31, 32. But here this Iair, the Judge, had thirty sons and
they had thirty Cities, seven more then the former Iair had, all which they
called by the same name of Havoth-Iair, as their progenitor had called his
twenty three.

Philistines] In this time of their oppressing Israel, Sampson lived, and was a
Judge, and began to deliver them, Chapter XIII. 5.

Ammon] This was the fifth oppression; And Iephthah was the Judge and deliverer.

And that year] The last of the eighteen of their oppressing the Israelites.

Eighteen years] Which years of oppression fell upon the two Tribes and a half
beyond Jordan in Iairs time.

Passed over Iordan] In this eighteenth year the Ammonites proceeded Jordan.
And then Iephthah does vanquish them; and begin his six years of judging
Israel. And all this stands well with the Chronology of the times, viz: of two
hundred ninty nine years in the Book of the Judges; and of the four hundred and
eighty mentioned, 1 King VI. 1.

The Sidonians] Diverse of these Deliverances are not expressed in the holy
History.

Grieved] Gods compassion to his people.

Mizpeh] There is mention of the Land of Mizpeh, Hermon, Josh. XI. 3. But most
commonly there were Citiet of that name; And those builded on hills or high
places, as the word signifies, fit to set wath-towers upon, as our Beacons. We
read of diverse such in Scripture. One Mizpeh in Moab, 1 Samuel XXII. 3. Another
in Mount Gilead, in Manasseh, beyond Jordan, not far from the Tribe of Gad,
Josh. XIII. 26. Here Laban overtook Jacob, Genesis XXXI. 49. And here the
Israelites encamped against the Midianites, in this text, Judge. X. 17. And
Iephthah their Judge and General had his house here, Judge. XI. 11, 29, 34.
Another Mizpeh was in Judah, Josh. XV. 38. Likely that rebuilt by Asa, 1 King.
XV. 22. 2 Chronicles. XVI. 6. But the most famous Mizpeh was that in Benjamin upon
the border of it, Josh. XVIII. 26. which was near the middle of the Land; and
not far from Shiloh, which stood East from it. This was a Place and City fit
for general meetings and Assemblies of the Land. Thither all Israel assembled
against the Benjamites, Judge. XX. 1, 3. and XXI. 1. There Samuel brought all
Israel to public Repentance, 1 Samuel VII. 5, 6. And thither likewise, as to
Bethel and Gilgal, he came in c^rcuit from year to year; to judge Israel, ver.
16. There Saul was found out, and made King, 1 Samuel X. 17, 21. And there
Gedaliah was Governor; so made by Nebuchanezzar; and there slain by Ishmael,
2 King. XXV.

Tob] Some thirty miles East from the waters of Merom.

My Land.] No. It was the Land of the Moabites; after of Sihon; and from him
conquered by the Israelites, by Gods command and donation, ver. 21, 22.

Three hundred years] And four of five over, which are omitted for the
roundnesse of the number. As Chapter XX. 46. 2 Samuel V. 5. See the Observations on
Ch XX. 46.

A Vow] Of Vows, Annotations on Jonah. I. 16.

And I will offer it] These words of Jephthah's Vow do fairly admit a
Disjunctive acceptance of the letter Vau to be interpreted and rendered Or,
and not and. As it is likewise used in Genesis XXVI. 11. Exodus I. 10, and XXI. 15,
17. Deuteronomy. XVII. 9, 12. and XIX. 17. Judge. XV. 18. 1 Samuel VI. 3. Jer. VI. 20.
and IX. 12. and XIII. 23. and XVI. 2, 7. and XXI. 9. and in very many other
places.

Bewail my Virginity] Much more her death,

And she knew no man] But lived a Virgin,

To lament] Or talk with her, ver. 34.

Smote Ephraim] In a Wood, Ephraim, from that slaughter of the Ephraimites.
Where afterward Absalom was slain, and his army, 2 Samuel XVII. 6. Ephraim
having in truth no Wood, or Land, or portion of inheritance on that side of
Jordan Eastward.

Because they said] The Ephraimites said; the Gileadites are fugitives,
mungrels, the refuse of both Tribes. Or, the Gileadites being got between the
Ephraimites and Manassites; said to the Ephraimites, ye are but the fugitives
of Ephraim.

Took the Passages] As the Ephraimites were to return back from Gilead,

Shibboleth] Which signifies the stream of a river,

Forty years] These forty years of Oppression by the Philistines fall in with
the times of Sampson and Eli,

Angel] The Angel of the Lord, Manoah, Elohim, God, ver. 22. And by his wife,
Jehovah, ver. 23. He whose Name is Wonderful, ver. 18, 19. Esaias IX. 6.

Nazarite] Of Nazarites, Observations on Number. VI. 2.

Begin] Sampson did but begin only. For the Philistines prevailed, and Lorded
it over Israel, all the days of Sampson, Chapter XIV. 4. of Eli, of Samuel partly,
1. Sam. VII. 8. 13* and of Saul; slain by them. This deliverance was not
perfected till David's days.

Drink no Wine] The mother is thus forbidden, ver. 14. Likely because the
infant was to receive hutriment and suck from her.

If the Lord] A good plea, and comfort,

Sampson] Sampson's Birth has relation to that, Chapter X. 7. where the
Philistines are mentioned before the Ammonites. And he began to deliver Israel
being young; and died about forty.

To move him] Inspire him with magnanimous,

Timnath] In the Tribe of Dan: Ekron of the Philistines* Here Sampson intended
to have his first wife. And Judah had his sheep-shearing, Genesis XXXVIII. 12.
This City was given to the Tribe of Judah, Josh. XV. 57. And after, out of
that Tribe to Dan, Josh. XIX. 43. But the Philistines most what possessed it.
And in the days of wicked Ahaz, we read that they took it from him, 2 Chronicles*
XXVIII. 18. Some make this in Dan, and that in Judah to be diverse Cities.

Sampson] Sampson by extraordinary motion of the Lord, the lawful Dispenser
with his own Law, seeks a marriage, though a Nazarite, with a Philistine: had
thirty of the Philistines brought as companions to be with him at the nuptial
feast, to honor him in show; but more in jealousy and fear of him, seeing and
noting some things extraordinary in his person. His wife weeping before him the
seven days while the Feast lasted, but more after the third day, and most upon
the seventh and last day, he expounds his Riddle to her; and she to the
companions. He performs what he had promised thereupon: And in anger; for
their fraud, and her treachery, he went away; leaving them; and her too behind
him.

Foxes] The Lan^ was full of them.

Hip] Sampson hip and thigh, Lehi, that is, the jaw bone* of an Ass, upon that
occasion he called the place jaw bone, or Lehi: And at his prayer, had a Well
of water, which he therefore calls Enhakkore, springing in that place of Lehi,
to revive his spiri, being near dead with thirst.

Rock Etam] We read of a City of that name* 1 Chronicles. IV. 32. Called also
Ethar. Josh* XIX. 7. in the Tribe of Simeon; as it joins to the Tribe of Dan
and Judah; in the North-East corner of Simeon; and not very far from Zorah in
the South-East corner of Dan, where Sampson was borne, ver. 2. not meaning that
Dan, or that so far distinct portion of Dan, that lay in the North-bounds of
the Land of Canaan.

Of Judah] Judah joining to Dan,

Twenty years] These twenty years, Eli his forty, 1 Samuel IV. 18.

Gaza] See the Annotations on Amos I.

Harlot] Sampsons sin; yet upon repentance pardoned; and he registered among
those Worthies, Heb. XI. 32.

Took the doores] His strength came up to a miracle.

Before Hebron] Not so far as Hebron. Of Hebron, see the Observations on Genesis
XXIII. 2.

Sorek] The river or torrent of this name divides Dan, Simeon.

Delilah] The chief Passages of this part of the History are these; That
Delilah had a very great sum paid in hand for betraying of Sampson, ver. 5,
18. whose strength yet lay not in his hair, in the having of it; or in the
growing of it again; the hair being but a ceremonial sign of it; But in Gods
presence with him: And so his weakness, not in the losing of his hair; which
here he lost unwittingly, and unwillingly; But in the Lords departing from him,
for his sins, ver. 20. The shaver might easily have cut his throat, being
asleep: But Gods Providence was in and over all. And blind Sampson coming at
last to see his sins, and repent; And being brought into the magnificent
house and Idol-temple, containing about three thousand persons spectators upon
the roof of it, verily a wondrous building is moved by an extraordinary
instinct of Gods Spirit, in his last act, not to murder himself, but to
undervalue his own life, so as he might therewithal, as a Judge, and public
person execute Gods mighty vengeance upon his own, and Gods peoples enemies and
oppressors, ver. 30. wherein many make him a Type of Christ's victorious
conquest over our spiritual enemies, at and by his death: Or at least do take
an occasion, to use an Allusion from the one to the other.

Dagon] Dagon] seems to have his name from Dag, Sam. V. 4. A sea-Idol,
worshipped by them of Gaza, and the Philistines that dwelt on the seacoast; as
the Heathens did their Neptune or Triton. And the Idolaters do here ascribe it
to this Idol their god, that he delivered Sampson into their hand; and
therefore offer a great sacrifice to him. In his most stately Temple they
fastened the head of King Saul, 1 Chronicles. X. 10. And at Ashdod, by Dagon in the
house of Dagon (for he had many Temples) they placed the Ark of God, 1 Samuel V.
2. Of this again you may see more in the Observations upon that text, 1 Samuel V.
2.

These five last Chapters of Judges contain Histories of things done, soon
after the death of Joshua, Judge. People mentioned, Chapter II. 11, 12 in the times,
if not before the times, of all the Judges, whose times and Histories are
recorded, Chapter III. and along to the XVII. Chapter, without any interruption.
And this appears by very many Passages in these five last Chapters.

Cursedst] So Prove. King. VIII. 31. Levit. V. 1. Number. V. 21. And so it is
expounded, 1 These. V. 27. And so put to our Savior, Matthew. XXVI. 63. And so
used, 1 Samuel XIV. 24. 2 Chronicles. XVIII. 15. Neh. XIII. 25.

The Lord] Micha's mother dedicated this silver to the Lord Jehovah; Chapter XVIII.
18. to worship Jehovah in and by them; and not any false god. For in this point
of the Object or Thing worshipped, the Idolatries of the Jews, and of the
Heathens most what differed. See Exodus XXXII. 4, 5. 2 Chronicles. XXXIII. 17. Hos.
II. 16. The other nine hundred Shekels, it is like, she bestowed on house,
vestments, and other necessaries for that Idolatrous service.

An house of gods] So great was the Idolatry of the Jews at this time. And
their zeal great in their Idolatry, Chapter XVIII. 24.

Ephod] This Ephod, mentioned again, Chapter XVIII. 14. As likewise that of
Gideon, Chapter VIII. 27. were not like those Linen Ephods, Exodus XXVIII. 40. 1 Samuel II. 18. and Chapter XXII. 18. But like Aarons rich and glorious Ephod, Exodus
XXVIII. 6, -- 34. See the Annotations on Hos. III. 4. and the Observations on 1 Samuel XXIII. 9.

Teraphim] Or Theraphim, a word of the plural number; and still so used in
Scripture; signifies Images, or Idols; Hos. III. 4. 1 Samuel XV. 23. But of what
kind or fashion, it is uncertain; some conceive them to be made like men;
because Michal put one of them in David's bed, thereby to deceive her father
Saul's messengers, 1 Samuel XIX. 13. Some take them to be houshold-gods; and as
such in Labans house and family, Genesis XXXI. 19, 34. Some to be such as they
used to consult with as Oracles; as in the case of the Danites here, and Chapter
XVIII. 14, 17, 18, 20. and of Nebuchadnezzar, Ezekiel. XXI. 21. and in Zecharies
time, Zech. X. 2. Answers likely being given by the subtilty of the Devil, or
forgery of their Priests. And to workers with familiar spirits, and Wizards,
They are joined in Josiah's Reformation, 2 King. XXIII. 24. See the Annotations
on Hos. III. 4.

Consecrated] And ver. 12. The gross abuse of Consecration. As in Jeroboams
time, 1 King. XIII. 33.

No King] King here is taken, Saul's reign.

A Levite] A Levite borne or* Bethlehem. Judah, or sojourning there as a
stranger.

Where I may find a place] The necessitous state of the Levites, ver. 10, 11.

Danites sought] Their inheritance by lot is set down, Josh. XIX. 40. But they
got it not all; through their own sin and default, Judge. I. 34. And their
tribe being numerous, they sought out larger bounds, and more commodious
habitations, Josh. XIX. 47. And this, though mentioned in that text of Ishua,
yet fell out after his death, and the death of those Elders that outlived him;
likely soon after, but surely before the days of Sampson.

Mount Ephraim] See the Observations on Josh. 2. XXIV. 1.

Ask counsel] These Danites, ver. 14, 17.

Laish] Laish very far off from the body of the Tribe of Dan; Simeon, and
Judah, in the South-parts of the Land of Canaan, and this under Mount Libanon,
by Asher, and Naphtali, in the North-bounds. This City first burnt, and after
rebuilt by these Danites, they then called Dan; which is taken as the
North-bound of the Land of Canaan, as Chapter XX. 1. 1 Samuel III. 20. 2 Samuel III.
10. and elsewhere. And here Jeroboam did set up one of his golden Calves, 1
King. XII. 29.

Jonathan] A Levite the great grandchilde of Moses, Bethlehem-Judah; and so, as
of the family of Judah, Chapter XVII. 7. And though a Levite, yet taken and used as
a Priest; and consecrated thereunto by Micah an Ephraimitie, ver. 1, 12. Who
likewise had consecrated one of his own sons to become his Priest, ver. 5. And
this Jonathan forced to seek and shift for his maintenance and livelihood; and
to accept of one so poor and base, ver. 10. All this bespeaks the sad and
lamentable condition and coufusion of those times wherein they lived.

Captivity of the Land] This Idolatry of the Danites, in this City Dan,
continued until the day of the Captivity of the Land; that is, as it is
explained, ver. 31. all the time that the house of God was in Shiloh, till the
Philistines took the Arc, 1 Samuel IV. Psalm LXXVIII. 60, 61. which was at the
death of Eli.

A Concubine] Or a wife a Concubine. Viro-conjux, an half-wife, or secondarie
wife. We read in Scripture of Concubines, and Wives, variously: Of many wives
to one man, in the Old Testament. And this, not only in profane and evil
men, as in Lamech, Genesis IV. and Esau, and other; but also in good and godly
men, as in Jacob, David, and others. And among these many wives, we sometimes
find a kind of distinction of them into two sorts; One sort, the First, and
principal, and absolutely lawful wife, and Mistress; The other sort, but in a
secondary and inferior degree. And such as had no Dowries; nor solemn Rites
of reception; nor Rule in the family; nor their children had any Inheritance,
but Gifts and Portions, For that of Jacobs sons by Bilhah, and Zilpah, was a
case extraordinary. And thus we find with Abraham, Sarah of the first sort;
and Hagar, and Keturah of the second: with Jacob, Rachel, and Leah, of the
first; Bilhah, and Zilpah of the second. And those of the second sort, are
sometimes called wives, and sometimes Concubines; as we see in Keturah, Genesis
XXV. 1, 6. 1 Chronicles. I. 32. And in Bilhah, Genesis XXX. 4. and XXXV. 22. and Chapter
XXXVII. 2. And David's ten Concubines, 2 Samuel XV. 16. and Chapter XVI. 22. and Chapter
XX. 3. are called his wives, 2 Samuel XII. 11. And thus Concubines are of two
sorts, some are wives, or half-wives; others plain Whores and Harlots. But
this Concubine of the Levite was his wife, and he her Lord, as appears, ver. 3,
4, 5, 7, 9, 26, 27. and Chapter XX. 4.

Gibeah] Distinct from Gibeah in the tribe of Judah, Josh. XV. 57. And from
Gibeon in the Tribe of Benjamin, Josh. XVIII. 25. This was either that which
afterward was called Gibeah of Saul in the Tribe of Benjamin, 1 Samuel XI. 4. or
else very near it, in the same Tribe, and not far from Jerusalem, and Ramah,
ver. 13, 14, 16.

House of the Lord] In Shilo. Chapter XX. 18. This was near Mount Ephraim; where he
sojourned. And thither the whole Camp came, Chapter XXI. 12.

Know him] So Genesis

My brethren] Men in nature,

Behold my daughter] Sinful this; Romans III. 8.

Not hearken] Yet did in the next words. ver. 2. was plagued by lust.

Divided her] An act barbarous in it self and inhumane: Belial to deserved
punishment; that such pests might not be suffered to live, and poi^on the air
with their breath, and so pollute the Land, and go unpunished. The unbowelling,
and enbalming of dead bodies, and anatomizing of them by Physicians and
Surgeons, to good uses, is a case different in diverse points,

Mizpeh] See the Observations on Chapter

Footmen] Footmen four hundred thousand. Solomon's time, 1 King. IV. 26. and IX.
19. and Chapter X. 26. 2 Chronicles. I. 14. and Chapter VIII. 9. and Chapter IX. 25. where the
four thousand stalls of horses for his Chariots, 2 Chronicles. IX. 25. agree well
with the forty thousand in 1 King. IV. 26. counting ten single stalls or
divisions in every stable: yet we find no express mention of the use of any
horsemen in any battle afterward. And to this the command and care for the
houghing of the enemi es horses* and the burning of their Char^o^s, may have
relation, Josh, XI. 6, 9. 2 Samuel VIII. 4. 1 Chronicles. XVIII. 4. yet we read of
many horses and Chariots in war; with the Canaan^tes, Josh. XI. 4. Judge. IV.
3* 13. And many among the Israelites; Esaias II. 7. Trust in them is forbidden,
D^u^. XVII. 16, 17. Psalm. XX. 7. and XXXIII. 16, 17. Prove. XXI. 31.

Asked Counsel] The eleven Tribes presume here more upon their own strength*
second overthrow, they seek God in a right manner; they more seriously mourn,
and Fast, and repent of their sins; Offering Burnt-offerings for the expiation
of them; and Peace offerings, to make their peace with God, and testify their
Faith in him: And gaining a Promise of success, yet they carefully use the
means, and stratagems, which formerly they slighted, and presumptuously
neglected. And by this stratagem they seem to divide their army into three
parts; some to lie in wait; some to fight, and seemingly flee: And the body of
their Army, as a strong reserve to fall on and gain the victory, upon an
appointed sign, when the Benjamites were brought to an amazed stand, and come
within the reach of it.

Phineas] Phineas here living, Sampson was borne; which shows this History
preceded Sampson a long time. As the like might have been observed, to a like
end, of many other Passages in these five last Chapters, as has been formerly
said.

All which fell] The odd hundred men mentioned, ver. 35 are here omitted;
David's reign, 2 Samuel V. 5. and Chapter II. 11. And of the time of Solomon's
building the Temple, 1 King. VI. 1, 38. And the like is in Jephthahs account of
the 300. years, Judge. XI. 26. And likely here in the number of the remain of
the Benjamites that were slain after the three battles.

Turned again] This done in heat of war, Jehoshaphat's time, comparing the
number of Benjamin with Judah, 2 Chronicles. XVII. 14, -- 18.

Had sworne] This Oath, ver. 18. was made in rashness, and rage, out of a
blind zeal, and superstitious ignorance; And by Gods Law might and ought to
have been broken; And was unlawful to be kept; and much less to have fraud,
and violent rape, without consent, either of parties, or parents, used, for the
keeping of it. Which yet they did, thinking to silence thereby the cry of a
superstitious conscience in themselves; and to provide also for the like in
those parents of the 200 Virgins, ver. 22.

Women] The women, and children,

Ruth.
THE Book and History of Ruth falls in with the time of Deborah, or Gideou; as
may be gatherd by comparing Matthew. 1. 5. with the end of this History: and what
formerly has been said upon Rahabs marriage. And the History serves mainly to
continue and declare the Genealogy of our Savior Jesus Christ, Chap. IV. 18,
-- 22.

Famine] In the time of the Oppression of Jabin,

Ephrathites] Chapter IV. 11. Bethlehem was called Ephrath, Genesis XXXV. 19. Micah V.
2. Matthew. II. 6.

Of Bethlehem Judah] To distinguish it from Bethlehem in the Tribe of Zebulun,
Josh. XIX. 15. And these persons from those of the Tribe of Ephraim, who were
likewise called Ephrathites, 1 King. XI 26.

Ruth] The subject matter; not the Author of this Book.

Mothers house] I am but your Mother-in-Law.

More sons in my womb] See Deuteronomy. XXV.

And unto her gods] Orpha's idolatrous inclination.

Return thou] As, Josh. XXIV. 19.

Testified against me] As a witness of his just displeasure,

Barley-harvest] Part of our March and April, Lev. XXIII. 10,

Let me gleane] Her modesty; notwithstanding the Law, Lev. XIX. 9, 10. and
XXIII. 22.

An 20. Ephah] See the Observations on Exodus XVI. 36.

One of our next kinsmen] Who has right to redeem, Levit. XXV. 25, 26. Deuteronomy.
XXV. 5, 6, 7. Mar. XII. 19.

Uncover his feet] Naomi well knew the piety and chastity of Boaz, Ruth; and
confidently trusted therein.

Spread therefore thy skirt] Receive me into thy protection, by taking me to be
thy wife,

Lie down until the morning] Boaz not offended with this manner of her
approach,

Not be known] Boaz then did lie alone, in a room by himself; and is careful
to avoid scandal.

Six] See the Observations on Genesis XVIII. 6.

Gate] Gates of Cities were the ordinary places of audience, Deuteronomy. XVII. 2, 8.
2 Samuel XIX. 8. Prove. XXXI. 23. Jer. XXXVIII. 7. Lam. V. 13. And the usual manner
of Prophets was to publish their Prophecies in the Gates, either of the Temple,
or of the City of Jerusalem, Jer. VII. 2. and XIX. 2. and XXVI. 10. and
sometimes of the Kings house; as places of greatest concourse of people, Jer.
XVII. 19. and XXII. 1, 2.

Lest I mar mine own inheritance] Want an heir,

A man plucked off his shoe] These Ceremonies then used in buying, Deuteronomy. XXV.
8, 9. But with diverse differences. See, Psalm. LX. 8. The Ceremonies that
respected the person of Ruth, are here not mentioned, but may seem either
omitted, or else transacted with much alteration from the first institution* as
those times now were.

THe two Books of Samuel are thought to be written by Samuel, Nathan and Gad,
one after another, 1 Chronicles. XXIX. 29. Yet some passages in them may seem to
intimate the writing of them to have been of a later time. As, 1 Samuel V. 5. and
XXVII. 6. and XXX. 25. 2. Sam. VI. 8, and XVIII. 8.

They may better be called, The I. and II. Book of Kings: The I. containing all
the History of King Saul; Samuel dying, 1 Samuel XXV. And the II. the History of
King Ishbosheth shortly; and of King David at large. And so do the LXX. and
many other style them.

I. Samuel.
THis first Book contains an History of eighty years: viz: forty in the time
of Heli, Chapter IV, 18. in the four first Chapters. And forty in the times of
Samuel, and King Saul, in the rest. If Samuels time be reckoned in with that of
Saul. Or rather thus; forty to Eli, whereof the former half runs up in the
times of the Judges, in the twenty years of Sampson: And the later half, or
twenty begins with this Book; after the death of Sampson, and the end of the
Book of the Judges. And then follow twenty years of Samuels Government alone.
And after that, forty years of King Saul, Acts XIII. 21. In the former part
whereof Samuel also lived, and partly judged with him, as appears in the XIII.
XV. and XVI. and XIX. Chaters of this Book: though he withdrew from Saul in his
last days, 1 Samuel XV. 35. And died, chapter XXV. And in regard whereof they are
named as joint partners in the administration of the Government. 1 Samuel XI. 7.
Still in the whole eighty years.

An Ephrathite] As the Jews are called Cretes, Acts II. 9, 10, 11. For though
borne, or at least dwelling in Mount Ephraim in Ramah; yet was Elkanah, and so
Samuel his son, of the posterity of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi,
1 Chronicles. VI. 33, -- 38.

Eli] Eli or Heli, Eleazer, the elder; but of Ithamar, the younger son of
Aaron, the son of Amram, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi. Eli was
extraordinarily both High Priest; and Judge; And a good and famous man; though
faulty, and infamous in his children. And therefore more grievously punished for
their flagitious wickedness, then Samuel for his sons lesser faults. See the
sins of the sons of the High Priest Joshua, Ezra X. 18. From Eli descended
Phinehas, his son; Ahitub, his son, 1 Samuel IV. 19, 21. compared with chap. XIV.
3. Ahimelech, his son, slain by Saul, [his brother was Ahijah] 1 Samuel XIV. 3.
and XXII. 9, 11. Abiathar, his son, in David's time, 1 Samuel XXII. 20. 1 King. I.
7. This Abiathar is named High Priest by our Savior, Mark II. 26. when David
did eat the Shewbread; because Abiathar then was with his Father Ahimelech
joined in that action of giving the bread to David instantly succeeded in his
Fathers room and Priesthood; was therein more eminent then his Father; and
continued therein, with David in his persecution by Saul, and in all the time
of his reign afterward. And thus have we no need in that whole History of
Ahimelech and Abiathar, Father, and son, to make them Binomii, to be both known
by both those names, and both indifferently called by either; yet see the great
Annotations on 1 Chronicles. XVIII. 16. This Abiather was thrust out of the High
Priesthood by Solomon, 1 King. II. 26, 27. And the sons of Abiathar were
Ahimelech, and Jonathan, 2 Samuel VIII. 17. and XV. 27. This Ahimelech, and not
his Grandfather, of the same name, is he that is usualy joined with Zadok in
David's reign. And both then are named Priests, 2 Samuel VIII. 17. 1. Chron.
XXIV. 31. i. e. Priests of the second rank, or next the High Priest, who then
was Abiathar. Such a second Priest we read of, 2 King. XXV. 18. Jer. LII. 24.
who upon any extraordinary occurrent, restraining or disabling the High Priest;
was to supply his place. This Jonathan the son of Abiathar was employed with
Ahimaaz the son of Zadok, as newes-bearer to David in his flight from Absalom,
2 Samuel XV. 27, 28. and XVII. 17.

Of Zadok, See 2 Samuel VIII. 17.

Temple] So is the Tabernacle here called. chap. III. 3. 2 Samuel XXII. 7. Psalm.
XXVII. 6. And so again, The Temple is called a Tabernacle, Lam. II. 6.

Samuel] We read not that he was High Priest, ver. 11. a Sacrificer; though a
Levite only, and most likely of the posterity of that Korah, Number. XVI. 32. and
of the race of Izhar the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, as was formerly said,
1 Chronicles. VI. A rare and worthy person.

The doors of the house of the Lord] The Hangings of the Gate of the Court,
Exodus XXVII. 16.

Ark] The Ark so precious in the eyes of God, Psalm LXXVIII. 61. and CXXXII. 8.
1. Sam. IV. 20. Was carried about the walls of Jericho, and then returned into
the Tabernacle, Being in the Tabernacle in Shiloh, it was taken thence (and
never came into the Tabernacle again), and was carried to Eben-Ezer (a place
ominous then, but a monument of Gods help soon after) into the Camp, 1 Samuel
IV. 1, 3, 4, 5. and V. 1. that it might save them out of the hand of their
enemies, the Philistines. (As we read, the Philistines themselves, in the days
of David, brought their Images into their Camp, 2 Samuel V. 21. 1 Chronicles. XIV. 12.)
The Ark being taken there by the Philistines, they carried it about to Ashdod,
into the house of Dagon: Thence to Gath: Thence to Ekron. And after they had
kept it seven months, they carried it to Beth-Shemesh, a City in the Tribe of
Judah, given to the Priests, 1 Chronicles. VI. 57, 59. Josh. XXI. 16. And it was
fetched thence to Kiriath-jearim, a City of Judah, likewise, 1 Chronicles. XIII. 6.
and Judge. XVIII. 12. So called, it may be, from Kiriath-jearim, the son of
Shebal, grandchilde of Caleb, the son of Hur, 1 Chronicles. II. 50, 52, 53. If
Kiriath-jearim be there to be understood of the name of a man, and not of the
City. Or thus called from its seat in a Wood, or woody Country, as the name
signifies; See ou Psalm. CXXXII. 6. It was called also Kiriath-Baal, Josh.
XVIII. 14, 15. And Baalah, Josh. XV. 9, 10. 1 Chronicles. XIII. 6. And Baale of
Judah, 2 Samuel VI. 2. It was brought thither into the house of Abinadab, a
Levite; builded in the hill, or Gibeah there, 1 Samuel VII. 1. 2 Samuel VI. 3, 4.
It abode there twenty years, till the time of the Repentance and Reformation
wrought by Samuel, 1 Samuel VII. 2, -- 6. And after in the times of Saul, it
seems to be fetched thence to Giglal, 1 Samuel X. 8. and Chapter XI. 15. and chapter XII.
3. and chap. XIII. 8, 9. And after to Gibeah of Benjamin; compare together 1 Samuel XIII. 6. and chap. XIV. 2, 18. It may seem to be thus fetched into
extraordinary Assemblies, upon extraordinary occasions both in War, and
Peace. But being returned to Kiriath-jearim, and the honse of Abinadab, it was
fetched thence by David, 1 Chronicles. XIII. 5. sixty seven years after it was first
brought thither; And was brought by him to the house of Obed-Edom, 2 Samuel VI.
10. a Levite, and Porter on the South Side of the Temple, 1 Chronicles. XV. 18, 24.
and chap. XVI. 38. and chap. XXVI. 4, -- 8, 15. if not a Singer also, 1 Chronicles.
XV. 21. and chap XVI. 5. And one of his race and name was treasurer in the
Temple, in the days of King Amatziah, 2 Chronicles. XXV. 24. He is called a
Gittite, likely because borne at Gath-Rimmon, a City of the Kohathites
Levites, Josh. XXI. 24, 25. situated near Gath of the Philistines. The Arc was
there three months, 2 Samuel VI. 11. 1 Chronicles. XIII. 13, 14. And then, and
thence, fetched by David, with great solemnity, into the Tent which he prepared
for it, in the City of David, in Jerusalem, 1 Chronicles. XV. 1, -- 29. and XVI. 1.
2 Chronicles. I. 4. And thence seems to be carried into Joabs Camp before Rabbah, 2 Samuel XI. 11. And begun to be carried with David in his flight from Absalom, 2 Samuel XV. 24, 25. And being returned to David's Tent for it in Jerusalem,
Solomon, as soon as he had builded the Temple, brings it thence with great
solemnity, and places it in the Holy Oracle, 2 Chronicles. V. 2, -- 14. and chap.
XXXV. 3. about one hundred and twelve years after it first left Shiloh. And
last of all was burned with the Temple by Nebuchadnezzar. And no more to be
minded, or remembered in the days of the Messiah, Jer. III. 16.

The hand of God] The hand of God in Punishments upon the Philistines, chap.
VI. 5. And in their bodies Emerods; and some other disease or plague, whereof
most died, chap. V. 12.

The house of Dagon] This Dagon was the Idol or God of the Philistines, Judge.
XVI. 22. They lived on the coast of the midland-Sea, on the East End of it from
us. This Dagon seems to be a kind of Sea-god, having his name from Dag, which
signifies a Fish; and is thought to be portraied like a Fish from the middle
downward; and his upper part like a man, if not a maid, 1 Samuel V. 4. Such Idols
other Heathens worshipped, as the gods of the Sea; as Neptune, Triton. This
House or Temple of Dagon was a mavelous House, Judge. XVI. 27. Hither the
Philistines brought Sampson to make them sport; and he brought down the House
upon them, Judge. XVI. 30. Hither they brought the Ark of God, as a captive in
triumph, to the honor of their Idol; And Dagon fell down before the Ark,
broken in pieces, 1 Samuel V. 3, 4. And here they fastened the head of Saul, whom
they slew in Gilboa, 1 Chronicles. X. 10.

Bethshemesh] Bethshemesh a City of the Priests, Judah, on the North-border of
it, Josh. II. 16. and XV. 10. 1. Chron. VI. 59. Here Amaziah of Judah fighting
against Iehoash of Israel was vanquished and taken, 2 King. XIV. 2 Chronicles. XXV.
There was another Bethshemesh a fenced City of Naphtali, Josh XIX. 38. Judge.
I. 33. Another Bethshemesh, a prime City in Egypt, Ier. XLIII. 13. called
anciently On, in later times Damieta. Bethshemesh signifies the house of the
Sun; and the Cities so called, from the Temples of the Sun built therein, and
the idol-worship of the Sun by the ancient inhabitants practiced there.

Fifty thousand and seventy men] These were not all of the City Bethshemesh,
Number. IV. 5, 20. If not prying presumptuously into it, out of an impious
curiosity, or a pretense to see whether the Philistines had taken ought out of
it, or put any thing into it.

Kiriath-jearim] A City, Judah, Josh. XV. 9, formerly called Kiriath-Baal,
ver. 60. and XVIII. 14. Of this City see more in the Observations on Chapter IV.
3. and on Psalm. CXXXII. 6. These Citizens fetched the Arc, but borne and
carried by the Priests of Bethshemesh.

Twenty yeeres] Till this time of lamentation and repentance, Observations on
Josh. VI. 6.

Thundered] By thunder here: by hailstones, Josh. X. 10, 11.

Now make us a King] The danger by Nahash, Samuels sons, made the Israelites
ask a King, 1 Samuel XII. 12. which they might have done warrantably, if they had
waited patiently and faithfully, as well for the time when, as the person whom
God should choose: But not tumultuously, and distrustfully, as they did now, 1 Samuel VIII. 5, etc. and Chapter XII. 19. Hos. VIII. 4.

This will be the maner] This manner of a King speaks in many things more then
what is the lawful power,

The fourth part of a Shekel] Samuel, Readiness Asses: As Ahijah did touching the
sickness of Jeroboams child, 1 King. XIV. And Elias did also, of Ahaziah, 2.
King. 1. And Samuel, in humility, seems to accept of a trifle, they having then
no better; not for a reward of Divining; but as a free testimony of their due
respect and thankfulness: As Ahijah did the like from Jeroboams wife, 1 King.
XIV. 3. And Elizeus also the like, 2 King. IV. 42. And as God accepts from the
poor widow two mites.

a Seer] And so ver. Sam. XXIV. 11. and Esaias XXX. 10. Prophets called Seers by
reason of the Visions and Prophecies which they saw from God; He, and they,
being seen of them in Visions and Dreams, Number. XII. 6. And that as clearly, and
as certainly as if they had seen them with their eyes, 1 Pet. I. 12. 1 Cor.
II. 10. 2. Cor. IV. 18. and V. 1. Heb. XI. 27.

to Gilgal] Not as soon as he parted from Samuel: Gilgal after his vanquishing
of the Ammonites before Jabesh Gilead, Chapter XI. 4, 5, 11, 14, 15. when, and
where, they made, or confirmed him King; though chosen before by Lot at Mizpeh,
Chapter X. 17, 24. But this seems to relate to a second time of being at Gilgal,
after that former, and above a year after this parting from Samuel, Chapter XIII.
1. when he was to be there upon that weighty preparation of the war against
the Philistines, Chapter XIII. 7, 8.

one year and he reigned tmo years] i. e. one year from his Election at Mizpah,
to his Coronation at Gilgal. And another year after that, which make two years,
Then he began to take upon him the Royal state of a King, and chose his Guard
and Army. Or thus, He reigned two years lawfully before he was rejected by God,
upon his sparing of Agag, King of the Amalakites, Chapter XV. Or rather, two years
quietly, before he was oppressed, and in a manner outed from his Kingdom by the
Philistines, 1 Samuel XIII. 6, 19, 22. Upon whose overthrow Saul is said to take
the Kingdom again, 1 Samuel XIV. 47.

If they say to us] The like is, Genesis XXIV. 14. and Judge. VI. 36, -- 40. These
done by some special divine instinct; and so not Patterns for our imitation
without like warrant.

a very great trembling] The Hebrew phrase is, God. And so, asleep of God, 1 Samuel XXVI. 12. Mountains of God, Psalm. XXXVI. 6. Cedars of God, Psalm. LXXX. 10.
and CIV. 16. an Host of God, 1 Chronicles. XII. 22. Garden of God, Ezekiel. XXVIII.
13. The wrastlings of God, Genesis XXX. 8. A City of God, Jon. III. 3. Visions of
God, Ezekiel. XL. 2. And so may we understand, Sinners of God, or unto God, Genesis
XIII. 13. that is, exceeding sinners against God, Jer. L. 29. And so fair to
God, Acts VII. 20. that is, exceeding fair. And so the flame of God, Cant.
VIII. 6. A most vehement flame. A Seed of God, Mal. II. 15. A most holy seed.
See my Observations on Jonah III. 3.

Utterly destroyed all the people] Not all the Amalekites slain
notwithstanding this, ver. 3. and Exodus XVII. 14, 16. For David fights them, 1 Samuel XXVII. 8. and they spoil Ziglag, 1 Samuel XXX.

The youngest] David young, Samuel, likely about two and twenty years old,
young when he killed the Lion and the Bear; when he slew Goliath; when, after
these, he slew his ten thousands (in Saul's sundry services); when afterward he
endured so long persecution by Sa^l; was with the King of Moab; and twice with
Achish King of Gath, abiding at one time an year there, and four months: And
yet was but thirty years old, when, after Saul's death, he was made King at
Hebron, 2 Samuel V. 4. neither seems he to have any child, till he was a King;
And then had six in Hebron of fix wives; four in Jerusalem of Bathshua or
Bathshebah, the daughter of Ammiel, or Eliam; and nine more; in all nineteen,
besides the sons of his Concubines 1 Chronicles. III. 1, -- 9.

Anointed] David thrice anointed.

Doubtful whether David slew Goliath before his first coming to Saul, Chapter XVI.
18, -- 23. Or after, that time: There are fair probabilities on either side; no
undoubted certainty.

And he prophesied] Besides the signification of the word for foretelling
things to come, Cor. XIV. 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 22, 24, 29, 31, 32. And for singing
and praising God, 1 Samuel X. 5. 1. Chron. XXV. 1. 1 Cor. XI. 5. And more generaly
for declaring the will of God to any by Revelation, or Mission from him. And so
Christ is the great Prophet, Luke XXIV. 19. And so Enoch, Ahraham, Moses, are
called Prophets: and after Moses in this rank none was greater then he, Deuteronomy.
XXXIV. 10. And after his time Samuel, David, Gad, Nathan, Elias, Elizeus, the
four great Prophets, the twelve small Prophets inspired Penmen of Holy
Scripture, and others many, were such, and so called. And as these
Extraordinary Prophets; so there were multitudes of Ordinary Prophets among the
people: And Colleges of Prophets, and the sons of Prophets at Bethel, Jericho,
Gilgal, Ramah, Naioth, in the times of the Old Testament. And in the New
Testament, Zacharias the father, and John Baptist the son, Barnabas and Paul,
Judas and Silas, Agabus, and many others, are called Prophets; some
Extraordinary, others Ordinary Prophets, Matthew. XXIII. 34. Acts XI. 27. and
XIII. 1. and XV. 32. Romans XII. 6. 1. Cor. XII. 10. and chap. XIV. 6, 9, 22, 24,
29, 31. Ephesians. IV. 11. Apoc. XI. 10. And in both Testaments there were as
men-Prophets; so women-Prophetesses: And in both Sexes, both True ones, and
False. In the female sex we read of good and True, Miriam, Deborah, Huldah,
Anna, Philips four daughters virgins: of bad and False, Noadiah, Jezebel, and
others, Ezekiel. XIII. 17, -- 23. Yea, among the Heathen some Poets pretending to,
or reputed to be Declarers of Gods will, or Divine truths, are in a like sense
termed Prophets, Tit. I. 12. Prophets in their esteem. And the mode and manner
of the expressions of their minds, Oracles, and Prophecies among these Heathen
Enthusiasticks was most-what in a wild, raving and raging sort, with strange
motions and agitations of the body, thereby the more to pretend their divine
raptures; as in the Sybils, and others. And not unlike thereunto is this of
Saul's prophesying here; In this his rage he casting a jaylin at Davi^, ver. 11.
yet in what sense properly he is said here to Prophecy, is well guessed in the
great Annotations upon this text, though it be not altogether sure and
certain. As neither that of Eldad and Medad, and the rest of the LXX. Number.
XIII. 26, 27. Only this is unquestioned in the LXX. That it was some
extraordinary Act and Testimony, That the Spirit of God rested upon them in
some extraordinary manner, and as such was discernible to all, and so fit to
authorize them in the eyes of others, as by a miracle, and to declare to all
That they were gifted and assumed to that their present Office and employment.

Naked] i. e. Stripped of his upper garment or military habit. So Peter, John
XXI. 7. and Micah, chap. I. 8. Esaias, chap. XX. 2, 4. And those Acts XIX. 16.

Slew] Saul's most horrid and bloody Act.

Ephod] The Ephod here is that of the High Priests; Urim and Thummim, Exodus
XXVIII. 30. which Urim and Thummim were not the twelve precious stones of the
Breast Plate; mentioned, v. 17-21. Or the words of Vrim and Thummim, engraven
in the midst of those twelve precious stones on the Breast Plate; Or things
committed into the hands of the workmen to make them: But rather given by God
to Moses, to put them not on, but into the Breast Plate; which happily to this
end and purpose was doubled, ver. 16. so to have them hid there. And
accordingly, Levit. VIII. 8. Moses is said to put in the Breast Plate the Urim
and the Thummim. Yet what things, or what kind of things they were, appears
not. Only we know the names signify Lights, and Perfections; happily intimating
Knowledge of Doctrine, and Integrity of Life and Conversation: And that by
these the High Priests extraordinarily did ask Counsels of the Lord, and did
receive Answers, as Oracles from him. So we see the Precept for it, Number. XXVII.
21. Joshuah shall stand before Eleazar the Priest, who shall ask Counsel for
him, after the judgment of Urim before the Lord: at his word shall they go
out, and at his word they shall come in, both he ( i. e. Joshuah) and all the
children of Israel with him. And the Practice of it we find, expected
earnestly by Saul, 1 Samuel XXVIII. 6. though the same, it may seem, lighty
slighted by him, 1 Samuel XIV. 18, 19. And here acted by Abiathar the High
Priest, for David; David hereunto adjoining his Request unto the Lord, for the
Answer, ver. 10, 11, 12. And again, 1 Samuel XXX. 7. And not unlike but David's
enquiring of the Lord, 2 Samuel II. 1. and chap. V. 19, 23. and XXI. 1. And
possibly that, Judge. XX. 18, 23, 27, 28. was by the same means, upon the same
ground. And if it were burnt, or lost at the ruin of the Temple, and all, by
Nebuchadnezzar, yet the Tirshatha entertains an expectation of the restoring of
it, Ezra II. 63. Neh. VII. 65.

a Messinger] Gods providence for the preservation of his.

unto Achish] This second time,

in Shunem] In Shunem and Aphek, 1 Samuel XXIX. 1. the Philistines pitched: And
the Israelites in Gilboa, by a Fountain which is in Jezreel. All in the Tribe
of Issachar, Josh XIX. 18.

This is David's Spoile] i. e. all that the Amalakites had taken from others,
save from them of Ziglag. This, by his right, and free consent and gift of his
soldiers, he made use of to gratify his friends, and engage them to him, ver.
26, -- 31.

they shall part alike] They both alike shall have their shares, Number. XXXI. 27,
-- 30. Josh. XXII. 8. Though not both equal shares.

fell upon it] Saul his own bloody butcher and self-murderer. David, 2 Samuel I.
5, -- 10. in hope of grace and reward from David; but in issue, to the losing
of his life. God in his secret justice justly takes it upon himself, that he
slew him, 1 Chronicles. X. 14.

his head] This they fastened in the Temple of Dagon, Chron. X. 10. His body to
the wall of Bethshan, or Bethshean. And his Armor in the house of Ashteroth, a
name of their female goddesses.

II. Samuel.
THis Book contains an History of forty years; from the death of King Saul, to
the death of King David, or the time immediately preceding it, 2 Samuel V. 4, 5.
The time, and story of David's reign.

Crown that was upon his head] Likely not so worn by him in the day of battle,
King. XXII. 30. But carried with him, or before him, by his armor-bearer,

bowe] That they might be skilful in the right use of their arms and weapons
against their enemies in this time of need. Of the Bow in war, see ver. 22.
And the Annotations on Hos. I. 5. and on Zech. X. 4.

How are the mighty fallen?] Repeated, ver. 25. and 27. as the foot of this sad
