In these Citations and Allegations, and Allusions, The Penmen of Scripture
regard more oftentimes the sense and intent of the Text cited, then the precise
terms, where the one swerves not much from the other, and what is in the words
so read or employed, is of undoubted truth. And sometimes they cite not the
entire Text, nor tie themselves to the precise words of the place, nor observe
strictly the Order of them, as they lie in the Text; but pick only out of them
so much as may serve for their present purpose; which in quotation of places is
sufficient. So John XII. 40. Matthew. IV. 15, 16. Ezekiel. XX. 7. And in Citations
in the New Testament, the holy Penmen in some places follow the LXX. as then
most in use in Synagogues, and Schools, publicly, and privately, though
therein departing from the Hebrew, but yet only in matters of no concernment as
to the present Allegation. Some are Accommodations only; when Prophesies
besides their Litteral sense; have sometimes another in this sort affixed to
them, To which when they are accommodated, they are said to be fulfilled, i. e.
to have a more eminent accomplishment in a higher sense; As Esaias IX. 1, 2. the
great Light and comfort and deliverance from Sennaoherib, and out of Babylon,
is accommodated, Matthew. IV. 13, -- 16. to Christ's preaching the Light and
comfort of the Gospel, and his deliverance of them from the bondage of Sin and
Satan.

Blessed] This is the maine end man aims at.

Walks not] Some here observe a Climax, or treble Climax, gradation, or
ascension, from the less and lower, to the greater and higher: And so there is
indeed in the sins here mentioned: But not in the shunning and avoiding of
sin, as some conceive. For so the first degree here mentioned seems to them
to be the highest of the three, in that kind. And so the speech does not
ascend, but descend lower, in each degree. A true Climax is that Romans VIII. 29,
30. And again, ver. 34. And Jer. XV. 5. The sense here agrees with David's
words, Psalm. XXVI. 4, 5.

He shall be like] Jer. XVII. 7, 8. VIII. 16, 17. Ezekiel. XIX. 10. and XXXI. 4.
Psalm. XCII. 12, 13, 14.

a tree] No mind or mention here of the Palm tree, or allusion to the tree of
Life in Paradise.

not so] Thus are these words used, Genesis XLVIII. 18. Exodus X. 11. Number. XII. 7.
Deuteronomy. XVIII. 14. Prove. XV. 7. Esaias XVI. 6. repeated Jer. XLVIII. 30. Ephesians. IV.
20. And in Matthew. XX. 26. where Christ forbids not the exercise of Superiority
among Christians, or among Ministers of the Gospel, or requires parity of
authority among them; but says, that those things, though good and lawful in
themselves, yet have no place in, nor relation to, his spiritual Kingdom,
which is in the soul.

not stand] As Number. XXX. 5, 12. Josh. II. 11. and VII. 12, 13.

Knoweth] Acknowledge and own; Exodus III. 7. Deuteronomy. XXXIV. 10. Psalm. XXXI. 8.
and XXXVII. 18. and CXLII. 5. and CXLIV. 12. Prove. XII. 10. Hos. XIII. 5.
Matthew. VII. 23. Romans VII. 15. John X. 14. Job XXIII. 10. Prove. II. 8.

Why] I his Psalm by many of the Ancients is joined to the former, Psalms.
But Saint Paul does distinguish them, Acts XIII. 33. And the Church does
ascribe this Psalm to David, though it bear not his Title, Acts IV. 25. And in
this Psalm David bears a Type of Christ, who is here more realy, properly,
principaly, and immediately intended. All which appears Acts IV. 25, 26. and
XIII. 33. Heb. I. 5. and V. 5. So that the first and open sense points to
David; the mystical and more abstruse to the Messiah. And no doubt, but this,
and such allusions more, were out of all question, even from the beginning so
forecast, and appointed, as it were, by the holy Ghost.

Why] The Psalmist demands, and wonders at the banding and conspiring of all,
and all sorts of enemies, against David and his Kingdom typicaly, as did Saul,
Ishbosheth, Abner, the Philistines, Jebusites, and others: But against Christ,
and his Kingdom principaly, as is the prime purpose* maine scope, and intent
of this Psalm, Acts IV. 25, 26. Mark III. 6. John XI. 53. Luke XIX. 14. Though
all in vain, ver. 1, 2, 3.

The Kings] 2 Samuel VIII. and X.

heavens] 1 King. VIII. Jer. XXII. 24. Psalm. CXXXIX. 7. The King of heaven
against those Kings of the earth, ver. 2.

laugh] And have them in derision, as Job XLI 29. dictum (...); intelligendum
(...). Psalm. XXXVII. 12, 13. and LIX. 8. Prove. I. 26.

wrath] No passion properly has any place in Gods will. in him, but without
him; not in his affection, but in his act. These expressions are but
condescentions to the weakness of our capacities, Psalm. LXXVI. 6, -- 9. and
CIV. 32.

yet have I] God the Father who makes and orders all earthly Kingdoms, Dan.
IV. 14. and II. 21. and VII. 14. Ezra I. 1.

my King] Prove. VIII. 22, -- 30. Acts II. 36.

Sion] See the Observations on Deuteronomy. III. 9. and on 1 Chronicles. XI. 5. See Psalm.
LXXVIII. 68. and LXVIII. 17. and CXXXII. 13. and LXXXVII. 2. Esaias II. 2, 3, 4.
and IV. 4.

I will declare] David typicaly;

The Lord has said] Hebr. V. 5. Psalm. CX. 1.

my sonne] Not as holy men. Princes, David, or Angels are called the sons of
God, John I. 12. Jer. XXXI. 9. Psalm. LXXXII 6. Job I. 6. But in a peculiar
manner far above all these, Hebr. I. 4, 5, 9. not by adoption or grace, but by
nature.

This day] Relates to his Nativity, as man; not to his Divinity, as God. And as
(...), he is called the Son of God, Luke I. 35. Heb. I. 5. And that raising
up of Jesus, Acts XIII. 33. relates to this Exhibition of him in the flesh,
mentioned also, ver. 23. That other raising him from the dead speaks plainly of
his resurrection from the grave, Acts XIII. ver. 34, -- 37. Romans I. 4.

have I begotten thee] Not relating here to his eternal generation as the Son
of God, the second Person and Hypostasis in the Trinity: But to his gigniture
(...), when he revealed him to the world.

Ask of me] God Decrees, Assuerus to Ester, chap. V. 3. And Herod to the
daughter of Herodias, Mark VI. 23. And God himself to Solomon, 1 King. III. 5.
So, and much more here God the Father to Christ his Son, the Mediator. Thus
Christ asked and prayed, in the days of his flesh; and was ever heard in
whatsoever he asked, according to the nature of his asking, John XI. 22, 42.
Heb. V. 7. John XVII. 9.

and the uttermost] Psalm. XXII. 29, 30. Heb. I. 2. Dan. II. 44.

them] Thine enemies, ver. 1, 2, 3.

rod of iron] Esaias XXX. 14. Jer. XIX. 11. See the actual execution, Apoc. II.
26. and chap. XII. 5. and XIX. 15. Esaias XI. 4.

Be wise] Take better counsel then that, ver. 2; use better wisdom.

now] Heb. V. 7. Prove. V. 7. and VII. 24. and VIII. 32. Esaias XLIV. 1. Delay is
dangerous.

Kings] Ye, ver. 2.

serve] Kings; Luke I. 74, 75. Psalm. CXVI. 16.

with fear] A filial fear, which is joined with joy, Psalm. C. 2.

rejoice with trembling] These two also are coexistent; joy, Romans XIV. 17. Ps.
IX. 2. 14. Phil. IV. 4. Trembling, Phil. II. 12. The regenerate man is a kind
of mixed person; has, as Rebecca, two struggling in him.

Kisse] A sign, Genesis XXXIII. 4. 1 Samuel XX. 41. Romans XVI. 16. 1 Cor. XVI. 20.
Of Subjection in inferiors, Genesis XLI. 40. 1 Samuel X. 1. Prove. XXIV. 26. Of
religious adoration, 1 King. XIX. 18. Job XXXI. 27.

the Sonne] 1 John II. 23. John V. 23.

lest he be angry] Genesis III. 3. Certainly he will, ver. 5. 2 These. I. 8. Apoc.
VI. 16, 17.

and ye perish from the way] The way of happiness; you, and your way perish,
Psalm. I. 6. or your way of combination against Christ, ver. 1, 2. or in the way
of your conceited peace and secure prosperity.

Blessed] Apoc. XIX. 9. Romans IX. 33. John III. 36.

ten thousands of people] And likely more now gathered against him, Absalom.
Most of David's Psalms in order of time go before this Psalm.

my glorie] The glory of my Kingdom which God has promised me,

godly] (...), Macc. 7. 13. 2 Macc. XIV. 6. may seem to have their name. And
whence the Pelican has the name of (...), from the pious benignity it shows,
as to her young ones, so to her dam when overgrown with years, as some write.
And from her Greek name (...) arises the Greek Proverb (...), to denotate a
retribution and recompensation of pious duties, offices, and benefits, such as
the Pelican uses. The same word (...), is taken also and used by some for the
Stork, as Jer. VIII. 7. the Stork having the like pious benign properties and
qualifications.

stand in awe and sin not] Ephesians. IV. 26. Be anrgy, and sin not. And that
sense the word here used will bear; David speaking thus to his friends; Let not
your indignation, and just resentment of these scandals and confusions in my
sufferings, proceed to a sinful murmuring against God; but consider of it
wisely in your most retired thoughts, and be silent, contented, and quiet.

into thy house] David.

toward thy holy Temple] And so David, Psalm. XXVII. 4. and XXIX. 9. and LXV. 4.
and LXVIII. 29. and CXXXVIII. 2. And yet in David's days the Temple was not
built. He minded that which after his days he knew presently should be: And
mean time he styles the Arc, or Tabernacle, by the name of the Temple. See
the Observations on Exodus XXXIII. 7.

rebuke me not] Psalm.

heal me] David was in some soar sickness at this time.

bed to swim] See the Observations on Josh. XI. 4.

If I have done this] Whereof Cush Saul's Courtier or Favorite,

return thou on high] To ascend, Kings X. 19. And this; to judge for me; and
against Cush; as it follows in the rest of the Psalm.

Out of the mouth] This is alluded to Mat.

What is man] This, ver. 5, 6. are applied to Christ by the Apostle, Heb. II.
6, -- 9. 1 Cor. XV. 27. Ephesians. I. 22. so taking in both Christ the head; and
mankind, specialy the faithful, as members; showing thereby that mysticaly and
propheticaly in these words is intimated the humiliation and exaltation of the
man Christ Jesus.

O thou enemie] A kind of scoff and derision, David upbraids him for his
bloody designs and threats.

Know thy name will] Know experimentaly, verse 20. in all their hearts, and
souls; in themselves; as the phrases of Scripture are, Josh. XXIII. 14. 1 Samuel
VI. 9. Heb. X. 34. Of this knowledge is that John XVII. 3. and 1 John II. 3, 4,
5. and chap. III. 19 24. and chap. IV. 6, 7, 8, 13. and chap. V. 2. 18, 19. 20.
Noetical, speculative knowledge, swimming only in the brain, and not sinking
into the heart, is none of this knowledge.

till thou find none] Rid the world of them,

flee a bird] 1 Samuel XXVI. 19.

If the foundations] In Church and Kingdom.

what can] He help; but suffer in such a general ruin?

The fool] Psalm. Psalm are by Saint Paul applied to all mankind in general,
in the state of the Fall, and natural corruption, Romans III. 10, 11, 12.

usury] Of this see Exodus Levit. XXV. 36, 37. Deuteronomy. XXIII. 19, 20. Neh. V. 17.
Levit. XXVIII. 8. And the Annotations on Ezekiel. XVIII. 8. and XXII. 12, 13. Mat.
XXV. 27.

that hasten] Or give gifts to another god. Ezekiel. XVI. 33, 34. The true God
needs them not, ver. 2. But false gods do; which gifts do redound in the end to
the damage and sorrows of the givers.

their drink offerings of blood] Their Offerings and Sacrifices of man's blood.
The drink offerings to the true God, were of wine, according to his Law, Number.
XV. 5. But Idolaters in stead thereof did many times offer man's blood. Paul's
readiness to be offered, Phil. II. 17. 2 Timothy IV. 6. imports no more then his
willingness to die and spend his blood, for Christ's cause, and the good of his
Church and people.

their names] See the Observations on Josh. XXIII. 7.

I have set the Lord] Acts II. 25, -- 31. David speaks here of himself, in this
regard, as having Christ in his loins, in a Prophetical spirit relating to
Christ.

right hand] Psalm. CIX. 31. and CX. 5. and CXXI. 5.

not be moved] Psalm. CXVIII. 6. CXXXV. 1. Romans VIII. 31, etc.

my glory] My tongue, II. 26. Psalm. XXX. 12. and LVII. 8. and CVIII. 2. Genesis
XLIX. 6.

my flesh also] As Romans VIII. 19. 21.

my soul in hell] A Prophecy of Christ's Resurrection. David speaks here in the
Person of Christ.

Soul] Sometimes is taken properly, sometimes improperly, for the whole person
of man, Genesis XIV. 12. Acts XXVII. 37. sometimes for the life of the person,
sometimes for the body, Genesis XVII. 21. sometimes for the dead carcass, Levit.
XIX. 28. and XXI. 1, 2. Number. VI. 6. and V. 2, 9, 10. Hag. II. 14. And so (...)
is taken also. Here, my soul, i. e. my self.

hell] the Hebrew (...) is taken for the grave, Psalm. CXLI. 7. and LXXXVI. 13.
and XXX. 13. and LV. 15. Genesis XXXVII. 35. and XLII. 3. 1 Kings II. 6, 9. Number.
XVI. 30. Jonah II. 1, 2. Not for a place of souls under the earth. See Doctor
Rainolds, Praelect. 81. and 82. upon the Apocryphal books: and Robert Parker
upon Christ's Descent into hell; (...) is taken for death, or the state of the
dead: for the place invisible; for the grave, in relation to the body, Acts II.
27. And in relation to the soul, for heaven to the godly soul, as in our Creed;
and for Hell, to the soul ungodly; and so most usualy. Christ's soul did not
descend to the lower parts, or that imaginary place of Limbus Patrum. This
place here meant is a place of punishment, and therefore it is mentioned as a
mercy, that Christ was thence delivered; Christ's soul was not therefore there
in triumph. The scope of the Apostles in citing this place is not to deal
about the deliverance of Christ's soul out of Hell, but punctualy of Christ's
Resurrection: They infer nothing else out of this Text. But Resurrection is
properly of the Body, not of the Soul. Gehenna is sometimes taken for the
Grave; and most-times further, for Hell it self. The true meaning and sense of
the Article of Christ's Descent into Hell, as the Latins very improperly
translate the words, (...), seems to be thus rendered rather, he went into the
place of invisible souls: and to be understood of Christ's Soul; for his body
remained in the Grave; And his soul in that interim to pass to the place of
souls; to Heaven or Paradise; as the souls of the godly did, and his
principaly. As the souls of the wicked went to Hell. For (...) as a general
name does certainly and evidently signify both places. And thus the Articles
go on methodicaly, without any tautologie; That after Christ's death, his body
was buried in the Grave, his Soul went to the place of blessed souls; and the
third day, both soul and body were reunited in his Resurrection. This verse
then, and two before, and one following, are most properly meant of Christ, and
of his Resurrection. Acts II. 25, -- 28, 31. and XIII. 35, 36, 37.

Thou will show me] Experimentaly.

me] Christ spea^s of himself.

the path of life] Of glory after his Resurrection. David, of all his members.
Christ's Resurrection, and Glorification is the beginning of ours; he the
Author, and means of it to us; in our first Resurrection here by Regeneration,
to the life of Grace; whereby Christ lives in us, Gal. II. 20. He in us, and we
in him by Faith, Ephesians. III. 17. Romans I. 17 And in our second Resurrection, to
the life of Glory; as follows in. this verse.

In thy presence] Before thy face; in the light of thy countenance. See Genesis
XXXII. and Exodus XXXIII. 14, 15. Number. VI. 23. Psalm. IV. 6. and XXXI. 16. and
LXXX. 3. Deuteronomy. XXXIV. 10. Esaias VI.

fulnesse] Yet all the former but in part, whiles we are in the way; in
fullness, when we come to our country, or heavenly Canaan, Job XIX. 26, 27. 1
John III. 2. 1 Cor. XIII. 12. Matthew. V. 8. And yet this beatifical Vision of
God in glory shall be to our fullness; not to his. The fullness of his infinite
Essence, by any created power of Saint, or Angel by the eye of flesh, though
glorified, or by the intellectual eye of a soul or spirit glorified cannot be
seen, 1 Timothy VI. 16. But to our fullness, as far as creatures are capable
of, our vessel thrown into this infinite Sea, shall be brim full, though it
contain not all this Ocean, Psalm. XVII. 15. And how great then shall this
fullness then be, when of things in this kind revealed of God to his Apostles
in this life, by his Spirit, the Apostle so speaks, as we read, 1 Cor. XI. 9.
out of Esaias LXIV. 4? This is a fullness beyond all that of Faith, and Hope, a
fullness that fills up all desires, a fullness of fruition, of satisfaction,
without satiety. Apoc. III. Consider that saying of the Queen of Sheba, 1 King.
X. 8. and of the Disciples at Christ's Transfiguration, Mat. XVII. 4.

At thy right hand] And by thy right hand, Psalm. XX. 7. LXIII. 9. CXVIII. 16.

for evermore] Without which eternity there were no true felicity.

right] My plea for my righteous cause; ver. 2.

I am purposed] Psalm. XXXIX. 1.

of thy lips] Guiding and directing me.

when I awake] Our of the sleep of death, Esaias XXVI. 19.

with thy likenesse] 1 Cor. XV. 49. 1 John III. 2. Apoc. XXII. 4.

Horne] Signifies power, Psalm. XCII. 10. Amos VI. 13. And Christ called the
Horn of Salvation, Luke I. 69.

earth shook] Here, David's victories, in some sort Poeticaly set forth.

thundered] Thunder is called Gods voice, Apoc. X. 3, 4. and XIX. 6. Of
thunder. See Psalm. XXIX. 3, 10. and LXXVII. 18. and CIV. 7. Exodus XIX. 16. and
XX. 18. Jer. X. 13. Job. XXVI. 14 and XXXVIII. 25. Esaias XXIX, 6. Apoc. IV. 5.
and 8. 5. Some proud blasphemers have labored to imitate the thunder: and some
impious Tyrants have exceedingly feared it.

according to my righteousnesse] The justness of my Cause against Saul,

thy self froward] Meet with them in their own way. Levit. XXVI. 23, 24.

Bow of steel.

Therefore will I give thanks unto thee] This verse is applied, Romans XV. 9. to
the Calling of the Gentiles to the faith of Christ, and praise unto God
therefore. And so formerly, ver. 43, 44. and again, verse 50. are more truly
verified in Christ, then in David.

to his Anointed, to David, and to his seed for evermore] To his Messiah, his
Christ, as Psalm. II. 2. to David literaly; to Christ mysticaly called by the
name of David, Jer. XXX. 9. Ezekiel. XXXIV. 23, 24. and chap. XXXVII. 24. Hos. 5.
to his seed, both himself properly, called the seed of David, Romans I. 3. Acts
XIII. 23. as the seed of Abraham, Gal. III. 16. and to his seed, Esaias LIII. 10.
Heb. II. 13. And thus properly it is for evermore.

Day unto day] Or day after day:

There is no speech] Among all variety of Languages, ver. 4.

Their line] Romans X. 18. Micah V. 2. with Matthew. chap. II. 6. And again in Romans
IX. 33. with Isa. chap. XXVIII. 16. The Apostle fits this Testimony to his own
purpose; not derogating thereby from the truth of the literal sense. As that
Exodus XVI. 18. is applied, 2 Cor. VIII. 15. Or rather the Apostle retains the
literal sense, for the preaching of the Gospel to all the world, Romans XV. 19.
Col. I. 6, 23. And out of this testimony of the Psalm in its literal sense
proves that the Gentiles had heard and learned somewhat of God and piety
before, out of the book of the Creation, Romans I. 19. Acts XIV. 17. Which was a
forerunner to this more ample Doctrine and School of the Gospel, which now God
was pleased to vouchsafe unto them. In sum, the Apostle herein follows the
LXX. And applies this to the preaching of the Gospel to the Heathens; as God
had formerly taught them, in another and a weaker manner and degree, by his
works of Creation. They had as a voice to speak; so a line to write, rule,
direct, and instruct, as Esaias XXVIII. 10.

sunne] The carbuncle of heaven; the eye, and heart of the world, for its
light, and heat.

to run a race] His race, is without intermission, or weariness; and the
swiftness of his running,

The Law] From the Book of Gods works, verses. And in this School, each verse
in a manner does express the name, the nature, the effects, the preciousnesse
of this Word; much against all those imbasements and impeachments which the
Papists would put upon it.

gold] Gold of Havilah, Genesis II. 11, 12. Ophir, 1 Kings IX. 28. Uphaz, Jer. X.
9. This is the chiefest gold, Dan X. 5. Job XXVIII. 15. Psalm. CXIX. 72. See the
Observations on Esaias XIII. 12.

great reward] Which reward yet is of grace, Romans VIII. 3. through Gods free
grace and bounty; not the merit of our works. The Apostle does thus distinguish
of merit, Romans IV. 4, 5. and XI. 6. There is no merit properly, if the work be
not properly out own; and not otherwise due debt; and justly equal to the
reward. They are justly due out of his true and free promise.

who can] Where then is that possibility,

dominion over me] There are sins reigning; and not reigning, but rebelling,
Romans VI. 12, 22. and VII. 15, -- 20.

The Lord hear thee] This Psalm, David, for a public form of a Prayer in the
one, of a Thanksgiving in the other, to be used by the people, for himself the
King. They seem to stretch this Psalm too far, and that without ground, who
make it to be a Prophecy of Christ's Sufferings, and his deliverances out of
them, for which the Church with him triumphs. As also the next Psalm to
gratulate the victory and Salvation of Christ.

Save Lord, let the King hear us] Most here understand God, or the Messiah.
Some David. The LXX. not observing or keeping the Hebrew distinction Athnach,
render it thus, Lord save the King, and hear us when we call upon thee.

for ever and ever] Psalm. David lived but seventy years: yet in his royal
posterity, for many ages; and in Christ, the Son of David, Matthew. XXII. 42.
for ever and ever, eternaly, Romans VI. 9. Apoc. I. 18. Heb. VII. 25. See the
Observations on Deuteronomy. XV. 17.

Thine hand] King David's hand.

In some Psalms there are passages that properly and literaly belong to David;
and to Christ only, as David was a Type of him. But in this Psalm, are some
Passages, as ver. 16, 17, 18. (besides many other which are applied to Christ
in the New Testament, as ver. 1, 7, 8, 22, 27.) which literaly and properly
belong to Christ, and are appliable to him only, or to him more then to David.
Then here is no place left for that question of the Eunuch, Acts VIII. 34. The
allegations out of this Psalm, Matthew. XXVII. 46, 35, 43. Heb. II. 12. and the
body of the Psalm it self do show, that little of it can be applied to David,
as a Type, most of it is proper and peculiar to Christ alone, as I formerly
said, 1 Pet. I. 11, 12.

my God] Jesus on the Cross little before his death, Matthew. XXVII. 46. Heb. V.
7. upon the weight of Gods wrath, under the burden of our sins; The Deity by
a special providence and dispensation withdrawing and suspending its influence
from the Humanity for this time; God withdrawing all sense of his favor from
him. Not that the hypostatical union of both natures was then or ever severed
or dissolved. But yet he suffered chiefly in his soul, all the pains, pangs
and agonies of a justly angry and punishing God, even more then can either be
expressed or imagined, even so far above the measure of ordinary sufferings,
as himself was above ordinary men; without any influence, or joy, or comfort
streaming from the Vision of God upon his mind and will for that time. So that
he suffered as in body, so in soul, in his whole man; as in his sensual part,
so in his intellectual also, in his whole soul, and body, and in all the parts,
powers, and faculties of them. And the greatest sufferings, as was said, that
could be sustained in this life, Lam. I. 12. yet without any derogation to the
integrity, purity, innocence, dignity of the person of Christ our Surety and
Savior. These words then are not a complaint out of impatience, ignorance,
disobedience, or diffidence. They are the words of sense, not of infidelity.
See ver. 24. Luke XXIII. 46. He strongly calls him his God, even in that
instant of these suffering; so expressing his firm faith in him. But they are
a Protestation of the bitterness of his Passion, so stricken, smitten of God,
and afflicted, and so far prevailing on him, in whom the spirit of fortitude
had his residence.

forsaken me] This sense of dereliction and carencie of Divine favor for the
time, as it was the Fathers pleasure to have it so, so the Sons office called
him unto it; and he did not contract it by any fault of his, but did
voluntarily undertake it for our sins, and the expiation of them: as he did
the death it self. So that in this then there could not be any defect or
defanlt of faith, and hope requisite in him, And likewise that Prayer and
Speech, Matthew. XXVI. 39. bewrayes the sense of the flesh; but joined with the
obedience of the Spirit in him: A double Will in him, against Monothelites: but
joined both in one holy obedience and subjection. All which show the nature of
sin, the infinite wrath of God against it; the infinite Love of the Father,
and the Son, toward the children of men; and the verity of Christ's Humane
Nature, both in body and soul.

roaring] Like that of Lions Psalm. XXXII. 3. and XXXVIII. 8. Matthew. XXVI. 38.
Mark XIV. 33. Luke XXII. 44. so that he had need of an Angel for his
Comforter. Yet he so wrestles and prevails, that no sign of halting was left
remaining after; no sign or voice of despair; as some are shamelesly wronged
to charge upon him. All the agonies of Christ's soul ceased with his death.

but thou hear not] We read that God ever heard him, ver. 24. John XI. 42.
Heb. V. 7. But here this Prayer was only conditional; a signification of a
natural desire; not an absolute, and plenary Prayer.

inhabit the praises of Israel] Whose praise thou art, Deuteronomy. X. 21. And they
praise thee, in thy House and Sanctuary. Thou art still praised by them for thy
benefits to them, and acknowledged their holy one.

Our fathers] And shall I be so forsaken,

Cried] Crying or clamor, Psalm III. 4. and XVIII. 7. Jer. VII. 16. Jonas III.
8. Micah III. 4.

a worme] So vile and contemptible in the eyes of men, Esaias LIII. 2, 3. as Job
XXV. 6. Esaias XLI. 14. Not only made lower then the Angels, Psalm. VIII. 5. Heb.
II. 7. but disesteemed more then Barrabas, or the two theives.

All they that see me] This verse, Matthew. XXVII. 39, -- 44. Luke XXIII. 35. Not
that Christ herein murmurs against God; but declares and deplores his own
misery, whereunto for man's sake, and his redemption, he willingly subjects
himself.

laugh me to scorne] Matthew. XXVII. 39.

He trusted] Matt.

But thou art] This verse, David, Psalm. LXXI. 5, 6, 7.

out of the womb] By a natural, not miraculous way; as David was, Psalm. LXXI.
5. by the opening of the womb, without any loss or laesion of Blessed Mary's
Virginity; not by a miraculous penetration of dimensions and substances, to
keep the womb still closed and shut.

breasts] So Job XXXI. 18. Psalm. LXXI. 6. 2 Timothy III. 15. Esaias XLVI. 3. and
XLIX. 1. Luke I. 15, 41.

I was cast] By him saved from Herod's intended murder, Mat. II.

Be not far from me] Therefore he was not utterly forsaken, ver. 1. So Psalm.
X. 1. and XXXVIII. 22, 23. So again, Esaias XLVIII. 9.

for trouble is near] Death it self.

none to help] Esaias LXIII. 3, 5. His Disciples fled; Peter forswears him: none
but God could help him.

Many Bulls] So afterward Lions, ver. 13. Dogs, ver. 16, 20. Such were his
enemies to him; the Devil and his instruments; the Priests, and Rulers of the
Jews, in our Saviors days.

Bashan] See the Annotations on Micah VII. 14.

roaring Lion] Even they forced Pilate, Matthew. XXVII. 17. -- 26. John XIX. 1,
-- 13.

like water] Such is his state. Sam. XIV. 14. His bones, heart, bowels, melted,
burnt, as it were, with the heat of Gods wrath.

the Assembly] In their Councils, Mark XIV. 55. and XV. 1. John XI. 47.

They pierced] Our Hebrew Bibles have (...), as a Lion. Which yet by anomalie
in Grammar may signify (...), they pierced. And such anomalies are found
sometimes in the Hebrew text, as Ezra X. 16. 44. Psalm. X. 15. And (...) is
confessed to be found in some ancient Copies, or (...); So that the text here
may be said to admit diverse readings. Yet the Spirit of God in the New
Testament does constantly render it, they pierced. The ancient Jews maintain
this reading; And some of the modern. The other reading as a Lion, is but a
various reading; and though in the text, yet in good sense it seems not so
well to stand; and therefore this foderunt, set in the margin, is to be read.
And some Copies have foderunt in the text; yea, and the other reading as was
said by anomalie in Grammar, not unusual in Scripture, will signify foderunt
also. And thus they dealt with our Savior Jesus Christ, John XX. 25. Luke
XXIV. 40. Zech. XII. 10. compared with John XIX. 37.

stare upon me] As Psalm. XXXV. 21. LIVE. 9. They fed their eyes with my
miserable spectacle; with all pleasure, and without any pitying of me.

parted my garments] John XIX. 23, 24. their Captain or Centurion, were there
present.

lots] Of Lots, see the Annotations on Jonah I. 7. Lots are for division; or
consultation, and Divination.

my darling] Psalm. ver. 11.

Unicorns] See the Observations on Number. XXIII.

I will declare] Recount,

unto my brethren] Heb. II. 10, 11, 12. brethren in that one and common
sanctification.

ye that fear the Lord] Christ's speech and exhortation to his Church, to
praise, Psalm. CXXXV. 1. etc.

has not despised] Christ, in his low and base estate; Esaias LIII. 3.

he heard] Heb. V. 7.

my praise] As Christ exhorted others; so himself will not be behind,

vowes] See the Annotations on Jonah I. 16.

The meek] Spiritual feeding, Sam. VI. 18, 19. See Esaias LV. 1, 2. Prove. IX. 5,
6.

All the ends] The large bounds of the Church of Christ, Psalm. II. 8. Genesis
XVII. 18. and XLVIII. 10. Esaias XLIX. 22. Acts XIII. 47. and XIV. 14.

worship] 1 Samuel I. 3* 19, 28. John IV. 20, -- 24.

For the Kingdome] His Kingdom of Grace, Esaias II. 4.

All they] All sorts and conditions of men shall worship before him, James I.
9. the rich and great ones, Psalm. XLV. 12. Esaias XLIX. 23. and the poor hungry
ones ready to die and perish, Matthew. XI. 5.

A seed] Christ's Church shall be Catholic, Esaias LIII. 10. Those worshippers in
the former verse, shall have a seed and succession to continue from generation
to generation, Psalm. LXXXVII. 5, 6. Acts XV. 16.

They shall come] They that are first in Christ,

shall declare his righteousnesse] In performing his promises, in the
exhibition of the Messiah, and the benefits of redemption and salvation by him,
Psalm. XL. 10. and LXXI. 15.

that he has done this] Like that Psalm. XXXVII. 5.

Shepheard] A frequent similitude: David the more willingly use it, as having
been a Shepherd himself. It is used of God; of Christ; and of Magistrates, and
Ministers under them. And the godly are called by the name of sheep. The texts
are numerous.

I shall not want] 1 Cor. III 21. Mat. V. 33.

in green pastures] Ezekiel. XXXIV. 14. Esaias XLIX. 10.

thou art with me] Genesis XV. 1. and chap. XXI. 22. 1 Chronicles. XI. 9. 2 Kings VI.
VI. 12. Acts XVIII. 9. Jer. XV. 20. Esaias XLIII. 2.

Thy rod and thy staffe] Micah VII. 14. Zech. XI. 7.

dwell in the house of the Lord] The place of Gods worship, Judge. XIX. 18. Psalm.
LXVI. 13. and XXVII. 4. yet God dwells not in Temples made with hands, Esaias
LXVI. 1. Acts VII. 48.

The earth] 1 Cor. X. 26, 28. twice alleged by the Apostle; and to two several
purposes; and both appositely

hill of the Lord] Though all the earth be the Lords, verse 1. yet the hill of
Zion, Psalm. II. 6. is his holy place. As Exodus XIX. 5. Deuteronomy. X. 14. Of this
hill, see Esaias II. 2, 3. Micah IV. 1. See Psalm. XV. 1.

holy place] Place, not capable of holiness in it self, of any inherent
holiness: But of a relative holiness, in a relation to Gods presence therein,
for the time, either by extraordinary signs and tokens as Exodus III. 5. or by
appointing his ordinary means of worship therein; ceremonial under the Old
Testament; which now is done away, and not to be recalled; or spiritual, under
the New. The former, though of Gods appointment and ordination, had not in
themselves, nor could give absolute holiness to the worship therein performed:
And much more now the Places of Gods worship do not make holy the Services
therein performed; but by them rather are made holy only relatively, being
appointed to such holy uses.

He that hath] Esaias XXXIII.

clean hands] Psalm. XVIII. 21. Esaias LVI. 2. Ezekiel. XVIII. 8.

pure heart] Matthew. XV. 19. Prove. II. 19. Jer. XVII. 9. yet Acts XV. 9. 1 Timothy
I. 5. Psalm. CI. 2.

nor sworn deceitfully] Oaths are taken in a strict and proper sense; or at a
great latitude. They are Assertorie, or Promissorie; single, or with a curse or
execration annexed; lawful in themselves; an act of Religion, Esaias XIX. 18.
Lawful in the Old Testament, by Gods precept, promise, and examples of holy
men. Lawful in the New Testament by same nature, and use of them, as in the
Old, Hebr. VI. 16. by those warrants, Esaias XLV. 1. Jer. XII. 16. speaking of
the times of the New Testament; by the example of the Angel, Apoc. X. 16. of
the Apostle, Romans I. 9. 2 Cor. I. 23. That text, Matthew. V. 34. and so that
James V. 12. is not to be understood simply and absolutely; but relatively, as
Christ thereby opposes the corrupt practice of the Pharisees, and their false
interpretation of Gods Law concerning swearing, as if swearing, so as Gods name
were not directly used in it, and no falsehood or perjury contained in it, were
no sin with them; but ever and altogether lawful, though it were never so
lightly and slightly, vainly, and customarily, unnecessarily, and causelessly
done, where yea and nay had been sufficient. Thus Christ opposes and
forbids even all swearing as much as lies in us; but forbids not lawful
swearing, upon just, urgent and necessary occasions. Of Oaths, see more in the
Observations on Hos. IV. 15.

He shall] He is a true member of the invisible and Catholic Church, Romans IX.
6. Matthew. VII 21. The former are members properly, univocaly, essentialy,
formaly, inwardly, in truth, and in the judgment of God; The later only
equivocaly, externaly, materialy, not formaly and essentialy, in show, in the
opinion of men as rotten members, or ill humors in the body, 2 Timothy III. 5.
Gal. V. 24. These are in the visible Church, as chafe is among the wheat.

receive] Not by merit of condignity, for the worth of his works, Dan. IX. 18.
Romans VIII. 18. For the works are imperfect in themselves; and again, not our
own, and wholly from our selves, and besides due debt otherwise, without this
reward; and lastly no wise equivalent, and equipollent to this reward. But
receive the blessing and reward by and because of Gods free grace, rich mercy,
bountiful promise, whereby he has freely engaged himself to give such and so
superabundant a remuneration. And so he gives it in justice now because engaged
and obliged thereunto by the truth of his so free, gracious, and bountiful a
promise. God is just to perform his promise, 1 John I. 9. 2 Timothy IV. 7.

Blessing] Genesis XII. 2. Gal. III. 9. Ephesians. I. 2. Mat. XXV. 34.

righteousnesse] Of Justification, and of Sanctification; Righteousness, with
the increase, fruit, and reward of it, according to Gods righteous promise and
performance.

This is the generation] This kind of men. Luke XI. 29. and XVI. 8. Matthew.
XII. 39. Not those that brag of being Abraham's or Jacobs seed, Matthew. III. 9.
John VIII. 33. but these are the true seed and generation, Gal. III. 7, 29.
Romans IX. 6, 7. These are the true Israel of God, that seek him.

that seek] Deuteronomy. IV. 29. Psalm. XXVII. 8. 2 Kings XX. 3, 4. which grace comes
of God, Esaias LXV. 1, 2.

thy face O Iacob] O God of Jacob. Or, this in Jacob; or the generation of
Jacob, that seek Gods face; as Jacob did, Genesis XXXII. 24, 30. See John I. 47.
Romans IX. 6. and II. 28, 29.

Lift up] Having mentioned the hill of the Lord, ver. 3. This may seem to
relate to the gates and doors of the Temple, vowed by David, and to be built by
Solomon; and to the coming in of the Ark into it: or rather, proceeding from
the Type to the Truth, we may mysticaly refer this to the Church of Christ,
and the true members of it, to lift up the gates and doors of their hearts and
everlasting souls, that the Lord whom they seek may come into his Temple, Mal.
III. 2. that they prepare themselves to receive and entertain him at his
coming in the flesh, at his coming into their hearts, Apoc. III. 20. who is
indeed the true King of glory. Apoc. XVII. 14. 2 Cor II. 8. the true Jehovah,
Exodus III. 15. Psalm. LXXXIII. 18. Col. II. 9. and Christ, compare Number. XXI, 5.
with 1 Cor. X. 9. and Esaias VI. 1. with John XII. 41. Even Jehovah our
righteousness, Ier. XXIII. 6. the mighty God, Esaias IX. 6. the increase of
whose Kingdom and government shall have no end, Esaias IX. 7. Dan. VII. 14. Mat.
XXVIII. 18. for whose in-coming the doors of our hearts and affections should
lie open.

To make the Alphabetical order perfect in this Psalm, verses in it not to be
rightly all distinguished: as namely, the second, and the fifth. And (...) to
seem wanting in the beginning of the seventeenth verse. And, the last verse to
be only the later part of the foregoing verse.

without cause] Given on my part;

for it is great] And so needs much mercy,

seek ye my face,] Deuteronomy. IV. 29. David's soul did most seek it, to be near where
the Ark of God was, and so before the face of the Lord, as the Scripture
phraseth it: being out of heart when he was barred from it, ver. 4. Psalm. LXV.
4. Psalm. LXXXIV. and XLII. 1 Samuel XXVI. 19. Gods command here was David's
request, and the thing he aimed at.

regard not] Esaias V. David to the Crown; in managing the matters of this world,
as to the godly, and as to the wicked; in husbanding man's salvation by
contraries, etc. Romans XI. 33.

in the beauty of holinesse] Psalm. XCVI. 9. the glorious, holy Sanctuary.

The voice of the Lord] Of thunder, Exodus IX. 23. Job XXXVII, 4, 5. and XL. 9.
See the Observations on Psalm. XVIII. 13.

Sirion] See the Observations on Deuteronomy.

but a moment] Esaias XXVI.

in my blood] By any violent death, Saul's means.

into thy hands] Luke XXIII. IV. 19.

My times] And troubles,

O how great] Esaias LXIV. II. 9.

in a] As in a fensed City.

in my hast] 1 Samuel XXIII. 26. Psalm. LXXVII. 7. etc. 2 Cor. I. 8, 9. yet this
might stand mixed with faith; as Psalm. XXII. 1. And as Fear and Confidence are
not altogether inconsistent, Phil. II. 12. Heb. III. 6, 14.

Blessed] Saint Paul, Romans IV. 6, 7, 8. alleges this to prove justification
by Faith, without Works. Faith and Works are inseparable, Ephesians. II. 8, 9, 10.
James II. 14, 17, 18, 20, -- 26. That Faith which is without Works is dead, no
true Faith. But Faith only acts in the point of our justification before
God, applying Christ and the Promises, believing according to the Covenant of
the Gospel; whereby Christ does become ours his righteousness our
justification; and all the benefits of his redemption do redound and amount to
our salvation.

imputeth] Frequent is the use of this word in the point of justification.

mule] See the Annotations on Genesis

near unto thee] To hurt thee: or not near to thee to do thee service, unless
forced by the bridle, Iam. III 3.

Harp] Invented by Iubal, Genesis IV. 21. made by Solomon of Almug trees, 1 Kings
X. 12. called the pleasant Harp, Psalm. LXXXI. 2 much used for mirth and joy,
Genesis XXXI. 27. Job XXI. 12. Esaias V. 12. Ezekiel. XXVI. 13. And much used in Gods
worship and service, in the praising of him, by ordinance in the Temple, 1 Chronicles. XV. 21. and XXV. 1, 3, 6. And upon other religious occasions^ both
public, as 1 Samuel X. 5. 2 Samuel VI. 5. 1 Chronicles. XV. 16. 2 Chronicles. V. 12. Nehem.
XII. 27. and private, wherein David excelled, 1 Samuel XVI. 16, 23. and abounded,
Psalm. LVII. 8. and CVIII. 3. And much in holy use with others also; as here;
and so XLIII. 4. and LXXI. 22. and XCVIII. 5. And of spiritual harps we read in
the Revelation, chap. V. 8. and XIV. 2. and XV. 2.

Psalterie] Or Lute, or Viol. In Hebrew Nebel. Whence the Greeks and Latins
seem to have the names of their instruments Nablium, Naulon.

a new Song] So Psalm. XL. 3. XCVI. 1. and XCVIII. 1. and CXLIV. 9. New still,
upon new and fresh occasions renewed. As Love is said to be both an old and a
new Commandment. Yet in Scripture phrase very much, Things appertaining to the
times of the Gospel, are called New; as a New Covenant, Heb. VIII. 13. a New
Testament, 1 Cor. XI. 25. a New Jerusalem, Apoc. III. 12. New Heavens, and a
New Earth, Esaias LXV. 17. a New name, a New man, Ephesians. II. 15. Esaias LXII. 2. a
New Commandment, John XIII. 34. a New way, Heb. X. 28. a New heart, Ezekiel.
XXXVI. 26. yea and all things New, 2 Cor. V. 17. Apoc. XXI. 5. See that Song,
Luke II. 14.

Abimelech] The common name of the Kings of the Philistines, Achish being the
proper name for this King of Gath, a City of the Philistines, 1 Samuel XXI. 10.
The LVI. Psalm is also upon this same occasion. And this one of the
Alphabetical Psalms: Only Zain is omitted, and Phe twice used.

They looked unto him] To God; David.

afflictions] They serve to them as cures, Psalm. CXIX. 67, 71. Heb. XII. 6, etc.

not one of them is broken] See Exodus Number. IX. 12. John XIX. 36. The sense here
is more general.

Let them] See the Observations on Psalm.

False witnesses] Mat. XXVI. 59.

my prayer returned] Though they got no good by it,

my darling] Psalm. XXVI. 20, -- 23.

within my heart] I verily believe it of them,

not good] Extremely bad. Observations on Prove. XX. 23.

great mountains] Mountains of God. Observations on Jonah III. 3. and on 1 Samuel
XIV. 15.

The matter of this Psalm, Job is much upon it, as chap. XXI. 7. etc. and
chap. XXIV: and chap. XXVII. and in other places. Diverse other Psalms also
insist upon it more or less; as Psalm. XLIX. and LXXIII. and XC. Jeremie
professedly, chap. XII. 1. etc. And Habakkuk somewhat, chap. I. 13. The case in
point of fact is plain and undeniable. The Providence, Wisdom, and Justice of
God in it, is a Mystery to man. Yet to the Christian who believes the
Resurrection of the body, and eternal life, things not so clearly revealed in
the infancy of the Church, the difficulty is now soon dissolved. And the well
and wise weighing of the point by an Heathen, or natural man, may much avail
him for his further and better information in matters of great consequence and
concernment. See the Annotations on Psalm. XLI. 1. The greatest doubt arising
hence to the godly, may seem to be this, How these same occurrences of
administrations in Gods Providence may stand with such constant, continual, and
abundant promises of Gods blessings in temporal things to the godly in this
life, 1 Timothy IV. 8. and with his like threatenings of plagues and punishments to
the wicked in this world. The issue will be, That these Promises and
Threatenings, specialy under the Law, are spoken to vulgar capacities, in those
times; and yet have their exceptions and limitations in the Word: And that the
prosperity of the wicked is but a seeming prosperity; and a short, and
momentany prosperity in relation to eternity; and many ways disadvantageous
and hurtful to them; and ends with an overthrow sudden, and terrible, and
everlasting: And again, That the affliction of the godly is but momentany,
nothing to eternity, and mainly profitable for the work of Grace here, more
then abundantly recompensing and over-poizing their afflictions; and for the
increase of Glory hereafter. Yet super-adding this, That Gods wisdom and ways
of Providence are not commensurate with man's finite and shallow capacity, Psalm.
XXXVI. 6. Romans XI. 33. Genesis XVIII. 25. Esaias LV. 8, 9.

Fret not] Another Alphabetical Psalm. verse, but every second verse, begins
with the letter of the Hebrew Alphabet in order. Only verse 7, 20, 29, 34.
stand single in their due order, without any other letter or verse interposed.

cease from anger] Upon unjust causes, Ephesians. IV. 31. yet in it self lawful,
Ephesians. IV. 26. Mark III. 5.

A little] Prove. XV. Eccl. IX. 7.

I have been young] This was David's experience in his time.

to bring to remembrance] That he might remember Gods chastisement upon him for
his sin;

lest otherwise] A like argument or expression God uses, Deuteronomy. XXXII. 27.

to Jeduthun] Or for him, Chron. XXV. 3. So Psalm. LXXVII. title.

Even from good] Not much unlike that idiotisme and expression, Genesis XXXI. 29.
Number. XXIII. 25.

the fire burned] See Jer. XX. 9. Job XXXII. 18, 19.

a moath] The moath is suddenly crushed, Job IV. 19. and does insensibly
consume a garment, Job XIII. 28. Hos. V. 12.

That this Psalm should wholly be understood of Christ; David; may seem not
so safe and warrantable.

I waited] They are David's words throughout this Psalm. Heb. X. 7, 8, 9.

and heard my cry] Thus from experience of mercy formerly received, in Gods
hearing his Prayers, and delivering him from deepest dangers, in the former
part of the Psalm; he strengthens his faith in Prayer for obtaining like
mercy, and deliverance, in the later part of the Psalm: so as there is no
show of opposition or contradiction, between the beginning, and ending of it.

an horrible pit] Not that imaginary Limbus Patrum: David was plunged after
his conversion, and the graces of faith, hope, and invocation appearing in him,
ver. 1.

a new song] For new benefits and deliverances;

many shall] Psalm. XXXII. 6.

fear, and shall trust.] These two conjoined in a pious soul; fear, and faith;
a reverent fear, and trust in Gods mercy, Psalm. CXXX. 4.

unto our God] To god, and Christ.

his trust] Whose sure mercy to them is such, Tim. IV. 10. Deuteronomy. I. 31. and
XXXII. 10, 11, 12. John III. 16.

Many, O Lord my God] David speaking to God and Christ;

Sacrifice] Christ's words, Heb. X. 5. So that these words, and the next are
spoken unto God, in the person of the Messiah, who was to come of the seed of
David, Heb. X. 5, 6, 7. See the like before, XVI. 10. David having spoken in
the former verse of Gods wonderful works and thoughts toward mankind, does
in this manner in the words of the Messiah rise up to the very highest of them
all in these two verses. For Sacrifices, see my Table of them in Leviticus.

not desire] Jer. VII. 22. Hos. VI. 6. Prove. XXI. 3. 1 Samuel XV. 22. Psalm. L. 5,
-- 16. Matthew. XII. 7. Mark XII. 33. And Christ was now to put an end to them,
Dan. IX. 27. as not able in themselves to purge away sin, Heb. X. 4.
Therefore God desired them not simply of themselves, without inward piety
concurring, as the very life and soul of them; Or, in comparison of the
spiritual worship of God; or, in comparison of that all-sufficient Sacrifice of
Christ, which he was to offer in the body of his flesh, Heb. X. 1, 4. Romans
VIII. 3, 4. After which these Legal Typical Sacrifices were to be abolished, as
was said. And that Sacrifice of Christ one offered never to be reiterated, Heb.
IX. and X. chapters; contrary to that blasphemous sacrifice of Christ in the
Popish Mass.

mine ears have thou opened] Dug open, or peirced; made me obedient to thy
voice: or bored, to make me thy servant for ever; in allusion to the Law Exodus
XXI. 6. For these words here, we read, Heb. X. 5. but a body have thou prepared
me, or fitted me. Wherein the Apostle either follows the LXX. or cites, not
the words, but the sense, Romans VIII. 3. Phil. II. 7. it being the same both
ways, in issue. Besides that varieties of readings in both places are alleged
out of ancient Copies by the learned. Papists themselves deny not this text to
be incorrupt. The Apostle faithfuly retaining the sense and scope of the place,
without tying himself to the letter of the words in his quotation. The
variation is but a change of the figurative phrase into a proper, to express
the ready obedience of Christ to do the will of his Father in the work of the
redemption of mankind, John V. 30. VI. 38. and IV. 34. whereunto by framing him
a body God had fitted him.

Sinne-offering] Heb Sin. Put often in the Law for the Sinne-offering. So
Levit. IV. 3. 24. Exodus XXIX. 14. In which sense Christ is called Sin, 2 Cor.
V. 21.

Then said I, Lo, I come] When thou had so fitted me, Mark X. 32, 33, 34.

In the volume] or Scroll rolled up, Jer. XXXVI. 2. Ezekiel. II. 9. The Volume of
the Law and Scripture, Luke XXIV. 27, 44. John V. 39.

of the Book] Sepher, or Book generaly signifies any writings, Court-rools,
etc. Deuteronomy. XXIV. 1. 2 Kings V. 5, 6. Jer. XXXII. 11.

it is written of me] So Christ himself says, Matthew. XXVI. 24 John V 46. See
Luke XXIV. 44, 46. Acts XIII. 29.

I delight] Luke XXII. 15. Heb. X. 10.

to do thy will] Heb. X. 10. John VI. 38. Luke XXII. 42. In all things to be
performed by me in my flesh, which are required by thee for the redemption and
salvation of man; even to my obedience in suffering the death of the Cross,
Phil. II. 8. Thus Christ in regard of his humane nature was truly less then
the Father, John XIV. 28. was subject to him; his will to the will of his
Father; took upon him the form of a servant, Phil. II. 7. was truly a servant,
Esaias XLII. 1. obeyed the mandates of the Father, John XII. 49. and XIV. 31. and
XV. 10. Being our Surety, was made under the Law, Gal. IV. 4. under the Law of
Moses, Moral, and Ceremonial; that the righteousness of the Law might be
fulfilled in us, Romans VIII. 4. And these are not figurative and metaphorical,
but proper elocutions, in regard of Christ's humane nature; not making a Person
in it self, distinct from the Person of the Son of God, with Nestorius; nor
yet hereby making the Person of the Son of God hypostaticaly uniting to
himself the Humane Nature, inferior to the Person of the Father, as Arius
would.

I have preached] Though Gods works were such as the fifth verse expresses;
John XVII. 6. Luke XXIV. 47. even Gods righteousness, faithfulness, truth,
loving-kindnesse, salvation, to the great Congregation of his people, Romans III.
21, 22. Esaias LXI. 1, 2, 3. and XLIX. 6. which office and duty David also the
Type, in his degree, and all Christ's messengers in their place and function, do
perform.

withold not thou] David prays here for what he had preached in the former
verse,

heart fails me] Psalm. and XXXVIII. 10.

Be pleased] Hence to the end of the Psalm agrees with Psalm. LXX. David
petitions, verse; the confusion of his enemies, verse 14, 15. to the joy of the
godly, and the glory of God, verse 16.

confounded] David's imprecation against his enemies. Sam. XV. 31. and Acts IV.
29. and Psalm. LXXXIII. 16. more then a mere prophetical prediction of evils to
befall them. Here is more: And so Psalm. XXXV. 4. and LXX. 2, 3. and CIX. 7.
etc. and LIX. 13. and 2 Timothy IV. 14. And in many other places. David here, and
other holy Prophets do not thunder thus against their enemies, desperate
sinners, out of any immoderate carnal passions, of private hatred, or desire of
revenge; or out of any rash and inconsiderate zeal; but moved and inflamed
rather by the Spirit of God; acting herein the public cause of God, and of his
glory; against those whom they knew by the spirit of discerning, 1 Cor. XII.
10. to be Gods, and their forlorn foes. Yet possible that in some of these
imprecations some mixture of humane infirmities might be: as in Jeremie XV. 15,
16, 17. But for us; touching private and personal enemies, our duty is, as we
read, Matthew. V. 44. as we find in the example of Christ, Luke XXIII. 34. and
of Stephen, Acts VII. 60. and 1 Pet. II. 23. And for public enemies of God and
his Church; we may not absolutely use execrations against their persons; as not
knowing but God may convert them afterward, of Saul's make them Paul's; and lest
we incur that rebuke, with those Disciples, Luke IX. 55. Let us stay till we
know that we be of their spirit before we do as these Prophets did. Of
imprecations, see more in the Observations on Psalm. CIX. 14. and the
Annotations on Neh. IV. 5.

Let all those] David's prayer for those that seek God,

But I] He concludes with commending his own case to God,

Blessed] This Psalm by some is applied to Christ;

deliver him] That is, the poor or sick weakling: David so comforts the poor
afflicted. So we must judge charitably, that God in his ordinary course of
providence will in due time, raise and restore them whom for a while he has
cast down. Some by him understand him that considers the poor.

his bed in his sicknesse] Make it to his ease.

As Acts XXVIII.

eat of my bread] This our Savior applies to Judas, John XIII. 18. See Psalm.
LV. 12, 13, 14.

Amen] A concurrence of wishes, Psalms.

Korah] This, Psalms, without David's name in the Title, are inscribed for
Korah's posterity, to be sung in the Temple, with voice, and instrument. Heman
the singer, the grandchilde of Samuel the Prophet, being one of his posterity,
1 Chronicles. VI. 33, -- 43. See the Observations on Number. XVI. 32.

This Psalm seems written by David; and when he was banished by Absalom, or
Saub rather, from the Sanctuary, and sacred Assemblies, and Solemnities, verse
1, 2, 4, 6. 9.

As the Hart] Or Hind. Hind; reading the Hebrew here in the foeminine gender;
for which the Hebrews render diverse reasons. And though the Hebrews have a word
of the masculine gender for the Heart, and of the foeminine gender for the Hind;
yet by either of them many times the other sex is understood. And so it is also
in other names of beasts with the Hebrews. As in Zech. IX. 9. the word for Ass
is of the masculine gender, yet the female sex is thereby understood, Matthew.
XXI. 2. So the name of the fish which swallowed Jonas is named both in the
masculine, and in the foeminine termination. See Jer. II. 24.

Kept holy day] Three solemn feasts in the year. Exodus XXIII. 14. and XXXII.
5, 6 19. Deuteronomy. XVI. 14, 15. Judge. XXI. 19, 21. Esaias XXX. 29.

for the help of his countenance] Or, his presence is salvations i. e. number
is used to advance and amplify the matter subject whereunto it is applied, as
in this word, Ps. XVIII. 2. and XXVIII. 8, and XLIV. 4. and LXXIV. 12. So in
others; as may be seen in the Observations on Psalm. LI. 17.

from the land of Jordan] From the places of his banishment,

Deep] Afflictions upon afflictions, breaking in as billows, wallowing as
waves,

Seems written by David,

hill, and to thy Tabernacles] The Ark was then at the hill of Kiriathjearim;
Nob, or Gibeon.

This Psalm of Instruction, David's reign; or of the Babylonish captivity; and
not to be extended to the days of Antiochus Epiphanes.

and cast them out] Or rather did propagate, Psalm. LXXX. 12. Ezekiel. XVII. 6.

them] That is, our fathers.

command] Psalm. XLII. 8. Deuteronomy. XXVIII. 8. Psalm. CXXXIII. 3.

But] Having remembered Gods former mercies, Psalm. LXXXIX.

Yet] They profess their integrity.

neither] In Hebrew it is, and. But this particle is diverse times taken to
signify neither. And so Psalm. L. 8. and Prove. XXXI. 3. Esaias XLI. 28. and chap.
XXVIII. 27, 28. See the Cinnus p. 182, 183.

for thy sake are] Applied by Saint Paul, to the present state and condition of
himself; Romans VIII. 36.

Awake,] They beg his help, and mercy.

a song of loves] A marriage song or Epithalamion of the well-be-loved
(Virgins) verse 9, Ephesians. V. 32. It sets forth Christ in his glory; and his
Spouse, the Church, in her beauty. See Heb. I. 8. John III. 29. Apoc. XXI. 9,
10. Typified here in Solomon, and Pharaohs daughter; wherein yet some things
are proper only to the Antitype.

My heart] Matthew. XII. 34.

touching the King] My Poems of the King.

Thou art fairer] Cant. V. 10, -- 16. I. 16. Heb. VII. 26.

lips] Cant. V. 13. Luke IV. 22. Esaias L. 4. John I. 18. and III. 37.

gird thy sword] The spiritual sword is the Word of God, Ephesians. VI. 17. Apoc.
I. 16. And with the breath of his lips shall he slay the wicked, Esaias. XI. 4.

ride prosperously] As in a triumphant Chariot, Esaias LIII. 10.

because of truth, etc.] Sitting and riding as it were, upon these three royal
virtues and graces; and they, as it were, drawing the Chariot.

truth] Ephesians. I. 13. Prove. XX. 28.

Meeknesse] Matthew. XXI. 5. and chap. XI. 29. and chap. XII. 19, 20. Esaias XLII.
2. Zech. IX. 9.

righteousnesse] Verse 7. Dan. IX. 24.

teach thee] Experimentaly, by its own actings, Psalm. XCVIII. 1. Esaias LXIII. 5.

Thine arrows] Heb. IV. 12. 2 Cor. II. 14, 15. and X. 4, 5. verse not so
properly suits to Solomon, or befits him. Therefore a greater then Solomon is
here, Matthew. XII. 42. Esaias XLIX. 2. Of these arrows is that true, 2 Samuel I. 22.
and 2 King. XIII. 17.

Thy Throne] Heb. I. 8. 2 Samuel VII. 16. Psalm. X. 16. Esaias IX. 7. Luke I. 33.
Dan. III. 44, 45. and VII. 14 Psalm. CXLV. 13. John XVIII. 36. Solomon, either
for the perpetuity of his Throne; or righteousness of his Scepter: But to
Christ, who is here called God.

the Scepter] Esaias XI. XCVI. 10.

Thou love righteousnesse] Esaias XI. 3, 4, 5. and chap. IX. 7. and LXI. 8.

Therefore] To that end and purpose anointed; not anointed for that cause and
merit, because he loved righteousness. As Esaias LXI. 1. And so is therefore to
be understood in the second verse aforegoing. So Genesis XVIII. 5. and XIX. 8.

God thy God] The first of these may be read either in the Nominative, or
Vocative case. The later is God anointing; who is truly the God of the Messiah;
as Psalm. XXII. 1.

has anointed] God anointed him to his Offices of Prophet, Priest, and King:
as such Officers were of old anointed, Exodus XXIX. 7. 1 Samuel IX. 16. 1 King.
XIX. 17. But this anointing here is to be understood of spiritual, inward,
invisible anointing, Acts X. 37, 38. And so Psalm. CV. 15. The Patriarchs are
styled anointed, who never were so outwardly with material oil. And this
spiritual Anointing here is the superabundant infusion of the gifts and graces
of the holy Ghost, not into the Divine nature of Christ properly, which is
incapable of grace infused, or of having any thing added to it; but into his
Humane nature, plentifuly furnishing him with all abilities and graces for his
execution of his said Offices, Luke IV. 17, -- 21. Esaias LXI. 1. Dan. IX. 24.
Yet as he is (...), Emmanuel, the Mediator, reserving ever the property of
either nature entire to it self, He may be said to be anionted in both natures,
taking anointed in that sense as it denotes the designation and inauguration of
him to his said Offices. And this Anointing may be appliable specialy to the
time of his Incarnation, of his Baptism, and of his Rising from the dead.

above thy fellows] Both Kings, Priests, and Prophets, Psalm. LXXXIX. 27. above
all his fellows, in nature, Heb. II. 14. in Christian Prerogatives, 1 John II.
20, 27. Apoc. I. 6. 1 Pet. II. 5, 9. And this both extensively, and
intensively; Esaias XI. 2. John I. 16. and III. 24.

garments] Are odoriferous,

out of the Ivory palaces] 2 Kings XXII. 39. Amos III. 15. 1 Kings X. 20.
Meaning, that either the King comes out of them, as the bridegroom; like that
Psalm. XIX. 5. Or that the garments were taken out of such palaces or coffers.

Whereby they have made thee glad] By those odoriferous smells and perfumes:
Prove. XXVII. 9. Or those that meet thee, or the bridegromes friends John III.
29. by their joyful acclamations and congratulations. Or, as some, more then
theirs that make thee glad, i. e. thy garments more odoriferous then theirs,
thy fellows and friends. All this was true in Solomon literaly. Much more in
Christ spiritualy and mysticaly. Whereof his Spouse makes use, Cant. I. 3. Esaias
LXI. 10.

Kings daughters] The daughters of minor-Kings, Judge. VIII. 18.

thy honorable women] Those beloved Virgins, intimated in the Title; honored
also by their invitation to this marriage, and honoring it, as the brides
maids.

thy right hand] The prime place next the King: as the left hand is the second
place; the King being in the middle. So Bathsheba, 1 King. II. 19. So Christ in
respect of his Humanity, Matthew. XXVI. 65.

did stand] Or sit; had her seat, or station. So both standing and sitting on
Gods right hand, in one and the same sense, are ascribed to our Savior, Mark
XVI. 19. Acts VII. 56. For us, See Ephesians. II. 6.

the Queene] This royal and honorable English word is very nigh the dishonest
name of a Queen. And so the Hebrew word here used (...) for a Queen, a wife,
is very nigh to the unseemely word (...): for which the Massorets, as more
mannerly forsooth, still in the margin put another word (...), Deuteronomy. XXVIII.
30. Esaias XIII. 16. Zech. XIV. 2. Jer. III. 2.

in gold] In cloth of gold; of threads of gold, of fine glistering gold, with
rings, chains, and bracelets of gold, the most pure and splendent gold, Job
XXXI. 24. Cant. V. 11. Dan. X. V. Of the several names of gold in the Hebrew,
see the Annotations on Job XXVIII. 15, -- 19.

of Ophir] See the Observations on 1 King. X. 11.

He arken] Matthew. XVII. 5. Romans X. 17.

O daughter] John I. 13. Apoc. XXI. 9, 10.

forget also] Luke IX. 23. and XIV. 26. Matthew. X. 37. As Abraham did, Genesis XII.
1. and Ruth, chap. I. 16, 17.

So shall] Upon these terms,

greatly desire] This true in Solomon. But Christ loves his Spouse first, 1
John IV. 10. Loves her in her blood, Ezekiel. XVI. 6.

thy Lord] 1 Pet. III. 6. Judge. XIX. 26. And that no common or vulgar person.
In the highest degree is Christ so to his Spouse the Church, even her Lord and
God.

Worship thou him] Pharaohs daughter was with civil worship to do it to
Solomon, with civil reverent incurvation and adoration. The Church to Christ,
with religious worship.

of Tyre] Of this City, Annotations on Amos I. 9. This rich Merchant-Citie,
the prime Mart for traffic, should bring to Solomon's Spouse gifts and nuptial
presents. And much more, Tire and all Heathen Nations should bring themselves,
and their Gifts, with all offices of submission and subjection, to the Spouse
of Christ, Esaias XLIX. 23. and LXVI. 12. Psalm. LXXXVII. 4.

the rich] Esaias LX. 3, 10, 11, 16.

glorious within] 1 Pet. II. 4, 5. Helen without, and Hecuba within. This true
in Solomon's Spouse partly. But in Christ's Spouse true altogether, by her
bridegroomes donation and operation, Ephesians. V. 27.

brought] With pomp,

of needle-work] As formerly costly for matter; so here curious for Art and
work. As the like, Exodus XXVIII. 6, 8, 15, 39.

with gladnesse] As is fit in marriage solemnities.

they be brought] The Spouse first; the Virgins and brides maids, following and
waiting on her; Cant. IV. 8. Apoc. XIX. 7, 8, 9. 2 Cor. XI. 2.

palace] As the wise Virgins, Matt. XXV. 10.

thy children] We read not that Pharaoh's daughter had any child by Solomon.
Esaias XLIX. 18, -- 21. and LIVE. 1, 2, 3. Heb. II. 13.

I will] Says the Psalmist; by himself;

thy Name] The name of the Bridegroom.

therefore] By my example; as well as for all the reasons foregoing in this
Psalm.

praise thee] Christ the Bridegroom, for ever and ever: whereas Solomon by his
foul fall worthily merited and inherited shame and dispraise.

present help] Deliverer;

will not we fear] Though a natural fear; as Prove. XIV. 16. and XXII. 3. Matthew.
VIII. 26. yet not a godless, and faithless fear. Here faith triumphs over
such a fear.

though the earth] Hyperbolical expressions, usualy intimating the fearful
alterations of States, and Polities; or the most dreadful dangers.

a river] Alluding to that of Kidron, Gihon, Shiloah: intending chiefly that,
Ezekiel. XLVII. 1. Joel III. 18. Apoc. XXII. 1. Or, the meaning of this seems
best expounded in the next verse; and in the two verses following.

He maketh] Esaias XLV. 7. Amos III. 6. Psalm. LXXVI. 3.

Exalted] Esaias XXXIII. 9, 10. and XXX. 15.

O clap] A sign of joyful acclamation used at the coronation of Kings 2 Kings
XI. Ezekiel. XXV. 6. See Psalm. XCVIII. 8. Esaias LV. 12. Psalm. LXVI. 1. The Psalmist
exhorts all people to sing Praises unto God, ver. 1. 7. A thing usual in the
Psalms.

For the Lord] Reasons, from Gods nature and properties; Mal. I. 14. Matt.
XXVIII. 18.

He shall subdue] The Jews enemies. Ezekiel. XX. 37.

He shall choose] He did choose Canaan for his people Israel, Psalm. LXXVIII.
55. Canaan, that inheritance incorruptible, 1 Pet. I. 4. for all that believe
and hope in him.

for us] The Jews seeming here to include the Gentiles, as called by Christ
into the same communion of the Covenant, for grace, and glory, John X. 16. Ephesians.
II. 14.

the excellency of Jacob] High and glorious excellency, whereby Jacobs
posterity excelled, Ezekiel. XXIV. 21. Amos VI. 8. and VIII. 7. Nahum. II. 2. viz.
the Temple, Priesthood, etc. all those most excellent and precious promises and
blessings made in Christ unto Jacob, and his posterity.

God is gone up] When the Ark was carried from Kiriathjearim to the house of
Obed Edom: David: thence by Solomon into the Oracle: 1 Chronicles. XIII. 8. and XV.
28. and 2 Chronicles. V. 13. Spiritualy and mysticaly, when Christ ascended with
triumph into heaven. See Ephesians. IV. 8. Col. II. 15.

the King of all the earth] The universal Kingdom of God, and of Christ. verse
8. Differing from earthly Kings.

with understanding.] 1 Cor. XIV. 15. The word Maschil is here used for Psalm,
which is the Title of sundry Psalms, signifying an instructing Psalm. Thereby
to instruct your selves, and others, of the Kingdom of God, and Christ; and of
your duty.

of throne of his holinesse] Psalm. IX. 4. Apoc. IV. 2.

The Princes] The voluntary,

of the God of Abraham] His spiritual seed, Luke III. 8. VIII. 33. etc. Romans
IV. 16, 17.

Sheilds] He is the great Shield, Genesis XV. 1. Psalm. V. 12. and XVIII. 35. the
great conqueror, and protector of all. And Magistrates Sheilds under him; Hos.

greatly exalted] Psalm. XCVII. 9.

A Song and Psalme] used; the voice began, and the instrument after; And where
the Inscription is a Psalm and Song, there likely the instrument began, and
the voice followed. Of the former sort are, as this Psalm; to Psalm. LXVI.
LXXXIII. CVIII. Of the later, are Psalm. LXVII. LXVIII. LXXV. LXXXVII. and XCII.

whole earth] Or Land of Judea. Exodus X. 15. and most likely Matthew. XXVII. 45.

the sides of the North] The Temple on Mount Moriah, and the City of Jerusalem,
joined North to Mount Sion. Moriah is the North part of Sion. So Esaias XIV. 13.

the Kings were assembled] The Philistian Princes, 2 Samuel V. or those
Jehoshaphat, 2 Chronicles. XX. or of Ezekiah, 2 Kings XVIII. Upon some of which
occasions this Psalm seems to be composed and inspired, Psalm. XLVI. 6.

marvailed, and were troubled] At Sions beauty,

Thou breakest] As in a Shipwreck; Sam. V. 20.

Tarshish] See the Observations on 1 Kings X. 22.

East wind] See Ezekiel. XVII. 10. and XIX. 12. Hos. XII. 1. and Chapter XIII. 15.
Jonah IV. 8.

As we have heard] Psalm. XLIV. 1.

seene] By experience.

because of thy judgements] In confounding thine enemies,

tell the towers] Mark if any of them be demolished,

that ye may tell it] How God had preserved and kept them.

a parable] A sententious, Prove. I. 6. not beseeming simple ones, Prove. XXVI.
7. used by Balaam, Number. XXIII. and XXIV. by Ezekiel at Gods command, chap.
XVII. 2. and XX. 49. and much by our Savior himself in his preaching, Matthew.
XIII. 35. sometimes in plainer manner, Mark IV. 33 sometimes in intended
obscurity, Luke VIII. 10. requiring sharpness of wit to understanded and
expound them. Here the Psalmists extraordinary Preface ushering it in; and this
enigmatical manner of delivering it, argues the matter to be of great weight and
difficulty. As indeed it is that which so much troubles and puzleth the wisest
and the best men of the world; the afflictions and miseries of the godly, and
the prosperities of the wicked. See Psalm. XXXVII. 1. and LXXIII. 2, 12. and
XCIV. 3, 4. Job XXI. 7, 13. Jer. XII. 1. Hab. I. 4, 5. And the wicked thereby
take encouragement to evil, and nourish impious conceits in their hearts
touching God, and his providence; Job XXI. 14, 15. Psalm. X. 3, 6, 11, 13. and
XIV. 1. and XCIV. 7, 8. Mal. II, 17. and III. 15. See more of this in the
Observations on Psalm. XXXVII. 1.

should I fear?] The godly should not fear,

boast] The wicked, and wealthy,

wise men die] Eccl. II. 16. and III. 19.

Their inward thought] They hunted after honor,

Neverthelesse] They shall have no more good by their honors, Psalm. XXXVII.
36. 1. John II. 17.

abides not] Heb. Abides not for a night. Which text many Jews, and other
Writers, both old and new, do urge for their opinion, that Adam fell the same
day wherein he was created; which point the great Linguist and Chronologer
Master Hugh Broughton does press and prosecute, even with some heat, and
overmuch passion, at large. But the learned Gataker does clear this text from
any such meaning, and gives reasons most probable, That Adam did not fall the
same day wherein he was created, in his Cinnus, p. 189. -- 198.

yet their posterity] Not warned thereby; Psalm. X. 3.

like sheep] Rotten sheep that die of themselves.

feel on them] And devour them.

and the upright] The righteous in Christ, men of sincere integrity.

in the morning] Of the resurrection; when Christ the Sun of righteousness
shall arise at his second coming.

But God] This answers that question, verse 5.

will redeem, etc.] Raise up my body, and receive me into everlasting life;
which is here opposed to all the worldly prosperity of faithless wicked men.
See Genesis V. 24. Psalm. LXXIII. 24. John XIV. 3. Acts VII. 15. 1 These. IV. 14. A
clear testimony of the resurrection of the body, the immortality of the soul,
and the life everlasting.

Be not thou afraid] Stumble not,

never see light] Job XXXIII. 28, 30. Psalm. LVI. 13. nor the light of heaven,
Matthew. VIII. 12.

man] Verse 12.

beasts] The Sheep, verse 14.

Asaph] Either the Author, Chron. XXIX. 30. Or chief Singer; to whom, and his

it, and sing it, and play it upon musical instruments. And thus, Psalm. LXXIII.
to LXXXIII. are entitled all to, or for Asaph.

The mighty God] God himself is brought in as a Judge upon the Bench,

But unto the wicked] Here God sentenceth those gross hypocrites that place
all Religion in outward Rites and Ceremonies: Psalm.

And speak against] Psalm. LXIX. 13. Psalm. XXVI. 4. 5.

Nathan] To reprove him for his sin, Sam. XI. and XII. chapters. Written,

gone in] Genesis VI. 4.

Bathsheba] The daughter of Eliam, 2 Samuel XI. 3. called also Bathshua, daughter

Have mercie] A rare example of repentance:

wash me] And so verse 7. Levit. XI. 25, 32. Exodus XIX. 10. Number. XIX. 19. Thus
he prays, and thus he deals throughout this Psalm; even after Nathans

For I acknowledge] Prove. XXVIII. 13. 1. John I. 9. So Esaias LIX. 12. Jer. III.
13.

Cited, Romans III. 4. with no variation in sense.

thee only] Not because he a King, and so exempt from the power of others: Sam.

should so suffer in this his sin; 2 Samuel XII. 14. who yet only could pardon
his sin, Matthew. IX. 3. as against whom, and whose commandment properly, all
sin is committed.

in thy sight] God then sees the sins of his Saints; yea more, he is offended
with them, reproves them, makes his Saints smart for them; as in the Scripture
plentifully appears. That place Number. XXIII. 21. is blindly brought against this
truth, as if they would make God a blind idol, and not an omniscient God. Or,
as if that text had not relation to the Saints under the Old Testament, before
that grace, which they say, is given in the New.

that thou might be justified] Acquitted, glorified, by this my confession,
Josh. VII. 19.

when thou speakest] In thy reproof by Nathan.

and be clear] Clearly overcome, be unreprovable, and win the victory in
judgment.

when thou judgest] In sentencing my sin, and my punishment for it: Or, when
thou art judged; in the opinion of men, and in their censures, for thy dealing
with me. Saint Paul citing these words, Romans III. 4. applies them from the
hypothesis, in David's singular case; to the thesis, to Gods general faith and
truth in all his promises and proceedings. And thus the injustice of man does
commend the justice of God.

in iniquity] This we call Original sin. Romans VII. 17. whereby all men are
carnal, sold under sin, John III. 6. Romans VII. 14. The fountain of actual
sins, John IX. 34. Ephesians. II. 1. So as whole man is in evil, and whole evil
is in man.

the hidden part] The hid man of the heart, 1 Pet. III. 4.

thou shall make me] Thus rising up by faith to this hope: have made me; thus
opposing that integrity which God requires, to his present state of corruption
by his foul fall contracted.

to know wisdome] 1 John II. 4. by his sin now eclipsed.

with hysop] Exodus XII. 22. Levit. XIV. 4, 6, 49. Number. XIX. 6, 18. Heb. IX. 19.

Create] Ephesians. II. 10. and IV. 24. Jer. XXXII. 39. Ezekiel. XI. 19. and XXXVI. 26.

take not] Yet Gods holy Spirit was in him; even in this case,

free spirit] Freely and bountifully bestowed, freeing me from the bondage of
sin, making me free to righteousness, 2 Cor. III. 17. Romans VI. 18. 22.

blood-guiltinesse] Bloods of Uriah, and others slain with him.

Open thou my lips] Give me new occasion by the pardoning of my sin:

not Sacrifice] See the Observations on Psalm. XL. 6. Indeed we find not
expressed any sacrifice for murder,

the Sacrifices] The plural number is here used for the greater emphasis, and

20. Mal. I. 6. Lam. III. 22. 2. Sam, XXII. 1.

unto Sion] The whole Church was in danger of Gods judgment by his sin: Sam.
XXIV. 15.

and whole-burnt-offering] See Levit. VI. 23.

the Edomite] Of Edom, Idumea* or Adonite, from Adam, a City in Reuben; or
Admah, a City in Judah; or Adam* a town in Naphtali; or Adummin, in the
borders of Judah and Benjamin. The History of this is in 1 Samuel XXI. and XXII.
chapters. Here we have David's (...) ^ation of Doeg; and imprecation against
him; and his own glorious (...) in God.

This (...) ^uch like the fourteenth Psalm. Psalm are much alike.

(...) Citizens of Ziph in the tribe of Judah,

said (...)] This they did twice, 1 Samuel XXIII. 19. and again, chap. XX^I. 1.

strangers] Though of the same tribe, Job complains, chap. XIX. 13, 14, 15. and
so estranged from God, Psalm. LVIII. 3. No strangers more strange then they that
cast off the bands of civility, and nature, wherein they were bound.

cut them off in thy wrath.] Psalm. CXLIII. 12. Of Imprecations, see the
Observations on Psalm. CIX. 14.

and make a noise] In the earnestness of his Prayer,

cast inquity upon me] From themselves upon me,

my heart] Psalm. XXXI. 9, -- 12.

O that I had] A passionate with, Psalm. XIV. 7.

flee away] As a bird, Psalm. XI. 1. swiftly and speedily.

wildernesse] As Apoc.

divide their tongues] Their language, Genesis XI. 7. 2 Samuel XVII. 1, 5, 14.

not an enemie] Psalm. XLI. 9. John XIII. 18.

mine equal] My Peer, Achitophel: and the whole Psalm, to his distress in
his flight from Absalom, and his conspiracy.

quick into hell] As Number.

Evening, VI. 10. Acts III. 1. and chap. X. 9.

battel] 2 Samuel XXVII. 2, 3.

because they have no changes] In their temporal estate and prosperity, Job X.
17. ( David therefore blesses God for afflictions, Psalm CXIX. 67, 71.) which
yet should have made them change from evil to good; but it wrought no change in
them, but the contrary; they were in evil unchangable, Jer. XIII. 23.

drawn swords] Psalm. LVII. 4. and LIX. 7. and Prove. XII. 18. and XXX. 14.

cast thy burden] 1 Pet.

half their dayes] Job XV. and XXI. 21. Psalm. XXXVII. 35, 36. Jeremie XVII. 11.
Eccles. VIII. 12, 13.

Jonath Elem Rechokim] Many take not these words for a musical instrument;
concerning the dumb Dove in a far place; understanding them of David himself,
and his case and condition now in Gath. See Psalm. XXXIV. and the Title. Of
Gath, see the Annotations on Amos VI. 2. Michtam is a jewel, or golden Psalm.

I am afraid, I will trust in thee] Faith and Fear stand together. And so Fear
and Love.

In God I will praise his Word] So again verse 10. 1 Samuel XXX. 6. in his word
and promise. Psalms, is not worth the while to take notice of them.

shall they escape by iniquity?] It is not fit so to do. Psalm. VII. 15. and IX.
15. and X. 2. Prove. V. 22.

my wandrings] From Saul's presence to Gath. Adullam; to Mizpeh in Moab; to the
Forest of Hareth in Judah; to Keilah; to the Wilderness of Ziph; of Maon; to
Engedi: hunted as a Partridge in the Mountains.

wilt not thou] Verse 9. 2 Cor. I. 10. Surely thou will, Psalm. CXVI. 8. 9.

Al-taschith] That is, Destroy not: which seems to be the subject matter of
this Psalm. The same is in the Titles of Psalm. LVIII. LIX. LXXV. Possibly the
word here may relate to that, 1 Samuel XXVI. 9. though that fell out after his
being in the Cave.

Cave] 1 Samuel XXIV. 3. And in the Cave he made a Prayer, which is the CXLII.
Psalm.

performs all things for me] Psalm. CXXXVIII. 8. Phil. I. 6.

Some understand this Psalm in this sense, Psalm, exclude all, or any
relation had to Saul, and his wicked Courtiers.

Doye] He appeals to their consciences.

speak righteousnesse] Or dumb justice: boasting so to do, when indeed justice
was dumb, and opened not her mouth.

O congregation] O assembly, company of Saul's Courtiers and Counselors;
complying with the King against David.

you weigh] Not justice;

from the womb] Esaias XLVIII. 8. John IX. 34. Ephesians. IV. 18. Jer. XIII. 23.

Charmers] The Addars craft against them is recorded by diverse Authors. Acts
VII. 57. Charmers seem to practice thus upon Addars, Eccles. X. 11. Jer. VIII.
17. And Charmers are forbidded by Gods Law, Deuteronomy. XVIII. 11. Yet this may seem
a proverbial speech used by David, without any purpose to maintain either the
truth of the thing in matter of fact, no more then Sirenum voces, or Cygnea
cantio do prove such things to be; or else the lawfulness of it in relation to
God and his Law. And Proverbs and Similitudes may be taked from things in
themselves unlawful; as from a thief, Apoc. XVI. 15. the unjust Steward, Luke
XVI. 18.

O God] The plural word Elohim here used is most times meant of one true God in
the singular number. Genesis XX. 13. and XXXV. 7. And so may be understood that in
Exodus XXXII. 1. and verse 4. comparing therewith Neh. IX. 18.

Before your pots can feel the thornes] The general meaning is plain, verses.
Yet this proves a thorny text, to expound aright the simiiude of thorns here
used, and the rest of the words contained in this verse. Pots, thorns, living,
are words here of various significations; whence three maine renditions and
interpretations do arise, thus: Before your pots can feel the fire of thorns,
which is short, Eccles. VII. 6. so shall God take them away, as raw (flesh) by
the heat of his indignation. Or thus, as quick, or as yet living, and
flourishing, in his wrath. Or thus, Ere men shall perceive your young springs
of thorns grow to a perfect pricking bramble, God will as with a whirlewinde
destroy every one of them, even as alive or quick, even in wrath as in burning
anger. Thus speaking to the wicked, of their sudden destruction. Or thus, As
raw flesh is snatched out of the pot, or flesh snatched out of the pot, being
yet raw, before the heat of that light bramble-fire be come to it; so God, etc.
Thus variously we may extend our minds and meanings; without any peremptory
determination of any one particular.

wash his feet] As Psalm. Esaias LXIII. 3. Mal. IV. 3. Apoc. XIV. 20.

at evening] Saul's messengers watching the house to kill David. verse 14.

of his strength] Saul's. Deuteronomy. V. 10. Dan. IX. 4. Mich. I. 2. meaning David's
strength. And so it is verse 17.

my mercie] So by the vowels, his mercy.

Slay them not] At once; verse 13. he says Consume them -- that they may not
be. And in the next words, and let them know. All which may so well agree
together, as needs no words of reconciliation.

Shushan-Eduth] Shushan signifies an instrument of six strings, from (...)
six; or a Lilly called (...), because it consists of six leaves: Eduth
signifies Testimony; either implying this Psalm to be a testimony of David's
