faith and thankfulness; or to be sung by the Priests before the Ark of the
testimony; or rather, being joined to the former word by a Maccaph, as in some
kind a part of it, it makes up the name of the musical instrument.

to teach] The Doctrine in this Psalm contained; that all might learn it. As
Deuteronomy. XXXI. 19. 2 Samuel I. 18. 2 Chronicles. XXXV. 25.

when he strove] See the Histories, 2 Samuel VIII. 13. 1 Chronicles. XVIII. 12. And
see the Observations on 2 Samuel VIII. 5, 13.

Edom] The Edomites joining with the Syrians.

in the valley of salt] At the South end of the dead Sea. Or, that called the
valley of Siddim, Genesis XIV. 8. Or the valley of Saveh, verse* 17.

twelve thousand] And after in the pursuit of the victory, six thousand, or
these six thousand, by Abishai, before the main battle. From both does arise
the number of eighteen thousand. Which victory being archieved by David's two
Generals, Joab and Abishai, both under him, is ascribed to each of these three,
in the places before cited. And as David, and his Generals, obtained a victory
here, 2 Samuel VIII. 13. So afterward did Amatziah slay of Edom in the valley of
Salt 10000. And other 10000. were cast down the top of the rock, or Selah, or
Petra; which Amatziah took by war, and they all were broken in pieces, 2
King. XIV. 7. 2 Chronicles. XXV. 11, 12.

Thou have given] Now a banner of conquest and victory.

That] From hence to the end accords with Psalm. CVIII. 6,

I will reioyce] David by reason of Gods truth, Judea, and those bordering
about it.

I will divide] This implies a possession first.

Shechem] It was a City in Mount Ephraim near Samaria; given to the
Kohathites-Levites, and a City of Refuge. Abram came thither. Jacob had his
daughter Dinah ravished there. Joshua thither gathers all Israel, and renues
Gods Covenant with them a little before his death. The Shechemites conspire
against the house of Gideon to make Abimelech King, and he destroys them.
Thither Rehoboam came to be made King; but Jeroboam gains the Kingdom of
Israel, builds, or repairs Shechem, and dwells in it. Of this see the
Annotations on Hos. VI. 9.

Succoth] Not that in Egypt, Exodus XII. 37. But that where Jacob built booths,
Genesis XXXIII 5. Afterward a City in the Tribe of Gad, upon the river Jabbok,
East of Jordan; justly destroyed by Gideon, Judge. VIII. But repaired after.

Gilead is mine] Thus David triumphs in having, Judea beyond Jordan, though
they stood longest out for Ishbosheth, Saul's son.

Moab is my washpot] I can and will use it to base offices, Sam. 2. VIII. Psalm.
CVIII. 9.

Over Edom] Trample it under foot, or use it to base offices. See Matt. III.
11. as to pull off my shoe, to wipe my shoe; or as Sapores the Persian used
Valerian the Romand Emperor; or Temerlan the Scythian used Bajazeth the Turk;
or Pope Alexander the third used Frederik the Emperor; and Pope Caelestine the
third did to Henry the Emperor: bring it to a base and ignominious subjection.

triumph thou] An ironical apostrophe, or bitter mock to Philistia, or the
Philistines, in the West border of Palestine. And diverse such ironies are in
Scripture; See the Observations on Amos IV. 4.

who will] The answer is in the two next verses.

Through God] David's wish, Chron. XIX. 13.

From the end of the earth] Of Judea; Saul, or Absalom rather, 2 Samuel XVII. 24.

prolong] In this likely David has a principal eye to Christ.

once, twice] See the like Job XL. 5.

mercy; for thou renderest] Even reward it self is of mercy.

in the wilderness of Judah.] Sam. XXII. 5. and XXIII. 14, 15. Thus David's
Psalms are not set down in this Book according to the Order of time, and
occasions, wherein, and whereupon they were made and inspired.

seen thee in the Sanctuary] David's desires to the Sanctuary, Psalm. XXVII. 4.
and LXV. 4.

meditate] David's night-meditations.

my soul follows hard after thee] 1 Cor. VI. 17. Phil. III. 13, 14.

that swears by him] Swearing here taken for the whole worship of God, Deuteronomy.
VI. 13. Esaias XLV. 23. and LXV. 16. Of Swearing; see the Observations on Hos.
IV. 15.

O thou that hear prayer, to thee] An heavenly encouragement to Prayer.

choosest, and causest] Gods free grace; not man's free will.

Thou visitest the earth] This Psalm may seem composed after some year of
famine.

with the river of God] The rain, Deuteronomy. XI. 10, 11.

submit] Though feignedly and falsely, Psalm. XVIII. 44. 1 Samuel XXII. 45. As the
faithful shall obey God willingly and sincerely.

with the incense of rams] Meaning their fat which was burned on the Altar:
Levit. II. 1, 2, 16. and VI. 15.

If I regard] John IX. 31. IV. 3. Job XXVII. 8, 9. Prove. I. 28, 29. Esaias I. 15.
Micah III. 4. Ezekiel. VIII. 18. Prove. XV. 29. He that turns away his ear from
hearing the Law, his prayer is abomination, Prove. XXVIII. 9.

David penned by inspiration this Psalm; over the Philistines, and other
neighboring enemies; and upon the occasion of that public joyful solemnity in
bringing the Arc into the City of David, 2 Samuel VI. 1 Chronicles. XIII. XIV. XV.
chapters. It consists most of Praises, and Prophesies.

Let God] These words Moses used, Number. X. 35 at the removing of the Arc and
Tabernacle from Mount Sinai. And may be taken as a Prayer, or a Prediction; or
an assertion of what is done when God thus arises.

arise] To help his: to scatter his enemies. See Psalm. III. 7. and X. 12. and
LIX. 5.

extol him that rides upon the heavens] Verse 33. Psalm. XVIII. 10. Deuteronomy.
XXXIII. 26. Esaias 19. 1. some translate thus, make an highway for him; prepare
it, as Esaias XL. 3, 4. Matthew. III. 2. Luke I. 76. as Matthew. XXI. 8. And thus was
done. Or thus, him that rides in the Deserts; that is, as he did in the
Wilderness of Arabia before his Arc and people, verse 7. This variety of
interpretation is of small concernment.

Jah] Some would have it the contract of (...) as (...) is of (...), if not of
(...), to signify the strong God. Jah is used again, ver. 18. God is called
also by the Heathens (...) and Jove or Jupiter, that is Iah-father; deemed by
Varro to be the God of the Jews. This is the proper name of God, Esaias XLII. 8.
Exodus VI. 3. 2 Chronicles. VI. 33. Acts XVII. 23, 25, 28. Psalm. LXXXIII. 18. See
more in the Observations on Esaias XXVI. 4.

habitation] Of heaven; ^ings VIII. 30, 38, 39.

solitary in families] Senseless here is the Popish text; Bellarmines
interpretation, and application. See Exodus I. 21. Psalm. CXIII. 9. Ruth IV. 11.

a dry land] Without fountains of waters, or showers of rain. A special
judgment in those hot countries.

when thou wentest forth] Judge. Egypt; in giving them the possession of Canaan;
in destroying the Kings their enemies, verse 7 -- 13.

The earth shook] Ezod. XIX. 18. Judge. V. 4. Psalm. CXIV. and CIV. 32. Heb. XII.
18.

Sinai] An hill of a great height. Of Sinai see more in the Observations on
Exodus II. 11. and on XIX. 3.

a plentiful raine] God did bless his inheritance of the Land of Canaan which
he gave to them, Canaan, and all temporal promises, and earthly blessings to
them were shadows and types, intimations, and pledges of spiritual blessings,
and eternal life in heaven; Heb. XI. 13, -- 16 and 26. John V. 39.

gave the word] The occasion; Psalm. CXVIII. 23.

of those that published it] The word here is of the feminine gender; and so
may be understood of maids and women, entertaining, and publishing these good
news of victories with Songs and melody. As Exodus XV. 20. Judge. V. 11. and XI.
34. 1 Samuel XVIII. 6. Or of men, as the feminine is used for a masculine, in
Koheleth, Eccl. I. 1. Such publishers, as 2 Samuel XVIII. 19.

did flee] Deuteronomy. Exodus XIV. 25, 27. Josh. X. 11, 16. Judge. V. 19, 22. and VIII.
12. 2 Samuel V. 25. And in this verse again, the Popish text scarce bears any
sense; and their interpretations are suitable.

though ye have lien among the pots] A promise and consolation for the future:
Heli and Saul ye have lien in black darkness of afflictions, as a Skullion
lies in a Camp or Leaguer among pots.

as the wings of a Dove] Shining and bright.

When the Almighty] (...),

scattered] Dispersed, discomfited, vanquished the Kings by his powerful
presence, that they did flee apace, verse 12. Or, when he shall so do: so
continuing and amplifying the former Promise.

Kings] His, and their enemies, in Canaan.

in it] In thy inheritance, wherein thy Congregation did dwell.

it was white] An emblem of prosperity and joy; shall be black no more, as
verse 13. but joyous and prosperous: or, white with the dead bones of the
scattered slaughtered enemies.

Salmon] Judge. IX. 48. A Mountain nigh Shechem, and Samaria, in the tribe of
Ephraim, not far from Jordan: likely snow was much upon it.

as the hill of Bashan] Of Bashan, Annotations on Micah VII. 14. The hill of
Sion does equal, yea excel it; by reason of all its spiritual prerogatives and
privileges; as verse 16. Or thus, the Hill of Bashan is an hill of God, i. e.
a most excellent hill; for so the Hebrews express the most excellent things.
See the Observations on Jonah III. 3. and on 1 Samuel XIV. 15. It is an high
hill. All this is true: yet falls short of the hill of Sion; as it is in the
next verse.

Why leap ye] Insult proudly, Sion.

dwell] Psalm. LXXXVII. 1, 2. and CXXXII. 13, 14. This does infinitely advance
this humble hill of Sion above you.

for ever] And not flit with his Ark and Tabernacle from place to place, as
formerly.

The Chariots] Gods glory in Sion by the multitudes of his ministering Angels,
Heb. XII. 22. as it was in Sinai, when he gave the fiery Law, Deuteronomy. XXXIII. 2.
Gal. III. 19. Acts VII. 53. Or rather these words may have a direct relation to
the glorious manner of Christ's Ascension, with the attendance of infinite
Angels. Angels appeared and ministered at his Incarnation, Luke II. 9, 13. Heb.
I. 6. And why not so, or more, at his Ascension into the highest heavens? See
Acts I. 10. well might the Angels then sing that song, Apoc. V. 11, 12. We read
of a Charet of fire, and horses of fire at the rapture of Elias. And of a
mountain full of horses and Charets of fire round about Eliseus in his defense.
And why not these Angels here to attend our Saviors triumphant Ascension, set
down in the next verse.

Thou have ascended] Literaly and typicaly true, David. But without any type,
it is Mysticaly most tr^e, and most verified in Christ, and his Ascension into
Heaven. And so David here turns his speech to Christ himself. Whereunto the
Apostle does apply it, Ephesians. IV. 8. Ascended in his humane nature properly. In
Ephesians. IV. 8, 9, 10. He is said to descend; which being understood of his Divine
nature, is spoken improperly. But Christ being God and Man in one person, That
one Person without dissolving it, by reason of the Union of both natures in it,
admits properly and truly of such speeches as contain the Proprieties of
either Nature; the natures themselves, and their properties, nevertheless
remaining ever realy distinguished. The person then of Christ, without the
conversion of the one Nature into the other, in proper speech did ascend in his
Humanity, by the power of his Deity; localy from mount Olivet, into that third
heaven of Paul, which our Savior calls his Fathers house, John XIV. 2. above
these visible heavens, Ephesians. IV. 10. Our Saviors humane Nature then is
contained in Heaven, Acts III. 21. is not in the Popish hoasts; and much less
every where, according to the Ubiquitarian fancy. Though a time was, when
Christ in his body was in the grave; in his soul in Paradise, in his Divine
nature or Deity every where; yet without dissolving the Unity of his Person.

captivity captive] Lead and taken them captives; or a multitude of captives;
subdued thine enemies unto thee, made them thy captives Judge. V. 12. Not
leading the Fathers out of Limbus Patrum; but captiving the World, and the
Flesh, Sin, and Satan, Death, and Damnation, which otherwise held Gods people
in captivity and slavery. Col. I. 15.

received gifts for men] Taken gifts for them i. e. receiving, gave; as the
phrase is, Exodus XXV. 2. And in diverse other places taking is used for giving,
1 King III. 24* and XVII. 10. Judge. XIV. 2. And giving is sometimes used for
taking, as Genesis XLII. 30. What the chief of the Gifts were, are specified,
Ephesians. IV. 11, 12.

rebellious also] Even the most averse and rebellious of them, that God might
dwell in them; as Soul made a Paul, Tit. III. 3, 4, 5.

dwell in them] Jah in them; not they dwell in the Church.

Blessed] David blesses God,

loadeth us] With those gifts and blessings which Christ received for us, verse
18.

and unto God the Lord] Here (...) has the points of Elohim, Adonai* And so
still when (...) and Adonai are joined together, lest otherwise Adonai should
be twice read. But where Adonai is not conjoined, (...) has the pricks of
Adonai more often then of Elohim. Or, Jehovi here may be used as a more
pathetical kind of expression; as in Genesis XV. 2, 8. Deuteronomy. III. 24.

issues from death] As 1 Cor. X. 13.

But God] This seems to be the fruit and powerful effect of Christ's Ascension,

The Lord said] Number. Exodus XIV. 13, 14. i. e. as I did from Og, King of Bashan;
and from Pharaoh at the red sea. Thus he recals to their memories these two
great victories: and to strengthen their faith for like victories over their
enemies in David's days, or in times of future extremities.

thy foot may be dipped] So great should the slaughter of them be. Jehu did, 2
Kings IX. 10, 36.

thy goings] In the procedure of the verse, Genesis XLIX. 9. And it is very
frequent with the Hebrews to pass from one person to another. Thy goings then
and thy doings, thy ways and administrations, i. e. when God marched out of
Egypt, through the Wilderness before his people: or when David brought the Ark
into Jerusalem.

The singers] All sorts,

damzels] As Exodus XV. 20, 21. Judge. V. 1. and Chap. XI. 34. 1 Samuel XVIII. 9, 7.

Bless ye God] The beginning of their song, from the fountain of Israel] Ye
that flow from that fountain, are of that progeny, Esaias XLVIII. 2. Deuteronomy.
XXXIII. 28. Deuteronomy. V. 15, 18.

There is] Both those near, Psalm. LX. 9.

little Benjamin] The youngest son of Jacob; and least Tribe, since their
fatal blow, Judge. XX. and contesting most for Saul's house against David. Yet he
here one, if not first among them. And all the rest likewise^joyne.

ruler] Of the enemies; or rather, of the Benjamites; but no way of the other
Tribes.

Thy God] He petitions for strength and growth of blessings;

has commanded] So Deuteronomy. XXVIII. 8. Psalm. CXXXIII. 2. XLII. 8. and XLIV. 4.
and LXXI. 3. See Psalm. XXXIII. 9. Matthew. VIII. 8, 9.

thy strength] The strength of the King, and of the people.

Because of thy Temple] Because of thy Promises made to thy Church,

Shall Kings] David, and his successors shall therefore with all grateful and
thankful acknowledgement worship thee.

Rebuke] He petitions against the adversaries of the Church, cruel, and
malicious* Rebuke them in word, and deed. The meaning is contained in the last
words of the verse.

the company of spear-men] Of enemies armed with Lances and Spears; or Reeds
fitted and used for Spears; or arrows, as the manner of those times was.

bulls with the calves] The robustick and strong enemies; with the rest of the
rude and Epicurish multitude, Psalm. XXII. 12. Amos. IV. 1.

submit himself with pieces of silver*] Though hypocriticaly. Or rather, that
glories and vaunts himself in his brave attire embroydered with pieces of
silver* and out-braves and tramples upon others; or is so rich, as he seems to
tread silver under foot, yet indeed trusts in it, and boast himself of it. And
such usually, though unprovoked, delight to break forth into war and
wrong-doing: such enemies of thy people rebuke and break.

Princes] Prophesying of the calling of the Gentiles to Christ, Ephesians. III. 5,
6. Esaias XLIX. 6. and LXVI. 19.

stretch out her hands] In prayer, in offerings, in way of subjection.

a mighty voice] Psalm. XXIX. His thunder, Heb. IV. 11.

Ascribe] Adds arguments for Gods praise.

terrible] To be had in reverence in the assembly of his Saints;

fail while I waite] The constancy and earnestness of David's hope and
expectation.

For the zeal of thine house] Literaly true in David, Psalm. XXVII. 8.
Principaly true in Christ the Son of David; and to him applied by his
disciples, John II. 15, 16, 17. And so are the later words of this verse, by
the Apostle, Romans XV. 3.

They gave me also gall] Verified in our Savior: John XIX. 28, 29.

Let their table] This used by David against his enemies: Romans XI. 9.

Let their habitation] That which David speaks here of his enemies; Peter
applies to Judas the traitor, Acts I. 20.

blotted out] Phil. IV. 3. Apoc. III. 5. Luke X. 20. Heb. XII. 23. Observations
on Psalm. CIX. 14, 15.

Sion] The Type of the Church.

inherit it] Under the temporal promises of the Land of Canaan, Psalm. CII. 28.
to the true Israel of God, the true members of the Church, Esaias XLIV. 26.

for to bring to remembrance] For to record. Psalm. XXXVIII. Both Psalms are,
not to remember any notable deliverance or benefit already received: But rather
a time and case of affliction and distress. For the matter of both show, that
they were inspired in such a time; and do make earnest petition for deliverance.

to deliver me] This Psalm is in a manner the same with Psalm. XL. 13, -- 17.

Cause me to escape] Likely from Absalom. Psalm may seem to be penned by
David, though his name be not in the Title, and in his old age.

God.] This word is Jehovih, Elohim. So again verse 16. and Psalm. LXVIII. 20.
And so it is usually written when, as I have said, Adonai goes before it, or
next follows it. At other times having the vowels of Adonai, it is pronounced
Lord. See 2 Samuel VII. 18, 19, 20.

a wonder] Esaias VIII. 18. Heb. II. 13. Zech. III. 8. and 1 Corinthians. IV. 9.

even of thine only] not mine own:

quicken me again, in the Hebrew margin; but us, us, in the text.

For Solomon] Made by David for him; verse ult* by David in his old age. The
like inscription is Psalm. CXXVII.

This Psalm is composed, as in the name of the Church. And contains a Prayer,
a Praise, and a Prophecy, of the just, peaceable, righteous, merciful,
plentiful, flourishing estate, and large extent and bounds of the Kingdom of
Solomon; set out indeed with some hyperbolical expressions; scarcely appliable
to him, or to any mortal man. So as Solomon may be the immediate object of the
words, he literaly intended in them. But yet he so, as a Type of Christ, and of
his Kingdom; who is in truth the maine subject of this Psalm. For all in a
mystical sense is appliable to Christ more truly, then to Solomon; appliable to
him in a spiritual sense, exactly without any hyperbole. For Solomon, see that
2 Samuel VII. 14. etc. For Christ, see that Heb. I. 5. And that passadge, Psalm.
LXXXIX. 19, -- 37. is not unlike the subject matter of this Psalm. This
premised, may serve to clear the hardest places of this Psalm.

The prayers] Psalms,

are ended] As the like is said of David's words, 2 Samuel XXIII. 1. The one may
be as an Appendix of the other. This his last Prayer, though not placed in the
last place. Or the last of those that David set in order before his death: or
the last in this second part or book of the Psalms, as they are all divided
into five parts. Or his last, touching Solomon; and his prophesying of Christ
and his Kingdom. So various may our thoughts and interpretations be; and so
uncertain and unsafe to pitch and fix upon any single one.

Truly] The Psalmist premiseth this, Ier. XII. 1. and Hab. I. 12, 13.

covers them as a garment] They wear it, Psalm. CIX. 18, 19. But the meek, and
godly cover and array themselves otherwise, Ephesians. IV. 24. Col. III. 10, 12,
14. Phil. IV. 5. Gal. III. 27. Romans XIII. 14. Ephesians. III. 17. cum Gal. IV. 19.

Their eyes stand out] Stand out in the Hebrew is in the singular number.
distributively, for either or each of their eyes. The like is Genesis XLIX. 22.
Exodus XVII. 12. and XXXI. 14. Josh. II. 14. Job XII. 7. Prove. III. 18. and XIV.
1. and XXVII. 9. Joel I. 20.

Therefore his people return hither] Gods own people turn to these thoughts
and tentations following;

verily I] Thus subject to these dangerous tentations.

As a dream when one awaketh] Job XX. 8. John XVI. 21. and to that Acts XII.
9. and to that Psalm. CXXVI. 1.

when thou awakest] To judgment, Psalm. LXXVIII. 65. and VII. 6. and XXXV. 20.

thou shall despise their image] their pageant of worldly pomp, and pride, make
it to be despised. Yea, in their own eyes, if God awake their consciences.

Maschil] An instructing Psalm.

of Asaph] See on Psalm. L in the Title. This Psalm most likely was committed
to some of Asaphs posterity, long after David's time, to tune, sing, and play it.

The time of desolation which this Psalm mentions, and bemoanes, seems not to
be that in the days of Antiochus Epiphanes; who profaned and polluted much
the Temple of Jerusalem; but did not cast it down, and burn it to the ground.
And he himself was long after the Canon of the Old Testament was concluded. But
that rather in the days of Nebuchadnezzar, and Nebuzaradan, 2 Kings XXV. 8.

the rod] Or tribe; Jer. X. 16. Deuteronomy. XXXII. 9.

thy congregations] Meaning the Temple, where the holy Congregations assembled.
verse 7. it is in the Hebrew, thy Sanctuaries in the Plural number, meaning the
Temple. The Plural number being used discretively to note out, and design one
of many. And so is that Genesis XXIII. 6. Judge. VII. 10. and XII. 7. 2 Kings V.
13. 2 Chronicles. XXIV. 25. John VI. 45. Acts XIII. 40. Zech. IX. 9. Mat. IV. 3
compared with Luke IV. 3. And so we may understand that, Matthew. XXVII. 44.
compared with Luke XXIII. 40* And that 2 Chr. chap. XXVIII. 3. compared with 2
Kings XXVIII. 3. And that Matthew. XXVI. 8. compared with John XII. 4.

no more any Prophet] Ezekiel, Jeremie, were now dead. Others happily not so well
known or regarded, Lam. II. 9.

Dragons] The Princes of Pharaoh.

Leviathan] Pharaoh.

gave him to be meat] Him, as Prove. XXX. 25, 26. Or, their spoil, as meat to
the Israelites. Or gave meat, that is, Manna, to him, that is, thy people in
the Wilderness.

When I shall receive] This Psalm seems to be penned by David, Asaph to use;
and likely at the time, and upon the occasion of the State of affairs at, and
upon the murder of Abner by Joab, 2 Samuel III. which being then much shaken and
shattered, he promises to uphold, and rectify. And rebuking the foolish,
proud, and presumptuous opposers of his Promotion, he renueth his resolution to
proceed in judgment toward the wicked, and the righteous, uprightly.

the pillars of it] He did so, Gal. II. 9.

cup See Esaias LI. 17. Ezekiel. XXIII. 32. Ier. XXV. 15. Apoc. XIV. 10.

In Salem] Of Salem, see the Observations on Josh. X. 1.

There brake he] This likely was done in the Assyrian Came Gods Angel, Hezekiah,
2 Chronicles. XXXII. 21. ^^p by

then the mountains of prey] A proverbial expression of greatest glory. Esaias
IX. 3. and LIII. 12. Or, from the mountains of prey, where the Assyrian armies
were preying upon thy people, and now slain by thy glorious power, and given by
thee as a prey to thy people.

their sleep] of death.

shall praise thee] Turn to thy praise.

the remainder] Keep within compass the further attempts of our enraged
enemies.

to Ieduthun] Psalm. and LXII. 1 Chronicles. XXV. 2, 3.

my soar ran] Or, my hand was stretched out,

and was troubled] Or,

Thy way, O God* is in the Sanctuary] Or, in sanctity; most holy. And thy manner
of administration and proceeding is to be learned in thy Word, which is taught
in the Sanctuary, Psalm. LXXIII. 17.

The waters saw thee] Psalm. CXIV. 3, 5. the waters of the Red Sea.

The clouds] Exodus XIV. 24. Psalm. LXVIII. 7, 8, 9, 33. and XVIII. 13, 14.

Thy way is in the Sea] The Red Sea, XIV. 21.

footsteps are not known] Before or after; the waters returned, and hid that
way, Exodus XIV. 27. Or more generaly, Gods ways are unsearchable, Job XXVI.
14. Psalm. CVII. 23, 24. Romans XI. 33, 34.

in a parable] Matthew. parable; and therefore with some alteration of the words
of the Psalmist. And that form of allegation is usual with the Evangelists, as
well in allusive and indirect, as in more direct and proper applications. Of
Parables, see more in the Observations on Psalm XLIX. 4.

The children of Ephraim] Some make this relate to that, Chron. VII. 21, 22.
while their father lived in Egypt. Others to the Ephramites flight before
Jephthah, Judge. XII. 46. Others understanding all the Israelites under that
name, refer this to their flight before the Philistines, 1 Samuel IV. 10. Or
before Abijah, 2 Chronicles. XIII. 17. And others understanding by Ephraim, the ten
Tribes, whereof Ephraim was the head, make it to relate to the final
extirpation of that Kingdom, 2 Kings XVII. 7. etc. whereof Hosea prophesied,
chap. X. 11, 14. So various expositions may these general words admit.

By sending evil angels] As Job I. 12, 16. i. e. messengers of evils; which may
be understood, either of good Angels; or of Moses and Aaron.

hinder parts] 1 Samuel V. 1, 6, 9, 12.

he refused] Shiloh, Ephraim, the son of Joseph: The Ark never came thither
again.

his Sanctuary] Temple, Solomon. By this, and some other passages, this Psalm
may seem not to be composed by David; but by some later inspired Prophet.

the Heathen This Psalm seems composed, Antiochus Epiphanes; but in the times
of the Babylonish captivity rather. Bemoaning those miseries which were brought
upon them by those barbarous Babylonians.

Poure] Ier. X. 25.

our neighbors seven-fold] That did not pity us in our calamity; Genesis IV. 15,
24. Esaias LXV. 6, 7.

Shoshannim Eduth] See the Observations on Psalm. Eduth here, which signifies a
testimony, to import the Churches testimony and profession of her faith in the
promise of God for her deliverance out of the Babylonish captivity, at the end
of seventy years, Ier. XXIX. 10. And so this Psalm to be made in the time of
that captivity.

Asaph] See the Observations on Psalm. L.

upon the man of thy right hand] Thy beloved one; Benjamin was, Genesis XXXV. 18.
And here may be meant, David, in his posterity, Psalm. CXXXII. 10, 11. and
LXXXIX. 19, 20, 21, 35. Or, Zerubbabel particularly. But both as shadows and
types, of Christ the substance, principaly intended, Col. I. 13. Psalm. XLV. 3.
Luke XXIV. 19. Heb. II. 18.

in the new moone] Psalm seems sung at the Jewish Feasts.

When he went] Or had gone.

I heard a language] Was a stranger.

in the secret place of thunder] In that pillar of a cloud, Exodus XIV. 24.
happily troubling the Egyptians with thunder, lightning, and tempest, Psalm.
LXXVII. 17, 18.

gave them up] See the Observations on Esaias VI. 9.

congregation of the mighty] Assembly, Romans XIII. 1, 2. and they so called
gods, Exodus XXII. 8, 9, 28. John X. 34, 35. And the cause before them, the
cause of God, Deuteronomy. I. 17. 2 Chronicles. XIX. 6.

all the foundations] Laws,

Alleged by our Savior, John X. 34.

like men] As Adam did. Hos. VI. 7. Job XXXI. 33. But rather the sense is more
general; ye shall die as other men do, that last line of death shall put an end
to your height and haughtiness, Psalm. CXLVI. 3* 4. Ye die as the meanest men
do; for so the word is most what taken, specialy when it is put in opposition,
as here, Psalm. XLIX. 2. and LXII. 9. Esaias II. 9. and V. 15. Death makes no
distinction between man and man; as is excellently expressed by Heathen Poets:
die all shall, equaly and alike, one with another.

like one of the Princes] As one of the other Princes of the world, as other
mortal men; as one, or any one, even the meanest, who among the rest of men
make but a number, as it were.

A Song as Psalme] See the Observations on Psalm. XLVIII. title.

This Song seems composed and inspired, as a form of Prayer, when the Church
and people of the Jews were in great danger by many enemies conspiring against
them, to destroy them: And this likely either in the days of David, 2 Samuel
VIII. or rather long after David's time, in the days of Jehoshaphat; or of
Ezekiah.

thy hidden ones] Hidden as his peculiar treasure, Exodus XIX. 5. secret,
preserved under the shadow of his wings, Psalm. XVII. 8. and XXVII. 5. and XXXI.
20. Whose life also is hid with Christ in God, Col. III. 3.

Hagarens] And Hagarites, Chro. V. 10, 19, 20. So called from Hagar, the mother
of Ishmael, Genesis 16.

Gebal] The Giblites, Sidon, whence Solomon had stone-cutters, 1 Kings V. 18.
Ezekiel. XXVII. 9. See Josh. XIII. 5.

Endor] In Manasseh; Dor, which lay on the mid-land sea* Saul goes to a Witch
at Endor; which indeed was not far from the mountains of Gilboa, where Saul
was slain. Taanach, and Megiddo not far from it.

whose name alone is Jehovah] Which has his being of himself, Exodus III. 14.
Deuteronomy. VI. 4. An eternal Being, Esaias XLIV. 6. Apoc. I. 4, 8. and IV. 8. and XI.
17. and XVI. 5. And gives being to all things, Acts XVII. 25. to his word, and
promises, and threatenings, Exodus VI. 3. Ezekiel. VII. 27. See the Observations on
Esaias XXVI. 4* of Jehovi, see the Observations on Psalm. LXXI. 5. Of Jah, see the
Observations on Psalm. LXVIII. 4.

Gittith] So Psalm. Obed-Edom, a Levite, and Porter or Singer in the Tabernacle,
is called a Gittite, 2 Samuel VI. 10. happily from Gath-rimmon, a City of the
Levites, Josh. XXI. 25. And there is Gath a City of the Philistines. The word
then may signify an Instrument of music, not such as our Gitterne; such as
was used in Gath; or rather used by the posterity of Obed-Edom the Gittite: Or
it may import that those three Psalms were sung upon occasion of David's
removing the Ark from Kiriathjearim to the house of Obed-Edom the Gittite; and
from thence to Jerusalem, 1 Chronicles. XIII. and XV. chapters. More certainty is
not found out.

Korah] See the Observations on Psalm. XLII. Title.

thine Altars] The places near them might happily become the nests of birds,
Josh. XXIV. 26. Or this may relate to the Psalmists longing and crying after
them, by an abrupt and pathetical exclamation and naming of them, Oh thine
Altars, thine Altars: not yet excluding the force of that argument from the
birds nestling, either near, or elsewhere. Some hence conceive, That this
Psalm was penned by David in the time of his Exile and banishment from Gods
house and service by the means of Saul, verse 9. not so likely of Absalom.

the ways of them] Of the travelers that go up to God house,

of Baca] Or Mulberry trees, Jerusalem, 2 Samuel V. 22, 23. Joshua XV. 8.

make it a Well] By digging Wells therein for water: no drought, or
difficulties shall hinder them from coming to Gods house, but they will break
through them. Or, make him a Well; that is, God in stead of a Well to them,
Jer. II. 13. and XVII. 13. Psalm. XXXVI. 9.

the rain also fills the pools] Which they dug; God so provides for them.
Or, the bountiful rain of Gods blessings, of grace and comfort, shall cover and
comfort them.

from strength to strength] increasing so, Romans I. 17. 2. Cor. III. 18. Or,
from company to company; from troop to troop; as by troops they came up to Gods
house thrice a year.

of thine anointed] David the type; the truth.

a door-keeper] Fixed* and a servant,

grace and glory] Many refer grace to this life, glory to that which is to
come. But grace rather may seem here to signify favor, estimation, honor,
as Prove. III. 34. James IV. 6. 1 Pet. V. 5. Exodus III. 21. Number. chap. XII. 36.
and XXXIII. 12. Genesis VI. 8. and XXXIX. 4. and L. 4. Esther II. 15. 17. and V.
2. Prove. XXII. 1. and chap I. 9. and IV. 9. Luke II. 52. and I. 28. compared
with verse 30.

Thou have been] Formerly.

brought back] Out of Babylon. Some understand this of the bringing back of
David to Jerusalem after the rebellion of Absalom. But not so likely.

covered all their sinne] See the Observations on Psalm. LI. 4.

Turn us] Do now so again.

I will hear] Complain no more;

are met] Will meet.

have kissed] Will kiss, verse 4, 5. This, and what follows had it most
complete fulfilling in and by the coming of Christ.

A Prayer] So is the Title of Psalm. set form of prayer for the godly in
distress; without any particular circumstances used in it of persons, places,
or times; appliable to all; and may not unfitly be applied to Christ.

I am holy] So rather then as in the margin, one whom thou favourest. The
Hebrew word is (...), which imports an active, rather then a passive
signification. And so Psalm. IV. 3. and XXXII. 6. and L. 5. and LXXIX. 2. This
word is actively taken, and that rightly in our translations; though many
learned men, not so well advised therein, render it passively, to denote, not
the author and agent, and his quality, but the object spoken of.

Among the gods] Verse 10. Psalm. LXXXIX. 6. Deuteronomy. XXXII. 39. Esaias XXXVII. 16*
and XLIV. 6. 1 Cor. VIII. 4, 5, 6. Exodus XV. 1^. From the first Hebrew letters
of which four words in Exodus came the name of the Maccabees, as is thought.

unite my heart to fear thy Name] Loose it from all other things,

give thy strength] John XV. 5. II. 13. and IV. 13.

a toaken] as in the end of the verse.

His foundation] Gods,

Mountains] Moriah, and Zion. Not now in a flitting Tabernacle.

Glorious things] See Esaias LIVE. and LX. Apoc. XXI. and XXII. And see the
Observations on Josh. 10. 1.

Rahab] So LXXXIX. 10. Esaias LI. 9. See the Observations on Genesis XII. 10. Egypt
is meant hereby: And the calling of Egypt to the fellowship of the Church. Of
whose calling, see Esaias XIX. 19, 21, 25.

to them that know me] Or among them; as of my known familiars.

Philistia] Palestine, the Philistines, Psalm. LX. 8.

this] And the rest before named, were born in the City of God; by regeneration
spiritual made the sons of God, and of the Church, verse^ 5, 6. 1 Pet. I. 23.
James I. 18. Esaias XLIV. 5.

Singers] The spiritual joy both great,

Springs] Of my joy, and of Gods spiritual gifts and graces also; John VII. 38.
Esaias XII. 3. Ephesians. III. 10.

A Song] See the Observations on Psalm. title.

Mahalath] A kind of winde-instrument, Psalm. LIII.

Leannoth] May either make up the name of the Instrument; or may seem to
signify to sing by turns or courses, as Exodus XV. 21. Ezra. III* 11.

Heman] The next Psalm^ is of Ethan. These were sacred Singers and Musicians,
descended of Levi, 1 Chronicles. XV. 17, 19. and XVI. 41, 42. and VI. 44. Of Heman,
see 1 Chronicles. XXV. 1. 4, -- 7. He was of the posterity of rebellious Korah, and
grandchilde of Samuel the Prophet, 1 Chronicles. VI. 33. and himself King David's
Seer, 1 Chronicles. XXV. 5. There were two brethren, Heman, and Ethan, of the
posterity of Judah, 1 Chronicles. II. 6. men renowned for their wisdom, 1 King. IV.
31.

This Psalm is one of the most doleful of all the Bible: And may serve as a set
form of a sad complaint to any man in his greatest distress. Some make
application of it to Christ in his Sufferings.

free among the dead] Psalm. XXXI. 12. III. 18, 19.

I am shut up] As a close prisoner in the Dungeon of sorrows,

wilt thou] Psalm. VI. 5. Esaias XXXVIII. 18.

prevent thee] Psalm. V. 3. II. 1.

into darknesse] That they hide themselves from me,

a Covenant] In faithfulness, verse 1, 2. How then comes it to be made void?
verse 38, -- 45.

David] The figure, and father of Christ; who is also called David, Ezekiel,
XXXIV. 23. Jer. XXX. 9. Hos. III. 5. Of him this Psalm is chiefly to be
understood; though not in all the particular passages.

Rahab] See the Observations on Psalm. LXXXVII. 4.

Tabor] Westward, Observations on Judge. IV* 6.

Hermon] Eastward, see the Ohervations on Deuteronomy. IV. 48.

joyful sound] Of the Trumpet,

to thy holy one] To Samuel, who anointed David.

laid help upon one that is mighty] Or, help against the mighty: both ways
meaning David: who yet here may be taken as a Type of Christ.

I will set] Psalm LXXII. 8.

my Father] This, verse 27, 28, 29. universaly and plenarily belong to Christ:
And only imperfectly, as in a weak type, are applyable to David, or Solomon, 2 Samuel VII. 14. Heb. I. 5. Luke I. 32, 33.

my first-borne] The firstborn had the privileges of double portion, Col. I.
15, 18. Matthew. I. 25. Romans VIII. 29. Heb. I. 6. Apoc. I. 5.

His seede] Verse 36. Christians, his spiritual seed; Esaias LIII. 10. Heb. the
everlasting Father, Esaias IX. 6.

his throne] Verse 37. Heb. I. 8. Dan. II. 44. and VII. 14. Luke I. 33. The
accomplishment of these Promises cannot be found in Solomon.

If his children] So 2 Samuel VII. 14, 15. Solomon, and of his children; and
cannot be understood of Christ's person; who was not the natural of son of
Solomon; but of his brother Nathan; And who was without sin, 1 Pet. II. 22:
But as he bare our sins, and was made a Sacrifice for sin for us, 2 Cor. V.
21. Esaias LIII. 6. Yet this may have a right understanding of Christ's spiritual
children, who are subject to the lapses and infirmities of sin, 1 John I. 8.
Romans VII. 15.

sworne] Of Oaths, Observations on Hos. IV. 15.

as the Moone] Which although it sometime waxes,

Witnesse] See Jer. XXXIII. 20, 21. And Christ is so called, Apoc. I. 5. Esaias
LV. 4.

But thou] The Psalmist complains of the miseries of the Church,

youth have thou shortned] Wherein by thy promises he should have flourished,

how short] How vain,

the footsteps of thine Anointed.]

Blessed] The voice of faith, end of the third Book of Psalms. See the
Observations on Psalm. XLI. ult. and on LXXII. ult.

of Moses] This seems inspired and penned by Moses for the use of the people,
Number. XIV. 22, 23, 29, 34.

Returne] The body to the earth;

watch] The night divided into four Watches;

threescore years and ten] So for the most part, David. And none of the Kings
of Judah, or Israel, after him attained to those years. Or seventy here, in
regard of that judgment denounced, Number. XIV. 29.

even according to thy fear, so is thy wrath] Thy wrath is as thy fear
teaches it to be: which teaches us to fear thee for thy wrath. But who
knows the power of it?

to number] They might number the utmost extent of them, Number. XIV. But not how
much sooner they might die.

establish] Esaias XXVI. 12.

he shall deliver thee] Having practiced in the second verse what he taught in
the first; others to do the like, applies his example to them.

not be afraid] Esaias XLIII. 2. shall work for our good, if we be not delivered
out of them, Romans VIII. 28.

his Angels charge over thee] Alleged by the Devil to Christ, Mat. IV. 6.

in all thy wayes] Of holiness and righteousness. These words the Devil
omits; as making against his temptation, which was against the mind of the
text.

tread upon the lion] Esaias XI. 6, -- 9. Hos. II. 18. without harm or damage.
Not as the Pope applied it to his treading upon the neck of the Emperor.

on high] Safely above all perils and dangers.

with long life] If God shall see it good and fit for him.

for the Sabbath day] For the Rest on this day, Observations on Exodus XII. 16.
For Hallowing it; That was, by an holy convocation; by offering of Sacrifices;
singing Psalms; reading, and expounding, and hearing Scriptures; Praying;
Disputing, and Conferring; by meditating on Gods word, and works; and doing
works of mercy, Exodus XX. 10. Esaias LVIII. 13. Jer. XVII. 21, 22. Levit. XXIII.
3. Number* XXVIII. 9, 10. Acts XIII. 15. and XV. 21. and XVI. 13. and XVII. 2. and
XVIII. 4. Matthew. XII. 2, -- 7, 8, 11, 12.

as the Palm tree] The LXX. read, (...), tree. As the Hebrew word here does;
And the meaning of the whole verse imports. Yet hence many learned men, taking
it up one from another, have raised that fable of a wondrous bird called a
Phoenix, which yet never was seen, or known in the world.

holiness becomes thy house] In the services,

The Lord knoweth] Cited,

But judgment shall return unto righteousnesse] Though they might seem
awhile parted;

O come] David's Psalm; Heb. III. 7. and IV. 7.

to day] This extends to the whole time wherein Christ speaks by his Gospel,
Heb. III. 7. 13, 15. and IV. 7, 8. So 2 Cor. VI. 2.

Provocation] Meribah,

temptation] Massah, in the Hebrew. See Exodus XVII. 1, -- 7. Number. XX. 1, 3, 13.
Deuteronomy. VI. 16.

tempted me] Tempted Christ,

my work] Works, Heb. III. 9. of miraculous mercies; and judgments.

I sware] At Kadesh-barneah, etc. Heb. III. 17, 19.

my rest.] Canaan; a Type of a better Rest, Heb. IV. 3, 8, 9, 11.

O sing] This Psalm, Psalm CV. 1, -- 15. with small alterations, make up that
Psalm composed by David, upon the bringing of the Ark from Obed-Edoms house,
into the City of David, 1 Chronicles. XVI. 8, -- 36.

a new song] See the Observations on Psalm. XXXIII. 3.

beauty of holinesse] In the glorious holy Sanctuary.

searoare] In token of joy.

the trees] Humane affections ascribed to insensible creatures;

for the cometh] Or, when he comes. Which may relate to Christ's coming into
the world, Matthew. XII. 20. Acts X. 42. and chapter XVII. 31. Psalm. XCVIII. 9. and
CX. 6. Esaias II. 4. and XI. 3, 4. and XVI. 5. 2 Timothy IV. 1. Apoc. XIX. 11.

The Lord reighneth] Here seems the Kingdom,

a new song] See the Observations on Psalm.

made known] Esaias LII. 10.

Let the sea roare] Psalm. XCVI. 11.

let the people tremble] And so, Apoc. XI. 17, 18. Acts XVII. 13.

The Kings strength] God mixeth his power with justice, Job XXXVI. 5.

Moses and Aaron among his Priests] Moses did many things of the Priestly
office. Cohen here used, does signify also a Prince, and principal officer, as
2 Samuel VIII. 18. and in many other places.

though that tookest] Even when thou tookest vengeance of their inventions,

and not we Or, and his we are; as the Hebrew in the margin reads it, Deuteronomy.
VII. 6, 7. and chap. IX. 4. etc. Psalm. XCV. 5.

A Psalm of David] This seems inspired and written by David,

not know] Matthew. VII 23.

of the afflicted] Or, for the afflicted. A set form of Prayer for him, for
any in a poor afflicted estate. And so diverse other set forms of prayer are
found in Scripture, in a set form of words. As Number. VI. 24, 25, 26. Matthew. VI.
9, -- 13. And again at another time, and upon another occasion, Luke XI. 1, --
4. Psalm. XX. and XXI. This Prayer may seem inspired and composed by Daniel, or
some other Prophet toward the end of the Babylonish Captivity, verse 13, 16.
Zech. I. 12, 13.

the appointed time] Jer. XXIX. 10. Dan. IX. 2, 24. etc.

in her stones] Neh. II. 13. etc. and IV. 2. Zech. I. 22.

Of old] This verse, Heb. I. 10, 11, 12. and applied to prove the Deity of
Christ.

This Psalm,

thy youth is renewed like the Eagles] Thou keep thy self fresh and vigorous,
Job XXXIII. 25. And like the Eagles youth, or strength and vigor; which abides
so long, even to and in old age, and length of very many years; and seems to
renew her youth by the casting of her feathers yearly, not her bill; the upper
beak whereof grows at last in an extreme old age, so to over-grow and bend
over the lower beak, as causes the Eagle to die of famine, not of feebleness,
Arist. lib. 9. cap. 32. de historia animalium. See Esaias XL. 31.

hoasts ye Ministers] Both Angels, Ephesians. 3. 10. Col. I. 16. 1 Kings XXII. 19.
Genesis XXXII. 2. Psalm. CIV. 4. Dan. VII. 10 Apoc II. 1. Esaias LXI. 6. Neh. IX. 6.

This Psalm is exquisite for loftiness,

with light, as with a garment] Genesis I. 3. 1 Timothy VI. 16. He wholly so shines,
as the eyes of any, no not of the Angels, are able to behold the luster and
splendour thereof. As neither we, that of the Sun.

the beams of his chambers in the waters.] Makes and distinguishes the
regions of the air, ver. 13.

his Angels spirits] Alleged and interpreted of Angels, Heb. I. 7. uses them
being spiritual substances, as speedy, active messingers, ministers, and
executors of his will, Heb. I. 14.

his ministers a flaming fire] The Angels such, 2 Kings II. 11. and chap. VI.
17. Or, the flashes of lightnings, and other meteors are his ministers to do
his will.

waters stood above the mountains] At the Creation, Genesis I. 2. And at the
Flood, Genesis VII. 20.

to cover the earth] Job XXXVIII. 8, Jer. V. 22. Genesis IX. 11, 13, 15.

oile] Psalm. XXIII. Eccles. IX. 8. Matthew. VI. 17.

her house] In them is her house, Psalm. LXXXIV. 4. Job XXIX. 18. Matthew. VIII.
20. Luke IX. 58. Dan. IV. 12.

Conies] Prove. XXX. 24,

in wisdom have thou made them all] By wisdom here to understand Christ
punctualy, Prove. III. 19. though that be a sacred truth, Heb. I. 2.

Sea] Not that Psalm. that; which particle does distinguish the great Midland
Sea, from the other lesser.

go the ships] See verse 10. Genesis II. 14. Esaias XXXIII. 21.

Leviathan] The Whale, Job XLI.

renewest] By causing new creatures to come in the place of the old, Eccles. I.
4.

Praise ye the Lord] In the Hebrew, Halelu-jah, Praise ye Jah. This Halelu-jah
is kept in the Greek, and in other languages; set sometimes in the beginnings,
sometimes in the end of Psalms. Apoc. XIX. 1, 3, 4, 6.

O give thanks] See the Observations on Psalm. David's Psalm.

his strength, seek his face] The Ark, where God declared his power, and
presence, Psalm. LXIII. 2. and LXXVIII. 61. See the Observations on Psalm. XXVII.
8.

his judgements] Esaias XXVI. 9.

oath unto Isaac] To Abraham, Isaac, Genesis XXII. 17. and XXVI. 3.

mine anointed] This is spoken of the Patriarchs:

my Prophets] So Abraham is called, Genesis XX. 7.

with fetters] Gen XXXIX.

his word came] Gods word in dreams touching his advancement, Genesis XXXVII. 7,
9. came to be fulfilled. Or, Joseph's word in the interpretation of the dreams
of Pharaohs Officers, and of Pharaoh himself.

He turned] See the Observations on Esaias VI.

they rebelled not] The Signs and Wonders did not: Moses, and Aaron did not
rebel, etc.

hail for raine] Rain rare in Egypt, Zech.

first-borne] Thus all the ten plagues of Egypt are reckoned up;

a cloud for a covering] A large cloud to cover all that host from the
parching heat of the Sun.

Quailes] Twice; Exodus XVI. 13. Number. XI. 31.

dry places] In the deserts of Sin, Zin: from the rocks of Rephidim, Exodus
XVII. and Kadesh, Number. XX.

That they might] Obedience the end of all Gods mercies, Exodus XIX. 4, 5, 6.

leannesse] By their ratson, razon, leanness; yea, a plague and death, Psalm.
LXXVIII. 30, 31. Esaias X. 16.

Dathan] Korah is omitted here.

Oxe] Elsewhere the term of Ca^^ is used.

Ham] Genesis X. 6.

pleasant land] Deuteronomy. Ezekiel. XX. 6. See the Observations on Zech. VII. 14.

Baal-Peor] See the Observations on Judges VIII. Baal signifies Lord, Master,
Husband, or Patron. Peor is the name of a mountain: And Beth Pehor the name of
Baals Temple there, Number. XXIII. 28. Deuteronomy. III. 29. For the idolatry committed
to this idol, the Scripture sometimes for the word Baal, uses Bosheth, which
signifies shame. Hos. IX. 10. See Jer. III. 24. and XI. 13. and the
Annotations of learned Master Gataker upon those places.

of the dead] Offered to those dead idols, Number. XXV. 2. Jer. X. 5.

And that was counted unto him for righteousnesse] i. e. this fact of Phineas
was approved of God as just and righteous, and for such ever to be esteemed.
The same phrase used Genesis XV. 6. has another sense of justifying Abraham's
person before God by faith, though a man without faults in himself otherwise.
And so is rightly applied by Saint Paul, Romans IV. 3, 5, 8, 9, 22, 23, 24. to
the justification of sinner before God by Faith merely.

for righteousnesse] A right and just action; not the fruit of a rash zeal;
though done without ordinary authority.

unadvisedly] Number. XX.

Devils] Levit. XVII. 7 See the Observations on Judges VIII. 33.

his Covenant] This, verse 8 are the ground of Gods free mercies.

among the heathen] among whom diverse Israelites were scattered, Saul, by
reason of their often troubles at home, till the Kingdom came to David, whose
words these are, 1 Chronicles. XVI. 35, 36.

This Psalm has much elegancy and sublimity in it.

South] In the Hebrew, Sea; meaning the Red Sea, which was South from Canaan.
But much more usualy in Scripture by Sea is understood the West, because the
great Mediterrane Sea lay West from Canaan.

mount up] And hyperbole. Observations on Josh. XI. 4.

them] Mariners,

rivers] Watery fruitful places.

dry] Barren, thirsty.

will observe] Not that such deliverances are vouchsafed always to all in such
dangers:

A Song, a Psalme] See the Observations on the Title of Psalm XLVIII.

This Psalm is composed of Psalm. LVII. 7, -- 11. and Psalm. LX. 5, -- 12. See
the Observations on both those Psalms.

glorie] See the Observations on Psalm XVI.

wash-pot] So Psalm. Moab; or their Land to be washed in blood; or themselves
wiped clean away, as a pot is wiped. But rather to be used to servile, sordid,
base offices.

of David] By the matter of the Psalm, Saul's reign, when all things were
grown to a forlorn and wicked state. See 1 Samuel XXVI. 19.

unto Prayer] The use and comfort of Prayer.

Set] Many Imprecations follow. Psalm. XXXV. 4, -- 8. and LIX. 5, 13. and LXIX.
22, -- 28. and LXXIX. 10. and CXIX. 84. and CXL. 10. Job XXXI. Nehem. VI. 4. 5.
and VI. 6, 14. Esaias II. 9. Jer. XI. 20. and XV. 15. and chap. XVII. 18. and
XVIII. 21, 22, 23. and XX. 12. 2 Timothy IV. 14. And these with exquisite forms
of speeches. And uttered by David, and the rest, against transcendent sinners,
rather as Prophets, but of zeal to God and his glory therein, then in relation
to their private passions of revenge, or respect to themselves as parties. And
yet these, or the like Prayers and Imprecations may possibly be mixed with
Humane infirmities; as those in Jeremy. See the Annotations on Nehem. IV. 5. Or
in some they may be understood with silent limitations and reservations.

right hand] He plead and prevail against him.

condemned] Go out guilty,

become sinne] Let no suit, or defense of his avail for him, but rather hurt
him.

8 his office] Applied to Judas, Acts I. 16,

their desolate places] Their houses and families that are desolate and
destroyed.

fathers] Thus God punishes to the third and fourth generation, Exodus XX. 5.

As he clothed himself with cursing] See the Observations on Psalm, LXXIII. 6.

Let it be unto him] The curse wherein he delighted in cursing others; which
pleased him as water, and oil, Let that same be unto him. Or, let a curse thus
cover, and cleave unto him; and come into his bowels and bones. See the
Observations on Psalm. LXXIII. 6.

shaked their heads] Psalm.

This Psalm is all Prophetical; Matthew. XXII. 44. Mark XII. 36. Luke XX. 42.
Acts II. 34. Heb. I. 13. and V. 6. and VII. 17.

The Lord] The Messiah himself applies, verse to himself, Matthew. XXII: 44.
Mark XII. 36. Luke. XX. 42. Saint Peter from this verse proves Christ's
Ascension into heaven, Acts II. 34. Saint Paul relates to it in the point of
Christ reign over all enemies, 1 Cor. XV. 25. Denying that the words of this
verse were used, or could be used to any of the Angels, Heb. I. 13. And
therefore they cannot be appliable to David himself, or to any mere man.

The Lord] Heb. Jehovah. See the Annotations of learned Master Gataker on Esaias
I. 2. and XXVI. 4. See also my Observations on Psalm LXXXIII. 18. and on LXXI.
5. and on LXVIII. 4. This Name of Essence never admits any affix in the Hebrew
tongue. And it may lawfully be pronounced; though the ancient Jews refrained
from doing so, to gain thereby the more reverence to it. And this Name is
common to the three Persons; yet according to the sense and circumstances of
diverse texts and places, Personaly. And so here for God the Father. As
likewise, Psalm. II. 7.

said] In his eternal Decree, predestinating his Son to be the Messiah, to
execute in time the Office of Mediatorship.

unto my Lord] David's Lord, as well as his Son.

sit thou] This, and other phrases here, are not proper, but figurative: to be
understood, not corporealy, but spiritualy. Christ is said in Scripture
promiscuously, both to stand, and to sit at the right hand of God, Heb. I. 3.
Acts VII. 55, 56. 1 Pet. III. 22.

at my right hand] The right hand signifies power and strength, Psalm. CXVIII.
16. Exodus XV. 6. Psalm. CXLIV. 8. Power to help, verse 5. Psalm. XVI. 8. and
CXLII. 4. Eccles. X. 2. To be or sit there, imports dignity and honor, 1 Kings
II. 19. Matthew. XX. 21. And such is the meaning here. And this dignity here
expressed by this phrase is ascribed to Christ; not in relation to his Deity,
for so he and the Father are one. Herein he is, and always was of equal
dignity with the Father: But in regard of his Humanity whereby the Father was
greater then he: And wherein formerly he had emptied and humbled himself, and
suffered, even to death; and so was made a little lower then the Angels. But
now hereby he is crowned with glory and honor. Yet this dignity here is not
ascribed to his Humanity singly in it self considered, but in supposito, as it
hypostaticaly subsists in the Person of the Son of God. And this Dignity is
not an elevation and exaltation of the Humanity of our Savior into the Majesty
and essential properties and prerogatives of the Divine-nature; and so to have
a parity of Dignity with it, an equality in all points; realy communicated to
the Humanity in it self, as the Ubiquitaries contend and plead for, and which
they refer, not to the Person only; but to the very Humane nature also in the
Person of the Son of God. But this Dignity of Christ's Humanity is that which
is next in degree under God and the Father, above that of the Angels, and all
creatures, Heb. I. 3, 4. Ephesians. I. 20, 21, 22, 23. given to him in time, after
his Ascension, as a consequent and reward of his exinanition and passion, Phil.
II. ult. Heb. II. 9. Luke XXIV. 26. This Dignity Saint Paul declares, 1 Cor.
XV. 25. and Saint Peter, Acts V. 31. and X. 42. John V. 27. In sum then, as
Christ emptied himself, and subjected himself to the Father, not in regard of
his Divine nature, but in regard of his Person God-man, and that only out of
his Voluntary dispensation; So out of the same his voluntary dispensation it
is, that he exercises this office of Mediation in both natures, And here after
his Ascension; not before; in the Personal Union of both Natures; he receives
this Dignity of sitting on the Fathers right hand; his Person reigning so in
both natures. It is not then the Humanity in it self singly taken that sits on
the right hand of God; but the Humanity of that Person that sits at the right
hand of God: as in the Incarnation it came to pass, not that the Humanity
became God, but that the Humanity became then the Humanity of God. And Christ
now sitting at the right hand of God does reign every where* even as Man also;
though his Humanity be not every where: as a King does in his Kingdom, though
his body be not every where* as the Head in the Body, though the Head be not
every where as the Sun in the firmament enlightens, heats, cherishes,
quickens things below, though the Sun remain in its own place above.

until] 1 Cor. XV. 14, 25, 28. Not yet that the Son shall then leave off all
Rule and Reign, and be subject to the Father simply: But that then he shall
leave off his Office of Mediation, having then overcome his enemies, and fully
gathered his Church; he shall not thenceforth use those means, and actings
which formerly he did; the whole work being then finished; then shall he leave
off the administration of that delegation which he had formerly freely
undertaken, there being then no more need of it. But thenceforth shall he
reign together with the Father to all eternity; Dan. VII. 14. Luke I. 23. In a
sense not unlike is this particle until used, Psalm. CXXIII. 2. Matthew. ult.
ult. Genesis XXVIII. 15. what is affirmed of the time past, is not denied for the
time to come.

I make] I God the Father. Not excluding God the Son. For the same action is
attributed to him, 1 Cor. XV. 25. John XVI. 33, Opera Trinitatis ad extra sunt
indivisa.

thine enemies] The Devil, John XIV. 30. 1 Cor. XV. 24. The World; John XVI.
33. and XV. 18. Antichrist; and all wicked men; Luke XIX. 27. Not, but that
these are the enemies of God, and the Father also; John V. 23. And so both are
joined together, Psalm. II. 2. yet more immediately and directly enemies to
Christ the Son, who came into the world to destroy the works of the Devil, 1
John II. 8. enemies to his Kingdom, and his inheritance, Matthew. XXI. 38.

thy footstool.] All utterly subdued, and put under thy feet, 1 Cor. XV. 14.
As Judge. I. 7. Psalm. XLVII. 3. and Psalm. XVIII. 39, 40. 1 Kings V. 3. Josh. X.
24. 25. Thus did Sapor the Persian King; Tamerlane the Scythian; and Pope
Alexander the fourth to the Emperor Frederick the first. This Conquest was
made by Christ's Resurrection and Ascension, Col. II. 15. Ephesians. IV. 8. John
XII. 3. and chap. XVI. 11. 33. They touch not Christ's person now, as they did
when he was upon earth. They have not power over his mystical body; and true
members, to domineer over them, subdue them, or deadly destroy them: yet they
have power to bite and bruise their heel; and so to persecute Christ in his
members, Acts IX. 4. and chapter XXII. 7.

Zech. II. 8. And so the victory is not yet fully complete, Romans XVI. 20. And
this makes for Christ's greater glory, and his childrens good. But at the last
day, in the end of the world, all the enemies shall be altogether utterly
subdued, and destroyed, and punished everlastingly, 1 Cor. XV. 25, -- 28.
Matthew. XXV. 41, etc.

The Lord shall send] The Prophet David here turns his speech to his Lord and
Son; and speaks here of Jehovah, what he shall do to, and for him.

the rod of thy strength] Thy royal Scepter, or Shepherds staff; thy Kingdom,
and the Dominion thereof, Ier. XLVIII. 17. Ezekiel. XIX. 4, 11. thy royal power;
which shall be strong, to overpower all the strength of the world opposing it,
Romans I. 16. And this is his Word and Gospel; not any temporal arms or power.

out of Zion] There began the promulgation, and thence sprang the Propagation
of the Gospel, and of Christ's Kingdom; which wondrously subdued all the world,
Ps. II. 6, 8. Esaias II. 2, 3. Mich. IV. 2.

rule thou in the midst of thine enemies] Here is the success of Christ's
Kingdom, even among his enemies. He, and his Church Militant in this world
shall still have enemies, Matthew. X. 6. Yet he shall rule and reign in the
midst of them, in despite of them; and that with all confidence and boldness

Thy people] As by right of Creation; so chiefly here,

shall be willing] Their first property; to be prompt, ready, devout,
cheerfully obedient, 1 Pet. II. 9. freely led thereto by Gods free Spirit,
Psalm. LI. 12. Romans VIII. 14. Psalm. LIVE. 6. 2 Cor. IX. 7. As Judge. V. 9. Nehem.
XI. 2. Acts II. 41. Made such by Christ, of unwilling, to be so willing; John
VI. 44. Psalm. CXIX. 10, 11. 108. and in many other places of that Psalm, Esaias
ELIX. 18. and LV. 5. and LX. 4.

in the day of thy power] When by the powerful preaching of thy Gospel, thou
shall rule in the midst of thine enemies; and powerfully convert thy people to
so willing an obedience unto thee. The word here translated Power, signifies
also an army; and may relate to Christ's mustering of his people, as armies, in
the days of their solemn assemblies for his worship and service.

in the beauties of holinesse] Or in the comely honors of the Sanctuary;
meaning either the comely or honorable places of holiness, the Sanctuary, or
Church; or rather, in the beautiful ornaments of holiness, that is, holy
graces and virtues, which with admirable variety adorn the faithful, and
their inner man.

from the womb] The second property or condition of the subjects of Christ's
Kingdom, to be very numerous: as willing; so numerous: as the dew from the
womb of the morning, 2 Samuel XVII. 12. by a sudden, unusual and wonderful
increase and multiplication, Esaias LIVE. 1. Micah V. 7. Esaias LXVI. 9. so numerous
shall his youth be; his newborn people; John I. 13. and III. 3. Gal, IV. 19.
Heb. II. 14. 1 Pet. II. 2. See Esaias LIII. 10. So that these words are not to be
understood of the temporal Nativity of Christ from the Virgin, or his eternal
generation from the Father as some do; but of his active spiritual generation
of his children, the subjects of his Kingdom.

The Lord has sworne] The Vocation of Christ to his Office of Priesthood.
Jehovah is the Author of it.

has sworne] Jehovah swears, to confirm matters of greatest moment: when, and
where his wisdom pleases. And upon this point here of Christ's eternal
Priesthood man's salvation depends. He swears by himself; though that is not
here expressed; because he has no greater to swear by; Heb. VI. 13, 16. Genesis
XXII 16. And so by his life, Esaias XLIX. 18. by his soul, Jer. LI. 24. by his
righthand, and the arm of his strength, Esaias LXII. 8. The result of all which
is the same with himself. And implying thereby thus much, Let me not be
accounted what I am, namely God, the living God, the omnipotent God, if that
which I speak be not true, or my promises or threatenings do fail of
performance. Of Oaths, See the Observations on Jer. LI. 14. and my Annotations
on Hos. IV. 15.

and will not repent] Will not change or retract what he has sworn, Number.
XXIII. 19. James I. 17. Repenting is sometimes ascribed to God; as Genesis VI. 6,
7. Psalm. CVI. 45. 1 Samuel XV. 11. 35. Not that there is any change of mind of
will in God; as there is in man's repenting: But the change is in the work; God
eternally and unchangably decreeing both, as to do the thing, so again to
change it upon man's repentance, or disobedience; Jer. XXVI. 3, 13, 19. Of this
see more in the Observations on Jer. XV. 6. In all this God condescends to man's
weakness, Heb. VI. 17, 18. Shows the greatness, and excellency of the thing
here avowed; that the Lord Christ was lawfully Called and Ordained to be an
eternal Priest for us, and our salvation; for our greater confirmation, and
consolation herein.

Thou art] The Lord Christ well knew this, and could not doubt of the will of
the Father herein. What then needed this Oath to be made unto him? Answ. It was
made to him, for the use of his Church; that his Church might know and be
assured of it. As that John XI. 42.

art] God saying, is as much as doing.

a Preist] So Genesis XIV. 18. Heb. VII. 1. Melchizedec in type; Christ in truth,
the Antitype. The Priests office was to Teach, Pray, and Sacrifice. The High
Priest among the Jews once a year entered into the most Holy place. Yet he in
all things was not an absolute and sufficient Type of our High Priest Christ
the Lord. For he is an eternal High Priest; and both King and Priest; and his
Sacrifice of another nature; and himself of another Tribe.

for ever] Not so the Priests after the order of Aaron, Heb. VII. 23. 34 and
chap. IX. 12.

after the order] Or similitude, Heb. V. 6. and chap. VII. 15.

of Melchizedec] Much question who this Melchizedec was. He was not the Son
of God himself, our Lord and Christ. Very many take him to be Sem the Son of
Noah, who saw both worlds, before, and after the Flood; and lived to the one
hundred and fiftieth year of the age of Abraham. Yet because Sems genealogy is
exactly set down in Scripture; and that the Levitical Priests themselves came
from him after sundry descents: and the Land of Canaan seems not to be Sems
habitation, which took its name from his younger brother Cham, or from Chams
son Canaan: Neither would Abraham so long have forborne his due respects and
visitation of Sem in Canaan, if Sem had lived there: Therefore diverse learned
men take this Melchizedec to be rather some eminent man in Canaan, raised up by
God in those corrupt times, both good and godly, both King and Priest, living
in Salem, after called Jerusalem; whose King in Joshuahs time was called
Adoni-Zedeck, that is, Lord of righteousness, Josh. X. 1. As this man here is
called Melchizedec, that is, King of righteousness. By which place, or near to
it, Abraham in his return from this war and victory, was to pass.

Of this Melchizedec, and his Priesthood, and the difference of it from Aarons
Priesthood, the Apostle to the Hebrews, chap, VII entreats at large, and
observes diverse things; his Name and Title; his greatness in that he blessed
Abraham, and received Tithes of Abraham; his being mentioned in Scripture
without any Pedigree, without father without mother, without descent, having
neither beginning of days, nor end of life. All these he had; as our Savior
himself had them; but none of them recorded or registered in the Scripture; that
he might so become a Type of the eternity of Christ's Person, and Priesthood;
verse 3. The Apostle further observes his Offices, that he was both King and
Priest; and that our Savior was made such, with an oath of God the Father; and
a Priest of a better Priesthood, Covenant, and Commandment; and that he was
made, not after the Law of a carnal commandment, having carnal successors in
his Priesthood; but after the power of an endless life, consecrated for
evermore, having an eternal Priesthood, and unchangeable, continuing ever, and
living ever to make intercession, and by his one, offering up himself once for
all, saving them to the uttermost that come to God by him. In all which there
are manifold resemblances between Christ and Melchizedec; and manifold
differences between theirs and the Aaronical Priesthood. As for those fond and
forced dreams of the Papist, That Melchizedec offered up to God the sacrifice
of bread and wine; And therein was a Type and Figure of their sacrifice of the
Mass; And that thereupon Christ our Lord is said to be a Priest after the
order of Melchizedec; These may well befall to them, who for want of the love of
the truth, are given up to believe lies; but are too weak, poor, and silly, for
us to trouble our selves withal.

The Lord at thy right hand] The prophecy of Christ the Lord his
administration of his Kingly Office, verse.

The Lord, God, the Father, who will make thine enemies thy footstool, He at
thy right hand, ready to assist thee. O Christ; as Psalm. XVI. 8. and CIX. 31.
Shall strike through Kings, Psalm. II. 2, 4, 5. even the highest Powers and
Potentates that oppose Christ and his Kingdom, 2 Cor. X. 5. In the day of his
wrath, the time appointed in Gods wisdom, the time of his just will so to
punish them with plagues temporal, eternal, in this life, in that to come, 1
These. I. 9, 10. Not that Christ the Lord shall be exempted from this powerful
conquest, and overthrow of his enemies; the Son being in all things coequal,
consubstantial with the Father; And so the Act coming from the Father, by the
Son; But in this speech relation is had to Christ, as (...), God and Man, as
the King Mediator, and receiving his Office from the Father.

He shall judge] The Lord at thy right hand shall execute judgments and
punishments.

among the heathen] Psalm. II. 1. Acts IV. 27. all his enemies whatsoever.

he shall fill the places with the dead bodies] All places with the carkases of
the slain. See Jer. XVI. 4. A figurative and poetical expression of an huge
slaughter; such as was that of the Jews at the final destruction of Jerusalem,
after the death of our Savior.

he shall wound the head in many countries] Wound, or strike through. Head for
heads collectively, Psalm. LXVIII. 21. in many or great countries. See that
Apoc. XX. 9, 10.

He] Christ the Lord.

shall drink of the brook in the way] In pursuing the victory over his enemies;
he shall do, as Gideons soldiers did, Judge. VII. 7. admit of no delays; which
occasioned that interdict, adjuration, and curse of Saul, 1 Samuel XIV. 24. Or
rather, these words seem to have relation to Christ's state of Humiliation; and
the rather because of that opposition thereunto in the words following. And so
here we have Christ's exinanition, and exaltation; his passion, and
resurrection; whereby he was brought to sit at the right hand of the Father,
verse 1.

drink] In passing through this valley of tears, in this world, he shall drink
deeply of the cup of sorrows: the waters, floods, and torrents of afflictions
and miseries should overtake and encompasse him, if not overwhelme and drown
him, Psalm. LXXXVIII. 7. 17. See Jer. XXV. 15, 16. and chap. XLIX. 12. Matthew.
XX. 22. John XVIII. 11. Matthew. XXVI. 39.

in the way] Of this life; the way of doing his fathers will for the work of
man's redemption, Phil. II. 7, 8. He hid for the time the luster and beams of
his Divine Majesty; that it might not hinder the sufferings and death of his
Humanity, 1 Cor. II. 8. Matthew. XVII. 9.

therefore] Thus Christ came from his humiliation to his exaltation, from his
Priesthood, to his Kingdom. Therefore here notes not a Merit preceding in
Christ, meriting for himself this exaltation; or his glory either in body, or
soul, his life eternal; All necessarily followed upon that hypostatical Union,
which he could not merit to himself. All Christ did, was to merit for us. The
particle here notes the consequence or sequel, and order, the means and manner
how he came to this exaltation.

shall he lift up the head] Be exalted; sit at Gods right hand. See for the
phrase, Psalm. III. 3. and XXVII. 6. Jer. LII. 31. Lam. II. 10. sublimi feriet
sydera vertice.

Praise] This is one of the Alphabetical Psalms. Psalm. Thereby to help
memory, and to mark out the excellency of these Psalms. See the Observations
on the beginning of the Book of Psalms.

wonderful works] In Egypt.

meat] Manna and Quails.

Covenant] Though they by their sins often and grievously provoked him.

heathen] Canaanites.

Praise] Psalm.

wealth] See the Observations on Psalm. XXXVII. 1.

light in darknesse] Esaias LVIII. 10. Job XI. 17. Psalm. XXXVII. 6.

of evil tydings] Prove. I. 33. Otherwise is it with the wicked, Jer. XLIX. 23.

gnash with his teeth] See that Luke XIII.

who humbles himself to behold] Psalm. etc. Job XXXIV. 21, 22. Prove. V. 21.
Jer. XVI. 17. contrary to that, Psalm. LXXIII. 11. and LXIV. 6. and XCIV. 7, --
10. Job XXII. 12, 13.

He raiseth] 1 Samuel II. 8.

mountains skipped] Sinai, Horeb, quaked and shaked, Exodus XIX. 18. Hab. III.
6, 10. Psalm LXVIII. 8.

Their idols are] Not like unto our God, verse 3.

are like unto them] As much without sense and reason,

their help] Theirs that trust in him: or one person,

has he given] To their use,

The dead praise not] Psalm. Esaias XXXVIII. 18.

I love] This may seem to be David's Psalm,

Therefore] The experience of Gods hearing our prayers,

Pains of hell] The sorrows and straits of death, Psalm. XVIII. 5, 6.

Gratious] The issue and effect of Prayer.

thy rest] Thy quiet comfortable estate in God without trouble of conscience,

I beleeved] 2 Cor.

I was greatly afflicted] The Hebrew word here has an Active form, but in a
Passive signification. As sometimes an Hebrew word in a Passive form, is of an
Active signification. See Esaias XXI. 10. and chap. XXV. 9. and LIII. 7. and Ezekiel
XIV. 4, 7.

haste, All men are liers] Even the Prophets, as Samuel that promised to me the
Kingdom. Yea, all men, in comparison of God; unable to help in time of need,
Romans III. 4.

cup of salvations] Used in the Israelites Peace Offerings of Thanksgivings,
Chron. XVI. 1, 2, 3 whence that seems to be, Luke XXII. 17.

vowes] Made in mine adversity. Annotations on Jonah I. 16.

Pretious] Psalm. LXXII.

Praise] The Apostle alleges this to prove Gods mercy to the Gentiles,

O give thanks] This may seem to be David's Psalm; Sam. XII. 29.

on my side] Heb.

All nations] David had to deal with all the neighboring nations round about
him.

Thou] Speaking to the enemy.

Open to me] The gates of the Sanctuary,

of righteousnesse] For the righteous and clean only were to enter in thereat,
2 Chronicles. XXIII. 19. See Esaias XXVI. 2. Apoc. XXI. 27.

The stone] David Typicaly; Mat. XXI. 42. Ephesians. II. 20.

builders refused] The Rulers refused David in the reigns of Saul, and
Ishbosheth. The Priests and Elders refused Christ, Mark XII. 2, 10. Luke XIX.
14. 1* Pet. II. 7.

the head stone] Acts IV. 11. Luke XX. 17. Of this stone see more, Esaias XXVIII.
16. Dan. II. 34, 35, 45. Zech. III. 9. Romans IX. 33.

the day] A chief and choice day of God showing his mercy.

Save now^beseech thee] Heb. Hoshiah^ na, Hosanna; wherewith Christ is welcomed
to Jerusalem, and the Temple; Mat. XXI. 9, 15. Luke XIX. 37, 38.

we have blessed you] These seem to be the Priests words, Number. VI. 23.

light] Prosperity, David, and Christ.

even unto the horns of the Altar] Likely the horns of the Altar Exodus XXVII.
2. intended for that use. Or, sacrifices abundantly all the Court over till you
come to the horns of the Altar, Levit. IV. 7.

Blessed] Of this Psalm see the Observations on the beginning of the Book of
Psalms. David probably is the penman of it. The style is plain, fitted for
all capacities. And the Alphabetical order was used for help of memory. It is
full of the ardent pious affections of a religious soul. Petitions for saving
knowledge, and gracious assistance from God, and Promises of all holy sincere
obedience thereupon, are in every Octonarie; with wondrous art and variety of
sense; yet running much upon the same words, without any tautologie.

Before I was afflicted] So verse 71. Junius; unless we understand it thus,
Before I cried out by reason of affliction.

my soul is continualy in my hand] i. e. Judge. XII. 3. 1 Samuel XIX. 5. and chap.
XXVIII. 21. Many read this text in thy hand, or hands, understanding Gods hand,
which imports, not danger, but safety and security, as Psalm. XXXI. 5. Luke
XXIII. 46. 1 Pet. IV. 19. And is indeed a wrong reading; and breeds sundry
senses, not consonant, or consisting with the tenor of this verse.

any iniquity] either in me, subjective; or of others against me, objective.
And so the later way may be understood that Gal. II. 7, 90 Ephesians. VI. 12. Heb.
XII. 4. Psalm. XLIX. 5. and XL. 12. and LXV. 3. and XXXIX. 8.

A song of degrees] or ascensions, Psalms following, have this Title prefixed.
The meaning whereof is variously conjectured; As thus, That they were to be
sung with a loud voice, as 1 Chronicles. XV. 16. Or, upon the steps and degrees of
the stairs ascending to the Court of the people, or to that of the Priests,
which, they say, were fifteen in number, according to these number of these
Psalms. Or, in the coming of the Ark into the Temple. Or in their return out
of Babylon. Or to be sung in their return into their own land in the time of
the Messiah. Others have other conjectures; yet without any certain
determination; neither is it much material. Of these, four bear David's title,
and some of the rest not unlikely were penned by him.

I] David likely.

from lying lips] Of such as falsely accused him to Saul. Sam. XXIV. 9. and
chap. XXVI. 19.

what shall be given] What good or profit shall thou get or gain by it.

sharp arrowes] Such is a false tongue:

Woe is me] Laments, Mesech, the son of Japhet, Genesis X. 2. and of Kedar, the
son of Ishmael, Genesis XXV. 13. or rather, with men of like evil cruel
conditions to them.

hills] Moriah, Zion; where God dwells. But most to God himself, verse 2.

The Sunne] By its parching heat; Jonah IV. 8. Nor the Moon, by its cold
vapors. Genesis XXXI. 40. nor any discommodity shall be able to annoy thee, Psalm.
XCI. 5.

I] David having brought the Ark of the testimony to Jerusalem, Psalm of joy
and gladness therefore: Praising the City; and praying for the prosperity of
it.

testimonie] The Ark. Observations on. Ex. 25. 16.

thrones of judgement] Both Ecclesiastical, Deuteronomy. XVII. 8, etc.

the captivity of Zion] Out of Babylon:

that dreame] So incredible it was, and the joy of it, that we half doubted
whether it were true, or but a dream. As Peter did, Acts XII. 9, 11. See Esaias
XXIX. 7, 8. And the like speech we read of in Abdolominus when he was taken
from manuring the earth, to possess a Kingdom: and in Isaacus Angelus, when
he was suddenly lifted up to the Empire: and in that famous John Chrysostom,
when he was first chosen into the Presbytery.

Turn again] Prays that the deliverance begun, Ezra, and Nehemiah.

They that sow in tears] That went mournfuly into captivity,

for Solomon] Seems to be inspired and penned for Solomon, David, a little
before his death, Psalm. LXXII. title

Except the Lord] This is true generaly: Solomon, and the safe keeping of the
City Jerusalem: or rather to the building of Solomon's house and posterity.

so] By building,

he giveth] Or surely will give, or rightly does give.

his beloved] Whom he loves, and who in assurance of his love commits himself
to him and his care. The Hebrew word Iedid seems to allude to Solomon's name
Iedidiah, 2 Samuel XII. 25. his darling.

sleep] Or quiet rest, without carking care and sorrow. The Hebrew word is
written with (...) a quiet dumb letter, otherwise then usual, to denote the
more quietness. And this rest, not your care and toil, but Gods blessing, will
bring unto you, Prove. X. 22.

Blessed] The Blessings that ordinarily follow them that Fear the Lord* Psalm.
LXXIII.

eat the labour] As on the other side it is true of the wicked, Prove. I. 31.

the cords] Wherewith they drew their Plough;

his bosome] Or arms; Esaias XLIX. 22.

The blessing] As Ruth II.

Out of the depths] Psalm.

forgiveness with thee; that thou may be feared] Hos III. his mercy, and our
plenteous redemption, is the true cause of our fearing of him, and hoping in
him, verse 7. If without this, God did strictly mark our iniquities, our hope
in him, and reverential fear and worship of him, would utterly fail and perish.

shall redeem] Psalm.

not haughty] In aspiring to the Kingdom; Saul's ruin and destruction.

as a weaned childe] That is,

Let Israel] By my example.

A Song] This seems to be David's, Jerusalem. Some say, Solomon's; acting what
his father purposed and ordered, 2 Samuel VII. 8. with 2 Chronicles. VI. 41.

his afflictions] In coming to the crown; verses following.

surely] If I enter.

my house] Newly built, and mentioned, 1 Chronicles. XV. 1.

sleep] In that house.

we heard of it] We Bethleemites heard of the Ark.

at Ephratha] That it was, or had been at Shiloh in the tribe of Ephraim: or
much rather, we at Bethlehem Ephratha, in our own country, heard of it, Micah
V. 2. Genesis XXXV. 16, 19. 1 Samuel I. 1. See the Annotations on Micah V. 2.

we found it in the fields of the wood] Or Jaar; in Kiriath-jearim, a City
seated in the woods, as the name imports. And of Kiriath-jearim, See the
Observations on 1 Samuel VII. 1.

Arise] 2 Chronicles. Number. X. 35. Psalm. LXVIII. 1.

thy rest] Ver. 13, 14. still flitting and wandering before.

cloathed] As with their sacred garments. Apoc. XIX. 8. Ephesians. IV. 24. Col. III.
10, 12, 14. Gal. III. 27. Romans XIII. 14.

For thy servant David's sake] Verse 1. Kings 8. 25. Psalm. LXXXIX. 20. Esaias
XXXVII. 35. And for Christ's sake, called David, Hos. III. 5. See the
Annotations upon that text.

of thine anointed] Me, thine anointed King.

of thy body] This relates to Christ, Acts II. 30.

If thy children] Thus conditional to David's posterity, Sam. VII. 14. Psalm.
LXXXIX. 30 -- 33.

for evermore] Verified only in Christ, the Son of David.

the horn of David to bud] Psalm. LXXXIX. 24. Luke I. 69.

a lamp] 1 Kings XI. 36. and XV. 4. 2 Kings VIII. 19.

Hermon] See the Observations on Deuteronomy. Hermon and Zion here are far distant
mountains. And so the dew of Hermon descends not upon the mountains of Zion;
but the similitude is twice repeated, of the dew falling upon those two several
distinct and distant mountains.

commanded] Psalm. XLII. 8. and XLIV. 4. and LXVIII. 28. and LXXI. 3. Deuteronomy.
XXVIII. 8.

by night] 1 Chronicles. Psalm. XCII. 3. and CXIX. 147. Luke I^. 37. 1 Samuel III. 3.
Some think that this, and the next Psalm, were made for the use of such
worshippers by night.
