for the raine] Or,

repent] Even in the judging of his people;

Rivers] May comprehend here Euphrates, Tigris, or Eulaeus or Chabor, being
then all under the Babylonish Empire.

of Babylon] In the seventy years captivity. Of Babylon, see the Observations
on Dan. IV. 30.

of Edom] Obadiah, verse 10, -- 16. Ezekiel XXV. 12. Jer. XLIX. 7. Lament. IV. 2.

thy little ones] Sin enough in Babylon, Shinar, Zech. V. 8, 11. Sin enough
in these little ones: as in the little ones of the old world drowned with Noah's
flood: as in the little ones of Sodom, burned with brimstone: etc.

thy Word above all thy name] Or,

with strength.] Ephesians.

in the ways of the Lord] Or, Psalm. CIII. 7. when they shall be converted.

will perfect] Phil. I. 6. Psalm. LVII. 2.

Praise ye the Lord] Heb. Halelu-jah. And thus do begin, and end likewise, the
rest of the Psalms that follow. In the Greek, it is Alleluia Apoc. XIX. 1.
Halelu-jah, is in Psalm. CIV. and CVI. and CXXXV. and in many others.

which executes judgement] Who succors and relieves all,

out-casts] Deuteronomy.

tells the number] Esaias XL. Ier. XXXIII. 22. at least in common opinion, and
of him indeed cannot be all seen. The number of the stars is counted by
ancient Astronomers; And all within, and without their several Constellations,
in their several magnitudes, are reduced by all, much under the number of two
thousand. Yet their number, in Scripturephrase, is marshaled with the sands of
the sea, as innumerable. Which is spoken according to vulgar opinions and
apprehensions; as that of the Sun, and Moon Genesis I 16. And diverse other
things are in Scripture in like sort spoken of. And yet the innumerable
multitude of them appears the more, in our times; Wherein Galileus, and others
after him by their new instruments and Tubi Optici, have made such strange
discoveries of many many numbers of them, never seen before.

young ravens] Job XXXVIII.

fat of wheat] Psalm.

runneth] Psalm. XXXIII. 9.

snow like wooll] accordingly the phrase is, fleeces of snow.

his ice like morsels] Frost, or frozen hailstones.

his word unto Jacob] This is singular mercy, and peculiar to his Church:
far beyond all those formerly mentioned: for which his Church is so bound to
praise him.

stars of light] Job XXXVIII.

havens of heavens] The heaven of heavens is the highest heaven; Cor. 2. XII.
The sky where the stars are, is the second heaven. And the air under it, and
next us, is the first heaven: In the upper part whereof are the waters here
mentioned. For this Text, and Genesis I, 6, 7. yield not a sure foundation whereon
to build an Orb of supercelestial waters, above the starry heavens; nor from
the windows of that Orb came the waters in Noah's flood. But from the lowest
region of the air, called Heaven, and the firmament of Heaven, wherein the
winds, clouds, and fowls do fly; and do divide between the sea-waters, and
the watery clouds which moysten the earth, and make it bring forth fruit for
the sustenance of man, and beast. See Genesis I. 20. Jer. LI. 16. Dan. VII. 2, 13.
Psalm. LXXVIII. 23. Mal. III. 10.

a decree] Statute, Job XIV. 5. and XXVI. 10. and XXXVIII, 33. Jer. XXXI. 35.
and XXXIII. 25.

the horn of his people] Psalm. Luke I. 69.

him that made him] Heb. his makers. Likely relating to the Trinity of persons,
as Genesis I. 26. and III. 22. and XI. 7. Job. XXXV. 10. Eccles. XII. 1. Esaias VI.
8. LIVE. 5.

King] Christ, of whom King David was a Type. As Mat. XXI. 5. Cant. I. 4,

upon their beds] Night and day, Psalm. LXIII. 6. Job XXXV. 10.

and a two-edged sword] Heb. Ephesians. VI. 17. Heb. IV. 12. Apoc. I. 16. which is
the Word of God, coming out of Christ's mouth.

To execute vengeance upon the heathen] Chiefly in and by the power and

To binder their Kings] Psalm. Esaias XLV. 14. Mark VI. 20. Acts XXIV. 25. Apoc.
XXI 24. Matthew. XVI. 19.

Or, to the exact rule of Gods Word, without any addition, or diminution. Deuteronomy.
XII. 32. Apoc. XXII. 18.

This honour] Deuteronomy. IV. 6, 7, 8.

Sanctuary] His holy place.

firmament of his power] His power seen in the firmament, in the stretching
out and spreading abroad of it, Psalm. XIX. 2. Dan. XII. 3.

that has breath] Apoc. V. 13.

Proverbs.
THE Book of Proverbs contains the chief of those three thousand Proverbs which
Solomon spoke, 1 Kings IV. 32.

They are Proverbs and instructions of Piety, and Wisdom; and the Praises of
it; with Exhortations to it, and Dehortations from the chief avocations and
impediments of it, in the nine first chapters. All which serve well, as a large
Preface and preceding Introduction. And then do follow Proverbs, or choice
sentences, (...), or wise Apothegines, Solomon's Ethics, our Digesta, and
Pandects; All of Morality, and prudential Civility, in the rest of the Book.

Wherein coherence of Sentences is not much minded: A Repetition of the same
things, by reason of the several Collections of them, is found sometimes: And
the verity of some of them, is not like that of Mathematical Theoremes; but
consists in such a generality of truth, as stands good, and is so (...), for
the most part; And yet admits of alteration by variety of circumstances, and
other incident occasions.

Throughout the Book, Solomon speaks, one while in his Own name; Another while
in his Fathers; Then in Wisdoms; Elsewhere, in his Mothers; and sometimes in
Gods name.

It may seem thus; That he speaks in his Own name, Chapters I, II, III. He
sets down the sum of his Father David's Instructions, Chapters IV, V, VI, VII.
Then brings in Wisdom speaking, Chapters VIII. IX. After he sets down those
Proverbs of his Own, which he had set in order in his Lifetime, Chapters X,
-- XXIV. Then others are added that were gathered by the Servants of King
Hezekiah, Chapters XXV, -- XXIX. Then follows the Prophecy of Agur, Chap. XXX.
And lastly, the Instruction which Solomon's mother taught him, Chap, XXXI. So
that the Collection was made by sundry; and at sundry times. For explanations,
where most need shall be, I shall give some short touches; And therein
willingly make choice to use such expressions as I can best judge in other
Authors helpful this way: And by way of collection and contraction pick out the
pith of them.

of Solomon] Of his wisdom, Kings III. 12. and IV. 29, 30, 31. and X. 23, 24.
Eccles. XII. 9, 10.

to give subtiltie] Sacred sagacitie, Cor. II. 10. 2 Cor. III. 18.

The fear of the Lord] It is Wisdom it self, Job XXVIII. 28. He sets it here
in the Beginning; and he makes it the End of all, yea, the All of man, Eccles.
XII. 13.

wisdome] The wisdom of God; Col. II. 3. 1 Cor. I. 30.

wisdom crieth] John VII. 37. The Hebrew is, Wisdoms cries. The plural
number is here used, by way of excellency, to denote the singular eminency of
the thing so spoken of. And so Behemoth, signifying beasts, for that singular
beast, Job XL. 15. And so, If I be masters, in the Hebrew, Mal. I. 6. And so
likewise Elohim pluraly is used for one only God. Unless, by way of Ellipsis,
we will take the meaning thus; the wisdom of wisdoms; the beast of beasts;
the master of masters; the God of Gods. In like sense the plural is used, Lam.
III. 22. Psalm. LI 17. 2 Samuel XXII. 1.

and ye refused] This is a step toward the sin unpardonable.

I also will laugh] Psalm. II. 4. Then man has cause to weep. The poison of
sin thus working upon God, and Christ. Esaias I. 24.

Then shall they call] Prove. Sam. XXVIII. 6. Psalm. XVIII. 41.

the prosperity of fools shall destroy them.]

quiet from fear of evil] Psalm. XLVI. 2,

if thou criest] Hos.

and searchest for her] Till ye get all those dimensions of Knowledge, Ephesians.
III. 18. Romans XV. 14.

who rejoice to do evil] Who cannot be merry, Ier. XI. 15.

none] For the most part,

Length of dayes] If a short life be not a blessing, Kings XIV. 13. Esaias LVII.
1. when there is a fire in an house or a town, men carry out their jewels. But
then God makes them up in his Cabinet, Malachi III. 17.

Be not wise] Bis desipit qui sibi sapit. chapter XXVI. 12.

the chastening] Is cited, Heb. XII. 5, 6. Schola crucis, schola lucis.
Adversity is the best University.

she is a tree of life] Alluding to Genesis

and happy is] The retainers of her. So in the Hebrew. And the meaning is well
rendered in our English, every one that retains her. The like phrase and use
of the plural, joined with a singular, and in a distributive sense, in the
Hebrew, is found, chap. XIV. 1. Genesis XLIX. 22. Exodus XVII. 12. and XXXI. 14.
Josh. II. 4. Job XII. 7. Psalm. LXXIII. 7. Joel I. 20. 2 Kings V. 13.

The Lord by wisdome] By his essential wisdom, chap. VIII. 30. Apoc. III. 14.
Heb. I. 2. Col. I. 16.

go,

surely he scorneth the scorners* but he gives grace to the lowly] Jam. Pet.
V. 5. Those scorners are such through pride. And the grace here given is not
meant of inward sanctifying grace, but of external favor, repute, and
estimation with men. And so chap. I. 9. and IV. 9. Eccles. VII. 1. and chap.
IX. 11. Luke II. 52. Acts II. 47. And so also may be understood, Luke I. 28.
and Ephesians. 1. 6.

scorneth] Psalm, I. 1. chap. I. 22. and IX. 7, 8. See the Observations there.

VII. 5. 2 Pet. III. 3. Jude 18.

Only] Not borne; Bathshebah. His Father loved also other of his sons but too
well.

He taught me] The substance of his Father David's doctrine, Solomon does
briefly set down to the tenth verse. And then proceeds in his own words.

Forsake her not] Falling Stars were never but Meteors.

with all thy getting] With any pains,

For they sleep not] Et si non aliqua nocuisset, mortuus esset.

thy heart] This is the chief Monarch in this Isle of man, c. XXIII. 26

Let thine eyes look right on] On right objects. If thine eye offend thee, pull
it out of the old Adam, and set it in the New man: Else better to pull it out
indeed.

Ponder] By the weight of the Sanctuary.

feet] Affections. For by these maids, Satan wooes the Mistress.

Lest strangers] Chap. VI.

own cisterne] Cant. IV. 12.

only thine own] Sow there where thou may reap,

if thou be surety] Of suretiship, Prove. XI. 15. and chap. XVII. 18. and chap.
XXII. 26. and XX. 16. and chap. XXVII. 13.

sluggard] Solomon is often upon him in the Proverbs. Once for all take it thus;
He paints him out in this wise; Yet a little sleep, a little slumber, a little
folding of the hands to sleep, chap. VI 10. and chap. XIX. 15. and chap. XXIV.
33. whereupon he bespeaks him thus, How long will thou sleep O sluggard? when
will thou arise out of thy sleep? chap. VI. 9. and chap. XIX. 15. As the door
turns upon his hinges, so does a slothful man upon his bed, for all its
turnings it hangs there still, chap, XXVI. 14. He hides his hand in his
bosom, and it grieveth him* he is weary, he will not so much as bring it to
his mouth again, chap. XIX. 24. and chap. XXVI. 15. and chap. XII. 27. His way
is an hedge of thorns, chap. XV. 19. He says, A lion is in the way, a lion is
in the streets, chapter XXVI. 13. I shall be slain in the streets, chap. XXII. 13.
a lion without, and a lazy lozel within. I went, says Solomon, by the field
of the slothful, and by the Vineyard of the man void of understanding. And lo,
it was all grown over with thorns, and nettles had covered the face thereof,
and the stone-wall thereof was broken down, chap. XXIV. 30, 31. He will not
plough by reason of the cold, chap. XX. 4. He rosteth not that which he took in
hunting, chap. XII. 27. As vinegar to the teeth, and as smoke to the eyes, so
is the sluggard to them that send him, chap. X. 26. His soul desires, and has
nothing, chap. XIII. 4. his desire kills him, for his hands refuse to labor,
chap. XXI. 25. And so he is brother to him that is a great waster, chap. XVIII.
9. whereupon his poverty comes as one that travelleth, and his want as an armed
man, chap. VI. 11. and chapter X. 4. and chapter XIX. 15. and chapter XX. 13. and XXIII.
21. and XXIV. 34. that he shall beg in harvest, and have nothing, chap. XX. 4.
but be under tribute, XII. 24. and be clothed in rags. And yet this sluggard is
wiser in his own conceit, then seven men that can render a reason, then the
seven wise men of Greece, c. XXVI. 16. Howbeit the wise man here sends him to
the Ant, to consider her ways, and be wise. See Mat. XXV. 26.

no guide] As in the Bees is an umbrage of Monarchy,

He winketh] Does twinkle with his eyes,

without remedie] A dreadful and dismal doom,

thou wakest] Psalm. CXXXIX.

to keep thee] To be as an amulet to that end.

her beauty] Helen without, but Hecuba within.

not be innocent] flagitium and flagellum, sicut acus and filum. Culpam Paena
premit comes, says Horace. Abraham might see Sodom burning; but Lot must not
look that way.

sevenfold] Often restore, Psalm XII. 7. But is not punished with death, as
the adulterer is. We read in the Law, of double, of fourfold, and fivefold
restitution, in several cases of theft, Exodus XXII. 1, 4. 2 Samuel XII. 6. Here
by sevenfold is meant manifold, as Psalm. XII. 6. a plentiful restitution.

the apple of thine eye] The least moat offends the eye;

I have peace-offerings] Pretends religion to her filthy practices.

with me] For thee; as she likely pretended.

my vowes] She is a Votarie too; such as many Popish Nuns are.

al plaine] In things necessary to salvation;

By me Kings reign] Romans

possessed me] i. e. Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotion, (...), accordingly: not

thereby the eternal Deity of Christ. And yet that Col. I. 15. the firstborn
of every creature, stands well in an Orthodox exposition, with the Catholic
Doctrine of Christ's eternal Deity. And the words in the verses following, do
agree unto Christ; compared with Psalm. II. 6. and XC. 2. Matthew. III. 17. John
I. 14. As moreover the words in the beginning of the next Chapter do agree to

foundations of the earth] Yet hangs in the air, ver. 30. John I. 1.

Wisdome] Hebr. wisdoms; the most excellent wisdom. See chapter VIII 1. and the

seven pillars] So many polished pillars as might be sufficient to uphold and

mingled her wine] This usual in those hot countries, verse 5. In relation to

come eat of my bread] As the Virgin Mary is not meant by wisdom, verse 1. so

Reprove not a scorner] Chap. chap. XXIV. 9. and XXVI. 4. Matthew. VII. 6. The

clamorous] The most lewd,

stolen waters] Those pleasures where the Devil is a play-fellow. But such

The Proverbs] Here the name of Solomon is prefixed again; Proverbs; wherein
the Opposition of Contraries in the same verse is very much used; and the first
part often serves much to usher in the second.

from death] The second death;

The Lord will not suffer] Though he refuse to enrich himself by evil arts,

shall be granted] If they fail not in the matter, manner, intention, or

Whirlwind] Job XXVII. 20, -- 23.

shortned] Eccles. VII.

The hope] Psalm. CXXX. 5. Prove. XIV. 32. Heb. VI. 18, 19.

Pride] Where pride is in the saddle,

the hope] His hope made a bridge of his own shadow; and thinking to go over

in his stead] As it befell Haman, Daniels enemies in the den of lions, and

holds his peace] From despising words,

concealeth] Tacitus to him is the best historian.

own flesh] As Baals Priests,

sure reward] Only he must have patience, and not look to sow and reap all in

pursues evil] As Asahel followed Abner. Ephesians. IV. 19. adding drunkenness to

a froward heart] A man may die by inward bleeding, Jer. IV. 14. The Heart

only good] Romans Heb. XIII. 18. Yet when the flesh gets the wind, and hill of

is wrath] Proves such, Romans II. 8, 9.

that scattereth] The five loaves in the Gospel were multiplied by division,

Wealth] As Nabals was for David; Hamans for Mordecai; the Canaanites for the

want of judgement] In tillage;

hates his sonne] As it proves in the issue. Eli to his sons: and in David

and XXXIII. 11. Psalm. CVI. 24.

satisfying] With contentation,

is easie] Chap. I. 20. and chap. VIII. 1, 17.

a mock at sinne] These dance with the Devil. Chap. X. 23. 2 These. II. 12. 2
Pet. II. 13.

favour] From God: or a complacencie in their righteous dealing: or gains them

not intermeddle] 1 Pet. Phil. IV. 7. 2 Cor. V. 4. It is an hansel of heaven.
The cock on the dunghill knows not the worth of this jewel.

seemeth] Chap. Exodus I. 10. And thereupon we willingly deceive our own hearts,
James I. 26. as Micah, Judge. XVII. 13. and Ier. VII. 4. And self-delusion is an
epidemical disease, and deadly.

even in laughter] Some frothy and flashy mirth the wicked may have; Cor. V.
12. Esth. V. 13

heavinesse] Job XXI. 12, 13. Luke 6. 25. Eccles. II. 2.

filled with his own wayes] have made a match with mischief,

from himself] 1 Timothy VI. 6. Heb. X. 34. Psalm. XIX. 11. Goodness is its own
reward, in hand, and in hope.

The simple beleeveth] As Jeroboam that old baby.

looks well] Looks before he leaps; tries before he trusts. 1 John IV. 1.
Ephesians. V. 15.

fears, and departeth] Fears the judgments whiles they hang in the
threatenings: counts them, not words so much, as thunderbolts, Hab. III. 16.

The evil bow] The worst cannot but think well of them;

his neighbour] Poor neighbor,

that devise evil? That plot and plough it,

labour] That is honest,

talk of the lips] Great talkers, are commonly do-littles.

is their riches] For God gives them wisdom to use them well.

fools] Rich fools. Riches to them is as a sword put into a mad man's hand.

strong confidence] Dan. III. XVIII. 5.

multitude of people] Which wars waste and consume. See 2 Samuel XXIV.

slow to anger] Anger may rush into a wise man's bosom; Eccles. VII. 9. James
I. 19, 20.

exalteth] Proclaims it aloud;

A sound heart] Well freed from passions and perturbations holds out long.

envie] A corroding disease it is: an hel-hag that feeds upon its own marrow,
bones, and strongest parts: it is as rust is to iron; as the viper: It both
sins, and is punished together, so quick and speedy justice accompanies it,
Job V. 2.

his maker] 1 Samuel Luke VIII. 43.

honors him] That is, honors God. God so takes it; chap. III. 8. And God
honors him; Matthew. XXV. 34. etc.

driven away] Being arrested by the Sergeant death,

has hope] Death to them is as the valley of Achor. Iustus etiam dum exspirat
sperat.

in the heart] Is not vainglorious, a sunning, to be seen and cried up.

in the midst of fools] Their zeal must be seen; 2 Kings X. 16. Their piety
must be shored up with popularitie.

a reproach] Sins are the snuffs of our candlesticks, Deuteronomy. XXVIII. 37. Ier.
XXV. 9. Ezekiel. V. 14, 15.

a wise servant] So to Joseph by Pharaoh; Daniel by Darius. And much more is
the favor of the King of Kings to his servants; Matthew. XXIV. 45, 46, 47. and
XXV. 21, 23.

his wrath] So to Haman, Shebna, and others.

A soft answer] Chap. Gideons to the Ephraimites, Judge. VIII. And Abigaels
apology to David, 1 Samuel XXV. 32, 33. Yet roughnes and hard language in some
cases, and circumstances, is necessary.

The tongue] Which David styles his glory;

The eyes of the Lord] As a well-drawn picture viewes all that come into the
room. Job XXXIV. 21, 22.

tree of life] Genesis II. 9. Ezekiel. XLVII. 12. Apoc. XXII. 2.

breach] A sting and a stain, in the conscience, and spirit: yea, and grieves
the spirit of God.

is prudent] Wise he is, Psalm. XIV. 5.

much treasure] The righteous man is always rich; capite, in Christ, he is no
usurper of them, 1 Cor. III. 22. Romans VIII. 32.

trouble] In getting, keeping, and fears of losing: together with sting of
conscience, Job XX. 15.

disperse knowledge] As Stars diffuse their light Phil.

The sacrifice] As good words uttered with a stinking breath, quoad fontem, and
quoad finem; not proceeding from a right principle; nor tending to the right
end, which is Gods glory, that should consume all other ends, as the Sun puts
out the light of the fire. See chap. XXI. 27. Amos V. 22. Esaias I. 11. and LXVI.
3. Jer. VI. 20. and VII. 22.

but the prayer] Esaias XLV. 11. command ye me.

The way] Prove.

follows after] With might and maine; as ravenous creatures have in chase
their prey. Phil. III. 11, -- 14. resurrection of the dead that is, that height
of holiness that accompanies the resurrection.

Correction is grievous] Being in love with his own ruin.

hates reproof] Being imbittered, not bettered by it.

Hell] Job XXVI. Psalm. CXXXIX. 12. Heb. IV. 13. (...); though invisible to us.

loves not] Yea hates, Amos V. 10.

neither will he go] As he should. Dan. XII. 4. 2 Kings IV. 23. Psalm. LXXXIV.
7. Esaias LXVI. 20. He says, as Jeroboam, 1 Kings XII. 28.

A merry heart] Acts VI. Cant. II. 4. This chiefly is true spiritualy.

broken] Is as a limb out of joint. A dejected spirit takes off as it were the

seeks knowledge] As an hungry man seeks meat;

feedeth] As swine do on swill.

a continual feast] This is eminently true in a good, Cor. I. 9, 12.

a little] It is not the great cage makes the bird sing: chap. XVI. 8. and

appeaseth strife] Is busy to stint it, chap. XXII. 24.

is made plaine] By much practice having gotten an habit, Esaias XL. 31. Christ's

is above] In heaven; Phil. III. 20. Col. III. 1. He deals in low and earthly
things, as a wise man may sport with children: but that is not his business.

hell beneath] That when the cold grave shall have his body, hot hell may not
hold his soul.

widow] That has none to stick to her, Sarepta, and of the poor Prophet, 2

The thoughts] Thoughts are not free, Jer. VI. 19.

pleasant words.] Mal. III. 16. chap. X. 20. and XXV. 11.

The light] Light and sight are comfortable, Eccl. XI. 7.

reproof] Better the Vine should bleed,

before honor is humility] The lower the ebb* the higher the tide.

is from the Lord] By the obstetrication of his assistance; and by his secret

in his own eyes] Chap. Luke XVI. 15. Romans II. 29. Judge. XVII. 13. we set up a

weighs the spirits] Chap. V. 21. the inside; and there discovers a Newfound

Commit] Luke XII. 29. Cast thy burden upon the Lord, Psalm. LV. 22. as it were,

established] Till then it flickers up and down, as Noah's Dove, till it return
to the Ark.

for himself] His own glory, Romans XI. 36.

for the day of evil] Job XXI. 30. as they are wicked men; and as such looked
upon by God: though he created them good; and he be the absolute Sovereign Lord
of all his creatures, and his will be both recta and regula. He justly keeps,
orders, and ordains such for the day of their deserved punishment, Romans IX. 17.
21, 22.

though hand] Chap. XI. 21. Heb. X. 31.

By mercy and truth] Of God; Chap. XIV. 22. there iniquity is purged. Piety,
and grace, and the fear of God, are a sure token of remission of sins.

even his enemies] Sin is the makebate. Esaias XXVII. 4, 5. and all his
creatures are at his beck and check. God made Laban, and Esau, at peace with

A divine sentence] Is, Solomon, 1 Kings III. 24. in David, 2 Samuel XIV. 17, 20.
a discerning power and sagacitie was in them, which God gave them.

his work] His Ordinance. Deuteronomy. XXV. 13.

to Kings] For they are more obliged to God then other men: Magnates are
Magnetes.

throne] Ier. XXII. 13, -- 20.

love him] Chap.

pacify it] As Abigael did David's; Benhadads servants did Ahabs. No other way

of the later raine] Deuteronomy. XI. James V. 7. Amos IV. 7. See my Annotations on

The high way] This is his road, Psalm. CXXXIX. 24. Acts XXIV. 16.

Pride] Swelling is dangerous in a wall, Esaias XXX. 13. dangerous in man's body;

Better] to be spoiled,

wisely] With due deliberation and circumspection.

trusts in the Lord] Not in his own wisdom. God can crack the strongest

lips] James III.

He shuts his eyes] With more freedom of mind to beat his brains,

then he that takes a Citie] Fortior est qui se,

gives heed] Is apt to believe scandalous reports.

poor] chap. XIV. 31.

childrens] If they,

an hundred stripes] Beaten he is, but not bent or bowed thereby to goodness;

only rebellion] Against God, and Man.

a cruel messenger] Gods executioners, all, and every of his creatures; Hab.

Whelps] Which she licketh into form,

evil for good] This ingratitude is a monster in nature. Ier. XVIII. 20, 21.

The beginning] Therefore stop it betime; James III. 5. It is hard to be

a price] Principaly appliable to those that neglect so great salvation, Heb.
II. 3. and let slip the opportunities put into their hands for heaven; and so
trifle and fool away their time, and eternal happiness. The vulgar Latin and
LXX. make another translation, and sense; not rightly.

A friend] A true friend, chap. XVIII. 24. and XXVII. 17. not such as those

Scilicet ut fulvum spectatur in ignibus aurum,
Tempore sic duro est experienda fides.
strife] Chap. James III. 16. Psalm. XXXVII. 8. It opens the gap to many
mischiefs.

gate] High and broad gates break men many times. Or rather, sets open a

begets a fool] Solomon's own case, chap. X. 1. and chap. XV. 20. and chap.

to punish] They should be cherished.

nor to strike Princes for equity] Rulers, for doing right in their offices.

Loquere ^tte videam.

separated himself] From the world,

A fool] It wilful to follow his own humor, chap. XIV. 33. Or phantastickly

brook] That the simplest may understand. The holy Scripture indeed is both

Train up a childe] Young Saints,

of a childe] Chap.

Bow down] Here seems to begin some alteration of style and method; Chapters;

a pleasant thing] Psalm. XIX. 11.

thy trust] Ephesians. I. 13.

even to thee.] We must read the Scripture, as men do Statute-books, holding

careless in the greatest danger whatsoever; and not refuse or forbear to sleep
on the top of ma^^.

not sick] A drunken man,

I will seek it yet again] Though they be sick with it, yet after their

the drunckard irrecoverable!

to be with them] In their state, David befools, and bebeasts himself, Psalm.

lips] It blistereth out at their tongues end.

yet a little sleep] Little,

povertie] The beggar shall catch him by the back,

These] Here begins a new Collection of Proverbs, Solomon's time; which some
choice men of King Hezekiah; likely by his appointment, Copied out of some of
Solomon's writtings then extant; or out of public Records, Registers, and
Commentaries, wherein for their worth and wisdom they were inserted. And in
these Solomon most-what entreats of higher matters, of State business, of
Regal and Civil administrations.

to conceal] Such as are, Romans XI. 33. Deuteronomy. XXIX. 29.

to search out] Chap. XVI. 10. Job XXIX. 16. 1 Kings III. 24, 27.

unsearchable.] Jer. XXXI. 37. profundum sine fundo Jer. XVII. 9. 1 King. IV.
29. Much more unsearchable are the deep and hidden ways of God; Romans XI. 33,
34. we must adore them, when we cannot comprehend them. Neither must the
subject think to attain to the depth of all the secret reasons and doings of a
King, even when he is upright, and does his duty.

hastily] Hasty men never want woe, Eccles. V. 2. chap. XXIX. 20. He soon

Debate thy cause] Matthew. V. 25. and XVIII. 15.

of a false gift] As the Devil, excelsa in excelsis, mountains on a mountain,

Judge. VIII. 1, 2, 3. And thus not ministering occasion to provoke him further.
Though it self be flesh, yet thus it breaks the bone.

sufficieut] Philosophandum, sed paueis.

and vomit it] By excess the sweetest comforts will be dissweetned, grow sower
and loathsome, 1 Cor. VII. 29. We must hang loose, and be weanedly affected
toward all creature comforts.

withdraw] Let thy foot be rare, Sam. III. 1, overlay not thy neighbor, nor
abuse his courtesy; take not too much of a free horse. Nulli te facias nimis
sodalem.

false witnesse] Chap. XIX. 5. Psalm. XLII. 10. and LVII. 4. A sin of a deep
die, of a crimson color.

Confidence in an unfaithful man] As was Achitophel to David. Jobs miserable
comforters, Job VI. 16, 17. There is faith to be kept with dogs, say the Turks;
with Heretics, say the Papists. David durst not trust Saul, 1 Samuel XXVII. 1.
notwithstanding his fair speeches and promises, chap. XXVI. 17, 21. 25.
Therefore try well before we trust.

songs to an heavy heart.] Ecclus. XXII. 6. Dan. VI. 18. Or, as some render
and sense the words, music drives away sorrow, 1 Samuel XVI. 24. 2 Kings III. 15.

Enemy be hungrie] Exodus XXIII. 4. V. 44. Romans XII. 20.

heap coals of fire] This seems to be related to, Romans XII. 19, 20. And the
words are commonly expounded and understood of heaping vengeance on thy enemies
head, and blessing on thine own, Psalm. CXL. 10. But this seems a very
uncharitable Exposition; but so savor of a vindictive policy; and not to suit
with Solomon's, or Paul's main scope, and charitable intention. And contrary to
that, chap. XX. 22. and chap. XXIV. 9. and to the tendencie of the text; And
therefore these coals of fire thus heaped on the enemies head, may better be
understood of his hearty repentance, kindled and burning in his head and heart,
whereby his malice is melted, and himself grieved with burning and scalding
sighs, that he has been thine enemy, who have been, and art so good as to
desire and do him good, whiles he did thee evil: And thus the fire of love and
charity is kindled in his heart, and his evil overcome with thy goodness: as
is in the Apostles Precept, and Exhortation annexed, Romans XII. 21.

reward thee] Though he should not; nor be overcome by thy kindness and
goodness.

a backbiting tongue] Brow-beat it. Apoc. XXII. 15.

good newes] The more unexpected,

falling down] By infirmity,

their own glorie] It is not glory, Gal. V. 26. John V. 44. and chap. XII. 43.
Gloria fugientem sequitur.

no rule over] Chap. XVI. 32.

so honour] Dignity should wait upon desert. Psalm. XII. 8. The contrary is of
very evil consequences many ways.

the curse causelesse] As the Popes Excommunications, Psalm. CIX. 28. Such
Cursers are cursed; the curse will fall upon the Cursers head.

for the fools back.] Verse 4, -- 12. Chap. X. 13. chap. VII. 22. Psalm. XXXII.
9. Much, and often is spoken of fools in this Book of Solomon's wise Proverbs:
to mark them out as rocks at Sea, that we might avoid shipwreck thereon.
Shortly thus; That the Fool feeds on foolishness; it is joy to him; he is
full of words: delights that his heart may discover it self: utters all his
mind; lays open his folly: says to every one that he is a fool: whereas, if
he held his peace, he might be counted wise: his instruction is folly:
Excellent speech becomes him not: honor is not seemly for him: The legs of
the lame are not equal; and so is a parable in the mouth of fools. His eyes are
in the ends of the earth; his heart at his left hand; he will be meddling: he
enters into contention, and his mouth calls for strokes, Job V. 2. A stone is
heavy, and the sand weighty, yet his wrath is heavier then them both. And as a
whip is for the horse, a bridle for the Ass, so a rod for the fools back: yet
he trusts in his own heart: that though thou should bray him in a Mortar
among wheat with a pestle, yet will not his foolishness depart from him: But
as a dog returns to his vomit, so a fool to his folly. He has no delight in
understanding; it is too high for him: though a price be put in his hand, to
get wisdom, yet he has no heart; he does despise, does hate knowledge and
reproof: yea the thought of foolishness is sin. He makes a mock of sin; it
is a sport to him to do mischief: And therefore says Solomon, meddle not with
him, or his company. Answer him not according to his folly; unless it be
shortly, to convince him; leave him, and go from his presence; for shame shall
be his promotion; and destruction is near at hand, to wait upon him.

Answer not] Say nothing, Esaias XXXVI. 21. Jer. XXVIII. 11. John XIX. 9, 10.
Luke XXIII. 9. Mark XV. 2, 3, 4, 5.

like him] As hot and as headlong as he: and so at length there will be never a
wiser of the two, but both fools.

Not foolishly] As he speaks;

Answer] Cast in somewhat that may sting him,

lest] He took upon himself as a conqueror; clap his wings, and crow.

These seeming contradictions and contrarieties, by due distinction of times,
and other incident circumstances, and considerations, are easily reconciled. So
Matthew. XII. 30.

fool] See on verse 3.

superstition did cast a stone.

from the Lord.] Who rules, chap. XXI. 1. and orders every man's state and

This Chapter is not Solomon's. Agur, some man famous in his time for wisdom;
his words unto his disciples, or friends, Ithiel, and Ucal; Or, here is a
Comportation and Collection of Agurs wise sayings and Sentences: though none of
all their names mentioned in the first verse, are found elsewhere in Scripture.

The words] Not of Solomon.

of Agur] Not mentioned elsewhere in Scripture. But seems a man famous for
wisdom, either in Solomon's, or Hezekiah's time.

Prophesie] Or, instruction; for so largely is the word Prophecy many times
taken. Or, Collectanies; gathered out of wise Agurs sayings, and proverbial
sentences, then extant, or well-known; and here added to Solomon's Proverbs, as
being of like argument, and consorting with them.

Ithiel, and Ucal] Some take these names for Christ, for his goodness, and
power. But with less straining, they rather seem to be the names of Agurs
scholars, or friends, here instructed by him.

more brutish] Agur begins in all humility, Adam; 1 Cor. II. 14. Psalm. VII. 3,
22. Job XXXII. 8. and chap. XI. verse 12. That flesh and blood, in natures
school, could not reveal saving mysteries unto him.

neither learned] Not of himself: but from God, Gal. I. 1. James I. 17.

of the holy] Holy God; and holy Angels, Dan. IV. 13. and VIII. 13. or holy and
heavenly things.

who has ascended] The difficulty great; John III. 13. And the Angels
Ministers to him, John I. 51. No man has seen God at any time: the only
begotten Son, which is in the bosom of the Father, he has declared him,
John I. 18. and declared heaven, Romans X. 6, 7. Heavenly wisdom by man of
himself is not attainable, Job XXVIII. Chapter. See Esaias XL. 12.

winde] Psalm. CIV. 3. and CXXXV. 7. Matthew. VIII. 26, 27.

waters] Job XXXVIII. 8, -- 11. Psalm. CIV. 3, 6, -- 13. Esaias XL. 12.

earth] I. Job XXXVIII. 4, 5, 6. Esaias XL. 12.

what is his Name] Job XI. 7, 8, 9. Judge. XIII. 17, 18. Exodus III. 13, 14, 15.
Matthew. XI. 27. John VI. 46. Esaias LIII. 8. The Son is like the Father, John
XIV. 7, 8, 9. Heb. I. 3.

if thou cast [ None can.

word of God] Psalm. XII. 6.

sheild] Genesis XV. 1. 2 Samuel XXII. 31.

Add thou not] Deuteronomy. IV. 2. Apoc. XXII. 18, 19.

Two things] Two special ones mentioned in the next verse.

deny me not] With importunity he reinforceth and follows his request, Psalm.
XXVII. 4. Genesis XXXII. 26. Luke XI. 8. Matthew. XV. 23. She came for a cure, and a
cure she would have. And God calls for, and delights in such importunities;
that so he may abound in his bounteous grants unto us, John XVI. 24. He would
have us smite five or six times, 2 Kings XIV. 18, 19. And he as Naaman would
then force two talents upon us; grant above all we ask or think.

vanity and lies.] Those lying vanities of sin:

neither poverty, nor riches] Both are naturaly attended, encumbered, and
burdened with many inconveniences. Yet sanctified both, to the child of God.
Mediocrite, a sufficiency without superfluity, is the estate that is most
easily managed, Matthew. VI. 11. 1 Timothy VI. 8. Tuta me media vehat
Vita decurrens via.


Lest I be full] Deuteronomy. XXXII. 15. 1 Timothy VI. 17. And so, Pharaoh-like, Who is
the Lord? as if they with their Mammon were pettie-gods, of, and within
themselves.

or lest I be poor] Stealth upon necessity, is less then adultery, Prove. VI.
30. Yet a sin always, Exodus XX. 15. Ephesians. IV. 28.

name of my God] This he grieves at more, then his own shame, burning in the
hand, whipping, hanging.

Accuse not] Romans XIV. 4. and II. 1. Matthew. VII. 1. Eccles. VII. 21, 22. Tit.
III. 1, 2, 3.

lest] The harm of the servants ill wishes fall upon thee.

Here begin his Quaternions, of some things Moral, Chapter.

that curses their father] A cursed crew, a bastardly brood, verse 17. and
chap. XX. 20. Levit. XX. 9. Exodus XXI. 17. Matthew. XV. 4. Deuteronomy. XXI. 18, -- 21.

are pure] As the Puritanes, Novatians, Donatists, Matthew. XIX. 20. Hos. XII. 8.
Esaias LXV. 5. Papists that pretend to works of Supererogation; And yet welter in
wickedness.

O how lofty] Chap. VI. 17. and chap. XVI. chap. XXI. 4. Esaias II. 11, 12, 17.
and V. 15. and X. 33. Job XXXIII. 17. Ps. CI. 5.

whose teeth] Psalm. LII. 4. and LVII. 4. Job XXIX. 17.

The horseleach] Has two forks in her tongue,

never satisfied] No more then Pharaoh's lean kine.

with a maid] That yet pretends so to be: verse: and that with impudency
enough. Incerta sunt virginis aut corruptae indicia.

for a servant when] Chap. XIX. 10.

little] Deus est maximus in minimis.

exceeding wise] Job XII. 1.

The Ants] Chap. VI. 6, 7.

Conies] Psalm. CIV. 18.

Locusts] Joel II. 4, 5, 7, 8. Apoc. IX. 11. have their King Abaddon

Comely] A comeliness of carriage belongs to us, Phil. I. 27. So Neh. VI. 7.

No rising up] Eccles. VIII. 2, 4.

in lifting up thy self] Against the King, verse 31. Eccles. VIII. 3. and chap.
X. 20. Exodus XXII. 28. Or, in any evil matter; then stop and silence thy self:
as Job XL. 4, 5. and chap. XLII. 6. and chap. XXI. 5.

so the forcing of wrath] Chap. XV. 1. Reiterated provocations extort strife.
James III. 16. Patientia laesa furor fit.

Here are the words of Bathsheba, Solomon; taught him likely when he was young,
against the time wherein he should be King; And when he was King, recorded
here, and registered by him. He is called here Lemuel, verse 1. And by his
mother Lemoel, verse 4. as tender mothers do often use to make loving changes
in their childrens names. And here she warnes him chiefly against women, though
he made ill use of this warning; And against wine. And from the tenth verse, to
the end, she elegantly describes the virtues of a worthy wife; as a pattern
for his choice; beginning every verse thereof with a several letter of the
Hebrew Alphabet in order.

Lemuel] Verse 4. Lemoel. Sam. VII. 14. and chosen him for King before any of
his elder brethren. His mother thus styles him; as mothers many times do frame
affectionate titles with some small variations, to insinuate with their
children; she breaks off the first letter of his name, and adds in the end the
name of God.

his mother taught him.] Lemuels lesson; taught him by Bathsheba; and if taught
him happily being King; then upon his beginning to warp and wander. He was taught
likewise by his father, chapter IV. 3, 4. Ps. CXXVII. and LXXII. Both which
heighten his after-fall, as well as that 1 Kings XI. 9. These words and
Prophetical documents may seem to be penned down by Lemuel himself afterward.

What my sonne] Passionate,

thy strength to women] Chap. V. 9. Deuteronomy. XVII. 17.

to drink wine] Chap. XXIII. 29, 30. Ephesians. V. 18. Hos. VII. 5. Esaias V. 11.
Hab. II. 15, 16. Eccles. X. 16, 17.

Lest] One, chap. XXIII. 29, -- 35.

and wine to those] Jer. XVI. 7. Mark XV. 23. Whereunto some apply that of Amos
II. 8.

and forget] Judge. IX. 13. Psalm. CIV. 15.

for the dumb] Chap. XXIV. 11, 12. Job XXIX. 15, 16. Ier. XXXVIII. 8, 9.

and plead] Levit. XIX. 15. Deuteronomy. I. 17. Psalm. LXXII. 4.

a virtuous woman] Chap. XII. 4. 1 Cor. XI. 7. Chapter. And that methodicaly,
beginning every verse with a letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, as it stands in
order. Such a woman as this is the female glory, the wonder of woman-kinde;
amiable, and admirable, as the paragon of the world. A fair pattern for
Solomon's choice in a wife. But a lesson ill learned by him, a worse practiced.
In this large Description, the whole Text needs not any Gloss.

Ecclesiastes.
THis is the Book of Solomon's Repentance; written in his old age, as may seem
to be gathered, both out of the Title of the Book, and the Closure of it in the
six last verses; and also out of the whole Body of it; Being written upon a
serious view of the Passages and practices of his life past, and the great and
manifold Experiences he had made and found therein. His maine business is a
curious search after true Felicity and real Contentation. And upon his search,
and experience he does find and pronounce. That in order thereunto, all things
under the Sun were but vanity of vanities, and vexation of spirit: and for
such experimented by him; though the same improved by humane wisdom in him to
the utmost, Chap. II. 3, 9. This he shows in a large manner, in sundry sorts, in
many particular vanities under the Sun; principaly in humane wisdom and
knowledge, humane labors, industries, and endeavors; in Delights and
Pleasures of all kinds; in Honors, Greatness, and Power; in Riches and
Possessions; and in the utter insufficiency that is in all these, to extract
from them, or the quintessence of them, any true happiness, or from any other
sublunarie thing, or creature whatsoever. He seems to speak sometimes in the
person, and according to the carnal reasonings of the Atheist and Epicure, as
reciting their opinions, with their arguments; yet he avers the truth of God
against them; and the just and wise course, though to us secret, hid, and
unsearchable, of his Providence, Administration, and government of all the
events, issues, accidents, and affairs of this life, in relation both to the
just, and to sinners; even in things befalling in common to both of them. He
gives sundry sound remedies to abate and heal the said Vanities. He speaks
much for Wisdom, and against Folly. And prescribes many good Rules for better
things, for procuring tranquillity unto the mind, and peace and comfort to the
life of a man; eftsoons minding and mentioning, among other things, a cheerful
fruition and enjoyment of the outward Blessings and Comforts of this Life, with
gladness, contentation, and thankfulness, as from the hand of God. And
lastly, in the twelfth Chapter he concludes, That in Old age, elegantly
described by him, and at Death, It will appear, That to Fear God, and Keep his
Commandments, is the whole of man, both the whole Duty, and Felicity of Man;
the one, and only thing wherein it consists.

The words] Solomon's Ethics, Sovereign good;

of the Preacher] Or of a preaching soul. The word (...) being Foeminine, has
(...) the soul understood. The penitent convert; gathering himself to the
Church. He again gives himself this title, chap. I. 2, 12. and VII. 27. and
XII. 8, 9, 10. Yet in those places it is construed with a Masculine. And so the
foeminine is sometimes used for the Common gender, which is wanting with the
Hebrews. The Greeks and Latins render it in the Masculine, Ecclesiastes. David
published his Repentance in Psalm. LI.

Vanity of vanities] Psalm. CXLIV. 4. and XXXIX. 5. Adam is all, Abel even at
his best estate, altogether vanity. And all worldly things are so, an heap, a
nest of vanities; vanity in the abstract. This the last issue and result, the
upshot of all his curious critical inquiry, search, and experiments.

what profit] A chief point in the wise man's Compass, cui bono? Who will show
us any good? Thus worldly men look after this, Psalm. IV. 6. Yea, wicked men in
their overtures of Religion, Mal. III. 14. No profit, toward the attainment of
true happiness.

Labor which, etc.] A labor in order to things above the Sun will profit,
Phil. III. 20. Colos. III. 1, 2. John VI. 27. No toilsome labor in earthly
things will do so. Nothing remains or abides with him, nothing more is added
to him by it; it adds nothing of real worth unto him at all. That we shall
find to be truth, which is in Habak. II. 13, 6.

One generation] Ecclesiasticus XIV. 18.

but the earth] Whereon as on a stage, the several Generations act their parts,
and go off, others come on.

abides for ever] Till its time of change, in the end of all, 2 Pet. III. 10.
See my Observations on Deuteronomy. XV. 17. The duration of the earth, opposed to
every man's duration, not the motion or standing of it, is here intended.

The Sunne] Psalm. XIX. 3. Observations on Psalm XIX. 5. See Job XIV. 7, 12. Here
the earth stands, and the Sun moves round about it.

The winde] Thus whirleth,

Rivers] Run thither whence they come through pores and passages of the
earth, way ever we cast our eyes, we every where meet with evidences of
inconstancy and mutability here below, as testimonies of that vanity which
all things under the Sun are subject unto; so that man cannot find
fatisfaction and full content in them.

full of labour] All these things are sweeter in the ambition, Prove. XXVII. 7,
20. After our utmost endeavors for plenarie satisfaction in the things of this
world and this life, we are still to seek, because it is not in them; we do so
but seek for the living among the dead, as Luke XXIV. 5. And they tire us in
the search, and toylesome labor after them; and cloy us in the use.

man cannot utter it] If not Solomon, then surely no man, chap. II. 12. As on
the other side our happiness in God, to our joy, is unutterable, 1 Cor. II. 9.
2 Cor. XII. 4.

The thing] Happiness cannot be extracted out of the creature;

no new thing] Though some kind of new inventions be, as Gunpowder, Printing,
the Mariners Compass, etc. yet but of the old stamp, as to this maine use and
purpose; they come still from defective and insufficient principles of
happiness, chap. III. 15. no new thing out of which man can extract real
content, comfort, and satisfaction, or any principle of true happiness and
blessedness, more then out of old and former things. And indeed Solomon speaks
here of natural things, and their natural actions.

This is new?] Such new things as may so far surpass the discoveries before,

There is no remembrance] If some new things be found out, Ezekiel. XXXVI. 26.
puts a new spirit within us, Ezekiel. XI. 19. and a new name upon us, Esaias LXII. 2.

I the Preacher] None had more abilities, Solomon had. And therefore his
verdict may be credited.

And I gave my heart] Solomon made this point his task; and that in the extent
and utmost employment of his great wisdom, chap. II. 3, 9. chap. IX. 10.

all things] 1 Kings IV. 33. and chap. X. 23, 24. the several kinds of them,
all natural causes and effects; all humane counsel and events.

and vexation of spirit] Active enough hereunto; Chap. XII. 12. chap. I. 18.

That which is crooked] Chap. VII. 13.

I communed] And this without vain boasting, Kings III. 12. and chap. IV. 30.
and X. 7, 23. 2 Kings III. and IV. and V. and X. none can outdo him herein.

and to know madness and folly] Chap. II. 12. chap. XI. 8, 9. 1 Cor. I. 20.

In much wisdom is much grief] Many ways, Verse 14.

I said] The sum of this Chapter is well set down in the Great Annotations.

I will prove thee with mirth] Missing of his expected good from the knowledge
of the creature, he now resolves to search what good may be found in the use
and fruition of it; And first in the sensual pleasure of it: In mirth, here.
Which most men count the only life, to sing all sorrow and care away; and melt
in mirth, jollity, and jovizansses, which emasculates the spirit, and draws
out, and draines away the very vigor and vivacitie of it: when they indulge to
themselves, and give up their heart to it, and make it the business of their
life to pour out themselves in delights, and wallow, and drown themselves in
them. This sort of men after Epicurus was borne, were called Epicureans.

mad] And indeed many mad men are very merry. chap. VII. 6. and has sorrow in
the bottom of it.

wine, yet acquainting] He would try,

till I might see] This the end of his inquiry by this experiment; whether
this voluptuous course of living were best, to sweeten the mortal life of man,
during all his days.

I made me great works] He shows what magnificent and royal provisions he made
in order to his foresaid design. Ester I. 4. These things he had as materials
for his wisdom.

houses] Besides what David had formerly built, 2 Chronicles. II. 3.

Vineyards] Cant. VIII. 11, 12. Besides what David had, 1 Chronicles. XXVII. 27.

gardens and orchards] Cant. VI. 2. and chap. IV. Hortus pensilis, a garden
hanging in the air, made by an Assyrian King for the pleasure of his Queen.

pooles] Chap. IV. 15. and VII. 4. Kings XX. 20. Neh. II. 14.

the wood] Of Forests; and likely in those Gardens and Orchards, which for
their spaciousness might be called woods.

servants, and maidens] See those servants, mentioned, Ezra II. 58. Neh. VII.
60.

cattel] More then David had, 1 Chronicles. XXVII. 29, 30, 31.

silver and gold] In all abundance, Chron. I. 15.

men-singers] See 2 Samuel XIX. 35. he labored to take all pleasure in pleasures.

also my wisdome] Verse 3.

I withheld not] Luke XII. Romans XIII. 14.

Then I looked] In the serious review he finds all to be but a feeding upon
the wind;

And I turned] To his first inquiry,

what can] True, without boasting. None can go beyond him; try who will.

wisdom excels follie] Foolish,

The wise man's eyes] He shows the great difference of worth between these two
contraries;

and I my self perceived] Though the one so far excelling the other; yet both
alike in this; no difference herein; but one event happens to them all; as
two ways meet at the same Inn; and Ships from several Coasts meet at the same
Haven; and Counters after casting sums, are put into the same bag.

And why was I then more wise?] To what purpose,

no remembrance] Chap. Prove. X. 7. Psalm. CXII. 6. and XLIX. 11, 12. Jer. XVII.
13.

and how dieth] As oblivion, so death, equal and common to both, Psalm. XLIX.
10. Ezekiel. XXI. 4. Only piety makes the difference, John XI. 25, 26.

Therefore I hated life] He saw little valuable or desirable in it.

all my labour] As being so vain and vexatious.

leave it] Psalm. XLIX. 10. and XXXIX. 6. And so Luke XII. 17. ere he was a day
elder.

a wise man, How Rehoboam proved, is well known, chap. VI. 2.

therefore I went about] Fetched a compass, Ephraim, Jer. XXXI. 18, 19. and the
Prodigal, Luke XV. 17. as those, 1 Kings VIII. 47. And being wearied in this
round, I was brought to a despondencie of spirit, and a despair of attaining to
my purpose and search, as being fruitless and unseazable; these empty things
only abusing and deluding me.

For there is a man] This particular did so pinch Solomon, Prove. XIII. 22. Yea,
leave it to a stranger, and enemy; as Nabals was to David; Hamans to Mordecai;
the Canaanites to the Israelites.

what has a man, etc?] A mere nothing; a coffin perhaps to his grave. Then
all the world is gone with him, Psalm. XLIX. 17. Eccles. I. 3. and III. 9 and V.
15

are sorrowes] In the abstract. Job V. 7.

not rest in the night] Though he lie upon a bed of down, yet these gnats will
not suffer him sleep; his heart does not rest, in that time of rest, Job IV.
13. as the clock cannot stand still while the plummets hang at it. Grace only
cures these cares, and procures this quiet rest, Phil. IV. 6, 7. Ps CXXVII. 2.

nothing better] Chap. verse 21.

the hand of God] It is not always in our power, Verse 26. Chap. III. 13. and
V. 19. Acts XIV. 17. God is then to be sought to, in whom only felicity is to
be found, Psalm. CXLV. 15, 16. Eccles. IX. 7, 8, 9.

For who can eat? verse 12.

For God giveth] To get these worldly things rightly, Chap. III. 12, 13.

but to the sinner] To scrape, and rape, chap. IV. 8. Hab. II. 6. Psalm. XXXIX.
6. Luke XII. 18.

give to him that is good] Job XXVII. 17. Prove. XIII. 22. and XXVIII. 8.

To every thing there is a season] Or rather a time prefixed, chap. VIII. 6.
And therefore we should quiet and content our selves in the good and
comfortable use of them; as chap. II. 24. And not seek to extract out of such
vain and variable things that good and felicity which is not in them. Yet
again, This may mind us not to neglect the seasons, times, and opportunities
of Grace, which are in Gods hand when he does please to offer and afford them,
Luke XIX. 42. Heb. II. 3.

A time] Chap.

What profit] Concludes that, Chap. I. 3. Matthew. VI. 27. no more then that,
James II. 14, 16. Consider that, Matthew. XVI. 26.

which God has given] God gives it,

beautiful] Though we at all times see it not in every thing; Esaias X. 12. we
being not able to find out the beginning or end of the causes or uses of Gods
works. Yet these seeming confusions God will reduce into an excellent and
beautiful order, and in a beautiful season too. Frost and Snow are as
seasonable in the Winter as heat, and flowers, and fruits are in the Summer.
The world is so much in our hearts, that we mind and mark not Gods dealings
sufficiently: and we are of so short continuance, that though we mind it, yet
we live not to observe a full point in the works of God: Their beginning may be
in one age, and their end in another, Romans XI. 34.

No good in them, but, etc.] To enjoy things present, and to do good here, and
so have good hereafter, Psalm. CXXVIII. 2. 1 Timothy VI. 18, 19.

it shall be for ever] His doing and counsel shall stand. Esaias XLVI. 10, 11.
Jer. 44. 28. And is perfect and holy; unalterable by man. Job XXXVIII. 31, etc.
We should therefore with willingness and contentment submit to him and his
doings, acquiesce in him, and dread, and adore him, though our blear eyes
cannot see the bright Sunshine of his actions. His decrees must not drive us
to despair, or to a neglect of using the means; but from deifying our selves,
and our own wisdom in the use of means, still depending upon his blessing.

And moreover] Having formerly showed the vanity and vexation of Knowledge,

the place of judgement] That should be a Sanctuary and City of Refuge for
wronged Innocence. That wickedness and oppression should be and reign there,
was a great vexation, and a great tentation too against Gods righteous
Providence.

I said] That God shall judge and right all, Acts XVII. 31. Some he judges
here, lest his Providence, but not all, lest his patience and promise of
judgment, might be called into question. Therefore this vanity and vexation
ought not to dismay the innocent, or hearten the oppressors: seeing God will
amend all.

that God might manifest them] Men in place and power, Psalm. XLIX. 20. God must
manifest it to them. And this should humble them, and stain their pride; This
shows, and should cure this vanity, Prove. XXX. 2.

For that which befalleth] Psalm. chap. II. 15, 16. hunger, thirst, diseases,
etc.

all turn to dust againe] Expire alike; Genesis III. 19. Job XXXIV. 15. This
still in relation to the body only.

Who knows the spirit of man] No man can by sense discern the ascent of the
one, Cor. II. 14, 15, 16. See chap. XII. 7. of this book. And Solomon's scope
throughout this Book, is to show the vanity of earthly things, and of humane
actions in order unto things under the Sun, as to satisfy the heart of man
in the acquiring of true felicity. Of his immortal or heavenly condition he
speaks not purposely. But as he makes Piety the Only Remedy against all these
earthly vanities and vexations; and so concludes his Book in the two last
verses. We need not here then to make these passages to be speeches taken up in
the Person of the ^picure or Atheist.

Wherefore I perceive] He resumes his Assertion, verse 13. and chapter II. XXIV.
and V. 18.

after him] What shall become of his goods; how used, and disposed; and by whom.

all the oppressions] More vanities and vexations in the Civil State.

no Comforter] Doubled here. This adds to their misery. This was Jobs case,
chap. VI. 14, 15. and chap. XVI. 2. and chap. XIX. 21. he cries and calls
for this pity and commiseration. It was David's case, Psalm. LXIX. 20. And
Jerusalems, Lam. I. 2, 9, 16. God calls for it toward Jerusalem, Esaias XL. 1, 2.
And himself does it, Esaias LI. 3, 12. See Nahum. III. 7.

praised the dead] He prefers the ease and quietness of death, before the
miseries of such a dying life. See Job, chap. III. throughout, Jonah IV. 3. 1
Kings XIX. 4. He speaks here according to the judgment of men under oppression:
without relation to the wickedness of men, whose state after death is in those
terrors and torments that shall either mend, or end, and they be never able to
abide or avoid, Matthew. XXVI. 24.

not yet been] Job III. and chap. X. 18, 19.

envied] For his eminent worth and works, Persia did Daniel. See Prove. XXVII. 4.

foldeth his hands The foolish sluggard so described, Prove. VI. 6. See the
Explanations there. And chap. XXVI. 15. and chap. XIX. 24.

eats his own flesh] Prove. X. 4. makes many an hungry meal.

Better is an handful] The sluggards plea.

saw vanitie] Another vanity, contrary to the former. Fools whiles they shun
the sands, do rush upon the rocks.

yet no end of all his labour] This matchless miser, Prove. XXX. 15. toiles
without end, Esaias V. 8. Hab. II. 5. and to no end trusts he can draw up Jordan
into his mouth, Job XL. 23. and yet knows he has none to whom he may leave his
goods so toiled for. This is worse then that of Psalm. XXXIX. 6.

neither is his eye satisfied with riches] Indeed the eye only has the use of
riches with such covetous men.

Two are better then one] In a natural, Jer. XLI. 13, 14. 2 Samuel X. 11. And
spiritualy, next to Communion with God is the Communion of Saints, Psalm. XVI.
2. Heb. X. 24.

he comes to reigne] The poor and wise child.

I considered] Another vanity and vexation: if this be not an exemplification
of the old foolish King dethroned, and the poor wise child standing up in his
stead.

all the living] All the present generation of men living under a present
Prince or Government; the multitude, many-headed, given to change, falling off
from the falling Sun, and adoring the rising Sun.

with the second child] The Successor; son, or who ever he be: joining to
him, and following him; as thinking they must live by the living, and not by
the dead; and so expecting protection and preservation by and under him. Such
is the vanity and vexation of Princes, that if they live long, they outlive
their own glory, and are looked upon by their own subjects, as faling,
sinking, bending to the grave: And such is the vanity and levitie of people,
that they are weary of present government, and even sick for a change, prove
the change what it will, 1 Samuel VIII. 5, 18, 19, 20. and XII. 12. 2 Samuel XV.
12, 13. and chap. XX. 2. 1 Kings II. 15. Prove. XXIV. 21.

no end of all the people] Infinitely discontented, another, that they are thus
variously affected toward their Princes in all ages.

shall not rejoice in him] But grow weary of him, whom now they so zealously
affect, and with so much loyalty adhere unto, and shall wish for another.

Surely this] Must needs be a vanity and vexation to people; but to Princes
specialy.

Keep thy foot] Having searched and found, Keep thy foot: Where the letters are
plural, the Points direct to read it in the singular number. That all and every
one should look well to his affections and inward man, that all be composed and
in a right temper when he goes to worship God, Ps. LVII. 7, 8. and CIII 1. See
Exodus III. 5. and chap. XIX. 21. Josh. V. 15.

house of God] The Gate of Heaven, Genesis XXVIII. 17. Psalm. CXVIII. 20. the
beauty of holiness, Psalm. XCVI. 9. This the likeliest place where Felicity is
to be found. But here then our preparation before, and our deportment in this
place, must be, as in the Presence of God, looking him full in the face.

ready to hear] As Acts X. 33. which includes obedience in it, Psalm. LXXXV. 8.
Job XXXIV. 32. 1 Samuel III. 10. Acts IX. 6. James I. 19.

the sacrifice of fooles] Outward services and ceremonies foolish sinners are
apt enough to, to load God with, even to loathing, Esaias I. 11, 14. So as their
heart and inward man, in spirit and truth, may be free to themselves, and far
enough from God, 1 Samuel XV. 22.

that they do evil] In so doing; doubling their iniquity by a seeming
sanctity, Ios. XI. 12. Esaias LXVI. 3.

nor rash] In prayer to God, Romans VIII. 26. nor hasty, precipitate, unadvised.

for God is in heaven] Job XXVI. 14. Esaias LVII. 15. Come thou with all possible
reverence, humility, and self-abasement, Job XLII. 6. Genesis XVIII. 27.

few] Luke XVIII. 13. Matthew. XXVI. 39, 42, 44. Against battologie, Matthew. VI.
7. Prove. X. 19.

For a dream] Multitude of business produces dreams; chap. X. 14.

Vowest] Of vows, Annotations on Jonah I. 16.

Better] It is a voluntary service to vow, Number. XXX. But being lawfully made,
must be performed, Deuteronomy. XXIII. 21, 22, 23.

neither say thou before the Angel] Exodus XXIII. 20, 21. Mal. III. 1. Psalm. II.
12.

For in the multitude of dreams] Verse 3. Prove. X. 19. As in those are many
Vanities, so vain will thy many words and excuses be, in pleading an erroneous
mistake, and extenuating the non-performances of thy vows and promises to God.

but fear thou God] The true remedy against the former vanities, of rash vows
and prayers, and addresses to God. The fear of God is the foundation of all
holy duties.

Marvel not] Be not amazed,

for he that is higher] There lies an appeal to an higher Court. And wherein
they deal proudly he is above them, Exodus XVIII. 11. Psalm. LXXVI. 12.

higher then they] Higher here in the plural number, may relate to the holy
Trinity or to Angels, by whom God does punish Princes, Esaias XXXVII. 36. Acts
XII. 23.

Moreover the profit of the earth] Is for all men,

the King] 1 Chronicles. XXVII. 26. 2 Chronicles. XXVI. 10. Amos VII. 1. The commendation
of tillage, and grasing. And this shows the vanity of earthly felicity, When
the highest stands in need of the lowest, to sustain and support them.

Shall not be satisfied with silver] The loving and desiring does increase with
the having. It is enough; but are like the grave, and barren womb, Prove. XXX.
15, 16.

What good?] Little else;

The sleep] And herein he has advantage over that great rich man.

He resumeth in this, chap. II. 24, 25, 26.

An evil] Another and another,

common] Usual among all sorts of men; an epidemical evil disease.

God has given] In way of Providence:

Wants nothing] That he can justly and reasonably desire; though indeed this
covetous man's desires are bottomless and boundless; And he wants all things,
not having power to make use of any thing.

but a stranger] Hos. VII. 9. Jer. V. 17. Lam. V. 2.

many years] And many children; chap. IV. 8. But filled both with children, and
years; and yet not filled with good, with the comfortable use and fruition of
his blessings and estate; lives beside it, is not master of it, but mastered by
it.

no burial] Deuteronomy. XXVIII. 26. Jer. XXII. 19. through enemies; or greedy heirs
to such covetous caitifs, and niggardly misers.

an untimely birth] An abortive, that comes from birth to burial, from womb to
tomb, Matthew. XXVI. 24.

is better then he] He is in rest; having never had sense or reason, to feel
loss or pa^ne, ver. 4, 5.

A thousand years] Which never man yet did.

yet has he seen no good] Better then to have been without those years;
Prove. XV. 15. Job XIV. 1.

to one place?] The house appointed for all living, Job XXX. 23. Esaias L. 11.
Thus he finds in the end all to be vanity, and vexation of spirit.

For his mouth] For food,

appetite] Yet that is never filled, it is insatiable, chap. V. 16. nor can be
filled with these worldly things, much less his soul can: Riches have no
suitableness with it, no proportion, either in excellency or in duration unto
it.

Wise more then the fool?] Speaking with relation to wealth,

Better is the sight of the eyes] To enjoy quietly and contentedly what a man
has in present possession;

That which has been, the name] And nature of it is known already. That which
is hoped for hereafter, is yet unknown.

That it is man] Man still, earthly Adam, sorry man, be his wealth or
greatness what it will. And God will make him know himself so to be, Psalm. IX.
20. Ezekiel. XXVIII. 6, 9. Esaias II. 22. and XXXI. 3.

Contend with] To enter plea against God, or require a reason of his
judgments, or strive against this stream, thinking to alter or break through
the order and bounds of his Providence or decrees, Esaias XLV. 9. Job IX. 2, 3,
12. and IV. 17. and chap. XXXIV. 23. Jer. L. 44. Romans IX. 20.

Seeing there be many things] A solemn conclusion of all the former
discoveries of vanities in the Creatures; chap. I. 3. which is the maine matter
of this Book.

What is man the better?] In regard of sound and solid happiness, for any, or
for all the former vanities.

For who knoweth] The animal creatures by instinct of nature know what is good
for them, What is best for him in this life, as to the things of this life;
Whether to be rich or poor, etc. Achitophel might have lived longer with less
wisdom: Nabal with less riches: Herod with less pride and praise, etc. God
is pleased to show man the only good, Mic. VI. 8. and Solomon, chap. XII. ver.
13, 14.

vain life] This life it self, a vain shadow, Psalm. CXLIV. 4. and XXXIX. 6.
Job XIV. 2. and chap. VIII. 1 Chronicles. XXIX. 15.

What shall be after him] He cannot promise to himself, when he is gone, any
satisfactorie content, in name, family, and posterity, no more then he could in
his lifetime, to himself, chap. II. 18, 19. Nescis quid serus vesper vehat.

A good name] Solomon in this Chapter proceeds to many other particular means
and remedies for healing the vanities and vexations of this life; and procuring
tranquillity and peace of mind, in the midst of them. Yet here and there he
does intermix some more vanities and vexations. The first means and remedy
here is a Good Name. or Fame. The first letter of the Hebrew word for Good, is
here greater then ordinary; to intimate belike the great and extraordinary
goodness of a good name. Which is better to a man, to his conscience, and
soul, then a precious ointment is to his body. It refreshes, and cheereth, and
comfort the soul and conscience, in the very midst of all wrongs and
sufferings; and specially at the hour of death; and remains fresh after the
body rots in the grave. They leave their names for a blessing, and are had in
everlasting remembrance; whereas the memory of the wicked shall rot, Job XVIII.
17. Prove. X. 17. and they leave their names as a curse, and a stinking snuff
behind them, Esaias LXV. 15. yea, in this life this fattens the bones, Prove. XV.
30. And procures reverence and esteem in the consciences of others. And is
rather to be chosen then all riches, Prove. XXII. 1. Herein the Hebrew is a
Paranomasia of the words (...) and (...) And the same is in Cant. I. 3.

and the day of death] To such a man of a good name: or to any man, relation
being had to the many vanities and vexations of this life, Job XIV. 1. Life
begins with crying: 2 Nondum loquitur infans, and tamen sic prophetat. And
Lawyers define life by crying, without which they are counted still-borne. 3
Now that day that delivers a man from them, is better then that which lets in,
and puts a man in possession of them. Which makes Solomon here prefer his
coffin before his cradle.

to the house of mourning] So wise men do, And fools they are that do the
contrary, verse 4. This is better for the living, as the former for the dead.

for this is the end of all men] Here is the reason, men will so fall into deep
and due consideration of their own dying life, as Job XXX. 33. Psalm. XXXIX. 4,
5. and XC. 12. that life is but to lie a dying, and so be weined from the vain
jollities of this life, and wrought to humiliation, mortification, and
preparation for a better life. From which, Feasting calls us off. See Josh.
XXIII. 14. Heb. IX. 2. And again, Amos VI. 3, -- 6. Deuteronomy. VIII. 12, -- 14.
Esaias XXII. 12, 13, 14. and chap. V. 12.

Sorrow is better] James IV. Luke VI. 21. 25. Matthew. V. 4. yet this is a
Paradox to the world, which is always set upon the merry pin, to be as merry
Greeks: to eat and drink, and laugh, and play, and labors to banish all sorrow
away, as the bane of their life.

sadness of the countenance] In our selves, by grave thoughts, and sad and
serious meditations and considerations: or, of a sower and severe, yet sure
friend.

the heart is made better] The better part is bettered: the inward man is
amended; by abandoning those loose noisome and destructive vanities and
jollities of laughter; and of penitential humiliation, compunction, contrition,
of mortality, death and judgment. These sorrowful tears have much joy in them,
they wash away the filth of sin; and as sweet April showers they bring on
amain the May-flowers of Grace, and Glory. And therefore, where ever the body
is, upon several occasions, yet the heart of the wise is here, he numbereth the
days of his life, and the days of darkness, Psalm. XC. 12. Eccles. XI. 8. And
where ever the body is, yet the heart of fools is on effuse mirth, runs a
madding; the way to rejoice in a thing of naught, Amos VI. 13. is on foolish
follies, in the filth and froth whereof is bred and fed that woeful worm that
never dies, Job XXI. 12, 13. Yet their laughter is indeed but the hypocrisy of
mirth, as the crackling of thorns under a pot, a sudden blaze soon gone, as
sudden lightning, which yet is followed with the rending and roaring of
thunderclaps, Luke VI. 25. Psalm CXVIII. 12.

The rebuke of the wise] Prove. XIII. 18. chap. XV. 31, 32. -- chapter XXVII. 6.
Psalm CXLI. 5. An enemy in this case many times proves a good and useful
Informer, though a bad Judge.

Crackling of thornes] Psalm. LVIII. 9. Prove. XIV. 13.

Surely oppression] Chap. IV. 1. and chap. V. 8. Deuteronomy. XXVIII. 29, 33. Psalm.
CXIX. 134. Jer. VI. 6. and chap. XXII. 17. Ezekiel. XXII. 29.

makes a wise man mad] To see it in the world upon others; to undergo it
himself. No man is so wise, but he is sometimes over-borne with passions and
rage, and indignation.

a gift] Job XV. 34. Psalm. XXVI. 10. Prove. XVII. 23. and the Observations upon
it. Deuteronomy. XVI. 19. Exodus XXIII. 8.

Better is the end] This maxim holds in many things; James V. 11. Psalm.
XXXVII. 37. Many graces run in the race of a Christian course: only
perseverance to the end gains the prize, crowns the enterprise and action,
Matthew. X. 22. Heb. III. 6. Apoc. II. 10, 26. Many seem to set out for heaven
with much eagerness; as Orpah from Moab; but return back; put their hand to
the plough, but after look back, as Lots wife; run well, but after fall off,
Gal. V. 7. leave their first love, Apoc. II. 4. begin in the spirit, and end in
the flesh. But better they had never known the way of righteousness, etc. 2
Pet. II. 20, 21. Heb. X. 26. 27, 38, 39. Some here understand the end of angry
contention. For so the Hebrew word sometimes signifies, as Prove. XVII. 9. And
so the sense ^wil best agree with that which follows.

the pa^ient] Prove. XIV. 29. and XV. 18. 1 These. V. 14. James V. 7, 8, 11. Heb.
XII. 1. And patient therefore under oppression, waiting on God till he bring
both ends together, not looking only on (...) present face of things; but
hoping and expecting that they which sow in reares, may reap in joy, Psalm.
LXXIII. 17, 18. Esaias X. 12, 24, 25, 26. 2 Samuel XVI. 11, 12. Habak. II. v. 3, ^.

the proud in spirit] Exodus V. 2. Prove. XIII. 10.

angry] Psalm. Mark II. 3. Prove. XIV. 17. and XVI. 32.

resteth] It may rush in and be as a passinger, for a while, for a fit; in a
wise man, as in David, 1 Samuel XXV. 21, 22. and in the Disciples, Luke IX. 54,
55. But it rests, remains, lodges, as an inmate abides, domineereth only
in the bosom and breast of fools, is there as in its proper place. Yet in some
cases anger is just, and a duty, Ephesians. IV. 26. Mark III. 5. But the sun
must never go down upon our wrath. We must not then hastily be angry, as to
murmur at Gods Providence, when things go not as we could wish, when we see
Oppression prevailing, Psalm. XXXVII. 1 Prove. XXIII. 17, 18. and XXIV. 19. We
must be slow to anger, James I. 19, 20. Prove. XIX. 11. and chap. XV. 18. Tit.
I. 7.

That the former dayes] And yet this has been a continual complaint in all
days and ages; Matthew. XXIII. 30. And yet the days are the worse because these
men themselves are no better, Acts VII. 51. Truth is, some days and ages are
worse then others: And we should be sensible of, and sorry for the evil of our
days; yet not be unmindful of the good things of our present days that we do
enjoy; much less repine at Gods Providence in the ordering of the times; a
thing we are too prone to, and the thing here checked: but our wisdom should
be to leave Gods work to himself; and for us to serve God in our generation,
and walk with God, as Noah did in the worst of times; every one to amend one,
and so the days would be better, Ephesians. V. 15, 16.

Wisdome] Good without it; Prove. XIV. 24. and such to Gods glory, and the good
of himself and others, Prove. III. 9. Luke XVI. 9. 1 Timothy VI. 11, 18, 19. The
poor man's wisdom is often despised, chap. IX. 15, 16.

A defence] Both, Job XXVIII. 15. Prove. VIII. and XVI. 16.

gives life] Prove. III. 16. and IX. 11. Whereas riches cannot, Psalm. XLIX. 6,
-- 9. but sometimes takes away the life of the owners thereof, Prove. I. 19.

Consider the work of God] See, and the crooked courses and crosses thereof,
look up above the creatures, and all second causes, and acknowledge and
acquiesce in Gods wisdom and justice, infinite above ours, who would not
suffer or permit such things to prevail, if he were not so wise and powerful
as to bring good out of evil, light out of darkness, order out of confusion,
and to make all serve unto his own glory. He can use crooked tools to make
straight work. And we cannot set things straight, or make the man straight that
is borne crooked, we cannot amend things amiss, nor rectify what he has made
crooked, Job XXXIV. 12. His purposes must stand, and cannot be altered or
resisted, Esaias XIV. 24, 27. Job IX. 12. This consideration wrought upon Aaron,
Levit. X. 3. upon Eli, 1 Samuel III. 18. upon David, 2. Sam. XV. 26. John XVIII.
11. See Job IX. 4. we must make our own burden lighter by our patient bearing
it.

In the day of prosperity] Enjoy it,

but in the day of adversity consider] God intermingles both, like
checker-work. As the Physician ministers sometimes Corrasives, sometimes
Cordials, sometimes lets blood, even to swooning, sometimes uses Restoratives.
We should consider this, Lam. III. 28. 33, 40. Heb. XII. 3, -- 12. Mic. VI. 9.
Psalm. XCIV. 12.

has set the one] That we should not either surfeit in prosperity, or despond
in adversity, Lam. III. 38. Esaias XLV. 7.

find nothing after him] What shall after befall him; whether prosperity or
adversity: or nothing better for him, and his advantage, then what God has
ordered and done.

All things have I seene] He confirms the former point of Gods dark and
wonderful Providence, Esaias XLV. 15.

There is a just man] As Abel, Zacharias, Naboth, Stephen, and Martyrs all,
Matthew. V. 10. Hab. I. 13. See 2 Kings XXII. 20. Esaias LVII. 1.

a wicked man] Job XXI. 7. Jer. XII. 1, 2. This is a sore stumbling block even
to good and wise men. But it should teach them, and all, That there is a just
and righteous day of doom to come, Acts XVII. 31. Romans II. 5. And if wicked
men live long, thereby they aggravate their sin; and God so shows his
patience; and makes their judgment the more heavy, and to appear the more
conspicuous.

Be not righteous over-much] Not in it self, Matthew. X. 16. not make our selves
over-wise, to do a thing conscienciously, scrupulously, upon opinion of duty,
when indeed there was no necessity so to do; and so to make sin where God
has made none. And thus all will-worshippers are all over-religious,
over-wise, or overweening, too too well conceited of their own religion,
wisdom and worth. See Rom XI. 20.

destroy thy self] By the former means involve thy self in much unnecessary
trouble and danger; which otherwise thou might and would fairly avoid.

overmuch wicked] Not allowing any degree of wickedness. But cautioning most
against the most excessive rank, the superfluity of naughtiness, James I. 21.
When we run to the excess of riot in sin, 1 Pet. IV. 4. And being past
feeling, give our selves over to it, to work it with greediness, Ephesians. IV.
19. doing wickedly with both hands earnestly, Mic. VII. 3. Jer. VIII. 6.

before thy time] Wasting thy body by such sinning; or exposing thy self to the
stroke of humane justice; or divine extraordinary vengeance upon such
exorbitant outrageous sinners.

Take hold of this] That thou be not overmuch wicked. Psalm. CXXV. 5. as
malefactors to execution. When he that fears God shall come forth of them
all, those dangers all that extremes do usualy bring men to; be freed, or
pulled as a firebrand out of the fire, Zech. III. 2. Psalm. XXXIV. 9, -- 16.

Wisdom strengtheneth] Chap. Prove. III. 21, -- 26. and Chap. XXI. 22. and
XXIV. 5. Thus prudence excels pussance, 2 Samuel XX. 16, -- 22. Cedant arma
togae.

Not a just man] This is reserved for the state of Perfection in Heaven, Heb.
XII. 23. Here we sin, yea even in doing of good; our best actions, even in
holy duties, are stained with imperfections and corruptions, come short of what
God by virtue of our creation, and his most righteous Law does most justly
require at our hands. Our whole hearts and souls now though we give them to
God, yet are not those but much unlike those which God at first gave us.
Pelagians and Papists are proud Justiciaries, Prove. XX. 9. 1 Kings VIII. 46.
James III. 2. 1 John I. 8. Nemo semper sapit.

No heed unto all words] That are spoken of thee, Sam. XXV. 25. and X. 27.
Prove. XIX. 11. 2 Samuel XVI. 10, 11.

lest thou hear] Though they lest should, 1 Pet. II. 18. yet sometimes it falls
out so, Job XXXI. 31. Yea, the abjects teared David's name, and ceased not,
Psalm. XXXV. 15. Yet see Jobs mind and moderation in this case, chap. XXXI. 13,
14, 15.

Thy own heart] The power of conscience, Gal. VI. 1, 2. Tit. III. 2, 3. Matthew.
VII. 1, -- 5.

I will bewise] Solomon had many extraordinary means, of man Job XXVIII. 12, --
21. and chap. XXXVIII. Romans XI. 33, 34.

Exceeding deep] As what not? Pet. I. 12 Job XI. 6, -- 10. Psalm. CXXXIX. 6.
This the cause why he was so far from Wisdom.

And to know the wickedness of folly] The vast, Romans VII. 13. For Contraries
do best set off, and illustrate the one the other. And this he did, that he
might the better anatomize and dissect both wisdom and wickedness to his own
conscience, and to the consciences of others. See 1 Cor. XIV. 24. 25. Ezekiel.
XIV. 5.

The woman whose heart is snares] One instance of his discovery; Prove V. 4.
and II. 16. and VI. 26. IX. 17. This Solomon found most woeful experience; and
here penitently proclaims it.

her bands as bands] So Dalilah to Samson. So Prove. XVII. 22.

escape-from her] As Joseph did; not by his own strength, but the supernatural
power of Gods grace. See Prove. V. 8.

but the sinner] Prove. XXII, 14. II. 19. Her steps take hold of hell, Prove. V.
5. and IX. 11.

This] Mentioned, ver. 26. and 28.

one by one] In his diligent search.

Among all those] Thousand, Kings XI. 3. Yet most evidently, many good women
there have been, and are. But in respect of the discovery of hearts and
natures, whether in good or evil, it is harder to find out thoroughly the
perfect disposition of a woman, and their deep sleights, then of men. For
whoredom takes away the heart of a man, Hos. IV. 11. Prove. V. 6. and chap.
VII. 21, 22.

That God has made man upright] In his creation, IV. 27.

but they] Here he discovers the Original and fountain of all these evils and
follies, not to be from God; but from themselves, and their Fall in Adam. So
that man now is of another make; whole evil is in man, and whole man is in evil.

Sought out] B^

many inventions] Many, and mighty; to be like to Angels, to God, Genesis III. 5,
22 many shifts to palliate their sins, and sinful courses.

Who is as the wise man] None like him, Abraham, Joseph, Job, Moses, Genesis
XXIII. 6. and chap. XLI. 38. Job I. 8. Number. XII. 7. as those excellent ones of
the earth, Psalm. XVI. 3. the Worthies of the world, Heb. XI. 5.

and who knoweth] Such are rare, one of a thousand.

the interpretation of a thing?] Rightly to discern in all affairs, what in
every case is to be done or left undone.
